title: Head & Neck / ENT
text:
Head & Neck / ENT
Most important consideration: usually a shared airway, and often a difficult airway

title: Rhinological Surgery
text:
Rhinological Surgery
Operations: FESS, polypectomy, septorhinoplasty
Most vascular part is anterior inferior septum – Little’s area / Kiesselbach’s
plexus – most common source of epistaxis
Innervation:
•
V1: → nasociliary nerve → anterior ethmoidal n. (int + ext)
o
Supplies: septum, nasal tip, anterior lateral walls, sinuses
•
V2: maxillary →
o
Pterygopalatine ganglia
▪
Greater + lesser palatine n.: septum, lateral walls
▪
Lateral posterior superior / inferior n.
o
Infraorbital nerve: maxillary sinus, skin lateral / under nose
•
VII: post-ganglionic parasympathetic – secretory
•
Olfaction: CNI
Topical vasoconstrictors:
•
Topical cocaine solution (2mg/kg, peak levels 30-60mins)
•
Topical cocaine paste
•
Ephedrine
•
Direct injection of LA + adr
Pre-op:
•
Assess:
o
CI to cocaine
o
Appropriateness for: hypotensive anaesthesia
▪
CI hypotensive anaesthesia: poorly controlled HTN, CVA, IHD/CAD, CKD, advanced liver dz
•
?OSA + other resp disease (2/3 of pts with chronic sinusitis have lower airway inflammation or COPD)
Intra-op:
•
Possible difficult BVM 2’ nasal obstruction
•
Airway: shared, reinforced flexi-LMA (benefit of spont vent) or south rae ETT (controlled CO2)
o
No routine throat pack
•
Remi +/- GTN for cocaine/adrenaline injection
•
Surgeons may request eyes uncovered to inspect for globe / orbital damage – use lube
•
Bloodless field:
o
Non-pharmacological: reverse trendelenberg
o
Vasoconstrictors + TXA + steroids + a2 agonists
o
Hypotensive anaesthesia: 20-30% reduction from baseline OR sBP 90-100/MAP 60-70, HR 60, TIVA + a2 agonist
o
Avoid obstruction to venous drainage:
▪
Head as neutral as able
▪
Tape tube cf tie
▪
Head slightly up
▪
PPV (low-normal CO2, low PEEP)
o
Sphenopalatine block
•
Regional (analgesia): infraorbital nerve block
•
Intra-op severe hypertension management: manage w/
alpha blocker first if akin to a phaeo presentation
(unopposed alpha will cause heart failure)
•
Prior to extubation: Valsalva, suction coroner’s clot,
analgesia
•
Remi extubation to cough
Post-op:
•
Day only unless comorbid / OSA
Throat Packs
•
No robust evidence to show 
•
Potentially catastrophic – routine use not
recommended
Management:
•
Discuss at TIME OUT
•
Inserted by surgeons + included in scrub count
•
Visual reminder i.e. fluorescent sticker on patient
forehead
•
Tied to airway to ensure cannot be left behind
•
Clear documentation

title: Middle Ear Surgery
text:
Middle Ear Surgery
Include: cochlear implant, myringoplasty, tympanoplasty, ossicular chain reconstruction, mastoidectomy, stapedectomy
Pre-op:
•
Query hearing – may need quiet place, allow lip reading
•
Assess: congenital syndromes (?difficult airway)
•
Ix: ECG (congenital sensorineural hearing loss associated with long QT)
Intra-op:
•
Prop + remi TIVA:
o
Facial n. monitoring
o
Good for PONV – very emetic surgery
o
Allows smooth extubation on remi
•
Avoid nitrous (non-compliant middle ear cavity)
•
Bloodless field:
o
Non-pharmacological: reverse trendelenberg
o
Vasoconstrictors + TXA + steroids + a2 agonists
o
Hypotensive anaesthesia: 30% reduction from baseline OR sBP 90-100/MAP 60-70, HR 60, TIVA + a2 agonist
o
Avoid obstruction to venous drainage:
▪
Head as neutral as able
▪
Tape tube cf tie
▪
Head slightly up
▪
PPV (low-normal CO2, low PEEP)
•
PONV prophylaxis +++
•
Analgesia: simple + LA (w/ adr) by surgeons
Post-op:
•
Often discharged DOS
Complications:
•
Change in taste
•
Transient facial palsy
•
Rare: CSF leak, meningitis, persistent facial n. palsy

title: Oropharyngeal/H&N Cancer Surgery
text:
Oropharyngeal/H&N Cancer Surgery
Oropharyngeal: tongue, tonsils, pharynx
Pre-op:
•
ASSESS:
o
History:
▪
Modifiable RFs: EtOH, smoking, iron deficiency
▪
Nutrition (may be  2’ EtOH, dysphagia, cancer anorexia, chemo, radiation mucositis)
•
BMI <18.5 or >10% weight loss → dietician, monitor for refeeding
•
+ thiamine + vit B, trace elements
▪
4Ms: chemo/RTx effects
▪
Functional capacity
o
Exam:
▪
AIRWAY ASSESSMENT
o
Ix:
▪
Imaging ?airway
▪
Nasendoscopy
▪
Flow vol loops ?upper airway obstruction v COPD
▪
CPET may aid in risk – value not fully elucidated
o
Risk: RCRI
•
MANAGE:
o
Nutrition
o
Iron deficiency
•
REFER:
o
MDT management: anaesthetics, surgery, ICU +/- dietician
o
Resp for COPD management
o
?Ceiling of care – rescue ECMO candidate
o
Post-op disposition ?need for flap management, trache + ICU
Intra-op: shared airway procedure
•
Monitoring: ANZCA standard + art line + UO + bladder temp
•
Airway plan + difficult airway equipment
o
Maxilla / nasal ca: oral intubation
o
Oral ca: nasal intubation
o
Submental intubation CI due to risk of fistula / false tract
•
Special considerations:
o
Flap management if indicated
o
Long procedure, pressure care
•
Avoid casual vandalism
•
Document laryngoscopy at end
•
Extubation:
o
If extubating:
▪
Suction +++ whilst deep w/ laryngoscope, avoid flaps and suture lines, Y suction nose + tube
o
If ‘at risk’: planned tracheostomy or delayed extubation
▪
Remain intubated if resection near vallecula or epiglottis
Post-op:
•
Head elevated
•
Trache care: emergency box
o
+/- nebulised lignocaine for comfort
o
PONV ++
o
Steroids
•
Nutritional support
•
Free flap care
•
FASTHUGS
H&N cancers most commonly
metastasise to cervical nodes
Types of neck dissection:
•
Radical: removes LN levels I-V
along with the SCM, IJV, and CN
XI
•
Modified radical: removes LN
levels I-V but spares at least one
non-lymphatic structure (SCM,
IJV, or CN XI)
•
Selective: removes any of LN
levels I-V based on patterns of
cervical mets
Accessory nerve monitored closely if

title: Laryngectomy
text:
Laryngectomy
Laryngeal cancer: 30% supraglottic, 65% glottic, transglottic, subglottic 5%
Pre-op:
•
ASSESS:
o
History:
▪
Modifiable RFs: EtOH, smoking, iron deficiency
▪
Nutrition (may be  2’ EtOH, dysphagia, cancer anorexia, chemo, radiation mucositis)
•
BMI <18.5 or >10% weight loss → dietician, monitor for refeeding
•
+ thiamine + vit B, trace elements
•
Consider admission for controlled EtOH withdrawal + feeding
▪
4Ms: chemo/RTx effects
▪
Functional capacity
o
Exam:
▪
AIRWAY ASSESSMENT – middle column pathology
o
Ix:
▪
Imaging ?airway
▪
Nasendoscopy
▪
Flow vol loops ?upper airway obstruction v COPD
▪
CPET may aid in risk – value not fully elucidated
o
Risk: RCRI, P-POSSUM
•
MANAGE:
o
Nutrition
o
Iron deficiency
•
REFER:
o
MDT management: anaesthetics, surgery, ICU +/- dietician
o
Resp for COPD management
o
?Ceiling of care – rescue ECMO candidate
o
Post-op disposition ?need for flap management, trache + ICU
Intra-op: shared airway procedure
•
Monitoring: ANZCA standard + art line + UO + bladder temp
•
Intubation: ideally trache end of case to avoid tracheostomal recurrence but may have to do elective if grave concerns
for airway – consultant anaesthetist + ENT scrubbed
o
PLAN + PLAN FOR FAILURE
o
LA front of neck before starting +/- cannula if below cancer
o
THRIVE + CASH (stridor: CPAP, adrenaline, steroids, heliox)
o
Spont breathing videolaryngoscopy + small reinforced tube
▪
FOB useful for supraglottic but laryngeal can be subglottic also must avoid ‘cork in bottle’
o
Trachea resected → tracheostome → change to J tube
•
Accessory n. monitoring by surgeons
•
Trache end of case (tracheostomal recurrence)
Post-op:
•
ICU
•
Trache care: emergency box
o
+/- nebulised lignocaine for comfort
o
PONV ++
o
Steroids
•
Head elevated
•
Nutritional support
•
FASTHUGS
•
Barium swallow test

title: Tracheostomy Emergency Post-Laryngectomy
text: Emergency laryngectomy management Call for airway expert help Look, listen & feel at the mouth and laryngectomy stoma ‘A Mapleson C system (e.g. ‘Waters circuit’) may help assessment if available Use waveform capnography whenever available: exhaled carbon dioxide indicates a patent or partially patent airway Is the patient breathing? Call Resuscitation Team CPR if no pulse / signs of life Assess laryngectomy stoma patency| Most laryngectomy stomas will NOT have a tube in situ Remove stoma cover (if present) Remove inner tube (if present ) Some inner tubes need re-inserting to connect to breathing circuits Do not remove a tracheoesophageal puncture (TEP) prosthesis Can you pass a suction catheter? ‘Apply high flow oxygen to laryngectomy stoma If any doubt whether patient has a laryngectomy, apply oxygen to face also* The laryngectomy stoma is patent Perform tracheal suction Consider partial obstruction Ventilate via stoma if not breathing Continue ABCDE assessment Deflate the cuff (if present) Look, listen & feel at the laryngectomy stoma or tube Use waveform capnography or Mapleson C if available Continue ABCDE assessment | | Is the patient stable or improving? REMOV

Paediatric face mask applied to stoma
LMA applied to stoma

Consider Aintree catheter and fibreoptic
‘scope / Bougie / Airway exchange catheter

Laryngectomy patients have an end stoma and cannot be oxygenated via the mouth or nose
‘Applying oxygen to the face and stoma is the default emergency action for all patients with a tracheostomy

National Tracheostomy Safety Project. Review date 1/4/16. Feedback & resources at www.tracheostomy.org.uk

title: Parotidectomy
text:
Parotidectomy
Indications: parotid mass (mostly benign)
Pre-op:
•
Airway: MO, ?distortion – consider pre-op nasendoscopy if unsure
•
Nutrition assessment
Intra-op:
•
Intubation: south RAE
•
Maintenance: prop + remi TIVA (remi helps with movement)
o
Facial nerve monitoring:
▪
Low dose NMBA (roc +/- sugammadex)
▪
Surgeon may request eye exposed: use lube
•
Ensure good access: malignant tumours have high bleeding risk
•
Bloodless field:
o
Non-pharmacological: reverse trendelenberg
o
Vasoconstrictors + TXA + steroids + a2 agonists
o
Hypotensive anaesthesia: 20-30% reduction from baseline OR sBP 90-100/MAP 60-70, HR 60, TIVA + a2 agonist
o
Avoid obstruction to venous drainage:
▪
Head as neutral as able + up
▪
Tape tube cf tie
▪
PPV (low-normal CO2, low PEEP)
•
Likely Valsalva at end of case
•
Extubate on remifentanil to avoid hypertension + coughing + bucking

title: Microlaryngoscopy
text:
Microlaryngoscopy
Pre-op:
•
Imaging
•
Consider nasendoscopy
•
Discuss with surgeons:
o
Plan ?laser
o
Risk of bleeding: MLT versus tubeless airway
•
Consider using jet ventilation
•
If large lesion consider placing pre-op subglottic cannula
Intra-op: shared airway procedure
•
Spont vent TIVA

title: Airway Stenting
text:
Airway Stenting
Treats obstruction of central airways i.e. trachea and main bronchi
Indications: malignancy (palliative), stricture, tracheomalacia
Pre-op:
•
ASSESS:
o
History: 4Ms, functional assessment
o
Exam:
▪
Obstruction: ability to lie flat, rescue position, ?stridor (rest v exertion), hypoxia
▪
Dental for rigid bronch
o
Ix:
▪
CT: extent of obstruction, involvement of carina → risk
•
MANAGE:
o
Document ceiling of care
•
REFER:
o
?ECMO candidate if airway obstructs – severe = >50% obstruction
Intra-op: shared airway procedure
•
Flexibronch (sedation): aim to maintain spont ventilation
•
Rigid bronch: requires GA
o
Jet ventilation: FiO2 100%, CPM 100, I time 50%, pressure 1.5 barr, pause pressure (mPAP) 25mBar, PP 25mBar
•
Emergency equipment for bleeding

title: Tonsillectomy / Adenoidectomy
text:
Tonsillectomy / Adenoidectomy
Pre-op:
•
Assess OSA
Intra-op: shared airway procedure
•
Intubation: south RAE
o
Boyle-Davis ‘gag’: monitor airway pressures
•
Analgesia:
o
NSAIDs: no evidence for bleeding
o
Dexamethasone
o
Dexmed / clonidine (limited evidence)
o
Inconsistent evidence for: LA infiltration, magnesium
•
Inconsistent evidence for antibiotics
•
Suction coroner’s clot
Post-op:
•
Analgesia: above + honey, acupuncture, opioid rescue
Post-Tonsillectomy Haemorrhage
Incidence 6%.
•
Primary <24hr
•
Secondary >24hr (often D5 – 14)
Pre-op:
•
Resuscitate
•
Group + hold + alert blood bank
Intra-op:
•
Resuscitate prior to induction as best able, wide bore access
•
Intubation: RSI with cricoid (aspiration risk)
o
Position: head down or lateral decubitus
o
Difficult airway equipment available
o
SUCTION x2
o
McIntosh laryngoscope for direct laryngoscopy (blood can make VL difficult)
•
Blood management bundle
•
TXA
•
Send ROTEM if ongoing bleeding
•
PONV management +++ (blood is highly emetogenic)
•
Extubation:
o
Completely awake
o
Drain stomach via NGT/OGT
Post-op:
•
Can consider ICU for close monitoring

title: Thyroid Surgery
text:
Thyroid Surgery
See thyroid disease + thyroid storm elsewhere
Indications:
•
Thyroid surgery: nodules, hyperthyroid, goitre, cancer
•
Parathyroid surgery: hyperparathyroidism (primary / tertiary)
Pre-op:
•
ASSESS:
o
History:
▪
Airway obstruction: stridor, sleeping, voice change, positional
+/- RLN involvement
o
Exam: thyroid disease
▪
Airway ?obstruction, safe position
▪
Consider nasendoscopy
o
Ix:
▪
Aim euthyroid last 3-6mo: TFTs, PTH, Ca2+, phosphate, vit D levels
▪
ECG +/- TTE
▪
Imaging:
•
Airway obstruction + extension of disease (retropharyngeal rare → laryngeal deviation +
failed intubation +/- surgical airway)
•
SVC obstructon
•
MANAGE: thyroid disease, arrhythmias
•
REFER:
o
MDT management with ENT, endocrine
▪
?extent of disease ?requirement for neck dissection
Intra-op:
•
LA: superficial cervical plexus + local infiltration
•
GA:
o
Intubation: awake / spont vent intubation if airway risk
▪
NIM tube (in line with VC – monitors RLN) + low dose roc
▪
TIVA with reminfentanil
•
Positioning: shoulder roll, neck extended, arms tucked, head up
•
Intra-operative
•
Monitor for:
o
Thyroid storm
o
PTH monitoring: short ½ life – PTH drop >50%
confidence all tissue excised
o
Carotid vagal stimulation
o
VAE
•
Valsalva at end to check for haemostasis in trendelenberg
•
Extubation:
o
Avoid BP + coughing / straining (remifentanil)
o
Risk of tracheomalacia: consider AEC
Post-op:
•
Monitor:
o
Haematoma/airway: emergency equipment @ bedside
▪
DESATS ACRONYM
o
RLN palsy: stridor, weak voice (unilateral okay, bilateral – airway emergency)
o
Tracheomalacia
o
Hypocalcaemia
•
Rare complications:
o
Pneumothorax
o
Myxoedema coma: extremely rare, DDx for unconsciousness (Rx IV thyroxine)
TRH (hypothalamus, inhibited by
somatostatin) → TSH (anterior pituitary)
Thyroid fx: iodine → thyroid hormones
•
80% T4 (prohormone)
•
20% T3 (bioactive) – majority
formed from conversion of T4
Parathyroid fx: produces PTH ( 1/Ca2+)
•
Ca2+
Thyroid storm: acute + life-threatening -
hypertension, HR, febrile, atrial fibrillation
•
Send TSH + T4 + T3 but do not wait for result
•
Rx:
o
FiO2, hyperventilate
o
BP: beta-blockers
o
Benzos for convulsion
o
Cooling: active + paracetamol
o
Block thyroid synthesis: PTU, carbimazole
o
Block release: iodine
o
Block T4 → T3: steroids, propranolol
o
AF: amiodarone

title: Post-Thyroidectomy Bleed / Airway Emergency
text:
Post-Thyroidectomy Bleed / Airway Emergency
Likely to be laryngeal oedema from venous congestion even if sutures released
Majority <24 hr; 50% within 6hr post-op – no evidence incidence with drains
DAS recommendations:
•
Obs: q1 hourly first 6hr, vigilance for subsequent 18hr – includes wound + pain scoring
•
Post-thyroidectomy emergency box + grab bag at bed space
•
Monitor: DESATS acronym –
o
Difficulty swallowing / discomfort
o
(n)EWS – early warning score charts i.e. BTG
o
Swelling
o
Anxiety
o
Tachypnoea
o
Stridor
If ≥1
▪
FiO2 100% 15L NRB
▪
Head up 45 degrees
▪
Immediate senior review – if surgeons not available → anaesthetics
▪
Any signs of haematoma → EVACUATE superficial + deep layers – SCOOP
•
Skin exposure
•
Cut sutures
•
Open skin
•
Open muscle
•
Pack
▪
Dexamethasone + TXA
•
Intubation if deterioration regardless of location:
o
Consider flexible bronch
o
Avoid multiple attempts
o
Early progression to FONA (needle cric preferred method)
•
Debrief
•
Psychological follow-up for patient
•
Preparation + ongoing training

title: Surgical Tracheostomy
text:
Surgical Tracheostomy
Patients are usually intubated and ventilated but can be awake under LA
Pre-op:
•
ASSESS:
o
History:
o
Examination:
▪
Airway if not intubated
▪
Ventilation requirements i.e. requiring O2 or just prolonged intubation / critical illness myopathy
▪
Haemodynamic requirements
o
Ix:
▪
Coags
•
MANAGE:
o
Correct coagulopathy
o
Aspirate NGT
•
REFER
Intra-op: elective should be done in hours
•
Prepare for need to intubate from above
o
Difficult airway, 2nd skilled assistant, ENT on standby throughout
o
If airway ≥2b consider placing bougie in case ENT loses airway
•
Airway:
o
Pre-oxygenate then minimise FiO2
▪
FiO2 <30%, cease for diathermy
o
Advance ETT prior to stoma formation – cuff distal to incision (between tracheal rings 2-3)
o
When ready to exchange for trache tube withdraw ETT
o
Trache tube inserted + connected to circuit – confirm ETCO2 prior to ETT removal
▪
Any doubt of false passage check with fibreoptic scope
Post-op:
•
ICU/HDU
•
Emergency trache equipment at bedside including appropriate signage
•
Humidified inspired gases
Features of different trache tubes:
•
Inner cannula: permits cleaning
•
Adjustable flange: useful in obese patients
•
Fenestrations / speaking valve
Complications:
•
Early:
o
Bleed
o
Dislodgement +/- obstruction
o
Subcut emphysema
o
Infection
•
Late:
o
Stenosis
o
Pressure necrosis
o
Persistent tracheocutaneous fistula
o
Tracheooesophageal fistula
o
Tracheoinnominate fistula

title: Transoral Robotic Surgery
text:
Transoral Robotic Surgery
Previously restricted “line of sight” has limited transoral surgery → transfacial or transmandibular approach (overcome by TORS)
Indications: oral cavity, larynx, pharynx, tongue base, radical tonsillectomy, other complex oral lesions
CI: trismus / limited MO, macroglossia, mandibular or maxillary invasion, carotid or bone involvement
Pre-op:
•
Dentition
•
Airway
•
Need for trache: often in salvage surgery + excessive resections
Intra-op: shared airway procedure
•
Airway: reinforced nasal tube (6/6.5) on contralateral side to operation, or north RAE – check cuff pressure
•
Meticulous padding + positioning
•
Gag used – stimulating
•
Deeply paralysed – LL NM monitoring + full reversal end of case
•
Laser safety
•
Document airway details
•
Valsalva at end to check bleeding
Post-op:
•
Airway details at patient bedside
•
Generally remain intubated in immediate post-op period
•
Dexamethasone (pain, LOS, swallowing)
Complications: bleeding + aspiration most common, then lacerations, dental damage, mandibular #, cervical spine #, ocular
injury, dysphagia, dehydration, PEG dependency, nerve injuries (hypoglossal, lingual)

title: Obstructing Organic Lesions
text:
Obstructing Organic Lesions
For all:
•
THRIVE / FiO2 100%
•
Difficult intubation trolley
•
Skilled anaesthetic assistant
•
Bronchoscope
•
ENT on standby +/- ECMO
•
Nasendoscopy very useful tool
Pre-OT management of stridor: CASH
•
CPAP (including HFNP)
•
Adrenaline
•
Steroids
•
Heliox
Airway: must remain spont venting
•
Topicalisation
•
Procedure:
o
Supraglottic: AFOI with topicalization
o
Glottic / subglottic:
▪
Nasendoscopy:
•
If likely able to intubate:
o
VL
o
Neck marked + LA infiltrated +/- cannula + ENT on standby
•
If risk of ‘cork in bottle’ → awake tracheostomy
ENT scrubbed on standby
Removal of Inhaled Foreign Body
Must ascertain exact location of FB from imaging.
For all:
•
FiO2 100% 15L NRB - do not use THRIVE or positive pressure
•
Difficult intubation trolley
•
Skilled anaesthetic assistant
•
Bronchoscope
•
ENT on standby +/- ECMO
•
Nasendoscopy very useful tool
Management:
•
TIVA spont vent induction
•
If using rigid bronch to retrieve object aim to deliver O2 down side arm of rigid bronch
Fractured Nose Reduction
Anaesthesia:
•
LA: bilateral infraorbital blocks + topical LA to septum and nasal floor
•
GA: associated with better patient satisfaction, improved appearance and function of nose, reduced need for corrective
surgeries (septoplasty, septorhinoplasty, rhinoplasty)

title: Head and Neck Infections
text:
Head and Neck Infections
Spread of infection via fascial planes - neck contains 2x fascial layers in communication with each other:
•
Superficial fascia
•
Deep fascia
o
Cervical / superficial fascia
o
Pre-tracheal fascia
▪
Contains danger space: extends to mediastinum (located
posterior to retropharyngeal, anterior to prevertebral
fascia)
o
Prevertebral fascia
Spaces:
•
Submandibular e.g. Ludwigs angina (mainly 2’ to dental extraction /
infection)
•
Parapharyngeal
•
Retropharyngeal
Pre-op:
•
ASSESS:
o
History: worsening or improved with abx, able to lie flat
o
Exam:
▪
Dysphagia, dysphonia, trismus (interdental distance), positional changes, tracheal deviation
•
Trismus 2’ infection often doesn’t relax with anaesthesia cf trismus 2’ trauma
▪
Tongue protrusion – suggests sublingual involvement
▪
Drooling + stridor are late signs
▪
Subcut emphysema
o
Ix:
▪
Imaging
▪
Nasendoscopy
•
MANAGE:
o
CASH
•
REFER:
o
ENT, ICU
Intra-op:
•
Intubation: no universal agreement – pathology dependent
o
ENT team scrubbed on standby
•
Extubate with caution: drainage does not = swelling
Post-op:
•
HDU/ICU
Complications:
•
Periorbital cellulitis
•
Cavernous sinus thrombosis
•
Facial vein thrombosis
•
Lemierres (IJ thrombus 2’ infection)
•
Mediastinitis
•
Rupture into airway
•
Airway obstruction
•
Haematogenous spread

title: Maxillofacial Surgery
text:
Maxillofacial Surgery
Same considerations as oropharyngeal surgery+
Pre-op:
•
ASSESS:
o
Same as oropharyngeal sx
o
Previous airway
o
Nasendoscopy if multiple procedures +/- radiotherapy
•
MANAGE:
•
REFER:
o
MDT: maxfacs + ICU
Intra-op:
•
Intubation: likely nasal intubation
•
Throat pack if indicated
•
Two-stage operations (resection, reconstruction) very long surgery: pressure points
•
Hypotension for bone work: difficult to stop bone bleeding, helps with surgical conditions
o
Avoid if: carotid stenosis, AS/MS, stage 4 kidney disease
•
Free flap considerations (if applicable)
•
If considerable bleeding empty stomach of blood with OGT + suction with laryngoscope
•
Extubation position:
o
30 degrees head up if risk of bleeding from venous congestion
o
Left lateral and head down if risk of airway soiling
•
Smooth extubation: can use remifentanil or switch ETT for LMA and wake slowly if safe
o
Suction via tube as withdrawing
o
Can withdraw nasal ETT to 15cm and cut to form NPA – place safety pin to prevent unwanted insertion

title: Facial Trauma
text:
Facial Trauma
Beware associated injuries: brain, C-spine, mandible / maxilla / orbit, base of skull, epistaxis, airway oedema, neck, chest /
abdominal, bleeding (blood in stomach → aspiration risk), dental injury
Anatomy:
•
Lower third:
o
Bilateral anterior mandible: tongue falls back
o
Sublingual haematoma
o
Teeth loss
•
Middle third: maxilla, zygoma, lower half orbit
o
i.e. le fort fractures
•
Upper third: frontal, sphenoid, orbit – consider skull base
Pre-op:
•
Know details of injury + planned mode of repair i.e. arch bars versus fixation screws versus Ivy loops
•
Assess for trismus and evidence of TMJ injury – may require awake nasal intubation
•
Must assess for possible base of skull # or CSF leak precluding nasal intubation
Intra-op: as above+
•
May require nasal intubation
•
Throat pack
•
Prepare for bradycardia when zygoma/mid-face fracture reduced i.e. “Gillies lift”
•
May require controlled hypotension
•
Blood loss management
Post-op:
•
Intermaxillary fixation rare these days, usually removable bands, but if used wire cutters must
be immediately available + surgeons present for extubation
•
Prolonged stay in recovery before ICU / appropriate ward
•
Consider delayed extubation – must check for cuff leak

title: Electroconvulsive Therapy
text:
Electroconvulsive Therapy
Indications: medication resistant depression, bipolar/mania, schizophrenia/schizoaffective, catatonia, NMS
MOA: GCTS under GA
CI:
•
MI or CVA within 3/12
•
ICP
•
Uncontrolled HF
•
DVT
•
Untreated cerebral aneurysm
•
Unstable major fracture/osteroporosis
•
Phaeochromocytoma
•
Retinal detachment / glaucoma
Method:
•
2x electrodes
o
Unilateral: cochlear implants, less cognitive adverse effects (if non-dominant)
o
Bilateral: faster effect
•
Twice weekly ~10-12 treatments (maintenance thereafter not recommended) or until lack of improvement
Evidence:
•
Some recent narrative reviews debating efficacy – low level evidence
•
Meta-analyses and systematic reviews:
o
No evidence for ECT over pharmacotherapy if used alone, supports superior outcomes in conjunction with
pharmacotherapy – however many limitations
o
No difference in MMSE between ECT and no ECT
Physiological effects:
•
CVS:
o
Initially parasympathetic response: salivation, bradycardia, hypotension, asystole
o
→ sympathetic response: BP 30-40%, HR 20%, CO (myocardial VO2)
•
Cerebral: CMRO2, CBF, ICP
•
Other: IOP, intragastric pressure, headache, myalgia, dental damage, hypersalivation
Complications:
•
CVS: MI/MACE
•
Neuro: ICH, TIA, cortical blindness, prolonged seizures, cognitive (memory, disorientation, retro- + antegrade amnesia)
o
Minimised by: altered stimulus intensity/waveform, unilateral electrodes, longer inter-ECT interval
•
Mortality 1/10,000
Agent
Advantages
Disadvantages
Propofol
•
PONV
•
Rapid onset, offset
•
Shortest seizure duration
•
Pain on injection
Thiopentone
•
Better seizure quality
•
arrhythmias
•
Short seizure duration
•
Precipitates with sux
Ketamine
•
Effective in resistant
seizures
•
duration
•
Emergence phenomenon
•
CVS stability
•
ICP
Sevoflurane
•
Difficult IV access
•
Tocolytic in pregnancy
•
Slow induction
Dexmed
•
No effect on seizure
duration
•
MAP, HR

title: Electroconvulsive Therapy
text:
Pre-op:
•
ASSESS:
o
Must know if voluntary or involuntary: capacity / consent
o
History: poor historians, elderly, comorbid
▪
Aspiration risk
o
Exam: cardiac, airway
o
Ix:
▪
ECG + bloods first time
o
Medications: d/w psych
▪
MAOis: hypertension if indirection sympathomimetics used
▪
Lithium: risk of delirium, prolonged seizures, toxic lithium levels, neuromuscular blockade
•
Avoid if possible, if cannot be discontinued omit day prior or monitor closely
▪
Benzos: seizure threshold, withhold prior if able
▪
Ensure PPI + anti-hypertensives taken prior
•
MANAGE:
o
Special populations:
▪
PPM switch to fixed rate, ICD will require magnet
▪
Pregnancy: pre-procedure tocolysis (otherwise safe)
▪
DBS: disable device via manufacturer
•
REFER:
o
Any CI
Intra-op: often remote anaesthesia + high turnover – check all emergency equipment
•
Pre-ECT: empty bladder, glycol if previous bradycardia
•
Monitoring: routine + 5-lead ECG if CVS dz
•
Goals: rapid onset + offset, muscle relaxation for safety, manage physiological effects
•
Induction:
o
Bite block
o
Propofol 1mg / kg, sux 0.5mg/kg
o
Hyperventilate to seizure threshold (ETCO2 ~30mmHg) + hyperoxia
o
Adjuncts:
▪
Beta-blockers for HR/BP
▪
Can use low dose remi/alfentanil at induction to reduce anaesthetic agent
o
Avoid:
▪
Indirect sympathomimetics if on TCA, MAOi
▪
Ondans, fentanyl, metoclopramide if on SSRI
•
Terminate seizure if >2 mins
•
Support airway whilst waking
Post-op:
•
Side effects: confusion, agitation, violence, amnesia, headache, myalgia, PONV
•
Complications: MACE 1/50
•
Post-op agitation: IV benzo, dexmed, antipsychotic

title: Cardiac Surgery
text:
Cardiac Surgery
Ix:
•
ECG, TTE, CXR, +/- spiro +/- CT chest +/- RH cath
•
Ix: Hb, HbA1c, albumin (vent, infection, mortality), EUC, coags, G&H x-match x2, plt count
o
Anaemia → iron studies → treat (anaemia independent RF, end up requiring more transfusions)
•
Cardiac cath
o
LCx → OM
o
LAD (is actually a branch of LCx) → diagonals + septal perforators
*intermediates occur at a trifurcation
o
RCA → acute marginals + posterior descending artery (may join LAD) + posterior branch to LV
Assess dominance i.e. PDA (80% right, 20% left)
Assess CI to TOE:
•
Absolute: perf, stricture, tumour, diverticulum, active bleed
•
Relative: neck radiation, GI surgery, recent bleed, Barrett’s, dysphagia, restricted neck ROM, varices, hiatus hernia,
coagulopathy, oesophagitis
Unsure: gastroscopy start of case
Examination: routine +dental health (valves), skin integrity
Optimisation:
•
Modifiable RFs
•
Pre-op CEA for carotid stenosis
•
Target HbA1c <6.5%
•
Intra-nasal muciprocin (Staph aureus sternal wound infection)
•
Rehabilitation
Medication:
•
Continue: beta blocker, statin, aspirin (ATACUS)
•
Withhold:
o
Clopidogrel/prasugrel/ticagrelor 5 – 7 days
o
Warfarin 5 days
o
DOACs 3 – 5 days
Consent:
•
Mortality: EUROSCORE II
•
1-2% permanent handicap
•
Post-op analgesia challenging
•
Post-op depression frequent (generally self-limiting)
•
POCD
•
Awareness: 1/8600
•
Risks of TOE: consent
•
General risk of GA: dental damage (ETT + TOE), risk of allergy / adverse drug reactions

title: ERAS Cardiac Surgery
text:
ERAS Cardiac Surgery
Pre-op:
•
EUROSCORE – risk
•
HbA1c <6.5% (myocardial injury and infections)
•
Albumin + nutrition (low albumin associated with prolonged ventilation, AKI, infection, LOS, mortality)
•
Anaemia: Hb <100 → 5x mortality
•
Prehabilitation: education + patient engagement tools, exercise, lifestyle modification
o
Stopping smoking + hazardous alcohol consumption for 4/52 prior to surgery
•
Pre-op carb loading (24g complex carbs night prior + 2hr pre-op)
•
Infection reduction care bundle (see below)
Intra-op:
•
Use of TXA on pump
•
Goal directed fluid therapy
•
Multimodal, opioid sparing analgesia
•
Avoiding T >37.9 whilst re-warming on CPB
•
Rigid sternal fixation
•
PONV prophylaxis
Post-op:
•
Aim extubation within 6hr post-op
•
Avoidance of T <36 (bleeding, infection, LOS, mortality)
•
Insulin infusions to treat hyperglycaemia
•
Post-op delirium screening once per nursing shift post-op (CAM-ICU)
•
VTE prophylaxis
•
Maintenance of chest tube patency
•
Avoid breaking sterile field of chest drains to remove clots
Surgical infection:
•
Level I recommendation:
o
Intranasal decolonisation prior to surgery
o
Cephalosporin 30-60 min prior to surgery
o
Clipping > shaving prior to surgery
•
Level II recommendation:
o
Chlorhex based skin prep
o
Remove operative wound dressing after 48 hours

title: Fast Track Cardiac Surgery
text:
Fast Track Cardiac Surgery
Fast track: extubated and transferred from ICU to step down unit on same day as surgery
Associated with:
•
ICU and total LOS
•
Similar 30-day post-op outcomes (all-cause mortality, stroke, renal failure, infection, AF, and readmission)
Fast tracking appropriate patients may reduce resource utilisation whilst maintaining patient safety

title: Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery
text:
Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery
Indications: left main >50%, TVD >70% +/- prox LAD, two vessel dz (LAD + other major), ≥one stenosis >70% w/ sig SSx, ≥one
stenosis >70% w/ cardiac arrest or ischaemia related tachycardia

title: On Pump
text:
On Pump
Pre-op:
•
ASSESS:
o
CI to bypass: e.g. porcelain aorta or TOE
•
MANAGE: consent / optimise
•
REFER/DISCUSS: CTSx, ICU +/- ECMO
Intra-op:
•
Monitoring: sats, 5-lead ECG, art line, CVC + PAC, temp x2, BIS, NIRS
•
Drugs: TXA, abx
•
Maintenance: sevo (ischaemic pre-conditioning)
•
TOE post-induction: 5% changes op course
•
Sternotomy: lungs off
•
Harvesting of internal mammary: VT
On pump: HAD2SAVE
•
Heparin: 300-400 units / kg
•
ACT >480s
•
Drugs: paralysis, volatile via CBP or TIVA
•
Drips: turn off inotropes, fluids
•
Swan: pull PA catheter back 5cm to avoid pulmonary arterial occlusion / rupture when pulmonary arteries collapse
•
Alarms: disable
•
Ventilator: off when bypass “full flow”
•
Emboli: check arterial cannula for bubbles
Bypass: RA venous, arch arterial return (arterial first in last out – sBP <100 dissection risk)
Bypass components: venous cannula → reservoir → pump → combined filter / oxygenator / warmer → arterial
Cardioplegia: temp: 25 - 32C (gradient <10C)
•
Antegrade: aortic root (requires competent AV)
•
Retrograde: coronary sinus (risk missing some veins – incomplete)
Flow:
•
Rate: BSA x CI (~2.4L/min/m2)
•
VO2: (CaO2 – CvO2) x CO
Monitoring:
•
Pump flow: SvO2 <75% → flow
•
Blood: ABQ q30 min (pH, iCa), ACT, SvO2, Hb, Hct >25%, K, BSL
o
HCT on CPB = blood volume x Hct / total circuit volume
•
Heparin re-dosing: based on ACT
Wean from CPB: TRAVEL
•
Temp: re-warm 0.5C/min to >36.5, temp gradient <4C, TOE
•
Rate, rhythm, reversal ready (protamine – 0.6x initial heparin bolus volume)
•
Air, acid-base, ABG, anaesthesia, alarms on
•
Ventilation (oxygenation), vasopressors (aim SVR 1000-1200)
•
Electrolytes (K+, Ca2+)
•
Level (bed + volume in reservoir)
Protamine after venous decannulation, prior to arterial decannulation – sBP <100
Check pacemaker settings
Post-bypass TOE + re-check ACT

title: Off Pump
text:
Off Pump
Indications: porcelain aorta
Considerations:
•
Warming patient more difficult (as pump helps to warm)
•
Need to keep well filled
•
Control HR and rhythm throughout
•
Patient is still heparinised (?ACT target)
•
LIMA to LAD first to optimise perfusion to pericardium (cf on pump)
Trials have shown no benefit to on pump surgery – ROOBY trial:
•
No difference in composite 30-day outcome: death & complications
•
1 year follow-up: patients with off-pump had worse outcomes + poorer graft patency cf on-pump
•
No significant differences in neuropsychological outcomes

title: Deep Hypothermic Circulatory Arrest
text:
Deep Hypothermic Circulatory Arrest
Indications:
•
Cardiac: aortic arch/thoracic aorta, pulmonary thrombo-endarterectomy, congenital surgery
o
Aortic arch: assess for compression of tracheobronchial tree i.e. stridor or oesophagus i.e. dysphagia
•
Neuro: aneurysm, complex AVM
•
Other: RCC with caval invasion, other tumours
Aim:
•
Circulatory arrest → optimises operating conditions
•
Deep hypothermia → neuroprotection (CMRO2 7%/1C <37C at 18C 60% will have isoelectric EEG)
Pre-op: CAGS +
•
Document neuro exam
Intra-op:
•
As for CPB → full flows
•
Neuromonitoring: EEG, NIRS, SSEPs, jugular venous bulb sats
•
Cooling: temp gradient <10C (to avoid air bubbles)
o
Monintor temp @ 2 sites: NPA (best measure of brain temp) + bladder
•
Neuroprotection:
o
Propofol + steroids prior to flow arrest
o
Extremely tight BSL control
o
Hct 20% / Hb 75 to improve microcirculation
•
At 18-20C → partial exsanguination, heparinised blood in stasis
o
Safe period:
▪
~30mins of arrest at 18°C
▪
40min: marked brain injury
▪
60min majority will have brain injury
•
Maintenance: no evidence for TIVA v volatile via circuit
•
Adjuvant perfusion strategies i.e. cerebroplegia:
o
Selective antegrade cerebral perfusion
o
Retrograde cerebral perfusion
•
Rewarming: temp gradient <5C, T <37C, rewarming rate <0.5C/min, core temp <36.5C
Blood gas measurements:
•
Alpha stat: measure at <37C – not temp corrected
•
pH stat: target normal pH, pCO2 regardless of actual temp
No evidence of benefit for either technique
Recommendations for DHCA:
•
Adults: alpha-stat
•
Paeds: pH stat during cooling and alpha stat during rewarming
Consequences:
•
CVS: arrhythmia, blood viscosity, vasoconstriction, impaired microcirculation
•
Haem: coagulopathy, plt fx, RBC rigidity
•
Metabolic: acidosis, hyperglycaemia, altered PK and PD
•
Renal: GFR
•
Neuro: hyperthermia during warming risk of brain injury, post-op cognitive dysfunction, stroke ~10%

title: Minimally Invasive Cardiac Surgery
text:
Minimally Invasive Cardiac Surgery
Advantages:
•
Post-op pain
•
Cosmetics
•
Early mobilsation + LOS
•
Blood loss
VATS Surgery
Most common is MV surgery. Right antero-lateral approach or minithoracotomy + ports.
Requirements:
•
OLV
•
NIRS
•
TOE
•
Peripheral CPB – more dangerous than central cannulation
o
Vacuum drainage can lead to airlocks or haemolysis
•
Aortic occlusion for cardioplegia: either clamp or endoballoon (endoballoon technically difficult)
Pre-op:
•
As for sternotomy – must be prepared to convert if needed
Intra-op:
•
Usual cardiac / sternotomy
•
DLT
•
TOE: check endoballoon
•
In contrast to sternotomy femoral venous cannulation first?
Complications:
•
Conversion to sternotomy (main reason is bleeding)
•
Post-op bleeding: 2’ incomplete opening of pericardium, difficult assessment via TOE
•
2’ retrograde / peripheral CPB: neurological complications, stroke, aortic dissection
•
Nerve injury: positioning, phrenic nerve, pressure points
•
Harlequin syndrome: hemicerebral ischaemia (improved by ventilation of L lung with 100% FiO2 until diastolic arrest)
•
OLV complications
•
Re-expansion pulmonary oedema

title: Transcatheter Mitral Valve Repair
text:
Transcatheter Mitral Valve Repair
Indications: severe primary MR + high surgical risk, if secondary MR optimise HF / CAD first
CI:
•
Valve: area <3cm2, leaflet length <6mm, mean pressure gradient >5mmHg, calcification at grasping area, thrombus,
regurg at commissure
•
Atrial access: unable to achieve >35mm above MV on intra-atrial septum, very small LA
Pre-op: cardiac+
•
LV function: LVEF <40% risk of afterload mismatch and worsening LV – not CI, just be aware
•
Favourable anatomy + access
•
CI to TOE
•
Medications: continue BB, anti-arrhythmics, antiplt + diuretics; WH warfarin / DOACs
•
Rhythm: SR if able
•
CIED check
•
Risk of conversion < TAVI (rare)
Intra-op:
•
Monitoring: routine + art line
•
Induction: prop, remi, roc; avoid benzos
•
Usual MR goals: high normal HR, euvolaemia, reduced afterload, SR
o
AF: treat, no thrombus on TOE can cardiovert
•
Aid procedure / coaptation gap:
o
Ventilation: PEEP 5 – 10 (can aid device placement), Vt 3-6mL/kg reduces movement
o
LV size: diuretics
Procedure:
•
Femoral v. puncture → heparin (ACT 250 – 300) → atrial septal puncture
•
Clips placed
•
After clips placed must normalise BP to patient awake state and assess for MR prior to deployment → deployed
•
Assessment, aiming mean diastolic gradient ≤6mmHg
•
Subjective closure of atrial defect based on shunting
•
+/- heparin reversal
•
Femoral access closure device – 1hr bed rest
•
If oropharangeal topicalization used must wear off prior to PO intake
TTE within 24hr: ?residual MR +/- new MS, assess ASD if not closed
Rx: antiplatelet only (only anti-coagulate if already taking for other reason)
Complications:
•
Bleeding (retroperitoneal is rare but possible)
•
TOE complications
•
AKI
•
Delayed tamponade
•
Arrhythmia
•
Pulmonary oedema +/- hypoxia (possible if new MS, excess fluids)

title: TAVI
text:
TAVI
Indications: severe AS not suitable for sAVR (consider comorbidity, age, porcelain aorta, previous surgery)
•
Indications for surgery: EUROSCORE <10%, anatomy not suitable for TAVI, endocarditis, LV thrombus, other cardiac
condition that requires surgical intervention
Absolute CI: endocarditis
Relative CI: life expectancy <2y + anatomical adverse features
Trials have shown equivalence and superiority to sAVR in high- and intermediate- risk patients
Pre-op: cardiac+
•
Favourable anatomy
•
Assess for conversion
Intra-op:
•
Monitoring: routine + art line
•
Anaesthetic: no difference in outcomes with GA v LA (usually LA + conscious sedation)
o
Sedation: must be able to breath hold, benefit of neuro examination
o
GA required if TOE needed
•
Access: usually femoral artery → retrograde implantation
•
Heparin ~5000iu → ACT 250s
•
Type of valve:
o
Core: self-expanding, can be repositioned
o
Sapien: balloon expanding, once deployed is stuck
•
Valve deployment: rapid ventricular pacing 200bpm → sBP <50mmHg for 5 – 10s – avoid misplacement
•
Post-deployment: must check for leaks +/- need for reintervention + check coronaries for obstruction
Post-op: 3-6mo of DAPT followed by aspirin only (if already anticoagulated recommence and add clopidogrel for 3mo)
Complications:
•
Vascular injury
•
Embolisation
•
Paravalvular regurgitation
•
Ostial obstruction
•
Tamponade
•
AV block
•
PEA
•
Asystole
•
Stroke
•
AKI

title: Pericardial Effusion / Tamponade
text:
Pericardial Effusion / Tamponade
Definitions:
•
Effusion: fluid in pericardial space
•
Tamponade: when pericardial effusion → pressure → ventricular filling and CO
Causes:
•
Effusion:
o
Infectious: viral, bacterial, TB, fungal, parasitic
o
Non-infectious: idiopathic, trauma, uraemia, neoplastic, autoimmune, Dressler’s syndrome (i.e. sterile
pericarditis post-MI), hypothyroidism, radiation
Common causes of tamponade: pericarditis, tuberculosis, trauma, malignancy, iatrogenic (e.g. cardiac surgery, invasive
procedures)
Pathophysiology:
•
Intra-pericardial pressure usually equals intrathoracic pressure
o
pericardial pressure → ventricular filling pressures, chamber compression, CO
•
Pericardial volume is fixed → in tamponade IV septum shifts to left in inspiration → ventricular filling
Accentuation of normal variation in spont breathing
Tamponade worsened by mechanical ventilation
Clinical presentation:
•
Pulsus paradoxus: sBP by 10mmHg on spontaneous inspiration (due
to left shift of IV septum)
•
Dyspnoea, orthopnoea, chest discomfort
•
Elevated JVP
•
Markers of CO: UO, lactic acidosis, cool peripheries, hypotension
•
Sympathetic tone
Ix:
•
Bloods
•
CXR: enlarged cardiac silhouette
•
ECG: sinus tachycardia, small QRS voltage, electrical alternans
•
TTE/TOE: size, location, haemodynamic consequences
•
CT/MRI
Management:
•
Pericardiocentesis: 16-18G needle inferior / left xiphisternum, 45 angle towards left shoulder, ideally US guided
o
Complications (1.5%): cardiac arrest, cardiac laceration, arrhythmia, lung / oesophageal injury, pulmonary
oedema, acute ventricular dilation
•
Surgical drainage i.e. pericardial window
Anaesthesia:
•
Goals: “fast, full, tight”
o
preload, HR normal-high, SR, maintain SVR, maintain contractility
•
Induction: consider pre-induction pericardiocentesis under LA
o
Prep + drape + surgeon scrubbed and ready
o
Invasive monitoring, CVC, large bore IV, defib pads attached and ready + emergency drugs
o
Drugs: ketamine 0.5mg-1mg/kg, rocuronium 1.2mg/kg, metaraminol 1mg chaser
o
Ventilation: low PEEP + large volumes, consider spont venting + spray chords
o
Maintenance: volatile + opioids, NMBA, intra-op TOE
o
Prepare for rebound hypertension post-drainage → deepen anaesthesia, cease vasopressors
Post op → ICU
Size: measured during diastole
•
Small: <10mm
•
Mod: 10 – 20mm
•
Large: >20mm + “swinging heart” –
with electrical alternans
TTE/TOE:
•
Collapse of cardiac chambers
•
IVC dilatation
•
Left shift IV septum
•
LV diastolic pseudohypertrophy
•
Tricuspid: 30% in inspiratory peak E-
wave velocity
•
Mitral: 30% in inspiratory peak E-
wave velocity

title: Re-Do Sternotomy
text:
Re-Do Sternotomy
Mortality 2-6x cf primary sternotomy)
Main risk: blood loss 2’ prolonged dissection of adhesions +/- direct injury to heart on sternal entry
Subsequent risks:
•
Prolonged bypass times
•
Coagulopathy
Highest risk period: 3 weeks – 6mo (density of adhesions)
Pre-op:
•
Risk/consent: NYHA, EUROSCORE II
•
TTE
•
Should have coronary angiogram to assess mobility & patency of grafts
•
CT/MRI high risk injury findings:
o
Grafts crossing midline
o
RV/major vasculature adherent to or within 1cm of sternum in AP direction
•
Treat anaemia
•
Re-program implantable devices to asynchronous mode
o
CRT: may need to be in sensing mode – d/w surgeons, will require diathermy for 1-2s with 10s pauses
•
Pre-med for anxiety
Intra-op:
•
Blood products available prior to starting + 14G x2 – set up cell salvage
o
Rapid infuser + 4 units pRBC
o
Platelet line
•
Monitoring: sats, art line, 5-lead ECG + CVC prior to induction if able
•
Defib pads in situ (cannot easily mobilise heart for internal pads)
•
Peripheral CPB: reserved for high-risk pts
o
Benefits: still + empty heart for entry, cooling for organ protection
o
Risks: stroke, heparinisation may blood loss during dissection
Consider pre-emptive sheath insertion → rewired in event of major haemorrhage
•
Drugs: TXA, heparin must be drawn up prior to incision
•
Trendelenberg: heart away from sternum
Management of catastrophic haemorrhage during resternotomy:
•
Direct pressure to sternal edges
•
Immediate heparin and institution of CPB
o
If no peripheral cannulas in situ commence MTP aiming to match losses
Post-bypass:
•
Ca2+, TEG, warm, normal pH
Post-op:
•
ICU
•
Re-do sternotomies risk sternal wound infections & mediastinitis

title: ECMO
text:
ECMO
Indications:
•
VV: respiratory failure with predicted mortality ≥50%
•
VA: eCPR or refractory cardiogenic shock with maximum medical therapy
o
Central: return cannula in aorta
o
Peripheral: return cannula in femoral artery
▪
Risk of Harlequin syndrome: 2’ impaired pulmonary function + recovering LV i.e. poorly oxygenated
blood → heart and brain, well oxygenated blood from circuit → LL – must have R sats / art line + NIRS
Must have reasonable expectation of recovery or be a bridge to definitive management
CI: age >75yo, severe other organ failure, severe brain injury, advanced malignancy, non-reversible pathology, aortic dissection
(VA)
Components:
•
Access cannula
•
Pump
•
Membrane oxygenator
•
Heater
•
Return cannula
VA-ECMO Indications
VV-ECMO Indications
•
Graft failure (heart/lung)
•
Cardiogenic shock / arrest
•
Post-cardiac surgery
•
Sepsis
•
Drug OD e.g. beta blocker
•
Myocarditis
•
Bridge to VAD
•
OE
•
Major heart / vessel trauma
•
Massive pulmonary haemorrhage
•
Anaphylaxis
•
Procedural support
•
Severe pneumonia
•
ARDS/COVID
•
Pulmonary contusion
•
Acute graft failure
•
Smoke inhalation
•
Asthma
•
Airway obstruction
•
Aspiration
•
BAL for alveolar proteinosis
CI: cardiac arrest without ROSC (unless ECMO-CPR), advanced age, active / terminal malignancy, chronic end stage organ failure,
irreversible neurological condition, recent ICH
Specific CI:
•
VV: mechanical ventilation >7 days, severe pHTN mPAP >50
•
VA: severe AR, aortic dissection
Daily investigations on ECMO:
•
CXR
•
Bloods: ABG, EUC, CMP, LFT, LDH, FBC
•
Pre- & post-membrane ABG
•
Coags: INR, aPTT, fibrinogen, anti-Xa level, D-dimer
•
Plasma free Hb
Monitoring:
•
Pump flow rate
•
Circuit lines: chattering, swinging
•
Pre- and post-membrane pressures  transmembrane pressure
o
Normal <50mmHg – increased may indicate clot on oxygenator
•
Temp
•
RPM
•
Vascular obs
•
NIRS

title: ECMO
text:
Anticoagulation:
•
UFH: aPTT, anti-Xa levels, AT level
o
Complications: HITS, heparin resistance
•
Bivalirudin: aPTT
Troubleshooting VV-ECMO:
•
Worsening hypoxia/hypercapnoea:
o
Ensure pump flow >2/3 CO
o
100% O2 at oxygenator
o
Post-membrane O2 >150mmHg (i.e. oxygenator is functioning)
o
Treatment: flow, ventilation, cool patient / O2 requirement
•
Worsening hypercapnoea:
o
As above
o
sweep gas
•
Check for recirculation: take venous PO2 – if higher than patient’s venous PO2 then withdraw access line
Troubleshooting VA ECMO:
•
Differential hypoxia:
o
Modify lung ventilation / oxygenation
o
Consider R subclavian return line
•
Flow not maintained:
o
A
▪
Access: tip position, kink, clot
▪
Airway: coughing, moving
o
B: oxygenation check TMP, plasma free Hb
o
C: ensure adequate preload
Complications:
Patient
Circuit
•
Bleeding: ICH, GIT, pulmonary, access site
•
Coagulopathy, thrombosis
•
Infection
•
Differential hypoxia (VA)
•
Limb ischaemia
•
Vascular injury
•
HITS (if heparin as anticoagulant)
•
Haemolysis: plasma free Hb >70, bili, LDH,
fibrinogen, potassium
•
Access insufficiency
•
Recirculation (VV)
•
Circuit breach: haemorrhage, air embolism
•
Thrombus / clot
•
Pump or oxygenator failure
•
Cannula malposition or decannulation

title: Heparin
text:
Heparin
Binds to ATIII → conformational change → potentiates effect (AT3 inhibits factors Xa and IIa)
Measured via ACT intra-op (aPTT inaccurate at higher doses, requires dilution + takes longer)
ACT:
•
Prolonged by: haemodilution, hypothermia, plt, plt inhibitors
•
Shortened by: surgical stress, plt lysis
Heparin Resistance
Definition: requiring >500units / kg to give ACT 400-480 (whole blood → activated with kaolin → time to clot is measured)
Heparin resistance mechanisms (3):
•
Excessive binding of heparin to protein, platelets, surfaces
•
AT3 deficiency:
o
Disease (liver failure, sepsis, DIC)
o
Asparaginase / CPB / ECMO
o
Recent sig heparin exposure (not LMWH)
o
Hereditary AT3 deficiency
•
States that effect ACT independently of heparin (e.g. coag factor deficiency, platelet impairment)
Rx:
•
Higher dose of heparin
•
AT3 supplementation (fractionated human-derived AT3 > FFP)
Heparin Induced Thrombocytopaenia (HITS)
Platelet: <100 or <50% baseline. 4Ts: thrombocytopaenia, timing, thrombosis, other causes for thrombocytopaenia
Diagnosis: via functional HIT assay
Heparin risk 1/200 therapeutic:
•
Type 1 (non-immune): 10 – 20%, within 4 days of UFH, usually nil thrombosis, self-limiting → observe
•
Type 2 (i.e. HITTS, immune): 1-3%, IgG mediated (forming IgG-pltF4-heparin complexes), usually 5-14 days after
starting heparin, marked thrombocytopaenia, associated with thrombosis requires alternative anticoagulation
Protamine Reactions
Protamine
MOA/Class
+ve protamine binds -ve heparin → forms stable inactive protamine-heparin salt complex → prevents heparin
binding to AT3 → reversal of heparin effect
Effect: UFH 100%, LMWH (60%), fondaparinux (0%)
Derived from salmon sperm
Pharmacokinetic
Dose: IV 1mg reverses 100IU of heparin (reversal within 5 minutes)
At end of CPB dose protamine 0.6 vol ratio to initial dose of heparin
Elimination
Complex cleared by reticuloendothelial system, t1/2β 60 mins (risk of re-heparinisation)
Pharmacodynamic
CVS
o
Vasodilation 2’ histamine/unknown (especially when given rapidly) → hypotension + flushing
o
Pulmonary hypertension (2’ compliment action + thromboxane release)
o
Direct myocardial depressant
RESP
o
Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema (thromboxane mediated) → pulmonary vasoconstriction
o
Bronchospasm (histamine)
HAEM
o
Paradoxical anticoagulation if dose exceeds required dose to reverse heparin → reacts with platelets and
fibrinogen
IMMUNO
o
Anaphylactoid / anaphylaxis – possible cross-reactivity as some insulins contain protamine (slows absorption) –
do not exceed initial 1:1 reversal ratio of initial heparin bolus
OTHER
o
Incompatibility with some antibiotics
o
May increase duration of non-depolarising MBs
Reactions:
•
Type I: isolated hypotension
•
Type II: hypotension + features of anaphylactoid reactions e.g. bronchoconstriction
•
Type III: 2’ large heparin-protamine complexes in pulmonary circ → may lead to acute RHF (rare)
Special populations:
•
APLS: no guidelines, difficult monitoring of
heparin/ACT, no evidence for IVIg
•
FVL: heparin + protamine reversal
•
Protein C & S deficiency: no guidelines – may
need higher heparin dosing, + protamine
reversal

title: Epicardial Pacing
text:
Epicardial Pacing
Temporary pacing wires: atrium + ventricle
1. Pacing
2. Sensing
3. Response
4. Programmability (i.e. rate)
Paced ventricle is not preferred as electrical activity does not flow like intrinsic activity
Modes:
•
Fixed/asynchronous: paces over intrinsic rhythm, useful for intra-op diathermy etc however risk of R on T should only
be used post-op in emergencies
•
Demand/synchronous: allows inhibition when normal conduction present and triggering of ventricular pacing when
atrial activity is sensed
Common modes:
•
AAI: atrial pacing beneficial if normal AV conduction - atrial pacing in early post-op risk of AF
•
VVI: RV before LV → broad QRS. LV ejection.
•
DDD/DDI: both chambers paced with a predetermined AV interval
•
VOO/DOO: emergency setting (usually 80bpm), asynchronous – risk of R on T
Temporary pacing usually initiated at time of weaning from bypass. AOO or DOO. AOO > DOO if AV conduction is <200ms.
Usually not possible to check the pacemaker intra-op as patient dependent when hypothermic and coming off bypass.
Capture threshold (should be checked prior to chest closure):
•
<5mA: good
•
5 – 10mA: d/w surgeon – may need repositioning or replacement
•
>10mA: unacceptable – will likely fail in early post-op period
Pacemaker check (in ICU):
•
Physiological: T >36, normal K
•
If pausing to check intrinsic rhythm ECG
and arterial line should be continuously
monitored
•
If intrinsic rhythm present:
o
1st: measure sensing threshold
o
2nd: measure capture threshold
Pacing issues:
•
Failure to pace: systematic check ?wire
migration ?improper wire connection
•
Failure to capture: check
•
Intermittent pacing: check
•
R on T induced VT/VF: pause pacemaker
→ external defib
•
Pacemaker mediated tachycardia
Must withhold heparin prior to pacing wire
removal + observation for at least 24hr.

title: Pulmonary Artery Catheter
text:
Pulmonary Artery Catheter
Indications:
•
Evaluation / diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension (gold standard) – measure at end expiration
•
Shock evaluation: MvO2, volume status
•
Cardiac illness e.g. tamponade
•
Assessment of right-sided valvular disease, congenital disease, shunts, when surgical repair is planned
Contra-indications: no consent, infection over insertion site, presence of RVAD
Relative CI:
•
LBBB – risk of RBBB on insertion, must have external pacing available
•
Severe arrhythmia
•
Severe right sided valve stenosis
•
TOF
Risks:
•
General: infection, bleeding, damage to local structures
•
Specific: arrhythmia, PA rupture, thrombosis, air embolism, pneumothorax
Right Atrium
Right Ventricle
Pulmonary Artery
PA Wedge
Waveform
Normal values
CVP ~0-6mmHg
15/2 – 30/8mmHg
15/8 – 30/15mmHg
8-12mmHg
Points of Waveform
a wave: atrial contraction
c wave: closure of TV /
ventricular contraction
x descent: TV pulled during
ventricular ejection
v wave: atrial filling during
ventricular systole
y descent: opening of TV,
diastolic filling
Atrial systole: small
upstroke
Systolic upstroke:
isovolumic contraction,
rapid ejection
Diastole: isovolumic
relaxation, rapid filling
Systole – same pressure
as RV systole
Diastole step up
Dicrotic notch: due to
reflection and resonance
Wedge = balloon inflated
to occlude a pulmonary
artery branch
Very similar to CVP!
a: atrial contraction
x descent: MV pulled
during ventricular
ejection
v wave: atrial filling
during ventricular systole
y descent: opening of
MV, diastolic filling
c wave absent because
LA pressure transmitted -
dampened
Pathology
↑ if:
•
↑venous return / blood
volume
•
RHF
↓if:
•
↓venous return
•
PPV
↑ if:
•
pulmonary
hypertension
•
pulmonary stenosis
↑ if:
•
left heart failure
•
Chronic hypoxia
•
PE
•
Idiopathic
Measures LA pressure –
indicates LH failure
SVO2 Monitoring

title: TOE / Aortic Doppler
text:
PAC sample. Normal 65 – 70%.
HIGH SVO2
LOW SVO2
O2 delivery
Increased:
•
FiO2
•
Hyperoxia
•
Hyperbaric
•
High flow states: sepsis, hyperthyroid,
severe liver dz
Decreased:
•
Anaemia
•
Hypoxia
•
Low flow state: shock, arrhythmia
O2 demand
Decreased:
•
Hypothermia
•
Anaesthesia
•
Neuromuscular blockade
•
Histotoxic (e.g. cyanide)
•
Shunting (e.g. sepsis)
Increased:
•
Hyperthermia
•
Shivering
•
Pain
•
Seizure

title: Pulse Contour Analysis
text:
Pulse Contour Analysis
SVV: <10% unlikely to be fluid responsive, >15% likely to be fluid responsive
PiCCO
PiCCO catheter: arterial line with thermistor (usually in femoral artery)
Method: CVC → injectate administered → produces temperature time curve via PiCCO catheter (attached to pressure
transducer + PiCCO monitor)
Thermodilution:
Clearance = dose / AUC
∴ CO = clearance = volume x (Tinjectate – Tblood) / area under temp-time curve (Stewart Hamilton eqn for thermodilution)
Derives: CI (+ others)
Pulse contour analysis:
Beat-to-beat parameters derived from shape of arterial wave
Derives: SVV (fluid responsiveness), slope
FloTrac
Sensor on arterial line (radial).
Parameters:
•
CI/CO
•
SV/SVI
•
SVR/SVRI
•
SVV
Connects to Vigileo.
TOE / Aortic Doppler
M mode of AV
CO = SV x HR
•
= CSA (aortic cross sectional area) x VTI (i.e. stroke distance) x HR
Correct for 70% if using descending aorta as only 70% CO passes through descending aorta

title: Chest Drains
text:
Chest Drains
Three essential components:
•
Pleural tube (large diameter, non-kinking, non-compressible)
•
One-way valve
•
Collection chamber
Requires pressure gradient between pleural space and collection system. Drain placed below level of chest (aim 100cm)
Three-Bottle Suction Drains
Safest method.
Components:
1. Trap: blood, fluid
2. Underwater seal w/ one way valve: prevents backflow of air to patient if disconnection occurs
3. Manometer: degree of suction (increases pressure difference)
Adding a fourth bottle ‘vents’ system to relieve any pressure if failure of suction occurs
Considerations:
•
Bellows (labelled E) will expand to the arrow, the suction regulator at A adjusts the suction pressure applied
•
Patient intrathoracic pressure equals suction control setting + float ball water column level
o
If no suction equals float ball level only
•
Only drain 1000 – 1500mL at a time then clamp to prevent re-expansion pulmonary oedema
•
Clamping: can cause tension pneumothorax
o
Never clamp during transfer or if on PPV
o
Indications: large volume drained, post-pneumonectomy, on removal, sample fluid, change bottle/tubing,
assess for air leak, if bottle must be lifted above patient chest

title: Intra-aortic Balloon Pumps
text:
Intra-aortic Balloon Pumps
Anatomy + procedure:
•
Sausage-shaped balloon sits in descending thoracic aorta
•
Upper part distal to L subclavian, lower part cephalad to coeliac trunk
•
Inflated with helium
Indications - as a bridge to therapy in: severe ischaemic MR, VSD, high risk CAGS / PCI (left main >70%), post-CAGS off bypass,
cardiogenic shock (LVEF <40%), pulmonary oedema, pre-transplant, pre-reoperation
CI: AR, aortic aneurysm/dissection, severe sepsis, coagulopathy, LVOT obstruction, futile, AAA, tachyarrhythmia, severe PVD
Counter-pulsation: i.e. balloon inflation in diastole and deflation in systole →
•
Volume displacement proximally and distally
•
Augments intrinsic Windkessel effect
•
Improved coronary and systemic perfusion
Principle: improved ventricular performance by →
•
myocardial O2 supply
•
myocardial O2 demand
Variable
Diastole
Systole
Balloon
Inflation at start of diastole
Deflation at start of systole
ECG timing
Middle of T wave
Middle of R wave
Haemodynamic
effects
•
DBP / aortic root pressure
→ coronary flow (note: in
severe CAD autoregulation
is lost so flow entirely
dependent on pressure
gradient)
•
DPTI
•
EDP and LV volume
•
afterload → CO
•
Pressure/work required to
open AV
•
systemic blood flow →
renal blood flow by 25%
•
LV afterload also improves
RV
•
regurg fraction in MR and
VSD
Insertion:
•
Double-lumen 8 – 9.5Fr catheter
•
25 – 50mL balloon <80-90% aortic diameter
•
Sized on height
•
Tip: 2-3cm distal to L subclavian artery at the
level of the carina
Less iABPs now in use due to ECMO
Triggers: ECG (see table) or pressure
Abnormal waveforms:
Early
Late
Inflation
• Incomplete LV
emptying
• No diastolic
augmentation
• LV demand
• LV supply
• diastolic
augmentation →
benefit on coronary
perfusion
Deflation
•
EDP
baseline
•
No
improvement in
afterload
• afterload

title: Cardiac Patient Handover
text:
Cardiac Patient Handover
Phase 1: equipment and technology
•
Monitoring
•
Ventilator initiated
•
Infusions and fluids checked
•
Chest drains secured and on suction
•
Above checked including vitals
•
Confirm ready for handover
Phase 2: information handover
•
Anaesthetist
o
Patient-specific information
o
Anaesthetic-specific information
•
Surgeon
o
Surgical course
o
Blood loss, complications
o
Plan / goals for next 6 – 12 hr
Phase 3: discussion
Anaesthetist should remain until haemodynamic stability

section_path: Cardiac Arrest After Cardiac Surgery - CALS
title: CALS
text:
CALS
For 10 days post-op; >10 days not helpful
Incidence 1-3% post-op
Initial management based on initial rhythm.
Main differences:
•
Delayed compressions unless PEA
•
Aim for re-sternotomy <5 mins
•
Avoid full dose adrenaline
•
3 stacked shocks / external pacing / internal pacing
Causes:
•
Bleeding:
o
Medical: heparin (?rebound), platelets,
factors, fibrinolysis – do ROTEM
▪
Aim Hb >80, HCT >25
o
Surgical: chest drain output – must check
drain is not occluded
▪
>400mL in 1 hour
▪
>200mL/hr in 2 consecutive hours
▪
>100mL/hr in 4 consecutive hours
•
Low CO:
o
Inotropic / mechanical support
o
Myocardial stunning, preload, afterload,
rate, rhythm
o
Graft/valve failure
o
Ischaemia
•
Tamponade
•
Tension pneumothorax
•
Arrhythmia: ensure Mg >1, K >4.5
•
Vasodilation
o
Temperature
o
Sepsis
o
Anaphylaxis
o
Adrenal insufficiency
o
Post-bypass vasoplegia
o
Inodilators
Ix:
•
Full bloods + ABG + coags / fibrinogen + ROTEM + consider multiplate
•
Ix: ECG, CXR, TOE, CI: <2.2
Management:
•
Delay external chest compressions initially up to 1 min (unless PEA) to allow:
o
3x stacked shocks
o
Pacing
If PEA start compressions immediately, if above unsuccessful start also
•
Airway + breathing: FiO2 100%, no PEEP, confirm ETT, exclude tension PTx
•
Circ:
o
Anti-arrhythmics (amio, lignocaine 1mg/kg), internal defib 20J
o
Pressure: sBP >60, internal cardiac massage
o
Switch iABP to pressure trigger 1:1 ratio 100bpm
o
Pacing to DDD or asynchronous 80 – 100bpm max ouput
Will need full arrest team

title: Difficult Weaning from Cardiac Bypass
text:
Difficult Weaning from Cardiac Bypass
Aim: HR 70-100 (correct either side), MAP 70-90 (if <70 optimise)
Must ensure preload optimised and adequate surgical repair (no valve dysfunction, graft failure or LVOT obstruction)
Ongoing inability to wean →
TOE:
•
LV impaired
1. Inotropes and pressors (i.e. dobutamine, norad, levosimenden, milrinone)
▪
Inotropes:
•
Unsure cause consider adrenaline
•
Milrinone: must add norad to offset vasodilation
•
Levosimenden: mainly pre-op
•
Dobutamine
2. Stepwise reduction of VR and pump flow
3. Cardiac pacing
4. Inhaled NO if pulmonary hypertension or RH failure
•
LV appropriate i.e. vasoplegia
1. Vasopressors (norad)
2. Vasopressin
Ongoing inability to wean i.e. MAP <70, CI <2.0, SvO2 <70%, elevated lactate → mechanical circulatory support
Mechanical support:
•
IABP (CI: AR, severe aortic disease)
•
Left heart assistance e.g. impella available
•
ECMO
Risk factors for RV failure on CPB wean:
•
RV dysfunction
•
Pulmonary hypertension
•
Long CPB time
•
LVAD
•
Heart transplant
•
Inadequate myocardial protection

title: Interventional Cardiology
text:
Interventional Cardiology
Considerations:
•
Patient: properly assessed, appropriate for procedure, ACD formalised
•
Anaesthetic: plan, personnel (AN/AT), equipment (piped gas? scavenging?), equipment absent (US, MH box,
anaphylaxis box)
•
Procedure: communication with teams (cardiology not always used to working with anaesthetics), times of high risk,
plan if things go wrong (OT +/- CPB / ECMO)
•
Environment: isolation, space allocation, radiation, sterile field, movement / table if ii used
•
Recovery: where? Specialist care i.e. monitoring, pacing wires, ICU
Cath Lab
Radiation safety:
•
PPE: lead apron, thyroid shield, leaded glass screen, eyewear
•
Exposure: shots > screening
•
ALARA
•
Maximise distance from source
•
Dosimeter
Complications:
•
Vascular: access site (vessel injury, pseudoaneurysm), thrombus, air embolus, stroke
•
Arrhythmia: induced, accidental, 2’ pathology (heart block, ischaemia, re-entrant)
•
Bleeding: access site, retroperitoneal, vessel rupture, tamponade
•
Equipment: embolisation, malposition
•
Cardiac arrest

title: Cardioversion
text:
Cardioversion
Indications: tachyarrhythmia (+/- haemodynamic compromise), resistant to medical Rx, deemed reversible, HF 2’ AF, new onset
CI: digoxin toxicity, AF >48hr without anticoagulation
Unlikely successful if catecholamine driven or multifocal atrial tachycardia (address underlying cause)
Complications: worse arrhythmia, asystole, stroke, cutaneous burns, ischaemia, APO
Pre-op:
•
Anticoagulation for >48 hr (regardless of thrombus)
•
Ix: routine bloods, ECG, TFTs, TTE, coags, digoxin level
•
WH antihypertensives
•
Consent for sedation, warn for potential procedural recall
Intra-op:
•
Defib pads anterolateral or AP (AP useful for pacing if asystole occurs)
•
TOE prior to cardioversion:
o
Thrombus → abandon + recheck 4/52
•
Propofol bolus / infusion
•
Biphasic, sync (unsync if VF occurs and defib required)
o
AF: 150J → 200J
o
Flutter, SVT: 100J usually adequate
o
Cease O2 just prior to shock
Post-op:
•
Anticoagulation 4/52 (prothrombotic + atrial stunning)
o
Atrial stunning: supportive care
Emergency cardioversion:
•
May be safer to stay and play (CCU etc) than to transfer unstable patient + allows earlier CV
•
Considerations for remote anaesthesia
•
Unfasted: RSI v sedation – tailor to individual circumstance i.e. risk of aspiration versus haemodynamic collapse
•
Safe in pregnancy if unstable (do FHR + facility with availability of emergency C-section if required)

title: EP Studies +/- Ablation
text:
EP Studies +/- Ablation
EP studies are rare in isolation – usually +/- ablation
Side of study:
•
Right: R venous entry (usually R femoral pain), no anticoagulation
•
Left: more invasive, trans-septal crossing, requires anticoagulation
Types of mapping software:
•
CARTO (magnets)
•
NavX (electrical field – interferes with ECG so makes it difficult to pick up ischaemic events)
Anaesthetic considerations:
•
Remote GA:
o
Figure out where equipment + crisis access
o
Limited access: C arms, fluoroscopy screens, dimmed lights
•
Specific:
o
Table doesn’t tilt: risk in aspiration
o
Side:
▪
R side: similar to coronary cath: sedation + local versus GA
▪
L side: GA, trans-septal puncture (TOE guidance)
•
ACT >300
•
Longer procedure
•
Thrombus burden/sicker heart
o
Radiation exposure
•
Crisis:
o
Perforation/effusion/tamponade
o
Stenosis
o
Regurgitation
Sides:
•
AVNRT: right
•
AVRT: right or left
•
Flutter: right (usually cavotricuspid isthmus in RA)
•
AF: left (usually PV isolation)
•
VT ablation: left
AF Ablation
GA + trans-septal puncture for pulmonary vein isolation
•
Monitoring: sats, 5-lead ECG, art line, temp probe for catheter ablation, BIS
•
Ventilation: low vol, high freq
•
No paralysis (phrenic n monitoring) – immobilise with remifentanil
•
Heparin: ACT 300 pre-septal puncture
•
Limit IVF (large irrigation)
•
Stop ablation if temp >38
Post-op:
•
Lie flat 4 hours post groin puncture
•
Overnight telemetry
•
Anticoagulation for 8/52
•
PPI for 6/52
Complications:
•
Early: tamponade, groin bleeding, groin aneurysm, oesophageal injury, CVA/TIA/air embolism, phrenic n injury, failed
procedure
•
Late: PV stenosis, radiation exposure / malignancy, recurrence

title: Device Insertion
text:
Device Insertion
Pacemaker Insertion
Failure of automaticity (i.e. SA node) – this is benign (sick sinus, Mobitz 1)
Failure of conduction (i.e. block) – not benign (Mobitz 2, complete heart block)
Usually L subclavian access (if right sided ask why – usually either L side already used, or congenital)
ii guided +/- L venogram
Submuscular versus subcut
Anaesthetic is proceduralist / location / patient dependent – local versus GA
AICDs
Pathology:
•
Primary prevention
•
Secondary prevention
Anaesthetic same as PPM, usually subcut – ICD box sits in pocket between SA and latissimus dorsi between anterior and mid
axillary line at level of the apex. Has 8cm shocking coil + 2x sensing electrodes → tunnelled subcut:
•
Sensing electrodes:
o
Distal: manubrium sternum
o
Proximal: xiphoid process
•
Shocking electrode: substernal notch
CRT
Indication: NYHA III or IV, LVEF <35%, QRS >130ms + LBBB
PPM: cause R → L septal depolarisation → filling of right heart first → reduced LV filling → SV and CO
CRT: both ventricles paced simultaneously mimicking normal physiology with L→R depolarisation
Device – 3 leads (cf PPM with only RA & RV):
•
RA
•
RV
•
Coronary sinus (paces LV)
Box is sub-pectoral.
Anaesthetic: R sided procedure, very sick patients, usually have diastolic dysfunction/orthopnoea/LHF, longer case (difficult to
find coronary sinus)
Implanted CRT can lead to positive remodelling of the heart
Device Lead Removal
Indications: infection, recall/malfunction, venous access issues, severe TR, chronic pain, MRI/radiotherapy
Pre-op:
•
TTE: cardiac function, course of the leads, presence of PFO, vegetations, severity of TR
•
Ix: routine + cross match
•
Be prepared for haemorrhage (+ difficult re-sternotomy if previous surgery)
•
Risk: EROS category, overall major complications 2-4%, mortality 1%
•
Consider: crisis management plan +/- availability of CTSx + CPB (perfusionist)
Intra-op:
•
GA + TOE
•
CVC + mode of temporary pacing
•
May need SVC balloon
•
Depends on ease of extraction – prepare for haemorrhage / inversion of RA / TV damage
Post-op:
•
Routine+
•
CXR ?PTx/haemothorax

title: Thoracic Surgery
text:
Thoracic Surgery
Right Lung
Left Lung
RUL
•
Apical
•
Posterior
•
Anterior
RML (or more correctly - just middle lobe)
•
Lateral
•
Medial
RLL
•
Apical . superior
•
Medial
•
Anterior
•
Lateral
•
Posterior
PNEMONIC: APALM APALM
LUL
•
Apical
•
Posterior
•
Anterior
Lingula:
•
Superior
•
Inferior
LLL:
•
Apical
•
Posterior
•
Anterior
•
Lateral
PNEMONIC: APAL(SI) APAL
Flexible bronchoscopy physiological effects:
•
Resp: airway resistance, gas exchange/Vt, lung compliance, intrinsic PEEP
o
Risk of hypoxia, hypercapnia, coughing, broncho/laryngospasm
•
CVS: SNS (CO, HR), pulmonary artery pressure, venous return
•
Neuro: ICP

title: Lung Isolation
text:
Lung Isolation
Absolute indications:
•
Prevent damage / contamination of healthy lung (e.g. lung abscess, pulmonary haemorrhage)
•
Control distribution of ventilation (e.g. bronchopleural fistula, traumatic bronchial disruption)
•
Single lung lavage (e.g. CF)
Relative indications:
•
Improved surgical access:
o
Strong evidence: thoracic AA, pneumonectomy, lung reduction, minimally invasive cardiac surgery, upper
lobectomy, VATS
o
Weaker evidence: oesophageal surgery, middle & lower lobectomy, mediastinal mass reduction
Methods of OLV:
•
DLT
•
Bronchial blockers
•
Single lumen tube advanced endo-bronchially
Must review relevant imaging pre-op + discuss with surgeons

title: Bronchial Blockers
text:
Bronchial Blockers
Options:
•
Coaxial: within SLT lumen
•
Independent: adjacent to SLT
Slight variations but mostly size of
bronchial blocker matches size of ETT.
Univent ETT is an all-in-one single
lumen ETT with an enclosed, moveable
bronchial blocker
3 way connector:
•
Bronchial blocker
•
FOB
•
Ventilator port on the side
Tube exchange:
•
Muscle relaxant
•
100% FiO2
•
Bigger AEC down TRACHEAL lumen – 14Fr

title: Endobronchial Single Lumen Tube
text:
Endobronchial Single Lumen Tube
Rarely used unless emergency or extremely difficult DLT placement.

title: Double Lumen Tubes
text:
Double Lumen Tubes
Features of DLT:
•
Bifurcated w/ 2 lumens:
o
Tracheal: above carina
o
Endobronchial (blue cuff + pilot): main stem bronchus
▪
Right DLT: shorter, straighter, wider
•
Murphy’s eye - right UL bronchus
▪
Left DLT
Choosing DLT:
•
Side:
o
Usually L unless surgery involving L main bronchus i.e.
pneumonectomy
o
Dependent lung easier to ventilate with endobronchial lumen
•
Size: best chosen based on CT sizing however
o
Default for 170cm – female 37 Fr, male: 39 Fr
o
Change a size per 10cm height from 170cm (i.e. female 160cm 35Fr)
o
11Fr 100cm AEC fits 35Fr bronchial lumen and bigger
•
Insertion: check integrity + lubricate -
o
Stylet in endobronchial lumen
o
Remove stylet once cuff through cords
o
Rotate 90 degrees depending on side
o
Pass tracheal cuff beyond glottis until resistance felt
o
Depth: 12 + (patient height / 10) @ teeth
•
Confirmation:
o
Three-step auscultation: sufficient for L DLTs
▪
Inflate tracheal cuff (high vol, low pressure): auscultate to confirm bilateral air entry
▪
Clamp tracheal limb, inflate bronchial lumen (low vol, high pressure), ventilate, auscultate
▪
Release tracheal clamp, and ventilate – confirm resumption of bilateral ventilation
o
Fibreoptic scope: essential for R DLTs
▪
Tracheal lumen: visualise carina
▪
Endobronchial lumen: blue cuff in bronchus
▪
Check murphy’s eye is aligned with RUL bronchus (R DLT only)
Issues with DLTs:
•
Malposition: overinflated cuff, movement with neck extension, surgical manipulation
•
Airway trauma: may rupture membranous airway → airleaks, subcut emphysema, massive bleeding
•
Tension pneumothorax
Lung Isolation with DLT
Prior to lung isolation:
•
Pre-oxygenation 100% FiO2 to de-nitrogenatate
•
Check 2 things on ventilator:
o
Peak airway pressure: expected post-OLV peak pressure ~5cmH2O higher
o
Check leak
Lung isolation:
•
Clamp appropriate tube and allow passive deflation via circuit disconnection
o
If required later can use low suction
•
Check Paw
•
Check leak (should still be zero) – if not:
o
Further inflate bronchial cuff
o
Re-check with bronch
Causes of failed lung collapse: misplaced airway, pleural adhesions, gas trapping, poor lung elasticity, airway compression

title: Double Lumen Tubes
text:
Special scenarios:
•
Tracheostomy: DLT or BB through stoma, DL trache tubes exist, orotracheal intubation + stoma coverage
•
Anticipated difficult airway: awake SLT + bronchial blocker (airway exchange catheter + DLT is an option but riskier)
•
Requirement for post-op ventilation: (risk of trauma + upper airway oedema)
o
Short procedure: DLT → SLT via airway exchange catheter
o
Long procedure: deflate endobronchial cuff and ventilate through tracheal lumen
Isolation Technique
Advantages
Disadvantages
Double Lumen Tube
•
Quick
•
Can suction + bronch isolated lung
•
CPAP to operated lung
•
Either lung ventilation
•
Can confirm without scope if needed
•
Limited sizes
•
Difficult in abnormal airways
•
Not ideal for post-op ventilation
•
Potential airway trauma risk
•
Risk of intra-op displacement
Bronchial Blockers
•
Easy size selection
•
Easily used with standard ETT
•
Easier placement in difficult airways
•
Selective lobar isolation is possible
•
Post-operative dual lung ventilation easy
•
Takes longer to insert than DLT
•
Must confirm with fibreoptic scope
•
Slow + incomplete lung collapse
•
Suction + bronch of isolated lung impossible
•
Difficult alternate OLV (unless Rusch EZ
Bifid)
Endobronchial Tube
•
Easiest in emergencies
•
Suction + bronch of isolated lung impossible
•
Difficult for L OLV

title: Hypoxaemia with OLV
text:
Hypoxaemia with OLV
Hypoxaemia with OLV:
•
No definition but generally accepted as sats <90% on FiO2 100% - must alert surgeons
•
Expect immediate in arterial oxygenation after starting OLV, improves as HPV increases (biphasic) – aim sats ≥90%
Immediate management: FiO2 to 100% (except previous bleomycin – however titrate FiO2 to sats >90 briefly if needed)
Likely cause depends on timing:
•
Immediately following lung isolation:
o
Likely atelectasis and de-recruitment
o
Check airway pressure & leak
o
Re-check tube position with bronch
•
Intra-op:
o
Check position of DLT / BB
o
Check cuff pressures + vent pressures
o
Optimise haemodynamics
o
Recruitment maneouvre of ventilated lung (anticipate transient worsening)
o
Treat bronchospasm (auscultate if able)
o
Therapeutic suctioning
o
Adjust PEEP to ventilated lung (if EEP > set PEEP + obstructive trace consider gas trapping → passive
expiration)
o
Oxygen insufflation + 1-5cmH2O to non-ventilated lung
o
Intermittent reinflation of non-ventilated lung (HPV reflex improves with repeated hypoxic exposure)
o
Clamp non-ventilated lung
o
Severe sudden desaturation → two-lung ventilation + consider:
▪
Major haemorrhage (discuss with surgeon, Hb)
▪
Tension pneumothorax (turn supine, drain)
▪
Gas embolism (head down, inotropic support)
▪
Acute right heart failure (TOE, correct resp acidosis)
Lung re-expansion:
•
Sustained inflation at low pressure i.e. 20-30cmH2O for 10 – 15s
•
Repeat as necessary
Post-op:
•
LPV
•
High FiO2 → VILI (lowest FiO2 for sats 90-94%)
Lateral decubitus position:
•
Compliance:
o
Awake: dependent lung > non-dependent lung
o
Anaesthetised: non-dependent lung > dependent lung → ventilation of non-dependent lung
 OLV in lateral decubitus V:Q matching (further aided by HPV)

title: Anterior Mediastinal Masses
text:
Anterior Mediastinal Masses
Anatomy: between two pleural cavities, from thoracic inlet → diaphragm
Superior and inferior divided by thoracic plane (imaginary line from sternal angle to T4 vertebrae)
4Ts:
•
Thymoma
•
Thyroid
•
Teratoma
•
Terrible lymphoma
Pre-op:
•
History:
o
Mass effect: ?positional effect - must know position of greatest comfort
▪
Airway: stridor, dyspnoea, SOB
▪
Vasculature: pre-syncope / syncope
o
Other 4Ms: metabolic (paraneoplastic syndromes, medication (chemo), mets)
•
Exam:
o
Airway: ability to lie flat, stridor, wheeze, sitting + lying sats
o
Vascular obstruction: Pemberton’s, facial plethora – do BP sitting + lying
•
Ix:
o
Routine bloods, G&H, TFTs
o
CT Imaging: airway diameter <50%, carina involvement, vascular obstruction
o
Upright + supine PFTs: usually insp + exp curves, a disprop in max exp flow consider tracheomalacia
o
High risk: supine PEFR <40%
•
Candidate for salvage VV-ECMO
•
Avoid pre-med if concerns for tracheal obstruction
•
Refer: CTSx, ICU – consider location
Resection: robotic (requires CO2 insufflation – may preload), VATS,
open / sternotomy
Intra-op:
•
Monitoring:
o
Right arm: sats probe (will alert to brachiocephalic compression)
o
Left arm: art line (will give true BP reading even if brachiocephalic compression)
•
Venous access LL (if bleeding from vessels draining into SVC)
•
Surgeons present / scrubbed on induction
▪
Rescue:
•
Obstruction above carina: rigid bronch
•
Carinal involvement: VV ECMO
+/- sternotomy
•
Surgical method:
o
Sternotomy: SLT – consider spont vent induction, pass ETT beyond obstruction prior to paralysing
o
Thoracotomy: DLT → OLV (DLT requires paralysis)
o
Risk of non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema with airway obstruction
•
Blood management
•
Regional:
o
PVB by surgeons
o
SA block: chest drain
Post-op: HDU, drain management, FASTHUGS, APS
•
Pre-op tracheal diameter <50% - high risk tracheomalacia – keep reintubation equipment at bedside
Diagnostic Procedure
•
Local +/- sedation
•
EBUS + needle: spont vent LMA
•
Mediastinoscopy: 3cm incision at suprasternal notch - spont vent LMA – rigid bronch rescue
o
CI: previous procedure (scarring), prev radiation, thoracic aneurysm, SVC syndrome, severe tracheal deviation
o
Must be prepared for bleeding + thoracotomy
Paraneoplastic syndromes:
•
Endocrine: hyper-PTH, cushing’s, SIADH, carcinoid
•
Neuromuscular: MG, Eaton-lambert, neuropathy
•
Haem: anaemia, plt, thrombosis
•
Other: amyloidosis, nephrotic

title: Lung Resection
text:
Lung Resection
Assessment domains/risk:
•
Operative mortality: THORASCORE – not very accurate
•
Peri-op myocardial events:
o
RCRI 6 Cs: refer to cardiology if ≥3
o
TTE: ?pulmonary hypertension (esp if pneumonectomy)
•
Risk of post-op dyspnoea: must do within last 6-12mo
o
Predicted post-op FEV1: pre-op FEV1 x remaining % lung segments
▪
>40% low risk, 30 – 40% mod, <30% high risk
•
VQ scan: consider for pneumoectomies or if ppoFEV1 <40%
o
DLCO
o
Functional assessment
▪
Shuttle walk test:
•
>400m = VO2 >15mL/kg/min
•
<400m → refer for CPET
4% SpO2 during exercise = risk
▪
CPET:
•
VO2 max >20mL/kg/min – safe for pneumonectomy
•
VO2 <10mL/kg/min contra-indicated – high risk of
dyspnoea
•
+ Cancer staging: PET-CT
•
Treatment side effects i.e. chemo and radiotherapy
NOTE: all guidelines differ on exact cut offs – broadly all follow the 3-legged stool
•
Lung mechanics: FEV1
•
Pulmonary parenchymal function: DLCO
•
Cardiopulmonary reserve: VO2 max
Risk stratification:
•
Low risk: <1% mortality
o
Low cardiac risk
o
FEV1 / DLCO >80%
o
VO2 max >20mL/kg/min
•
Intermediate risk: 2-9% mortality
o
Predicted post-op FEV1 and DLCO >30%
o
OR ≥1 is <30% but predicted post-op VO2 is >10mL/kg/min (or >35%)
•
High risk: mortality >10%
o
Predicted post-op VO2 is <10mL/kg/min (or <35%)

title: Lung Resection
text:
Operation
Indication
Surgical Technique
Anaesthetic
Considerations
Pneumonectomy
•
Bronchial carcinoma (85% NSCLC) not
amenable to sleeve lobectomy
•
Uncontrollable haemorrhage
Thoracotomy in lateral decubitus
See
pneumonectomy
Sleeve lobectomy
•
Locally advanced carcinoma involving the
main bronchus with sufficient tissue for
re-anastomosis (must achieve complete
excision)
Thoracotomy in lateral decubitus
– more challenging surgically
than pneumonectomy due to
reconstruction
Lobectomy
•
Primary lung cancer with curative intent
Take entire blood supply to lobe
+ bronchus + LNs
Segmentectomy
