•
Lung nodule (TB etc)
•
Primary lung cancer with
cardiopulmonary reserve (i.e.
parenchymal preservation)
•
Bronchiectasis
•
Rarely for lung metastases – only if
wedge resection not suitable
More challenging surgically than
lobectomy – no defined fissures
Bronchus and blood supply to
segment ligated → systemic
injection if ICG → resection of un-
dyed portion
Wedge resection
•
Metastatic nodule
•
Focal lung disease
Resection of diseased portion of
lung
Lateral decubitus: hypotension common in and out of position.
Head-to-toe check:
•
Dependent eye
•
Dependent ear pinna
•
Cervical spine (in line with thoracic spine)
•
Dependent arm (compression brachial plexus + circ)
•
Non-dependent arm (stretch brachial plexus + circ)
•
Bilateral suprascapular n
•
Dependent leg (peroneal n + circ)
•
Non-dependent leg sciatic nerve (avoid tight strapping)
Monitoring:
•
Art line: non-dependent arm – will be accurate, not altered by compression
•
Sats probe: dependent arm – will alert to decreased perfusion from lateral decubitus positioning

title: Pneumonectomy
text:
Pneumonectomy
Indications:
•
Bronchial carcinoma (85% NSCLC) – must be unsuitable for sleeve resection
•
Uncontrolled haemorrhage
CI: significant pulmonary hypertension
Mortality:
•
Right > left (+ bronchopleural fistula rate)
•
1 year mortality 25% (strongly  age - ability of RV to tolerate PVR)
Pre-op:
•
As per lung resection assessment
•
Sleeve lobectomy must be ruled out as possible option
•
4M’s of cancer
•
Modifiable RFs: smoking, infection, nutrition, pulmonary rehabilitation,
exercise
Intra-op:
•
Routine monitoring + art line, CVC, temp, IDC, ABG monitoring +/- TOE
•
Volatile or TIVA – TIVA easier for rigid bronch
•
Initial rigid bronch (confirms sufficient length free of tumour to proceed)
•
DLT: bronchial lumen for side not being resected → lung isolation
•
Position: lateral with table break
•
OLV targets: sats 94-98, peak pressure <35, plateau pressure <25, PEEP 5 – 8, Vt 6mL/kg, normal CO2
o
OLV prior to thoracotomy
o
TEST OLV prior to starting resection – must have good ventilation / O2
•
Posterolateral thoracotomy (5th intercostal space)
•
Test clamp of ipsilateral PA (if cardiac collapse / CVP rise ++ predicts post-op cardiac complications)
•
Vessel ligation + bronchus stapled / cut
•
Leak test to confirm stump patency
•
Analgesia: TEA / paravertebral block (by surgeons under vision)
•
Fluid:
o
Restrictive i.e. <20mL/kg in first 24hr to reduce risk of pulmonary oedema
o
UO aim 0.5mL/kg/hr – not more
•
Thoracostomy tube + closure
Post-op: ICU
•
Early extubation if possible
•
Respiratory physiotherapy
•
Single chamber chest drain without suction
Complications:
•
Haemorrhage
•
Post-pneumonectomy pulmonary oedema (50% mortality)
•
Secretions
•
Arrhythmia: 40% new AF
•
Cardiac herniation (mortality 50%)
•
Bronchopleural fistula (up to 20%): R > L SSx cough, continuous air leak, empyema, air fluid levels
Following pneumonectomy: volume of hemithorax 2’ mediastinal shift, elevation of diaphragm, contraction of chest wall,
replacement of air with pleural fluid +/- neovascularisation in younger patients
Cardiac Herniation
R > L. Usually within 24 hours post-op. SSx hypotension, shock, cyanosis.
Right side worse due to torsion of the heart → acute SVC syndrome.
Management: full lateral position with operated side up, intubation with SLT + pressors and inotropes to support whilst
exploration takes place
Type of pneumonectomy:
•
Standard: removal of affected lung only,
bronchial stump closed + vessels ligated
•
Intrapericardial pneumonectomy: if main
PA involved, or division close to atrium
•
Extrapleural pneumonectomy: radical –
lung, ipsilateral pleura, hemidiaphragm,
hemipericardium
•
Completion pneumonectomy: remaining
tissue from prior resection

title: VATS/Robotic Assisted Lung Resection Surgery
text:
VATS/Robotic Assisted Lung Resection Surgery
Benefits cf open:
•
Morbidity/mortality
•
LOS
•
Improved functional recovery (VIOLET trial)
Robotic versus VATS: overall very comparable results
•
RATS has significantly longer operating time
•
VATS has blood loss
•
No significant difference:
o
Duration of chest tubes
o
LOS
o
Low- and high-grade complications
o
Readmissions
o
30-day mortality
Indications:
•
Diagnostic: biopsy, thoracocentesis, staging
•
Therapeutic:
o
Pleural: pleurodesis, decortication
o
Parenchymal: wedge resection, segmentectomy, lobectomy, bullae resection, volume reduction
o
Mediastinal: tumour, thymectomy, chylothorax, pericardial window
o
Oesophageal: vagotomy, myotomy
o
Sympathectomy
CI:
•
Surgical: adhesions, extensive disease, anatomical location, tumour >6cm
•
Anaesthetic: CI to OLV
Intra-op for both:
•
TIVA > volatile (unplanned admission to ICU)
•
Position: lateral + table break (padding or bean bag)
•
Lung isolation + OLV (DLT or BB) – L side less likely to dislodge
•
Regional block + LA by surgeons
Robotic surgery considerations:
•
Robotic surgery requires CO2 insufflation (cf VATS open to air) – this is essentially a tension pneumothorax
o
Must watch for CVS effects + ETCO2: ensure inflation pressure ~8cmH2O (if insufflation > RA pressure will
lose CO)
•
Emergency: requires safe removal of robot + lead surgeon to scrub (can cause delay to management)

title: Lung Volume Reduction Surgery
text:
Lung Volume Reduction Surgery
Palliative procedure for severe COPD caused by emphysema – excision of emphysematous lung tissue
Aim: improvement of elastic recoil of remaining lung → hyperinflation → improved resp muscle efficiency and reduced
intrathoracic pressure improving LV filling
LVRS not shown to improve survival cf maximum medical therapy, but can improve QoL, dyspnoea, exercise tolerance
NETT trial: FEV1 or DLCO <20% predicted pre-op – unacceptably high peri-op mortality rate
Method: median sternotomy, thoracotomy or VATS (usually VATS)
Pre-op:
•
Quantify risk and ensure FEV1 or DLCO not <20%
•
No pre-med
Intra-op:
•
Routine + art line
•
DLT
•
Monitor for airway pressures/hypotension – high risk of pneumothorax with PPV, avoid gas trapping
•
Permissive hypercapnia unless pH <7.2 – may need intermittent 2-lung ventilation
•
Regional anaesthesia + post-op extubation
Bronchoscopic LVRS
Aims to achieve similar effect as LVRS but with less morbidity
Methods:
•
One-way endobronchial valves
•
Biologic sealants
•
Thermal ablation of bronchi
•
Bronchial blockers
Anaesthetic: GA or sedation
•
Flexi bronch amenable to sedation
•
Rigid bronch or thermal ablation – GA

title: Post-Thoracotomy Pain
text:
Post-Thoracotomy Pain
65% of patients post-thoracotomy (2nd only to amputation)
Physiology:
•
Nociceptive: T4 – T10 somatic, vagal/phrenic visceral
•
Neuropathic
•
Referred: i.e. ipsilateral shoulder
Reducing risk of chronic pain:
•
Thoracic epidural and paravertebral block are comparable
•
VATS > open
Pre-op / intra-op:
•
Paravertebral block: preferred, less SE + safety profile, chest infection, confusion, hypotension, N&V / itching,
urinary retention
•
Thoracic epidural (T5/T6)
•
Spinal morphine (4.5mcg/kg)
•
Operative technique: VATS > open, muscle sparing
Post-op:
•
Paracetamol
•
NSAIDs: unless CI, or pleurodesis
•
IV PCA
•
Thoracic epidural or paravertebral catheter for 2-3 days
•
Topical LA for drain removal
•
Suprascapular n. block for shoulder tip pain
Chronic pain management:
•
Pharmacological: NSAIDs, amitriptyline, gabapentin, opioids, ketamine
•
Non-pharmacological: TENS, spinal cord stimulator

title: Bronchopleural Fistula
text:
Bronchopleural Fistula
Sinus tract between main stem, lobar or segmental bronchus + pleural space
Many risk factors, highest post-op risk after pneumonectomy or R lower lobectomy 2’:
•
Ischaemic necrosis
•
Infection
SSx: dyspnoea, hypotension, subcut emphysema, cough +/- expectorated purulent pleural fluid, tracheal or mediastinal shift,
persistent air leak
Evaluation:
•
Bronchography + methylene blue
•
Bronchoscopic exploration
If cause not due to lung resection e.g. malignancy or infection → bronchoscopic treatment
Pre-op:
•
Pleural drainage: affected side dependent – thoracostomy + drain
o
Send: FBC, pH, protein, LDH, glucose, cytology, TGs, gram stain, culture
Intra-op:
•
Meticulous pre-oxygenation
•
Induction: RSI with small VT and low airway pressures until lung isolation confirmed
•
VATS → muscle flap
o
Other options: decort, complete pneumonectomy
•
Aim to extubate if able – ongoing PPV can reduce healing
o
If remaining ventilated: minimal PEEP, low mean airway pressures
Other options:
•
Awake intubation: patient likely already hypoxaemic
•
Spont vent: risk of aspiration into healthy lung, technically difficult with DLT

title: Tracheobronchial Mass
text:
Tracheobronchial Mass
Airway Stenting
Indications for stenting:
•
Malignancy: (adenocarcinoma, carcinoid, adjacent, mets)
o
4Ms
•
Non-cancer: consider tracheal resection
o
Strictures
o
Stenosis
o
Tracheomalacia
Complications:
•
Early: dental damage, airway damage + bleeding, barotrauma, airway obstruction
•
Jet vent: gas embolism, tension pneumothorax, tension pneumomediastinum, subcut emphysema
•
Late: erosion, stent migration, bacterial infection, granuloma +/- stenosis, fistula
Pre-op:
•
ASSESS:
o
Medical comorbidities
▪
Functional assessment
o
Tracheobronchial lesion:
▪
Mass effect: ?positional effect - must know position of greatest comfort
•
Airway: stridor, dyspnoea, SOB
•
Vasculature: pre-syncope / syncope
▪
Metabolic: paraneoplastic syndromes
▪
Medication, mets
o
Exam:
▪
Ability to lie flat, stridor, wheeze, sitting + lying sats
▪
Vascular obstruction: Pemberton’s, facial plethora
•
BP sitting + lying
o
Ix:
▪
Routine bloods, ECG
▪
TTE: ?pulmonary hypertension +/- RH dysfunction (apnoeic O2 + jet vent)
▪
CT Imaging: airway diameter <50%, carina involvement (risk), vascular obstruction
▪
Upright + supine PFTs: uusually insp + exp curves, a disproportionate in max exp flow consider
tracheomalacia
▪
High risk: supine PEFR <40%
•
MANAGE:
o
ACD documented
o
Optimise where able
•
REFER/DISCUSS: ENT + cardiothoracics + ICU + ECMO team
o
High risk: tertiary centre
o
Type of stent / need for GA
▪
Flexible bronch versus rigid bronch
o
?Need for laser
o
Rescue interventions - candidate for salvage VV-ECMO?
o
Limits of care ?palliative procedure
Intra-op:
•
Topicalization
•
Anaesthetic: TIVA +/- NMBA
•
Procedure:
o
Flexi bronch: spont vent HFNP +/- LMA
o
Rigid bronch: HFNP + jet ventilation
Post-op:
•
HDU

title: General Surgery
text:
General Surgery
RELIEF trial: elective major abdo surgery, no difference in disability free survival between liberal and restrictive fluid strategies,
AKI in restrictive group
Laparotomy
Pre-op:
•
Resus +++
•
ACS-NSQIP / NELA
•
Aspiration risk
•
REFER: ICU
Intra-op:
•
Suction NGT
•
Monitoring: 5-lead, art line, CVC, UO
•
RSI
•
Blood management
•
Goal directed fluid therapy
Post-op:
•
ERAS / FASTHUGS

title: Splenectomy
text:
Splenectomy
Coeliac → splenic a. → spleen → splenic v. → SMV → PV
Function:
•
Secondary lymphoid (white pulp): process + present antigens, adaptive immunity
•
Haematological (red pulp): RBC destruction + haem lifecycle, phagocytosis, haematopoeisis
•
Storage: 250mL RBC, 30% platelets
Disorders:
•
Accessory spleen 10%
•
Splenic artery aneurysm (may rupture in pregnancy)
•
Splenomegaly: infection, cancer, congestive, functional, immune, storage
•
Hyposplenism: functional (EtOH, sickle cell, BMT, coeliac, IBD), surgical/trauma
o
Presentation: encapsulated organism infection (S pneumoniae, N meningitides, I influenzae)
o
Blood film: acanthocytes, target cells, Howell-Jolly bodies
•
Splenic infarct: haematological, embolic, traumatic
•
Trauma: grades 1 – 5
Splenectomy indications:
•
Trauma
•
Haematological: ITP, hereditary spherocytosis, thalassemia, Hodgkin’s disease, leukaemia, Felty syndrome (RA)
Pre-op:
•
Cancer 4Ms
•
Steroids
•
Vaccination: 2 weeks pre-op (2 weeks post-op if emergency)
•
Pre-op splenic artery embolisation
•
ITP: platelets >20, IVIg, steroids
•
Surgical approach: laparoscopic v open
•
REFER: haematology
Intra-op:
•
Monitoring: art line, temp
•
Neuraxial safe: platelet >100 (cf pregnancy >70 – procoagulant)
•
Prevent sickling: normal O2
•
Stress dose steroids
•
Blood: irradiated products
•
Blood management bundle
Post-op:
•
Penicillin prophylaxis
•
Vaccination at 2 weeks if emergency
•
Monitor for complications: PV thrombosis, VTE, overwhelming sepsis

title: Oesophagectomy
text:
Oesophagectomy
Indications: adenocarcinoma 80%, SCC 20%
Pre-op:
•
Functional, RCRI
•
Cancer 4Ms
o
Wait several weeks after neo-
adjuvant chemo
o
5FU (bone marrow
suppression), cisplatin
(cardiotoxic, nephrotoxic, hepatotoxic)
•
Frailty
•
Nutrition
•
Anaemia
•
Modifiable RFs
•
Planned surgical approach:
o
Thoracotomy: Ivor-Lewis, Mckeown, trans-diaphragmatic, minimally invasive
o
No thoracotomy: trans-hiatal
•
Surgical risk (mortality 5%, morbidity 30%)
•
REFER: ICU
Intra-op:
•
Pre-med: PPI, sodium citrate
•
Monitoring: art line, CVC, temp, UO, BIS
o
Mediastinal manipulation → cardiac instability
•
RSI + DLT if thoracotomy (+/- lateral decubitus)
•
Goal directed fluid (too much – anastomotic oedema, too little – anastomotic ischaemia)
•
Analgesia: TEA, PVB, ESP
•
Long operation: pressure care
Post-op:
•
Early extubation
•
CPAP / BiPAP CI
•
ERAS + FASTHUGS - early enteral feeding
•
APS
Complications: resp (50%), RLN palsy, anastomotic leak, MACE, AF, sepsis

title: Gastrectomy
text:
Gastrectomy
Indication: gastric ca.
RFs: age, genetic, H pylori, smoking, previous gastric surgery, pernicious anaemia, low SES
Pre-op:
•
Staging laparoscopy + CT
•
Cancer 4Ms:
o
5FU (bone marrow suppression), cisplatin (cardiotoxic, nephrotoxic, hepatotoxic) + epirubacin
•
Frailty
•
Nutrition
•
Anaemia
•
Modifiable RFs
•
GORD
•
MDT + refer ICU
Intra-op:
•
RSI + ETT
•
TEA
Post-op:
•
ICU / HDU
•
Complications
o
Anastomotic leak
o
Malabsorption

title: Liver Resection
text:
Liver Resection
Indications: benign mass (haemangioma, adenoma) and malignant masses (primary or mets)
Anatomy:
•
8 functional segments – each consist of a portal triad
•
Regenerates – starts within 24 hrs of resection, original size by 6mo (functional
recovery 2-3 weeks)
•
Safe liver remnant:
o
20% in healthy liver
o
40% in cirrhosis
CI:
•
Child Pugh C
•
Child Pugh B with remnant <40%
•
NASH with remnant <30%
Complications - 40% (20% major): bile leak, pulmonary, ascites, thrombotic, post-op liver failure, mortality 1-3%
Pre-op:
•
As for liver disease
•
Future remnant:
o
Assess size: CT/MRI
o
Portal vein embolisation → remnant hypertrophy
•
Cancer 4Ms
o
Chemo: wait 4-6 weeks, risk of cardiotoxicity
•
Modifiable risk: nutrition, anaemia
•
Optimise:
o
Correct coagulopathy
o
Nutrition
o
Diabetes (operative mortality higher)
•
X-match 4 units
•
Risk score: Child Pugh, MELD, VOCAL-PENN
•
Minimise fasting + carb load
•
MDT
•
Avoid long-acting pre-med
Intra-op:
•
Pringle manoeuvre: 10-20 mins → 5 mins reperfusion, ischaemia + induces ischaemic preconditioning
•
Blood management bundle
o
+ aim CVP <5mmHg: main source of bleeding is backflow from valveless hepatic veins
▪
bleeding + transfusion but no difference in outcomes
▪
Position: steep head up + arms out (risk of VAE)
▪
intrathoracic pressure
▪
IVF until parenchymal resection complete
•
Analgesia: TEA or spinal with morphine + PCA
Post-op:
•
Early mobilisation
•
Analgesia + APS
•
PONV
•
ERAS
Post-op Liver Failure:
•
RFs: diabetes, obesity, metabolic syndrome, malnutrition, cholangitis, age >65
•
Surgical: blood loss >1200mL, transfusion, associated resection, FLR <20%, extended liver resection (>50%), operation
time >240min, other post op complications
•
Pre-op liver dysfunction
Management same as ALF.
Pringle manoeuvre:
•
Portal vein
•
Hepatic artery
•
Bile duct
•
“Hepatoduodenal ligament”
•
Effect:
o
SVR 20-30%
o
CO 10%

title: Nephrectomy
text:
Nephrectomy
Indications: live donor transplant, tumour (RCC, TCC, Wilms), trauma, non-functioning chronically infected
Pre-op:
•
Cancer: 4Ms
o
RCC: IVC invasion
•
Renal function + complications of disease (HTN, anaemia, electrolyes)
•
Surgery: partial / total / radical, laparoscopic v open
•
Functional capacity + RCRI
•
Ix:
o
Isotope renography: predicted post-op renal fx
o
CT/MRI: caval infiltration
▪
Heparin
▪
Arterial embolisation
▪
MDT: vascular, CTSx, UGI
▪
CPB
Intra-op:
•
Position: lateral w/ table break (preload, FRC)
•
Pressure care
•
Monitoring: 5-lead, art line, CVC, temp, UO
•
Blood management bundle + cell salvage
•
TOE if IVC disease
•
Local renal hypothermia (if WIT estimated >30mins)
•
Regional: TEA, PVB, ESP
•
Deep neuromuscular blockade: post-op pain
Post-op:
•
Monitor EUC

title: Prostatectomy
text:
Prostatectomy
Open or robotic.
•
Both: paracetamol, NSAIDs, opioid rescue
•
Open: TEA, IV lignocaine, LA wound infiltration
•
Robot: TAP blocks
Robotic Prostatectomy
Benefits: smaller incision, pain, blood loss / transfusion, faster recovery, shorter LOS
Risks: vision loss, AKI, atelectasis, air embolism, retroperionteal haematoma, aspiration / regurg, raised ICP, endobronchial
intubation, insidious major haemorrhage, acid injury to eyes, pressure area
No difference:
•
Cancer outcome
•
Incontinence
•
Sexual function
Anaesthetic robotic considerations:
•
Poor access to patient
•
Complete immobility
•
Pneumoperitoneum
•
Steep trendelenberg → ICP, IOP
facial oedema, orbital oedema,
regurg
•
Ventilation: PCV > VCV – greater
dynamic compliance
Pre-op:
•
Assess ICP / IOP
•
Cardiorespiratory function (effects SVR, oxygen consumption, hypercapnoea, airway pressures, V/Q mismatch)
•
Emergency undocking procedure must be known to staff
Intra-op:
•
Intubation: tape (not tie)
•
Ventilation: LPV, higher PEEP, permissive hypercapnoea but beware with ICP, recruitment
•
Position + pressure care check prior to drape
o
Ensure lube + TEG secured + gauze over
o
Nerve palsy: common peroneal, brachial plexus
•
Analgesia: include spinal morphine
•
Restrict IVF until urethral anastomosis complete
•
Paralysis + NM monitoring
•
Avoid N2O
•
Extubation:
o
Upright
o
Leak test
Post-op:
•
Risk of cerebral irritation → early neuro assessment

title: TURP
text:
TURP
Innervation: bladder T11 – L2, prostate S2 – S4
Pre-op:
•
Exclude UTI
Intra-op:
•
Spinal:
o
obturator spasm
o
2.3 – 3mL bupivacaine 0.5% heavy
o
T10 dermatome required for bladder
o
Treat hypotension with vasopressor
•
Gent 2mg/kg
•
Monitor for bleeding
Post-op:
•
3-way tap
•
Complications:
o
TURP syndrome
o
Bladder spasm
▪
Ketorolac, MgSO4, benzos, buscopan
o
Haemorrhage
o
Clot retention

title: Post-TURP / Hysteroscopy Syndrome
text:
Post-TURP / Hysteroscopy Syndrome
Issues:
•
Fluid overload (even with crystalloid irrigation)
•
Hyponatraemia (with hyponatraemic solutions)
Solutions used:
•
Bipolar: normal saline / ringer’s lactate
•
With monopolar:
o
1.5% glycine (200mOsm/kg)
o
3% sorbitol (165 mOsm/kg)
o
5% mannitol (275 mOsm/kg i.e. isotonic)
Incidence:
•
TURP 1%
•
Hysteroscopy 1%
RFs:
•
Volume used: 1000mL glycine → serum Na by 10mM
•
Female (i.e. hysteroscopy > TURP)
•
Irrigation pressure
•
Perforation
•
Operative time >1hr
•
Low venous pressure
•
Blood loss
Prevention:
•
Avoid non-conducting fluids
•
Low infusion pressures
•
Limit duration of surgery to <1 hr
•
Monitor fluid absorbed and stop at pre-determined threshold:
o
Hysteroscopy 100-1500mL
o
TURP 2000mL
o
Non-conducting fluid 2500mL
Presentation:
•
SSx: confusion, nausea, seizures, visual, headache
•
Ix:
o
Na, serum osmols
o
ECG: prolonged QRS
Management:
•
Asymptomatic: monitor
•
Symptomatic:
o
Hypertonic saline 3% 100mL
▪
Repeat q10 mins until symptoms improve
o
Diuretics
o
Stop surgery if intra-op
o
Treat complications:
▪
Seizures: mgso4
▪
Bradycardia
▪
Fluid overload
o
HDU

title: Bariatric Surgery
text:
Bariatric Surgery
Indications:
•
BMI ≥40 without comorbidities
•
BMI ≥35 with ≥1 comorbidity
o
Comorbidities: T2DM, OSA / OHS, HTN, hyperlipidaemia, NAFLD, NASH, idiopathic intracranial hypertension,
GORD, asthma, venous stasis, severe urinary incontinence, arthritis, impaired QoL, disqualifications from other
surgery due to obesity
•
BMI ≥30 with major comorbidity
o
Uncontrollable diabetes
o
Metabolic syndrome
All appropriate non-surgical measures have failed for ≥6mo
Patient otherwise fit for anaesthesia
CI:
•
Untreated eating disorders, major depression / psychosis
•
Current D&A use
•
Severe cardiac disease
•
Severe coagulopathy
•
Inability to comply with diet / nutrient replacement post-op
•
Inflammatory GIT disorders
•
Liver disease: cirrhosis, portal HTN
Outcomes:
•
long term weight loss than non-surgical
•
metabolic effects: T2DM, HTN, lipids, CVS risk
•
Cancer: hormone related ca, colorectal ca, skin cancer
•
Mortality: all cause mortality, CVS mortalit
•
Morbidity: OSA / AHI, GORD, function, QoL, PCOS,
GFR, urinary incontinence, sexual health, NAFLD
MOA:
•
Malabsorption
•
Restriction
•
Neurohormonal modification: ghrelin
Complications:
•
Intra-op: injury to organs
•
Post-op: routine +
o
Anastomotic leak (persistent tachycardia)
•
Late complications:
o
Gastric remnant distension
o
Stenosis
o
Ulcers
o
Hernia
o
Short bowel syndrome: nutrient deficiency
o
Fistula
o
Dumping syndrome: rapid transit into small bowel
o
GORD

title: Bariatric Surgery
text:
Pre-op:
•
Obesity severity:
o
Central v peripheral
o
BMI
o
Airway
•
Comorbidities: STOP BANG – OSA / OHS, GORD, resp, diabetes, HTN
•
Indicated Ix
•
Obesity Surgery – Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS)
•
Optimise:
o
OSA: 6/52 CPAP
o
Diet: 2 - 4 weeks of calorie restriction (liver shrinking diet)
o
Diabetes control
Intra-op:
•
Allow to walk to table
•
OT – weight appropriate
•
Equipment: straps, hover mat, table extensions
•
Pre-oxygenation:
•
Intubation:
o
Pre-oxygenation with CPAP, ETO2 >90%
o
RSI: aspiration risk, time to intubation
o
HFNP, VL, adjuncts, difficult airway trolley
•
Ventilation: LPV, recruitment
•
Drugs:
o
LBW: propofol induction, opioids, NMBA, paracetamol, LA
o
ABW: propofol infusion, neostigmine, sugammadex, antibiotics
o
TBW: sux, LMWH, dantrolene
•
Positioning + pressure sores
Post-op:
•
ICU if OS-MRS 4 - 5

title: Breast Surgery
text:
Breast Surgery
Types:
•
Wide local excision
•
Mastectomy: radical, simple, nipple or skin sparing
•
Sentinel LN biopsy: patent blue dye, methylene blue (largely replaced axillary LN dissection)
o
Risk of anaphylaxis
•
Axillary dissection
•
Reconstruction: long procedures + pain ++
o
TRAM: pedicle flap
o
Lat dorsi: pedicle flap
o
DIEP: free flap
Pre-op:
•
Cancer 4Ms:
o
Cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin: cardiotoxicity, myelosuppression → wait 6/52
o
Other treatment: radioTx, hormonal therapy (cardiotoxic, risk VTE)
•
Pre-med
Intra-op:
•
Access contralateral side
•
Monitoring: standard ANZCA
•
Airway: LMA or ETT
•
Positioning: supine, arm out (avoid brachial plexus injury), sit test at end
•
High risk PONV
•
Flap perfusion (see flap notes)
Regional:
•
PVB: T1-T5 → spreads 3 dermatomes
o
pain in first 72 hours
o
CPSP at 6mo
•
TEA
•
PECS:
o
I: medial + lateral pectoral nerves
o
II: lateral branch of intercostal nerve + intercostobrachial + long thoracic (covers wider area + axillae)
▪
May deliver longer analgesia than PVB – consider adding, includes long thoracic not covered by PVB
•
SA
ESP not recommended – lack of data
Recurrence:
•
Sevo + opioid versus TIVA + PVB: no difference in recurrence, chronic pain, incisional pain
APSME:
Chronic post-surgical pain:
•
PVB
•
IV lignocaine + LA infiltration
PVB:
•
pain for 48 hours
•
PONV
•
CPSP at 3, 6, and 12 mo
PECS block:
•
PECS I v placebo: no benefit
•
PECS II: pain, opioid requirement, mobilisation, satisfaction
IV lignocaine intra-op + up to 2hr post-op:
•
No improvement in pain scores up to 72 hours
•
acute opioid requirement
•
CPSP at 3 – 6 mo

title: Post-Mastectomy Pain Syndrome
text:
Post-Mastectomy Pain Syndrome
30%.
RFs: young, high post-op pain score, major reconstruction, psychological
Prevention:
•
PVB
•
IV lignocaine
•
Venlafaxine 10 days pre-op
•
Memantine 2 weeks pre- + post-
•
Gabapentin
Treatment:
•
Amitriptyline
•
Venlafaxine
•
Topical capsaicin
•
Fat grafting

title: Obstetric Anaesthesia
text:
Obstetric Anaesthesia
High Risk Referral
Indications:
•
Anaesthetic
•
Obstetric
•
Major systems disease
RANZCOG 6 tier system: simple
•
Level 6: all care regardless of risk
•
Level 5: care beyond 32/40 weeks
o
Would not look after major placental disease,
triplets or more, complex MDT
•
Level 4: 34/40+ with no other risk factors (obs +
paeds + anaesthetics 24 hours, usually supported by level 3
neonatal service)
o
Would not look after major placental disease or
multiple gestations
•
Level 3: midwives, GP or specialist obs, no 24
hour access to OT and pathology services
o
Would not look after: planned preterm birth, C-
section for placenta praevia, vaginal birth for
multiple pregnancy, other complex births
•
Level 2: midwives, GP obstetrician
o
Would not look after: pre- or post- labour,
induction or augmentation of labour, planned C-
section, instrumental birth, care requiring CTG
•
Level 1: antenatal / postnatal care only

title: Molar Pregnancy
text:
Molar Pregnancy
1/200-1000 pregnancies.
Gestational trophoblastic disease. No foetus. Pre-malignant.
Types:
•
Complete: absent foetal / embryonic tissue
•
Partial: some foetal / embryonic tissue
Presentation:
•
bHCG
•
Ovarian enlargement
•
Hyperemesis
•
Early PET
•
Hyperthyroidism (induced by molar pregnancy)
•
Vaginal bleeding
Ix: bHCG, US, group + antibody screen
Rx: surgical evacuation (promptly, in case malignant) +/- hysterectomy
Anaesthetic management:
•
Pre-op:
o
Optimise:
▪
Thyroid dz (ECG +/- beta blockade)
▪
G&H
▪
Manage pre-eclampsia
•
Intra-op:
o
D+C + prepare for bleeding
o
Oxytocin after evacuation to risk trophoblastic pulmonary embolization (supportive care)
•
Post-op:
o
Counselling (risk in future pregnancies 1/70)
o
Monitor for bleeding
o
Manage PET
o
Monitor resolution of bHCG

title: Miscarriage
text:
Miscarriage
Pregnancy loss <20/40 weeks gestation.
Assessment: gestation, presence of bleeding, GORD, hyperemesis
Complications: bleeding, infection / sepsis, DIC
Anaesthetic management:
•
Pre-op:
o
Resus
o
Anti-D if indicated
o
Misoprostal 1hr prior (at discretion of obs)
o
+/- Antibiotic prophylaxis (doxycycline 400mg PO) -
•
Intra-op:
o
Airway: RSI after 12 weeks, ramped, aspiration prophylaxis
o
Maintenance: TIVA (volatile bleeding)
o
Bleeding management bundle
o
Uterotonics: minimal oxytocin-R prior to 17/40 → ergot + carboprost
o
PONV: high risk – give ≥2 agents
o
Analgesia: paracetamol, NSAIDs
Complications: retained POC, uterine atony, cervical trauma, uterine perforation, infection, intra-uterine adhesions,
alloimmunisation

title: Termination of Pregnancy
text:
Termination of Pregnancy
•
Pre-op:
o
Anti-D if indicated
o
Misoprostal 1 hour prior (at discretion of obs)
o
Antibiotic prophylaxis (doxycycline 400mg PO 1 hour prior, azithro 1g PO 1 hour prior)
•
Intra-op:
o
Airway: ETT if ≥12 weeks gestation
o
Uterotonics: minimal oxytocin-R prior to 17/40 → ergot + carboprost
o
Complications:
▪
Haemorrhage: tone, trauma (including laceration/perforation), tissue (retained), thrombus (DIC?)
•
Post-op:
o
Day surgery if stable

title: Septic Abortion
text:
Septic Abortion
Uterine infection during or shortly after a spontaneous or induced abortion – gynaecological emergency
Consider if:
•
Febrile on two occasions >24 hours after abortion or
•
Any woman of reproductive age who presents with fever, abdo pain and bleeding
Management:
•
D&C if any retained products
•
IV abx
•
Supportive management of shock

title: Ectopic Pregnancy
text:
Ectopic Pregnancy
Extrauterine pregnancy. 2-10/100,000 births.
RFs: previous ectopic, tubal surgery/pathology, IUD, IVF, OCP, previous STI/PID, smoking, age ≥40
Location: 96% fallopian tube, 3% ovarian, uterine scar, abdominal
Clinical presentation:
•
1st trimester bleeding
•
Abdominal pain
•
CV collapse
Diagnosis:
•
Extrauterine gestational sac
•
Positive bHCG with no intra-uterine pregnancy
•
Visualisation at surgery
Ix: bHCG, TVUS, diagnostic lap
Management: expectant, medical (methotrexate), surgical
Anaesthetic management:
•
Pre-op:
o
Resus + bleeding management bundle
•
Intra-op:
o
Monitoring: routine ANZCA + art line + temp
o
Induction: consider haemodynamics
▪
NMB can release tamponade – surgeons scrubbed + ready

title: GORD & Aspiration Prophylaxis
text:
GORD & Aspiration Prophylaxis
Increased risk 2’:
•
LOS tone
•
gastric emptying (labour, opioids)
•
IAP
•
Difficult airway + apnoea time
Management:
•
Non-particulate antacid: sodium citrate 30mL within 30 mins
•
Ranitidine PO 150mg 1-8 hour prior
•
Metoclopramide 10mg IV
All women in labour considered to have a full stomach

title: Rhesus Iso-Immunisation
text:
Rhesus Iso-Immunisation
Can occur following: delivery, TOP, spontaneous abortion, ectopic, martial molar, chorionic villus sampling, amniocentesis, ECV,
antepartum haemorrhage, abdominal trauma, MROP, FDIU
Consequences:
•
Haemolytic disease of newborn
•
Hydrops foetalis
•
Thrombocytopaenia / neutropaenia
•
FDIU
Screening:
•
Maternal D-typing + antibody screen @ 1st visit, 28/40, delivery **this will be positive if recently administered anti-D
→ indirect Coombs if +ve ab screen
Prevention:
•
Anti-D immunoglobulin 625iu @ 28/40, 34/40, delivery
*in the setting of a sensitising event do a Kleihauer-Betke test to determine the dose
Management:
•
Check paternal Rh-D status
•
Check foetal Rh-D status
•
Monitor maternal anti-D titre by indirect antiglobulin
•
Monitor foetal MCA peak systolic velocity (non-invasive test of foetal anaemia)
•
Check foetal Hb → intra-uterine transfusion if Hb <2 SD below mean, gestation <35/40 – otherwise deliver
Subsequent pregnancies:
•
Consider plasmaphoresis
•
IVIg
•
Intrauterine blood transfusion

title: Platelet Disorders
text:
Platelet Disorders
Affects 7-11% of pregnancies. Thrombocytopaenia: plt <150 x 109/L. Most common haematological disorder of pregnancy.
Causes:
•
Pregnancy specific: gestational, hypertensive disorder, pre-eclampsia, HELLP, fatty liver of pregnancy
•
Pregnancy related: TTP, DIC, type 2 vWD
•
Non-pregnancy related: ITP, hereditary, marrow infiltration, viral infection, hypersplenism, drugs
Management:
•
Delivery: plt >50
•
Neuraxial: plt >70
•
Can do a blood film / manual plt count to confirm count and exclude clumping (generally adds ~20%)
•
Check trend
•
Check prior to catheter removal if concerns (repeat count in a citrate or heparin tube)
If low risk pregnancy do not need to wait for FBC to place epidural.
SOAP 2021 guideline:
•
Plt count >70 okay for epidural in gestational thrombocytopaenia, ITP, HDP if no other risk factors
•
Risk assessment must also include risk of GA (airway, comorbidities, available staff/equipment) + patient preference
•
Plt count 50 – 70: risk versus benefit, risk discussion with patient and document
o
Possible spinal, not epidural
Gestational Thrombocytopaenia
75% of thrombocytopaenia. Benign, self-limiting. 2nd half of pregnancy. Usually plt >100. Underlying pathology is unlikely to be
solely gestational thrombocytopaenia if plt count <100. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. Recurs in subsequent pregnancies.
ITP
1/1000 pregnancies. Large platelets on blood film. Autoimmune 2’ IgG against plt glycoprotein → splenic sequestration.
Crosses placenta → neonatal thrombocytopaenia  avoid vacuum / caution with forceps delivery (risk to neonate)
Treat if platelets <30:
•
Steroids: improves within 5-7 days (pred 1mg/kg, dex 40mg, betamethasone)
•
IVIg: 0.5g/kg (usually transient improvement)
•
Platelet transfusion will likely be rapidly consumed
•
Target plt >50 for delivery, neuraxial aim >70 (but risks need to be weighed against benefit)
•
If bleeding: platelet transfusion + IVIg + steroids
•
Recalcitrant disease: splenectomy, rituximab, TPO-R antagonists
Thrombocytopaenia in DIC
Causes: placental abruption, sepsis, FDIU, AFE
Thrombocytopaenia in Acute Fatty Liver
Must check coags.
TTP
Plasma exchange.
Thrombocytopaenia in Pre-Eclampsia
•
Plts >100: do not need coags – do not tend to see coagulation abnormalities if plt >100. FBC within last 12 hours okay.
•
Plts <100: needs coags with plts. Results within 6 hours of neuraxial. Proceed if plt >70 + no abnormalities on coags.
•
Plt 50-70: if no coag abnormalities can consider spinal but not epidural
•
Severe HELLP: platelets drop ~60/day or ~10-12/6 hours

title: Hypertensive Disorders
text:
Hypertensive Disorders
5-10% pregnancies world-wide. Second most common cause of maternal death.
Complications: cerebral haemorrhage, pulmonary oedema, coagulopathy
Hypertension in pregnancy:
•
sBP >140mmHg or dBP >90mmHg on two occasions >4 hours apart
Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy:
•
Chronic hypertension (essential, secondary, white coat)
•
Gestational hypertension: after 20 weeks gestation, previously normotensive (nil proteinuria)
•
Pre-eclampsia
o
+/- pre-eclampsia superimposed on chronic hypertension
•
Eclampsia
Treatment of BP:
•
Must treat sBP >160 and dBP >110 – risk of cerebral haemorrhage and eclampsia
•
Treating blood pressures below this is controversial (prevents severe hypertension, but not shown to risk of pre-
eclampsia or adverse perinatal outcomes)
Rx: target ≤135/85
•
Labetalol BD / TDS: 200 – 2400mg daily
•
Nifedipine SR: 30 – 120mg daily
•
Methyldopa BD / TDS: 500-3000mg daily
•
Hydralazine QID 40 – 200mg daily
•
Prazosin
*ACEis and ARBs contraindicated
Post-partum hypertension can persist for 8/52 post-partum + lifelong risk of CVS dz – should be followed up

title: Preeclampsia
text:
Preeclampsia
3% of all pregnancies.
Definition: hypertension plus involvement of one or more other organ systems and/or the foetus
RFs:
•
Strong: hx of PET, chronic HTN, BMI >30, pre-gestational diabetes, APLS/SLE, assisted reproduction, autoimmune dz
•
Moderate: primip, primi-paternity, pregnancy interval >5y, age >40, FHx, multiple gestation, CKD
Risk prediction models:
•
sFLT1/PIGF ratio ≥38
•
PREP-S: risk of complications in early-onset PET
o
Variables: maternal age, gest age, reflexes, PMHx, Pr:Cr, urea, plt, sBP, HTN, MgSO4, sats, ALT, Cr
•
fullPIERS: predicts adverse outcomes within 48 hours
o
Variables: gest age, chest pain/SOB, Cr, ALT, AST, Cr, plt, sats
Prevention:
•
Diet + exercise (+/- bariatric surgery)
•
Aspirin 75 - 150mg PO daily from 12 – 36 weeks
o
ASPRE trial: 1.6% versus 4.3%
▪
1 MAJOR RF: hx PET, diabetic, chronic HTN, multiple gestation, renal dz, autoimmune dz (APLS/SLE)
▪
2 MOD RF: nulliparity, BMI >30, age ≥35, socioeconomic, IVF
•
Calcium supplementation
High dose folic acid supplementation beyond 1st trimester not shown to prevent PET (FACT trial)
Diagnosis: hypertension after 20/40 with evidence of one or more organ system involvement
Two categories:
•
Pre-eclampsia: hypertension + proteinuria >300mg or protein:Cr >0.3
•
Pre-clampsia with severe features:
o
sBP >160mmHg, dBP >110mmHg (on two separate occasions at least 4 hours apart on bed rest)
o
Platelets <100
o
Liver enzymes >2x normal
o
RUQ pain
o
Progressive renal impairment with serum Cr >100 (or doubling of serum Cr without renal dz)
o
Pulmonary oedema
o
New onset cerebral or visual abnormalities, clonus ≥3 beats
*In absence of proteinuria pre-eclampsia can be diagnosed in setting of hypertension + severe feature
Massive proteinuria (>5g/24hr) and foetal growth restriction have been removed as severe features
Pathophysiology unknown – presumed impaired trophoblastic cell invasion → impaired spiral artery dilatation → cascade of
antiangiogenic factors → generalised maternal endothelial dysfunction
Biomarkers: uterine a. doppler, placental growth factor, soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1, sFLT-1/PIGF ratio
Management of hypertensive emergency: MUST GIVE DOSES
•
Treat if ≥160/110 for ≥15 mins or end-organ dysfunction (aim sBP <150, dBP 80-100mmHg)
o
Rapid reduction may be harmful, aim 1-2mmHg / minute
•
Ix: FBC / EUC / LDH / fibrinogen / haptoglobin / urine PCR + ACR + micro
•
ECG +/- TTE
•
Fundoscopy of eye
•
CTG / continuous monitoring until BP is stable
•
Rx:
o
Labetalol 20mg (up to 80mg) IV
o
Hydralazine 5-10mg (up to 20mg) IV
o
Nifedipine 10mg PO (20mg after 20 mins) – use cautiously with magnesium
o
GTN 5-100mcg/min
o
Frusemide if APO +/- IDC
Management:
•
Immediate: delivery with 48 hours
•
Expectant: delivery >48 hours with monitoring

title: HELLP
text:
Delivery <37 weeks if:
•
3 or more anti-hypertensives
•
Deteriorating renal / liver fx, haemolysis
•
Severe thrombocytopaenia
•
SpO2 <90% on RA
•
Ongoing neurology
•
Placental abruption
•
Reversed end-diastolic flow in umbilical a.
•
Non-reassuring CTG
•
FDIU
HELLP
Affects 4-20% of pts with PET. Maternal mortality <1%.
HELLP: haemolysis, liver enzymes (transaminases), platelets
If pre-eclampsia + HELLP is considered ‘pre-eclampsia + HELLP syndrome’.
Diagnosis: ACOG criteria
•
LDH ≥600
•
AST / ALT ≥2x ULN
•
Platelets <100
Bili >20.
If “hepatic angina” i.e. RUQ pain – may be delay in deranged bloods – must repeat
Treatment: same as PET (stabilise + deliver foetus)
DIC in up to 20%
Hepatic haematoma/rupture - 50% mortality
Must image if triad:
•
RUQ pain
•
PET/HELLP
•
Unexplained hypotension

title: Eclampsia
text:
Eclampsia
Definition: pre-eclampsia with seizure activity. 0.1% of all births.
Classic warning signs: headache, visual disturbance, epigastric pain
Prevention of eclampsia:
•
MgSO4:
o
4g IV loading over 20 mins → infusion 1g/hour
o
Repeat bolus of 2g for recurrent seizures (max 6g / hour)
o
Monitor for hypo-reflexia / Mg toxicity (resp failure, muscle paralysis)
o
Target serum concentration 2-4mmol/L
o
Rx toxicity: 10mL 10% calcium gluconate over 10 minutes
MAGPIE trial: MgSO4 v placebo – during labour + 24hr post-partum will risk of seizures in severe PET or imminent eclampsia
Receiving MgSO4 is institution dependent
Seizures may occur pre-, intra-, and post-partum
Treatment:
•
Resuscitation:
o
ABC
o
Benzodiazepine to terminate prolonged seizures
•
Prevention of further seizures w/ magnesium
o
Magnesium >> phenytoin & diazepam at preventing 2nd seizure (though high NNT)
•
Control of hypertension: treat any BP >160mmHg
•
Delivery – main treatment
Hypertension may persist post-delivery
Anaesthetic technique for pre-eclampsia/eclampsia: neuraxial is preferred if no contra-indications
•
Epidural: provides excellent sympathetic blockade
o
CI: thrombocytopaenia, rapidly dropping platelet levels, DIC – all pts should have FBC within 6hr of procedure,
or within 2hr if plt trajectory requires – safe plt level 80 (consider manual platelet count) though remember
may also have plt dysfunction. Must recheck prior to removal of catheter in severe pre-eclampsia.
•
GA: must blunt hypertensive response to laryngoscopy – cases of maternal death from cerebral bleed
o
IDC awake → reduced time from anaesthesia to foetal delivery
o
Monitoring: ANZCA routine + 5-lead ECG + art line + BIS
o
Induction: good pre-oxygenation
▪
Co-induction: propofol: 1-2mg/kg + sevo rapid wash in + roc 1.2mg/kg
▪
Alfentanil 20-30mcg/kg – ensure effect prior to laryngoscopy – paeds support
▪
Other Rx:
•
Remifentanil 1mcg/kg, labetolol 0.25mg/kg, esmolol 0.5mg/kg, ligonocaine 1.5mg/kg
▪
Caution: sensitivity to exogenous catecholamines
o
Intubation:
▪
Adjuncts - high risk airway oedema - ETT size
▪
VL + X-blade / stylet + ramped
▪
O&G start at the first sign of CO2
o
Maintenance:
▪
Switch to TIVA to uterine atony
▪
Minimise IVF - risk of APO (frusemide if concerns)
▪
Continue magnesium (risk of atony)
▪
Avoid NSAIDs
o
Blood management bundle +
▪
Targets in haemorrhage: Hb >80, fibrinogen >2, plt >75, INR/aPPT 1.5x normal
▪
Cell-salvage + leukocyte reduction filter
o
Uterotonics:
▪
Oxytocin 40ui in 100mL normal saline @ 25mL/hour
▪
Ergot CI unless life-threatening haemorrhage
o
Extubation:
▪
TOF ratio >0.9 (risk with MgSO4)
▪
Check cuff leak

title: Liver Derangement in Pregnancy
text:
Liver Derangement in Pregnancy
Causes:
•
Pregnancy related: intrahepatic cholestasis, acute fatty liver of pregnancy, HELLP syndrome, pre-eclampsia, PONV
•
Exacerbated by pregnancy: gallstones, vascular (Budd Chiari)
•
Unrelated: acute viral hepatitis, drugs
Hx: pruritis, toxins, headache, visual disturbance, abdo pain
Exam: jaundice, hepatic flap, encephalopathy, hepatomegaly, ascites, oedema
Note: spider naevi, palmar erythema can be normal with oestrogen
Inv: routine + blood gas + liver US, MRI
→ Lactate >2.8 + presence of encephalopathy are poor prognostic indicators of severe liver dz in pregnancy
Differentiating cause:
•
Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy: bile acids (bili normal)
•
Pre-eclampsia with hepatic impairment: >2 x ALT (bili and bile acids normal)
•
HELLP: up to 30x ALT, bili (bile acids normal)
•
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy: 4 – 15x bilirubin, ALT
Management:
•
MDT input in a specialist liver centre – early liver centre referral in case transplantation required
•
Assess: encephalopathy, synthetic function
Anaesthetic considerations:
•
Avoid NSAIDs
•
Consider alternative to rocuronium
•
Check plt + coags prior to neuraxial (role of TEG in this setting is not validated)
Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy
Incidence 27% (most common liver disease of pregnancy)
Description: pruritis + elevated bile acids in 2-3rd trimester that resolves after delivery
SSx: pruritus (hands / feet → generalised), RUQ pain, nausea, anorexia, steatorrhoea
Is unlikely to cause liver failure / encephalopathy
Ix: bile acids, transaminases 2x ULN, bili, ALP, vit K deficiency → INR (check coags)
Imaging: normal liver US
Relevance:
•
foetal mortality 2’ FDIU/stillbirth, meconium, preterm labour, neonatal respiratory distress
•
Vitamin K deficiency → coagulopathy
Treatment:
•
Ursodeoxycholic acid for pruritis
•
Early foetal delivery depending on bile acid level
•
Check coags prior to neuraxial
•
Avoid IT morphine → itch
Budd-Chiari Syndrome
Hepatic venous outflow obstruction. 75% of cases are due to thrombosis (pregnancy is a RF). Same prothrombotic conditions
pre-dispose to early foetal loss.
Incidental Hepatic Disorders
•
Viral hepatitis: includes hep A – E, HSV, CMV, EBV (Hep E and HSV → worse outcomes in pregnancy)
•
Autoimmune hepatitis: usually improves in pregnancy
•
Drug-induced
Chronic Liver Disease
Pregnancy + cirrhosis →
•
Worsening of portal hypertension
•
risk of variceal bleeding (C-section > labour to avoid Valsalva)

title: Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy
text:
Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy
1/7000 – 20000. Perinatal mortality 20 – 50%. Maternal mortality 2%.
RFs: foetal B-fatty acid oxidation disorder, previous AFLP, multiple gestation, pre-eclampsia, HELLP, male foetus, low BMI,
nulliparity
Presentation:
•
Usually 3rd trimester
•
Non-specific SSx i.e. nausea, abdo pain, headache, anorexia, HTN +/- proteinuria, HELLP in 20%, PET 40%
•
Acute liver failure
•
AKI, central DI, pancreatitis
Diagnosis: Swansea criteria for AFLP (≥ 6)
•
SSx:
o
Vomiting
o
Abdo pain
o
Polydipsia / polyuria
o
Encephalopathy
•
Ix:
o
Bili
o
Hypoglycaemia
o
WBC
o
AST / ALT
o
ammonia
o
urate
o
AKI
o
Coagulopathy
•
Imaging: ascites or bright liver on US
•
Histo: microvascular steatosis on biopsy
Also fragmented RBC / Burr cells
Management: MDT obstetrics, neonatology, ICU, anaesthesia, hepatology, haematology
•
Prompt delivery of foetus
•
Support as for ALF
o
Liver transplant if indicated

title: Peripartum Cardiomyopathy
text:
Peripartum Cardiomyopathy
Definition: diagnosis of exclusion
•
New onset cardiomyopathy with LVEF <45%
•
No reversible cause
•
Presenting last month of pregnancy or within 5/12 post-partum
•
No known heart disease
RFs: previous peripartum CM, PET, tocolytic Rx >4/52, obesity, age >30, viral infection, multiple pregnancy, cocaine, genetic
Symptoms: dyspnoea, cough, orthopnoea, ET, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, pedal oedema, haemoptysis, fatigue
Signs: JVP, pedal oedema, displaced apex beat, 3rd heart sound, MR murmur
Ix: ECG (non-specific findings), CXR, pro-BNP, CMRI, TTE (global LV, LVEF <45% +/- other features, may have thrombus)
Rx: heart failure management
•
Beta blockers
•
Frusemide
•
Anticoagulation
CI during pregnancy: ACEi, ARB, neprilysin inhibitors, spironolactone
Acute Rx: oxygen, IPPV, inotropic / mechanical support, diuresis
+/- arrhythmia management, mechanical support, cardiac transplant, bromocriptine (prolactin antagonist)
Delivery: stabilise mother first
•
Ideal method of delivery: vaginal with epidural and haemodynamic monitoring
•
Early delivery not required if stable
Suppress breastfeeding (if going to breastfeed avoid AT-2 blockers) + contraception
Prognosis: mortality 10% at 2y, 30-80% with persistent heart failure, recurrence in future pregnancies
Diabetes in Pregnancy
Complications (HAPO study): macrosomia, birth injury, perinatal mortality (5x), premature foetus, hyperbilirubinaemia,
congenital abnormality, C-section, PET, sepsis, neonatal hypoglycaemia +/- micro/macrovascular
Maternal hyperglycaemia → hyperplasia of foetal B cells → foetal insulin → risk of neonatal hypoglycaemia +/- neurological
consequences
Risk of hyponatraemia in intrapartum period with glucose administration + oxytocin  recommended to use glucose in saline/
Avoid fluid overload in pts with hypertensive disorders +/- PET
Post-partum:
•
Type 1 or insulin dependent T2DM: VRII should 50% post-delivery and stopped 30-60mins post-first meal
•
Pre-existing diabetes on OHGs: insulin should be ceased after delivery – discuss restarting OHGs with endocrine

title: Gestational Diabetes
text:
Gestational Diabetes
Human placental lactogen promotes insulin resistance in pregnancy
RFs:
•
High: previous GDM, previous hyperglycaemia, age ≥40, FHx, BMI >35, Hx macrosomia, PCOS, steroids, antipsychotics
•
Moderate: Asian / Indian, ATSI, pacific islander, Maori, middle eastern, non-white African, BMI 25 – 35
Diagnosis:
•
75g OGTT at 24 – 28 weeks (earlier if high risk) – present if
o
Fasting ≥ 5.1mM
o
1 hour ≥10.0mM
o
2 hour ≥ 8.5mM
Management:
•
Labour:
o
Q1 hourly BSL – target 4 – 7 mM
o
VRII if unable to maintain above
o
Insulin pump is safe in labour - if BSL >7 on two consecutive readings or ketones >1.5 → VRII
•
C-section: aim first on list
o
Q1 hourly BSL - target 5 – 8 mM (q30min if GA)
o
Consider aspiration risk
o
Post-op insulin rarely required (start with 50% dose reduction) – target 6 – 10mM
Repeat OGTT at 6 – 12 weeks post-partum; ~5% go on to have NIDDM

section_path: Anaesthetic Management of Co-Existing Maternal Conditions
title: Anaesthetic Management of Co-Existing Maternal Conditions
text:
Anaesthetic Management of Co-Existing Maternal Conditions
Maternal mortality causes: cardiovascular conditions > infection > non-cardiovascular medical condition > cardiomyopathy >
haemorrhage > VTE > hypertensive disorders of pregnancy

title: Obesity
text:
Obesity
Normal obesity classification system. 23% of pregnant patients.
Complications:
•
Maternal: mortality, GDM, hypertensive disorders +/- PET, OSA, CVD, infection / sepsis, instrumental delivery,
caesarean section (50%), PPH, prolonged admission, accidental dural puncture, wound infection, uterine atony
•
Neonatal: preterm, miscarriage, SGA, LGA, macrosomia, stillbirth, shoulder dystocia, neural tube defects, neonatal
death, NICU admission
High risk anaesthetic referral if:
•
BMI ≥40
•
Comorbid
*Most small hospitals have a BMI cut off
Assessment:
•
As for obesity: airway, resp (OSA +/- cor pulmonale), sleep study, ET, ECG, aspiration risk, diabetes
•
Neuraxial: dural puncture 4% cf 1%
Recommended:
•
Local guidelines for appropriate facility
•
Early epidural (challenging + risk of GA)
o
Leave in longer length
o
Obesity protective for PDPH
o
CSE - lower failure rates
•
Equipment likely needed: US, long spinal / epidural needles, large BP cuffs / invasive BP (consider forearm BP cuff),
appropriate operating table / pt bed
•
Caution use of opioids
C-section considerations:
•
Position: ramped, left lateral tilt, pannus retraction
•
Abx 3g cephazolin if >120kg
•
Regional technique: CSE recommended + spinal dose if BMI >50
GA C-section:
•
Ramp + position
•
Antacid prophylaxis
•
Pre-oxygenate >0.9
•
THRIVE
•
VL for first attempt
•
Dosing:
o
Sux – TBW
o
Prop – lean BW
o
Non-depolarising NMB – ideal BW
•
Decompress stomach with OG tube (nasal passage friable)
•
Extubate awake ++
•
OSA: commence CPAP immediately
Post-op:
•
Sats monitoring
•
VTE prophylaxis
•
Early mobilisation
•
Monitor for infection (risk)

title: Cardiac Disease
text:
Cardiac Disease
Leading cause of maternal mortality.
Risk – WHO classification:
•
Class I (very low risk):
o
Uncomplicated disease (small or mild pulmonary stenosis, PDA, MV prolapse)
o
Successfully repaired simple lesions (ASD/VSD, PSA, anomalous pulmonary venous drainage)
o
Atrial or ventricular ectopic beats
•
Class 2 (low to mod risk): if otherwise well and uncomplicated
o
Unoperated ASD/VSD
o
Repaired ToF
o
Most arrhythmias
•
Class 2 - 3 (between – depending on individual)
o
Mild LV impairment
o
HOCM
o
Native or tissue valvular disease not classed type 1 or 4
o
Marfan’s without aortic dilatation
o
Aorta <45mm in aortopathy with bicuspid valve
o
Repaired coarctation
•
Class 3 (high risk)
o
Mechanical valve
o
Systemic RV
o
Fontan circulation
o
Unrepaired cyanotic heart disease
o
Other complex congenital disease
o
Aortic dilatation <45mm in Marfan’s
o
Aortic dilatation 45-50mm in aortic disease with bicuspid valve
•
Class 4 (extremely high risk): pregnancy contraindicated – there are 7
•
Aortic:
o
Marfan syndrome with aorta >45mm
o
Aortic dilatation >50mm of any cause
o
Native severe coarctation
•
Pulmonary arterial hypertension
•
(Left) heart:
o
Severe mitral stenosis
o
Previous peripartum cardiomyopathy
o
Severe systemic ventricular dysfunction (EF <40%)
•
Admission for bed rest indicated to cardiac demand and to viability if borderline
CARPREG II Score – risk of maternal cardiac complications
Pro-BNP @ 20/40 → value >120pg/mL is predictive of adverse event, high NPV
Must determine:
•
Appropriate hospital / ward
•
Safe drugs
•
Anticoagulation regimen
•
Risk of labour Valsalva
•
Need for CTSx / ECMO
Indication for anticoagulation:
•
Low flow state
•
Fontans circulation
•
Pulmonary hypertension
•
Mechanical valve
•
AF
Optimise:
•
Anaemia / Fe deficiency
•
thyroid
•
Modifiable RFs: obesity, smoking
•
GDM
•
HTN

title: Cardiac Disease
text:
Important to appreciate major CVS changes and how that affects specific cardiac disease – preload +++ at time of delivery 2’:
1. Increased CO during pregnancy (including blood volume)
2. Uterine contractions
3. Decompression of the IVC at delivery
4. Post-delivery uterine involution
There are also major changes to afterload:
1. Overall decrease in SVR 2’ vasodilation by progesterone, oestrogen, PGs, relaxin, nitric oxide
2. Placenta creates a high-flow, low resistance shunt
→ high risk for afterload dependent lesions e.g. LVOT obstruction
Vaginal Delivery
Benefits: blood loss, infection, VTE, pain post-delivery cf C-section
Exceptions to vaginal delivery: aortic dissection and Marfans with dilated aortic root
Avoid sudden changes in preload and afterload, slow rising epidural usually best – beware autotransfusion and synto
Regurgitant valvular lesions generally tolerated better than stenotic lesions
Management:
•
Timing of delivery an MDT decision – usually IOL at 40 weeks, all methods of IOL are safe
•
Early epidural to catecholamine release and CO/tachycardia – replace if issues – avoid fluid bolus if risk of APO
o
Avoid adrenaline, go slow
o
Manage hypotension
o
Intrathecal morphine only can also decrease sympathetic response.
o
LOR to saline reduces risk of air embolism
•
IE prophylaxis: not required
•
Second stage: allow passive head descent to active phase, assisted 2nd stage, CI to Valsalva, ensure epidural with good
sacral coverage
Monitoring:
•
Continuous pulse ox
•
5-lead ECG
•
Art line (L heart obstruction, LVEF, RH dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension)
•
CTG
Caesarean Section
Indications: obstetric, unstable aortic disease, maternal anticoagulation with warfarin (note: warfarin reversal does not cross
placenta) → risk of neonatal haemorrhage, critical valve stenosis / severe LVOT obstruction, severe decompensated pulmonary
hypertension, acute HF requiring intubation, Eisenmenger syndrome
Management:
•
Neuraxial preferred: class I – II normal spinal, class III – IV slow epidural top up
•
Monitoring: invasive arterial +/- CVC +/- PAC
•
Uterotonics: caution, slow infusion (no boluses)
•
Monitor for PPH, treat early with goal-directed therapy
•
Aim to maintain sinus rhythm (treat as for non-pregnant, avoid amio / warfarin / noacs)
•
Avoid exteriorisation of uterus (risk of air embolism)
Indications for GA (3):
1. Maternal refusal neuraxial
2. Anticoagulation / thrombocytopaenia / coagulopathic
3. inability to lie flat
Interventions During Pregnancy
•
Percutaneous cath: best after 4 mo, radiation exposure
•
Cardiopulmonary bypass:
o
Outcomes for pregnant women similar to non-pregnant women
o
Foetal outcomes are poor; mortality ~20% - best time 13 – 28 weeks (2nd trimester)
o
Bypass: risk to foetus by using pulsatile flow (high flows >2.5L/min/m2), high perfusion pressures (MAP
>70mmHg), strict potassium balance, normothermic bypass, normocapnia
o
Consider caesarean delivery after 28 weeks with steroid cover

title: Aortic Disease
text:
Aortic Disease
Inherited aortic disease:
•
Marfan syndrome (3% dissection in pregnancy)
•
Loeyz-dietz syndrome
•
Osteoaneurysm syndrome
•
Vascular ehlers danlos syndrome (type IV)
•
Turner syndrome
Secondary causes:
•
ToF
•
Aortic coarctation (repaired)
•
Bicuspid aortic valve
•
Hypertension
Risk:
•
Dissection: 50% third trimester, 33% post-partum
•
Cardiac tamponade
Management:
•
Pre-pregnancy: aortic imaging (CT / MRI) + counselling
•
Antenatal: monthly TTE if high risk
•
Throughout:
o
Strict BP control: beta-blockade
o
Intervention if progressive dilatation
o
Rupture:
▪
Stanford type A: simultaneous C-section + vascular repair (foetal mortality 30%)
▪
Stanford type B: medical management +/- TEVAR
•
Labour:
o
Recommended if aorta is <40mm, CI if aorta >45mm
o
Continue beta blocker (celiprolol for ehlers danlos)
o
Early and effective epidural
o
Avoid Valsalva → assisted and passive second stage
•
Caesarean:
o
Art line + slowly titrated epidural – treat hypo + hypertension aggressively
o
No oxytocin bolus; ergot CI
o
Treat haemorrhage early
Goals:
•
Minimise aortic wall tension
•
Minimise haemodynamic fluctuations

title: Mitral and Aortic Regurgitation
text:
Valvular Disease
Aortic Stenosis
Physiology:
•
SVR → coronary driving pressure
•
High risk of pulmonary oedema
Well tolerated in asymptomatic severe AS
Red flags: exercise tolerance, LV impairment, progressive disease
Treatment:
•
BAV +/- TAVI
•
Medical management
•
Mode of delivery:
o
Symptomatic AS → C-section
o
Asymptomatic AS → labour
Goals:
•
Maintain afterload (art line, pressor)
•
Avoid tachycardia (early + effective epidural, 5 lead ECG, treat hypertension)
•
Maintain normovolaemia
 Avoid: terbutaline (SVR + HR)
Mitral Stenosis
See Blue Book Article. Mortality 0-3%. Physiology: CO →
•
transvalvular gradient
•
LA pressure
•
pulmonary oedema / pulmonary pressures +/- RHF
Fixed preload → inability to CO
Can also precipitate AF which is poorly tolerated → cardiac failure.
MV area is best predictor for APO i.e. severe dz (valve area <1cm2) 1 in 2 – heart failure usually in 2nd trimester
Other RFs: NYHA >2, sPAP >30, older age, mean gradient, co-existing MR
Foetal complications: prematurity 20-30%, IUGR, foetal death 1-5%
Goals:
•
Maintain SR: cardioversion if unstable
•
Avoid tachycardia: beta blockade, neuraxial, avoid terbutaline + synto boluses, 5 lead ECG
•
Ergot CI
•
Preload: avoid AC compression / hypovolaemia – strict fluid balance
•
Afterload: treat hypertension but maintain SVR, art line
•
Labour in upright position
•
Prevent pulmonary vascular resistance
Treatment:
•
Perc mitral commissurotomy (>20/40 is better) if NYHA class 3 or 4, sPAP >50
•
Medical: b-blockade, restrict anything that induces tachycardia, diuresis, anticoagulation
Management:
•
Mild MS / NYHA 1-2 / no pulmonary hypertension → labour with early, slow epidural, assisted / passive 2nd stage
•
Mod MS / NYHA 3-4 / CI to perc valve → C-section, give oxytocin slowly, ergot CI
Monitor post-delivery – autotransfusion → risk of APO
Mitral and Aortic Regurgitation
Physiology: SVR is beneficial → regurgitant volume; blood volume → ventricular dilatation → worsens AR / MR
Goals:
•
Avoid SVR: epidural analgesia, consider afterload reduction, treat hypertensive disorders of pregnancy
•
Avoid contractility and bradycardia: avoid beta-blockers, consider ephedrine > phenylephrine

title: Pulmonary Hypertension
text:
Pulmonary Hypertension
Maternal mortality 30-50%, mWHO class IV carries 40-100% risk. Pregnancy CI. Greatest period week post-delivery.
Potential complications:
•
mortality (30%) – highest during labour / post-partum
o
Foetal mortality also 30%
•
pulmonary emboli risk (hypercoaguable)
•
pulmonary vascular reactivity
•
myocardial contractility (in presence of decreased filling state)
Physiology:
•
CO overwhelms RV with fixed afterload
•
SVR → impaired RV perfusion
Management @ specialist centre with MDT care. 3rd trimester requires weekly r/v +/- inpatient management.
Medication:
•
Safe:
o
Sildenafil (1st line)
o
Prostacyclin analogues
▪
Eproprostenol (IV prostaglandins) may inhibit platelet aggregation
•
Contraindicated:
o
Bosentan /endothelin-R antagonists (due to embryopathy → category X)
o
Riociguat (nitric oxide pathway)
May be indication for caesarean – recommended at 34/40 (balance of risk benefit)
Most will be anticoagulated – must consider for epidural
GA has 4x greater mortality than regional
Goals:
•
PVR: normal measures + consider PAC
•
Maintain preload: fluids + early treatment of haemorrhage (avoid fluid overload)
•
Avoid myocardial depression: avoid beta blockers, consider dobutamine +/- low dose norad
•
Avoid arrhythmia/ischaemia: 5 lead ECG
•
Maintain SVR: art line + slow titration of epidural
•
Uterotonics:
o
Avoid: oxytocin bolus (low dose infusion okay or 0.1iu boluses), ergot, carboprost
o
Misoprostal safe
•
Postpartum: high risk → monitor in ICU, may need mechanical support

title: Anticoagulation in Pregnancy
text:
Anticoagulation in Pregnancy
Particular issue with mechanical valves - warfarin is best anticoagulant but causes:
•
Teratogenesis in 1st trimester
•
Foetal anticoagulation in 3rd trimester → risk of bleed (vaginal birth is CI)
MDT + pre-pregnancy counselling
Management:
•
Pre-pregnancy TTE to assess valve + ventricular function
•
Anticoagulation: risk benefit discussion with mother
o
1st trimester:
▪
Warfarin <5mg / day: continue
▪
Warfarin >5mg / day: replace with therapeutic clexane for weeks 6 – 12
o
2nd trimester: warfarin is better
o
Cease warfarin at 36/40 → clexane → IV heparin 36 hours prior to planned birth
▪
INR / anti-Xa monitoring at least weekly
▪
Delivery:
•
If warfarin within 2/52 → C-section (risk of foetal ICH even with normal INR)
o
Aspirin added only if indicated i.e. PET
Haemorrhage: major maternal haemorrhage complicates up to 11% of pregnancies with mechanical valves
Pros and cons of anticoagulants – specifically mechanical valves:
•
Warfarin:
o
Lowest maternal mortality & thrombosis
o
Lowest livebirth rate 2’ foetal ICH, embryopathy / foetopathy, lowest if <5mg / day
o
Can reverse with prothrombinex
•
Clexane:
o
High maternal complication
o
Highest livebirth rate + no adverse effects
o
Target anti-Xa 0.8 – 1.2 (though lack of established pregnancy-specific ranges)
o
Must wait pre-specified time period, reversal with protamine not reliable
•
IV heparin: cease 4-6 hours prior + normal aPTT prior to neuraxial (4 hours + normal aPTT is okay)
o
Able to reversed with protamine
o
Restart 4 hours post neuraxial or removal of epidural catheter
Breastfeeding is safe with therapeutic doses of LMWH and warfarin
Special scenarios:
•
TOP: surgical > medical for bleeding (+ better control of anticoagulation)
•
Thrombosed MHV: cardiac SSx +/- loss of mechanical “click” → urgent CTSx
•
Stroke: thrombotic or haemorrhagic

title: Neurological Disorders
text:
Neurological Disorders
Epilepsy
Treat intrapartum seizures as eclampsia. Hx of epilepsy should not dictate mode of delivery.
Neuraxial okay – may seizure risk by fatigue and stress.
Avoid pethidine. All GA drugs okay except etomidate.
Keppra safest AED (teratogenic potential 2%) and gabapentin.
Hepatic induction from AEDs may duration of action of neuromuscular blocking agents
Multiple Sclerosis
Pregnancy associated with relapse, but relapse within 3mo post-delivery is common
Not associated with epidurals, though possible association with high dose LA – use lowest effective [ ], avoid vasoconstrictors
ASA recommends epidural > neuraxial (but not CI)
DMARDs usually ceased prior to conception.
Ante-partum relapse: high dose steroids, IVIg or plasma exchange
Myasthenia Gravis
Pyridostigmine + other immunosuppressants are safe.
Assess for bulbar signs + resp weakness.
Neuraxial recommended in labour to avoid crisis.
Weakness → rate of instrumental or surgical delivery. Neuraxial is safe but must caution with level of motor blockade (resp) –
CSE recommended with low dose spinal component.
GA: non-depolarising NMBA at 10% dose + sugammadex
Caution weakness with MgSO4
SMA
SSx: severe scoliosis, resp failure, cardiac abnormalities
Obstetric outcomes poor. Rarely able to deliver spontaneously. Challenging neuraxial (caution deformities + spinal hardware)
Opioids – sparingly or avoid. Likely require NIV. Sux CI. Non-depolarising can cause prolonged blockade → sugammadex.
Spinal Dysraphisms
Congenital malformations of vertebral arches, spinal cord, meninges.
Types:
•
Open (no overlying skin) → repaired:
o
Unlikely to have patent epidural space or ligamentum flavum – epidural is CI
o
Spinal above area if recent MRI shows low risk spinal cord injury
o
Chiari malformation common – may have shunt, consider shunt malfunction if PET symptoms
•
Closed (overlying skin):
o
Underlying spinal cord and structures are abnormal
o
Skin abnormalities (lipoma, hair tuft, skin tag, naevi) – lipomas associated with dural defects +/- tethered to
spinal cord/filum terminale
o
Any suspicion:
▪
Spinal MRI: level of cord termination, CSF volume +/- presence of tethering +/- intact ligamentum
flavum
•
Epidural may not give complete block if dural space altered
•
Spinal okay above level
If spina bifida occulta (least serious, most common) can consider neuraxial if proper consent + counselling
Complex spina bifida:
•
Often associated conditions eg cutaneous manifestations +/- urinary / back / leg symptoms, LL pain, bowel symptoms
•
Should be considered a CI to neuraxial

title: Haematological Disease
text:
Haematological Disease
Von Willebrands Disease
Prophylactic Rx if vWF <50 units/dL
Type
Clinical Effect
Treatment
Partial reduction in vWF
Usually rises in 3rd trimester to >50
Usually not required
•
Consider desmopressin → release
•
Desmopressin CI in PET due to vasoconstriction
Defect in quality of vWF
Biostate
Desmopressin only works in some subtypes (not 2b)
Near complete absence of vWF
Biostate
vWF >50 + normal platelets → no concern for epidural. Ensure surveillance post-epidural removal
Usually use TXA and Biostate (factor VIII + vWF) – DDAVP rarely used anymore
If foetus at risk of type 2 or 3 avoid ECV, ventouse, and forceps
Haemophilia
X-linked congenital bleeding disorder.
•
Haemophilia A: factor VIII usually in normal range by 3rd trimester. Desmopressin can factor VIII.
•
Haemophilia B: factor IX doesn’t change in pregnancy
Should check baseline factor [ ] prior to conception.
Rx:
•
Recombinant factors (treatment of choice)
•
TXA
•
Avoid ventouse + forceps
Factor concentrations should be maintained >0.5iu/mL for 3/7 after vaginal delivery and 5/7 after C-section
Sickle Cell Disease
Most common inherited haemoglobinopathy.
Pregnancy →
•
Sickle cell complications: pain crisis, acute chest syndrome, infections (i.e. sickling at low O2 tensions → micro infarcts)
•
Pregnancy complications: PET, placental insufficiency, and C-section rates
o
Aspirin from 12/40 due to risk of PET
o
+/- LMWH from 28/40
Physiological changes including prothrombosis, aortocaval compression, vascular stasis and physiological anaemia can
exacerbate pre-existing organ dysfunction +/- acute decompensation.
Anaesthetic considerations: r/v prior to 36/40
•
Pulmonary hypertension 10%: TTE from past 1yr
•
Ix: Hb, retics, HbS%
o
Transfusion if: Hb <50, >20 drop from baseline, haemodynamic compromise
o
Risk of antibodies → cross-match delay
o
Transfusion painful crises in 3rd trimester, but does not change foetal outcomes and has risks of transfusion
o
Exchange transfusion (aiming HbS <30%) only if recommended by haematology
o
Hb >80 for delivery, >100 for C-section
•
May be on life-long abx 2’ splenic infarct
If presenting with acute pain – assess:
•
Infection
•
Acute chest syndrome
•
Dehydration
Give analgesia. Ensure normothermia.
SCD not an absolute CI to cell salvage.
If requires GA:
•
Incentive spiro
•
Good analgesia
•
VTE: prophylaxis 7/7 post vaginal delivery or 6/52 post C-section

title: Thromboembolism
text:
Thromboembolism
Leading cause of direct maternal death.
RFs:
Maternal: previous VTE, age >35, BMI >30, parity ≥3, smoking, varicose veins, cancer, heart failure, IBD, FHx
Obstetric: multiple pregnancy, PET, C-section, prolonged labour >24hr, mid-cavity / rotational operative delivery, stillbirth,
preterm, PPH
Other: post-surgery, post-partum sterilisation, hyperemesis, ovarian hyperstimulation, ART/IVF, immobility, fracture,
systemic illness, long distance travel >4 hr
Prevention:
Risk assessment
Conservative: avoid dehydration, mobilisation
Mechanical: TEDS, SCDS
Pharmaceutical: clexane, full anticoagulation
Presentation: LL oedema / pain (L side more common), erythema, palpitations, anxiety, chest pain, cyanosis, sweating, cough,
shock
No validated risk criteria for pregnancy (e.g. Wells) → challenging diagnosis
Ix: start therapy prior to firm diagnosis if high risk → ECG, CXR, venous doppler, V:Q scan, CTPA (do not to D dimer)
Advise that V:Q scanning may carry slightly higher risk of childhood cancer but is associated with less risk of maternal breast
cancer than CTPA
Rx:
Clexane (based on pre-booking weight)
CI to anticoagulation: active / high risk bleeding, allergy, coagulopathy, thrombocytopaenia, HITS, stroke <4 weeks,
uncontrolled hypertension
Vena cava filter (mortality 0.3%, filter migration >20%, filter fracture or IVC perforation 5%) – only if anticoagulation CI or
recurrent events despite anticoagulation
Thrombolysis: risk of major bleed is same as baseline population
CI to anticoagulation: high risk bleeding condition e.g. praevia, allergy, coagulopathy, thrombocytopaenia, acute stroke, severe
liver dz, uncontrolled HTN
Acute massive PE with haemodynamic instability → thrombolysis + IV heparin infusion
Labour:
Cease anticoagulation at onset of labour
Plan delivery time based on last dose

title: Labour
text:
Labour
Mechanism and progress of normal labour:
•
First stage:
o
Onset of labour until full cervical dilatation (latent <4cm, active 4-10cm)
o
Timing: 0.5cm/hour primip, 1cm/hour multip
•
Second stage:
o
Full dilatation to delivery of foetus
o
Timing: <3 hrs primip, <2 hrs multip
•
Third stage:
o
Foetus until placenta ~ 30 mins
Analgesia: full text in pain notes
•
Non-pharmacological:
o
May pain: (L1)
▪
Small birth ball
▪
Acupuncture
▪
Heat packs
▪
Massage (in first stage)
▪
No effect:
•
TENS unless severe pain and on pressure points
o
May analgesia consumption:
▪
Acupuncture
▪
Hypnosis
▪
Continuous 1:1 nursing (also rate of assisted birth)
▪
Water immersion
o
No effect: yoga, music, audio
•
Pharmacological: (L1)
o
Nitrous:
▪
Some analgesia but maternal adverse effects (nausea, vomiting, dizziness)
▪
Inferior to epidural
o
Remifentanil: cont sats monitoring + O2 – consider capnography
▪
Superior to other opioids but inferior to epidural
▪
Same APGARs as epidural – must have naloxone, sats monitoring, neonatal resus + paeds available
Neuraxial:
•
Improved by US (L1)
•
Epidural and CSE → superior pain relief for labour and delivery
•
Epidural cf systemic opioid:
o
N&V, need for O2 but slightly duration of the first and second stage of labour (L1)
o
Does not rate of Caesarean, long term back ache, headache, pruritus, PND (L1)
o
risk of foetal acidosis and need for naloxone administration with no in need for NICU (L1)
•
Epidurals:
o
Epidural may risk of assisted vaginal delivery, but not with low-concentrations (L1)
o
Low concentrations via epidural lead to shorter duration of second stage of labour, fewer assisted deliveries,
greater ambulation and less urinary retention cf higher concentrations (L1)
o
No difference between early v late epidural (L1)
o
PCEA effective but optimal settings not known (L1)
o
PIB > continuous infusion (L1)
o
No difference in LA for any outcome except ropivacaine may motor block (L1)
o
Single-injection intrathecal opioids provide comparable early labour analgesia to epidural local anaesthetics,
with increased pruritus but no difference in nausea (L1)
▪
Adding single injection IT morphine (250mcg) to LA + shorter acting opioids increases time to first
analgesic request, but is associated with increased adverse effects (L1)
•
CSE v epidural (L1), CSE →
o
time to effective analgesia
o
No maternal satisfaction
o
pruritus
o
risk of unilateral block
o
non-reassuring foetal HR

title: Total Spinal
text:
Epidural
Considerations:
•
Anticoagulants (APSME guidelines)
•
Thrombocytopaenia
o
Epidural haematoma risk:
▪
Plt 70 – 100: 0.2%
▪
Plt 50 – 69: 2.6%
▪
Plt <50: 9%
Must follow same criteria for epidural catheter removal
•
Previous surgery
•
Chorioamnionitis
•
FDIU: if no evidence of DIC
•
Raised ICP: benign intracranial hypertension okay, otherwise d/w neurosurg re: risk of dural puncture
•
Hypovolaemia – correct
COMET trial: comparative obstetric mobility epidural trial, low dose blocks i.e. bup 0.1% (or ropivacaine ≤0.2%) associated with:
•
Less instrumental delivery
•
Ropivicaine – probably less motor block than bup
Epidural related-hyperthermia: (mechanism unknown)
•
≥38C on one occasion
•
≥37.5C on 2x occasions two hours apart
Incidence is 20% with epidural, 5% without
Consequences:
•
caesarean / assisted delivery (2x)
•
neonatal brain injury / resus requirements
CSE
Commonly needle-through-needle technique. No difference between CSE + epidural in rates of PDPH and C-section.
•
Benefits:
o
Confirmed placement via CSF / incidence of failure cf epidural alone (despite “untested catheter”)
o
Better analgesia + more rapid onset
o
urinary retention
o
assisted delivery
o
rescue analgesia
o
unilateral block
•
Disadvantages:
o
Unable to assess catheter until spinal anaesthesia subsided
o
Parasthesia from spinal needle
o
Pruritis
o
CTG abnormality (manage with BP management +/- tocolytics)
Total Spinal
Normal CTG prior – resus will
improve.
ABC approach.

title: Urgent Delivery
text:
Urgent Delivery
Category:
•
Cat 1
Urgent threat to life or mother / foetus
<30 minutes
•
Cat 2
Compromise but not immediately life threatening
<1 hour
•
Cat 3
Requires earlier than planned delivery without current evidence of compromise
<4 hours
•
Cat 4
At a time acceptable to patient + staff - elective
Tocolytic
Mechanism
Adverse Effects
NSAIDs
↓prostaglandins
•
Bleeding
•
Peptic ulcer
•
Renal dysfunction
•
Hypertension
B2-agonists
(inc adrenaline)
SM relaxation (prevents pre-mature
labour ~48 hours)
•
Tachycardia
•
Tremor
Atosiban
Oxytocin-R antagonist
•
Vasodilation
•
N + V
Nifedipine
L-type Ca2+ channel antagonist
•
Hypotension
•
Peripheral oedema
Volatiles
SM relaxation
•
Hypotension
•
Sedation
GTN
NO release → SM relaxation
•
Hypotension
Monitoring assumes FHR proportional to foetal O2 status.
Foetal / intrauterine resus:
•
Call for help
•
Supplemental O2
•
Reposition (avoid aortocaval compression)
•
Correct hypotension: fluid resus, vasopressor
•
Treat uterine tone (cease oxytocin, terbutaline s/c 250mcg, GTN s/l 400mcg i.e. 2 puffs, salbutamol 100mcg)
•
Stimulate foetal head
•
Check descent / dilation
•
Exclude cord prolapse
CTG
Combines FHR + uterine contraction.
Evidence:
•
intervention/C-section
•
neonatal seizures
•
No decrease in perinatal death or cerebral palsy
•
No RCTs
Indications for continuous monitoring:
•
Augmentation of labour
•
Regional analgesia (role in low risk labour not established)
•
Non-reassuring FHR
•
High risk pregnancy
•
Prolonged labour
•
Suspected foetal compromise
Assesses 4 domains: baseline HR, variability, decelerations, accelerations
•
Decels: >15 bpm lasting >15 seconds (late = bad)
•
Baseline is assessed over 10 mins
•
Variability peak to trough over 1 minute

title: Conversion of Labour Epidural
text:
Conversion of Labour Epidural
Must stay with patient after top up dose given.
LA options:
•
Lignocaine 2% with adrenaline 1:200000
o
Fastest onset 1.5 – 4.5 minutes faster
o
Adding fentanyl → 2 minutes faster
o
Adding HCO3 → 4.5 minutes faster
•
Ropivicaine 0.75%
o
Lowest need for intra-op supplementation
•
Bupivicaine 0.5% - worst option
Loss of sensation to T5 dermatome is required to prevent pain reliably during C-section
Epidural morphine only if certain of location.
Failed top up:
•
No time → GA
•
Some time → CSE with 50% reduction in spinal dose + manipulate

title: Neuraxial Anaesthesia for Caesarean
text:
Neuraxial Anaesthesia for Caesarean
Safer for mother. Probably best for baby also – APGARs with GA vs neuraxial → 5x chance of lower APGAR (however must
acknowledge confounders such as indicators for Cat A delivery).
Spinal
ED50 for heavy bup is 6-8mg = 1.2 – 1.6mL usual dose far exceeds (usually 10-12mg)
*Neither weight nor height affect block extension except for extremes of height
SSS doses associated with hypotension, nausea & vomiting
SSS failure: <1%, reasonable to try 1mL repeat + CSE (otherwise GA)
High spinal: ~0.2%
Intrathecal morphine: 100mcg – good balance between analgesia + side effects. No effect shown on APGARs or foetal pH.
No other neuraxial adjuncts are recommended for routine CS.
Note: evidence for association between intrathecal / epidural morphine and reactivation of herpes
Incidence of extreme hypotension i.e. systolic pressure <75% of baseline is 38%. Significant maternal hypotension is greater with
SSS cf epidural. Must be anticipated and prevented.
Management:
Left uterine displacement (15 degree tilt)
Fluids
Pressors: phenylephrine > ephedrine – less foetal acidosis (2’ less foetal transfer)
Must know baseline BP (should be taken prior to OT) and aim to maintain BP at ≥90% baseline
Management of Suboptimal Block
Pre-op:
Assess: pain versus sensation versus nausea versus other
Manipulate position i.e trendelenberg v lateral
Repeat spinal if urgency permits
GARNER: whole dose if NO block, reduced dose 1-1.5mL if <T12, consider CSE
Versus predetermined upper dose
Always offer GA
Intra-op:
Inadequate block at any stage – inform surgeon and stop if able
Reassure patient and support person
Pre-delivery:
Top-up epidural with LA or opioid
N2O + short acting opioid e.g. alfentanil – notify paediatrician
Offer GA
After-delivery:
As above
Can consider ketamine IV 10mg aliquots
Topical LA infiltration into wound if dose allows
After procedure:
Always debrief patient and surgeon
Consider causes

title: General Anaesthesia for Caesarean
text:
General Anaesthesia for Caesarean
C-sections ~25% all births. Maternal mortality is 10x higher in Caesarean section versus vaginal delivery (many confounders).
Indications: foetal malpresentation, foetal distress, labour dystocia, prior c-section, maternal request, failed neuraxial, skin
infection over neuraxial site, intra-op complication
Considerations:
Airway:
↑Mallampati w/ gestation 2’ airway oedema (RASS, worsened by hypertension + post-pushing) +/- pregnancy
weight gain +/- breast tissue
Nasal capillary engorgement → vasculature becomes friable – nasal intubation should be avoided
Failed intubation: 1/400 (used to be 1/250 pre-VL) – 10x failed intubation rate cf non-pregnant population
RPA CICO - 1/40,000
Ramp + pre-oxygnate to ETO2 >0.9
Breathing:
↓FRC (↓20% erect, ↓30% supine) – closing col unchanged but ↓FRC → airway closure in 50% in supine position
↑O2 consumption 60% + ↓FRC → rapid desats
Circulation:
Response to laryngoscopy – must blunt in hypertensive disorders
Drugs:
pseudocholinesterase by 30% from 10/40 until 6/52 post-partum
plasma proteins / albumin → serum levels of highly protein-bound Rx
Ketamine can cause uterine tone + uterine arterial perfusion
Suxamethonium not detected in umbi cord unless dose >2mg/kg (requires 10mg/kg for any neonatal blockade)
Magnesium (esp high dose infusions) potentiate non-depolarising NMB
Other:
GI: ↓lower oesophageal sphincter tone regardless of labour or not → ↑risk of aspiration (up to 15% mortality)
BIS: awareness 1/670
Positioning:
Measures to minimise risk of injury
L tilt 15: no change in foetal acid-base status cf supine, however tilt → CO and requirement for phenylephrine
Consider risks: aspiration, difficult airway, hypertension to laryngoscopy, awareness, reduced t/f to foetus, passive pressure circ
Quantify:
Significant aspiration in induction – incidence 1/5,000 – mortality rate ~15%
Failed intubation: 1/400 (used to be 1/250 pre-VL) – 10x failed intubation rate cf non-pregnant population (RPA CICO -
1/40,000)
Awareness: 1/19,000 for all GAs versus 1/670 for C-sections (risk  in improper monitoring, inexperienced provider,
emergent setting, patient obesity)
Optimise:
Pre-op non-particulate antacid
Notify paediatric/neonatal team if emergency GA (note: Cochrane review showed no difference between APGAR scores +
need for neonatal O2 between regional + GA for uncomplicated non-emergent Caesars)
Anaesthetic plan:
Induction:
Ramped + abducted arms, L tilt 15
BIS monitoring
High flow + RSI with cricoid, VL always first go +/- Xblade stylet, back-up auragain available, ETT 6.0-7.0 cuffed
Failed intubation → auragain LMA + gastric tube down port + fundal pressure on delivery
Propofol 2mg/kg + sevo/N2O + suxamethonium 1.5mg/kg
Maintenance:
Volatile → propofol infusion (improve atony) + MAC 0.3
Do not re-paralyse until evidence of NMJ recovery post-sux
Halogenated anaesthesia reduce to <0.5MAC post-delivery to reduce atony
Emergence:
Must use neuromuscular monitoring, sugammadex reasonable
Disposition: specialised ward with PCA obs if IT morphine used

title: ERAS for Caesarean Section
text:
ERAS for Caesarean Section
Pre-op:
•
Antenatal care: obesity, diabetes, hypertensive disorders, anaemia, smoking
•
LSCS without medical indication should not be suggested
•
Antacid prophylaxis
•
Avoid sedation
•
Minimise fasting (6 hours) + carbohydrate fluid supplementation until 2 hrs prior (unless diabetic)
•
Pre-admission counselling
•
No bowel prep
•
Shower with antimicrobial soap (chlorhex-alc > pov iodine)
Intra-op:
•
Antimicrobial prophylaxis (30 – 60 mins prior to skin incision)
•
Skin + vaginal prep (chlorhex skin, pov-iodine vagina)
•
Regional anaesthesia preferred method
•
Avoid hypothermia <36C (forced air, fluid warmer, increased OT temp >23C)
•
Target euvolaemia
•
Surgical:
o
Blunt hysterotomy (bleeding)
o
Hysterotomy closure in 2 layers
o
No peritoneal closure
o
Tissue reapproximation
o
Skin closure with subcuticular sutures
o
Joel Cohen > Pfannenstiel (surgical time, blood loss + need for analgesics)
•
Neonate: delayed cord clamping for at least 1 min at term delivery (30s for preterm)
Post-op:
•
PONV: minimise intra-op hypotension + anti-emetic prophylaxis
•
Analgesia: multimodal
•
Diet: regular within 2 hours, chewing gum may help time to first flatus / bowel motion if delayed
•
BSL: normoglycaemia
•
VTE: compression stockings (TEDS / SCDS), heparin not routine, early mobilisation
•
IDC: remove at end of surgery (no evidence yet of bladder damage from urinary retention)
•
Discharge counselling
Vasopressor comparison:
•
