Noradrenaline versus phenylephrine
o
Less bradycardia
o
Higher CO
o
No difference: hypotension, foetal acidosis, APGARS, N&V
•
Phenylephrine versus ephedrine
o
Less N&V
o
Less foetal acidosis
o
More bradycardia

title: Post-Partum Headache
text:
Post-Partum Headache
Within 6 weeks.
Condition
Acute Ischaemic
Stroke
Intracerebral
Haemorrhage
Central Venous
Sinus Thrombosis
Reversible Cerebral
Vasoconstriction
PRES
Onset
Anytime during +
postpartum
Anytime during +
postpartum
3rd trimester,
postpartum
Postpartum
(abrupt)
Postpartum
(rapid – hours)
SSx
Focal neurology
Pain in 10%
Thunderclap
headache, LOC,
focal neurology
Headache, seizures,
focal neurology
Thunderclap
headache, transient
focal deficit,
seizures
Seizures, dull
headache, visual
disturbance
Imaging
CT/MRI – sensitive
CT
CT venogram
Usually normal CT
Vasogenic oedema
in occipitoparietal
regions
Rx
Thrombolysis,
anticoagulation
Supportive,
intervention or
coiling/clipping
Anticoagulation,
seizure control
CCB, triple H,
seizure control
Seizure control, BP
control
Dural Puncture Headache
CSF leak → vascular hyperaemia, migraine physiology + traction on pain sensitive fibres
Assess:
•
History: SOCRATES
•
Characteristics:
o
Usually bilateral, frontal, occipital
o
Worse when upright, relieved lying down
o
Associated neck stiffness, photophobia, nausea, tinnitus
•
Risk factors: multiple punctures, needle size, patient
o
High risk: risk with preventative morphine or aminophylline (L1)
•
Examination
•
Red flags: fevers, worsening back pain, neurology
o
Imaging i.e. CT/MRI
•
Incidence is by smaller gauge spinal or non-cutting bevel needles (or by orienting cutting bevel parallel to spinal
sagittal plane (L1)
Manage:
•
Conservative:
o
Euvolaemia (no evidence for hypervolaemia)
o
Caffeine
o
Lying flat
•
Pharmacological:
o
Simple analgesia
o
Caffeine, gabapentin, hydrocort and theophylline are effective treatments for PDPH (L1)
▪
Caution caffeine in breastfeeding
*Avoid dexamethasone → risk of PDPH (L1)
•
Interventional: epidural blood patch (> conservative or sham L1)
Epidural Blood Patch
If evidence of CN involvement e.g. diplopia → perform immediately. Otherwise if symptoms limit activity.
Note: c/o muffled hearing is common – not 2’ CN involvement but 2’ middle ear pressure (middle ear fluid connected to CSF)
Must lie flat for 2hr post. Avoid heavy lifting for 24hr.
Timing: effectiveness if >48 hours after dural puncture (<48 hours → rate of 2nd EBP)
Complications: back pain (35%), recurrence of headache (30%), subdural haematoma, facial n. palsy, intrathecal injection,
arachnoiditis, infection / abscess, spastic paraparesis, cauda equina syndrome, transient bradycardia

title: Sepsis
text:
Sepsis
Two or more of:
•
T >38 or T <36
•
HR >100bpm (>90 if not pregnant)
•
RR >20
•
WCC >17 (12 if not pregnant) or <4
= SIRS
Puerperal sepsis: GUT from labour until 42 days post-partum
Principle organisms: Strep pneumoniase, E coli, rarely Group A Strep (Strep pyogenes)
RFs: C-section, obesity
Management: hydration + early abx (<1hr)
Regional anaesthesia: generally CI in septic hypotensive pts, may have associated coagulopathy, small risk of epidural abscess /
meningitis – can consider if responding to abx
GA: highly likely to be required
Caution oxytocin boluses

title: Amniotic Fluid Embolism
text:
Amniotic Fluid Embolism
1 – 7 / 100,000. Fatality 20%. Neonatal mortality 40%.
Mechanical + immune theory. No sig in serum mast cell tryptases. Diagnosis of exclusion.
Phases:
•
1: initial entry – 30 min
o
PAP + RHF
o
Microvascular damage
o
Hypotension
o
DIC
•
2: progression
o
LV failure (risk by meconium in amniotic fluid)
o
Endothelial activation + leakage
o
DIC
Diagnosis: UKOSS
•
Absence of other cause
•
Post-mortem finding of foetal squamous / hair in lungs (can also be present in healthy normal women)
•
Acute maternal collapse with ≥1 of:
o
Acute foetal compromise
o
Cardiac arrest
o
Arrhythmia
o
Coagulopathy
o
Hypotension
o
Haemorrhage (exclude first)
o
Premonitory symptoms
o
Seizure
o
SOB
•
Timing: 70% labour, 19% C-section, 11% post-vaginal delivery
•
SSx: hypotension (100%), foetal distress (100%), APO/ARDS (93%), cardiac arrest (87%), cyanosis (83%), coagulopathy
(83%) + others
•
Ix: are no aid in diagnosis but aid in severity – full bloods including viscoelastic, ECG, TTE
•
Biomarkers:
o
Low C3/C4 complement
o
Zinc coproporphyrin & sialyl-Tn antigen (components of meconium and amniotic fluid)
o
Insulin-like growth factor binding protein 1
•
Histology: foetal squamous / hair
Supportive management

title: Post-Natal Neurology
text:
Post-Natal Neurology
Labour causes majority of injuries, not neuraxial.
Mechanisms:
Mechanical – stretch, compression, transection
Ischaemic, infective
Needle
Intraneural injection
Adhesive arachnoiditis, aseptic meningitis
NAP 3 findings:
Overall:
Permanent injury
1/24,000 – 54,000
Paraplegia / death
1/50,000 – 140,000
Obstetric:
Permanent harm
1/80,000 – 320,000
Spinal
1/67,000 – 100,000
Epidural
1/161,000
CSE
1/25,000
Direct spinal cord damage is exceedingly rare as procedures are generally performed below conus medullaris. In a small
group of patients with unintentionally high injections a spinal syrinx formed → all described pain on injection, if
patients complain of pain on injection stop immediately.
Neuropraxia following childbirth 1/2000
Intrinsic Obstetric Palsies
Incidence 1%.
RFs: prolonged 2nd stage, forceps delivery, primiparity, lithotomy position, diabetes, lumbar lordosis, obesity, increased intra-
abdominal pressure
Usual duration 6 weeks – 2 months.
Syndromes:
Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve: meralgia parasthetica (2’ extreme hip flexion)
Lumbosacral trunk: foot drop + sensation to lateral lower leg / dorsal foot
Femoral nerve: inability to climb stairs, knee jerk, femoral sensory loss
Obturator nerve: inner thigh sensation, weak hip adduction / rotation
Peroneal nerve: sensory loss
Investigation:
Hx: pre-existing neuro deficits, bowel / bladder / saddle parasthesia, back pain, fevers, symptom progression
Examination: full lower limb motor + sensory, ?bilateral v unilateral, presence of fever + tachycardia, inspect puncture site
Ix: WCC, CRP, MRI spine, NCS / EMG
Referral: neurology, neurosurgery
Red flags: bilateral symptoms, progressive worsening, motor deficit, fever, back pain, bowel / bladder dysfunction, saddle
parasthesia, coagulopathy

title: Premature Labour
text:
Premature Labour
Labour between 20 – 37 weeks. 10%.
RFs: previous, multiple gestation, infection, abnormal placentation, cervical incompetence, smoking, age <15 or >40, PPROM,
induction for obstetric reasons
Management:
Tocolysis: salbutamol, terbutaline, nifedipine, GTN, atosiban
Delay delivery for foetal lung maturation if <34 weeks
<34/40 betamethasone 2x doses q12 hr – aim to deliver >24 hr after 1st dose
<3/40 magnesium sulfate infusion for neuroprotection (cerebral palsy) – 4g loading over 20 mins → 1g/hr until delivery
NICU referral
GBS antibiotics

title: Multiple Gestation
text:
Multiple Gestation
Incidence: 4 in 1000 ( 2’ ART) - terminology:
Monozygotic: single fertilised ovum
Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) – deliver at 32 – 34 weeks
Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) – deliver at 34 – 36 weeks
Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) – deliver at 38 - 39 weeks
RFs: IVF, AMA, race, parity, FHx, obesity
Maternal physiology: → exaggerated resp + CVS changes
Resp: larger gravid uterus → TLC, FRC, IAP + regurgitation, breast size, MV
CVS: plasma volume (by 400mL), dilutional anaemia, CO, aortocaval compression
Neuro: LA sensitivity (but may not need dose)
Complications: higher rates of every complication except post-term delivery and macrosomia
Foetal: preterm delivery, congenital abnormality, polyhydramnios, cord entanglement, cord prolapse (2nd twin), IUGR
Monochorionic complications only: (monochorionic is highest risk)
Twin-twin transfusion syndrome
Twin anaemia polycythaemia sequence
Twin reversed antenatal perfusion sequence
Management:
Expectant
Foetoscopic laser ablation of anastomotic vessels
Amnioreduction
Selective foetal reduction
Early delivery
Monoamniotic complications:
Cord entanglement → foetal death
Conjoined
Maternal: all cause morbidity and mortality, PPROM, PROM, prolonged labour, HTN +/- PET, GDM ( severity and worse
aspiration), placental abruption, placenta praevia, DIC, operative delivery, atony / PPH, obstetric trauma
ECV is contraindicated due to risk of placental abruption and cord prolapse
anaesthetic intervention rate
Management:
Early epidural (facilitates vaginal delivery e.g. external / internal cephalic version)
CTG monitoring of both twins
50% c-section rate
2nd twin may require internal podalic version (tocolysis with GTN)
Twin birth study: no difference in outcomes with C-section versus vaginal delivery if 1st is cephalic (2nd twin has 10% c-section
rate mostly due to malpresentation) between 32 – 39 weeks
Most obstetric providers prefer C-section for triplet delivery or higher, however no formal recommendations are in place –
should be based on discussion with patient and care team’s ability / experience

title: Breech
text:
Breech
Foetal buttocks or lower limbs are presenting part. Incidence is 25% at 28/40, reduced to 4% by term.
Types:
Frank: flexed hip, extended knee
Complete: flexed hip & knee
Footling: incomplete
Risks:
Maternal: abruption, rupture of membranes, need for emergent delivery
Foetal: foetal bradycardia, perinatal mortality (2/1000), stillbirth >39 weeks though no long term morbidity
External Cephalic Version
May be rotated by ECV.
CI:
Absolute: LSCS required for other reason, APH, abnormal CTG, uterine abnormality, ruptured membranes, multiple
pregnancy
Relative: SGA, abnormal dopplers, PET, oligohydramnios, major foetal abnormality, scarred uterus, unstable lie
Analgesia for procedure:
Neuraxial anaesthesia associated with higher success rate (60% v 40%) 2’ relaxation of abdominal wall
Optimal dose unknown – should take into account hypotension + block level in event of urgent C-section
CSE good option – lower dose spinal with catheter in situ if required
Remifentanil infusion
NO2 – not supported in literature
Need to give tocolysis terbutaline 250mcg s/c 15 – 30 mins prior +/- GTN → monitor FHR + consider anti-D
Success rate overall ~60%, complication rate 6% (foetal bradycardia, PV bleed, ruptured membranes, abruption, maternal-foetal
transfusion, emergency CS, perinatal mortality).
Anaesthesia provider must be immediately available. Higher order pregnancies usually delivered by caesarean due to risk of cord
entanglement and possibility of head entrapment.

title: Assisted Vaginal Birth
text:
Assisted Vaginal Birth
Forceps or vacuum.
Indications:
Failure to progress to 2nd stage
Maternal exhaustion
Cardiac disease (to reduce maternal pushing)
Foetal distress
Location: labour floor v OT
Low-dose epidural analgesia may be inadequate.
Neuraxial options:
Epidural: lignocaine 1-2% 5-10mL
CSE: good option in event of C-section
Spinal: sufficient dose for C-section
Pudendal block S2-S4: can assist in second stage of labour, at discretion of obstetric team
Complications: uterine atony, PPH, peroneal injury / repair

title: Abnormal Placental Implantation
text:
Abnormal Placental Implantation
Placenta Praevia
Placenta praevia: placental tissue close to or over internal cervical os. Incidence 0.5%.
RFs: advanced maternal age, assisted pregnancy, multiparity, prior placenta praevia, or uterine scarring from infection or prior
surgery.
Diagnosis: US
Classification:
Minor:
Grade 1: lower segment but not os
Grade 2: reaches but not covers os
Major:
Grade 3: eccentrically covers os
Grade 4: centrally covers os
Need to know anterior or posterior.
Accounts for 15-20% of all APH:
30% prior to 30 weeks
30% 30 – 36 weeks
30% after 36 weeks
Only 10% have nil bleed
Requires C-section unless resolves prior to delivery.
Complications:
Maternal: APH / PPH, blood transfusion, morbidity / mortality
Neonatal: preterm birth, NICU, death
Management:
Monitor position with US
Exclude accrete
Avoid PV exam / speculum / sexual activity
Avoid strenuous activity
Steroids +/- MgSO4 +/- inpatient monitoring
Caesarean planned delivery
Placenta Accreta Spectrum
Incidence 0.04% of all pregnancies.
3 subtypes:
Accreta vera: 80% - abnormal adherence to myometrium with absent decidual line of separation
Increta: 15% - abnormal implantation and growth of placenta into myometrium
Percreta: 5% - growth of placenta through uterine wall with placental implantation onto other tissues which may include
bladder, bowel, ovaries or other organs
RFs: previous CS, myomectomy, curette, hysteroscopy, endometrial ablation, placenta praevia, IVF, asherman’s, multip, AMA
Diagnosis:
US:
Placental lacunae (lakes)
Uterine-bladder or uteroplacental interface abnormality
Myometrium 1mm thick
MRI:
Dark intraplacental bands (T2)
Disruption between uterus and placenta
Abnormal placental bulging
Assessment:
Pre-op review (routine obstetric + tailored) + counselling with partner / support person
Discuss need for GA or regional
Know exact placental location

title: Cord Prolapse
text:
Management:
Careful timing of delivery (35 – 36+6 weeks)
Elective CS in appropriate facility: blood bank, cell salvage, rapid transfusion capability, high volume centre, ICU, IR
Consider hybrid OT/IR – no evidence for pre-op balloons, consider sheaths
Correct anaemia / iron deficiency
Steroid cover if <36/40
Intra-op:
Neuraxial v GA based on surgical plan / predicted time, risk of bleeding, maternal preference, known difficult airway
Surgical options:
Hysterotomy with attempted placental separation
Classical hysterotomy
Pre-emptive vascular occlusion of IA with balloon catheters (→ blood loss + hysterectomy rate)
Ovarian a. is also important supply
REBOA (resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion of aorta)
Hysterectomy
IR embolization
Management of PPH (usual + →)
Quantitative blood loss methods e.g. calibrated under buttocks v drape
Note: expert consensus supports avoidance of prophylactic uterotonic drugs unless placental removal/separation
with atonic bleeding – use of uterotonics is a collaborative decision
Cell salvage (safe)
Post-op: may require ICU, VTE prophylaxis, monitor for anaemia / volume overload / PPH / organ dysfunction
Complications: mortality (maternal), PPH (+ coagulopathy, anaemia), AKI, hysterectomy
May require pre-op iliac balloons or selective embolization +/- hysterectomy.

title: Vasa Praevia
text:
Vasa Praevia
Vessels are adherent to membranes over the cervical os and can be torn open with cervical dilatation. Incidence 0.04%.
Significant foetal morbidity and mortality if not diagnosed antenatally.If diagnosed antenatally usually planned for C-section at
36 weeks with steroid cover. If bleeding → obstetric emergency requiring C-section under GA.

title: Cord Prolapse
text:
Cord Prolapse
Incidence 0.5%. Obstetric emergency. ~50% of cases caused by obstetric intervention.
Descent of umbilical cord through cervix:
Occult: alongside foetus
Overt: visualisation or palpation of cord in vaginal canal below presenting foetal part
May occur at rupture of membranes if abnormal foetal position or polyhydramnios
Risks: LBW, transverse/unstable lie, breech, multiple gestations (specifically 2nd twin), abnormally long umbilical cord, low lying
placenta, ARM with high presenting part, unengaged presenting part, ECV, transcervical balloon >180mL
*Elective admission at 37 weeks for women with breech/unstable/transverse lie should be offered – must present to hospital
immediately if signs of labour
SSx: abrupt prolonged foetal bradycardia
Management:
Reduce cord pressure / intrauterine ressucitation:
Manual pressure for cord inside uterus (avoid handling cord to avoid vasospasmF, pressure on presenting part)
Steep head down
Tocolysis
Fill bladder
Knee to chest or lateral position
Immediate delivery: vaginal if possible / imminent → emergency C-section if not or CTG abnormal
Neonatal resus: staff + equipment
Anaesthetic: top up epidural if in and working, usually GA as fastest decision-to-delivery interval

title: Shoulder Dystocia
text:
Shoulder Dystocia
After delivery of head anterior or posterior should impacts on maternal pelvis or sacral promontory – obstetric emergency
Risk factors: prolonged gestation, labour induction, obesity, high foetal weight, prolonged dilatation from 8-10cm, and epidural
analgesia (this is just an association) – however epidural provides superior conditions for infant rescue
Management:
McRoberts manoeuvre: mother’s legs flexed and pushed tightly to abdomen + suprapubic pressure
Deliver posterior arm → rest of baby
Internal rotation
Gaskin manoeuvre: mother on hands and knees (may not be possible with epidural)
Cleidotomy
Symphysiotomy
If above unsuccessful → foetus pushed back in (Zavanelli manoeuvre) + proceed to emergency C-section
Shoulder dystocia → ↑risk of PPH + fourth degree tears
Neonatal risk: HIE, mortality, brachial plexus injury

title: Uterine Rupture
text:
Uterine Rupture
Encompasses scar dehiscence to complete uterine wall rupture.
Risk factors: VBAC (1% of all VBACs), foetal malposition, instrumental delivery, macrosomia, excessive oxytocin administration,
rapid delivery, trauma + tumour, myometrial wall thickness <2.1mm
Typical presentation: foetal bradycardia (most reliable sign), cessation of uterine contractions, abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding,
loss of station (foetal head away from pelvis)
Management:
Emergency laparotomy and delivery of foetus → repair +/- arterial ligation +/- hysterectomy
Massive haemorrhage management
RSI + ETT
Post op ICU
VBAC
Ideal interpregnancy interval >18 months. Success rate 60-80%.
Benefits: less post-partum pain, faster return to function, lower risk of future placental issues, LOS, patient satisfaction
Risks: failure (25%), uterine rupture (0.5%) +/- transfusion +/- hysterectomy, foetal demise / morbidity, HIE, pelvic floor trauma
CIs: previous uterine rupture, classical incision, full thickness myomectomy, >2 previous C-sections, CIs to vaginal delivery (i.e.
abnormal placental implantation / location, untreated HIV / HSV)
Variables:
Favour success: previous VBAC, previous vaginal birth, 1 prior CS, spontaneous labour, low risk pregnancy
Do not favour success: IOL, ≥2 CS, obesity, macrosomia, AMA, comorbidity, >41/40
Management:
Appropriate facility with immediate help available
Continuous CTG monitoring
Preparation for haemorrhage management i.e. 2x large bore access + G&H
Frequent assessment of progress of labour
Analgesia: epidural is beneficial (able to top up quickly), though no effect on success of VBAC, no effect on rupture
presentation

title: Uterine Inversion
text:
Uterine Inversion
Passage of uterus through cervix. Incidence 0.04%. Associated with hypotension, pain, severe PPH.
Risks: excessive cord traction prior to placental separation, uterine atony, placenta at fundus, presence of placenta accreta.
Rx:
Discontinue uterotonics (relaxation of uterus) +/- GTN or volatile anaesthesia
Maternal resus
Replacement of uterus
Uterine contraction after replacement to reduce haemorrhage
If GA required RSI with volatile → propofol TIVA post-replacement

title: Foetal Death in Utero
text:
Foetal Death in Utero
No specific cause in 50%.
Assess for: sepsis, coagulopathy / DIC, anti-D requirement, PET, bleeding (e.g. abruption), psychosocial
Management:
Expectant: most spont labour within 3 weeks
Induction: recommended
Caesarean
Up to maternal preference
Goals of care:
Single room way from labouring women
Accommodate emotional and social needs including bed for partner, experienced midwife, social work
Investigate and manage complications: PET, sepsis, DIC, bleeding + all maternal complications
Analgesia: neuraxial if not CI (DIC/sepsis) or PCA
Afterwards:
Counselling
Social work
Culturally sensitive care
Debriefing (staff also)
Post-mortem testing if indicated
Follow up

title: Sepsis
text:
Sepsis
Two or more of: T >38 or T <36, HR >100bpm (>90 if not pregnant), RR >20, WCC >17 (12 if not pregnant) or <4 = SIRS
Severe sepsis is associated with organ dysfunction.
Puerperal sepsis: infection of genital tract occurring at any time from labour/ROM until 42 days post-partum associated with two
of – pelvic pain, fever, abnormal discharge, abnormal smell of discharge, delay in reduction of uterine size
Principle organisms: Strep pneumoniase, E coli, rarely Group A Strep (Strep pyogenes)
RFs: C-section, obesity
Management: hydration + early abx (<1hr)
Regional anaesthesia: generally CI in septic hypotensive pts, may have associated coagulopathy, small risk of epidural abscess /
meningitis – can consider if responding to abx
GA: highly likely to be required
Caution oxytocin boluses

section_path: Diagnosis and Management of Maternal Collapse
title: Diagnosis and Management of Maternal Collapse
text:
Diagnosis and Management of Maternal Collapse
Maternal collapse: acute event involving cardiorespiratory systems and/or central nervous systems → or absent conscious
level (and potentially cardiac arrest and death) at any stage in pregnancy up to 6 weeks post-partum.

title: Advanced Life Support in Pregnancy
text:
Advanced Life Support in Pregnancy
Similar to adult ALS +: (no alteration in drugs /doses or defib charge) – pads may need to be placed AP
Left manual displacement of uterus after 20/40
Compressions higher on chest
IV access ABOVE diaphragm
Early intubation – cricoid if enough people are present
No ROSC after 4 mins prepare for peri-mortem caesarean by 5 mins (only necessary equipment is scalpel + 2x cord clamps)
Maternal survival: 61% versus 35% by 5 mins
Neonatal survival: 96% versus 70% by 5 mins
Survival at site of collapse: 72% versus 36%
4 Hs + 4 Ts; obstetric specific causes →
Hypovolaemia
Bleeding: obstetric + non-obstetric, always consider possibility of concealed bleeding i.e. abruption, splenic a.,
hepatic a.
Sepsis
High spinal
Supine hypotension / aortocaval compression can precipitate maternal collapse
Hypoxia
PET → pulmonary oedema
PPCM
MI
Aortic dissection
Hypo/hyperkalaemia
Hypothermia
Thromboembolism
VTE/PE
AFE
Air embolism
MI
Toxicity
LAST (has been associated with TAP blocks – concentration should be no greater than 0.25% with adrenaline – no
more than 20mL each side. Should use US and aspirate frequently)
Magnesium
Illicit drug use
Anaphylaxis
Tension pneumothorax
Tamponade
Aortic dissection
Obstetric specific:
Anaesthesia: high / total spinal, anaphylaxis, airway complication, LAST
Obstetric: PET, ICH
Consider TOE
Early ECMO referral
Clinical governance: accurate documentation, incident form, continued ALS training with obstetric specific scenarios

title: Major Obstetric Haemorrhage
text:
Major Obstetric Haemorrhage
Type
Gestation / Timing
Volume
Causes
Early
1st and 2nd trimester
<24/40 weeks
Any
Ectopic, miscarriage, septic miscarriage
Antepartum
(Incidence 3-5%)
≥24/40 - delivery
Major: 50-1000mL without signs of shock
Massive: ≥1000mL and/or bleeding of any
volume with clinical signs of shock
Abruption 33%
Praevia 33%
Other 33%
Postpartum
Primary: within 24
hours of delivery
Secondary: 24hr – 12
weeks post-
delivery
No agreed upon volumes for PPH - WHO
≥500mL.
RANZCOG: severe >1000mL or SSx HD
instability regardless of volume
4Ts:
Tone 80%
Trauma (CS, epis, assisted delivery, LGA,
rupture)
Tissue
Thrombus (congenital / acquired)
RFs: previous PPH, placental abnormality, multiple pregnancy, polyhydramnios, chorioamnionitis, Asian, obesity, prolonged
labour/short labour, primip >40
Pathophysiology: uteroplacental unit = high-flow, low resistance and receives 25% CO.
Management:
Follow department PPH protocol
Priorities: lateral if antepartum, 2x large bore access, bloods (FBC, EUC, LFTs, coags + fibrinogen, blood gas, group & cross
match), keep patient warm, alert blood bank (O neg / uncrossmatched type specific / crossmatched), correct underlying
cause simultaneously
Low fibrinogen levels are an independent risk factor for development of severe PPH – one study showed fibrinogen <2g/L →
100% PPV for development of severe PPH.
Goals: correct volume, anaemia (to improve O2 delivery + acidosis/lactataemia), coagulopathy
Therapy:
Tone
Surgical:
Uterine massage
Intra-uterine balloon tamponade (i.e. Bakri)
Uterine compression sutures (e.g. B-lynch)
IR embolization / catheter balloon occlusion (radiation exposure)
Ligation of pelvic vessels: iliacs, uterine, hypogastric, ovarian
Uterine a. ligation - no major effects on fertility, only effective in 50% of cases
Hysterectomy
Medical
Oxytocin (after 17/40)
PPH: vaginal 5iu slowly, C-section 3iu over 30s
(both followed by infusion)
Ergometrine 250mcg IM + IV
Carboprost 250mcg IM q15 min x 8
Misoprostal 400-1000mcg PR
Thrombin
TxA 1g → another 1g at 30 min if still bleeding
Early cryoprecipitate (target fibrinogen >2.0)
iCa >1
Keep warm T >36
Correct acidosis pH >7.2
Platelets >100 if bleeding ongoing
Blood products 1:1:1 with early cryo (MTP versus goal-directed depends on stability of patient)
Viscoelastic testing:
Detects well: low fibrinogen, decreased plt fx, fibrinolysis, factor deficiency
Detects poorly: VWD, drug effects (e.g. aspirin, warfarin, NOAC)
Consider cell salvage - leukocyte reduction filter → removal of tissue factor, a-foetoprotein, fetal squamous cells,
bacteria and other contaminants → risk of AFE
Targets during haemorrhage: fibrinogen >2, PT & aPTT 1.5x normal, plt >75
Trauma / tissue → surgical management
If parturient is Rh -ve give anti-D as soon as able + Kleihauer-Betke testing to prevent alloimmunisation

title: Uterotonics
text:
TxA: no risk VTE, but seizure threshold
WOMAN trial:
1g over 10 mins versus placebo
2nd dose if still bleeding at 30 mins or re-bleed within 24hr
Significant: death due to bleeding if within 3 hrs, after 3 hrs
No difference:
Composite of all-cause mortality or hysterectomy
Complications e.g. VTE, CVA, MI
Surgical intervention
TRAAP2: routine TXA for LSCS, some issues with reported vs calculated blood loss, no difference in transfusion or pre- &
post-Hb, ↑N&V with TXA
CIs: active VTE, significant renal disease, subarachnoid haemorrhage
Uterine Tone
Risks factors: chorioamnionitis, labour augmentation, high parity, macrosomia, multiple births, prolonged labour, retained
products, volatile anaesthetics, magnesium, terbutaline
Non-Pharmacological
Mechanism
Adverse Effects
Uterine massage
Pressure and movement on uterus
Nil adverse though may not be effective
Time-consuming
Bimanual compression
Closed fist into vagina and hand on
abdominal wall
Low quality – only weak recommendations
Minimal actual adverse effects though may not work and
only temporising
Uterotonics
Drug
Mechanism
Adverse Effects
Oxytocin
Elective: 1iu bolus → infusion
(repeat 3iu slowly if required
after 2 mins)
Intrapartum: 3iu slowly (some
desensitisation if augmented
labour) → infusion
Oxytocin-R (Gq GPCR) →
↑IP3 / DAG → ↑[uterine SM
intracellular Ca2+] →
contraction (synthetic
analogue of endogenous
posterior pituitary hormone)
Hypotension, tachycardia, ST depression
Mild ADH effect
↓uterine blood flow may cause foetal distress
Recommend 1st line PPH though no RCTs
Adverse outcomes increase with bolus doses >1iu
If oxytocin/carbetocin fail to produce uterine tone →
consider second uterotonic early
Carbetocin
100mcg (= 5iu of oxytocin)
½ life of 40 mins
Synthetic oxytocin analogue
but chemical structure makes
it less susceptible to
metabolism
Same as oxytocin
Carbetocin > oxytocin in Cochrane review for avoiding
severe PPH + required less uterine massage
Oxytocin + carbetocin are CI in PET as they can cause
↓CO (however studies have shown no major adverse
effect)
Ergometrine
250mcg IM +/- 250mcg IV (can
rpt after 2 hr)
½ life 30-120 mins
Ergoid alkaloid – agonist at
α1, 5HT and dopamine
receptors → vasoconstriction
and SM contraction
N + V ++++ (D2-R in CTZ)
Vasoconstriction → ↑MAP + ↑pulmonary HTN
Coronary vasospasm
May cause placental retention if not delivered
CI: PET, pulmonary HTN, IHD, intracardiac shunt,
aortopathy / aneurysms
Carboprost
250mcg IM q15 min x 8
Synthetic PGF2α → ↑uterine
tone
Bronchospasm
↑pulmonary hypertension (can ↑PVR by >100%)
N&V
CI: asthma, fontan’s, pulmonary HTN, intracardiac shunt,
RHF
Misoprostal
400-600mcg rpt after 15 mins if
required (max dose 800mcg)
Synthetic PGE1 → ↑uterine
tone
Not as effective as others – co-uterotonic
Causes fever (can be difficult to discern if infection)
Safe in all patients
Vasopressin also a uterotonic.

title: Management of Obstetric Trauma Patient
text:
Management of Obstetric Trauma Patient
Must consider:
Altered maternal physiology
Maternal resus is always first priority
Early PC to obs + neonatology (+ clarify gestation)
Rh therapy to Rh negative mothers
Assign roles:
Left uterine displacement
FHR assessment
Resuscitative hysterotomy team
Neonatal resus team
Primary survey:
C-spine immobilisation / MILS
A:
High risk of aspiration
difficult airway
30 degrees head up (lower FRC, higher VO2) – use apnoeic oxygenation (must use <15L/min if possible BOS #)
Avoid nasal / blind intubation (friable, oedematous tissue)
FONA → longitudinal incision
B:
Target SpO2 >94%, PaCO2 30-35
Place chest tubes 1-2 spaces higher due to cephalad displacement of diaphragm
C:
Left uterine displacement >20/40
Secure IV access above diaphragm (caval compression may reduce circulation)
Bloods (check for foetal maternal haemorrhage)
Kleihauer-Betke test to calculate anti-D dose
Resuscitative hysterotomy started at 4 mins of arrest, completed by 5 minutes
D: damage control surgery → indications to empty the uterus:
Penetrating uterine injury
Placental abruption
Uterine rupture
Surgical access to pelvis for haemorrhage control
Maternal cardiac arrest
FDIU
E:
Everything else including massive haemorrhage management
Ratio 1:1:1: request CMV -ve RBCs and platelets irrespective of patient’s CMV status
Early cryo/fibrinogen
PV examination for blood loss
Trauma CT series is not contraindicated in pregnancy – risk to foetus from single CT scan is low
eFAST increasingly limited with increasing gestation
F: foetal monitoring (CTG) for 4 hours, longer if:
Contractions >1 in 10
Uterine tenderness
Abdominal pain
Ruptured membranes
PV bleeding
Positive KB test
Non-reassuring FHR

title: Aortocaval Compression
text:
Aortocaval Compression
Occurs in nearly all term parturients. Only 10% of women suffer supine hypotension syndrome: MAP by 15mmHg + HR by
20bpm (+/- diaphoresis, nausea, changes in mentation). Return of blood from lower extremities via epidural veins, azygos, and
vertebral veins. Left uterine displacement recently challenged – MRI shown no change in IVC volume with 15 L tilt (however
there is an increase with 30).

title: Placental Abruption
text:
Placental Abruption
Placental abruption: partial or complete separation of the placenta from the uterine wall after 20/40.
~1% all pregnancies. Accounts for 25% of APH.
Risk factors: advanced maternal age, chorioamnionitis, cocaine use, excessive alcohol, hypertension, premature rupture of
membranes, history of abruption, smoking and trauma.
SSx: vaginal bleeding + uterine tenderness on examination.
Remember bleeding can be concealed. Foetal distress if >30%. Beware coagulopathy.
Uterine monitoring.

title: Perimortem Caesarean
text:
Perimortem Caesarean
chance of maternal ROSC as it CO via two mechanisms:
uterine blood flow
Relieves diaphragmatic pressure + aortocaval compression
Also may save a viable foetus
Indication: maternal arrest within 4 minutes (do not wait for seniors or US or sterile prep AND >24/40 gestation
No CI – heroic attempt in an arrested patient
Procedure:
Most experienced person
Vertical incision from pubic symphysis to umbilicus or higher along linea nigra into peritoneal cavity
Retract abdominal wall laterally
Reflect bladder and empty (by aspiration)
5cm incision verticaly into the inferior presenting part of the uterus until amniotic fluid comes through
Insert 2 fingers and lift up uterus from foetus
Extend uterine incision up to fundus with safety scissors curved away from foetus
Deliver foetus – may need to disengage presenting part
Clamp cord twice and cut between → neonatology
Deliver placenta + swab cavity
Pack uterus and abdomen +/- clamp bleeding vessels and suture uterine incision
Oxytocin bolus + infusion
Continue maternal resuscitation

section_path: Anaesthesia for Obstetric Patient for Non-Obstetric Surgery
Anaesthesia for Obstetric Patient for Non-Obstetric Surgery
title: Anaesthesia for Obstetric Patient for Non-Obstetric Surgery
text:
Anaesthesia for Obstetric Patient for Non-Obstetric Surgery
~1% require during pregnancy. Most commonly acute appendicitis, cholecystitis, maternal trauma, and cancer.
In standard dosing, no current anaesthetic drugs have been shown to be teratogenic in humans (nitrous oxide may not be okay -
little evidence in humans, but better to avoid). Greatest risk to foetus is hypoxia / hypotension.
Foetal Considerations
Maternal Considerations
First
trimester
Teratogenesis: occurs during organogenesis (days
15 – 56) - major organogenesis complete by
week 8
Miscarriage rate: 10%
Avoid: hypo/hyperthermia, hypoxia, hypercarbia,
hypotension, N2O, atropine (use glyco), sugammadex
Avoid NSAIDS: risk of miscarriage and foetal
malformation in early pregnancy
Second
trimester
Lowest risk trimester
Consider steroids for foetal lung maturation 24-
34 weeks
Routine tocolysis not indicated
Miscarriage rate: 1%
Avoid: NSAIDs
Left tilt after 20/40
Third
trimester
Preterm labour risk: 10%
Avoid NSAIDs: after 32/40 can cause premature closure of
PDA (esp if >48 hours use) + oligohydramnios
At any
stage
•
Postpone elective surgery until 6 weeks post-partum if possible (emergent surgery should not be
delayed)
•
Overall miscarriage rate 6% (3x risk with abdominal surgery)
•
FHR before and after surgery at any gestation (intra-op after 24/40) – note that variability and
baseline is normal – but not bradycardia
•
Airway considerations, L tilt if able, PaCO2 30-35, ETO2 >80%, DVT prophylaxis + aspiration prophylaxis
(note: multiple studies have failed to show aspiration risk with pregnancy)
•
MAC + sedation doses (however always use BIS)
•
Regional always better than GA if possible (must LA requirements - a1 acid glycoprotein, drug
uptake due to venous engorgement + cardiac irritability from altered oestrogen and progesterone)
•
Volatile > TIVA due to tocolysis
•
Should always be done in hospital with obstetric / C-section services
•
Avoid: beta blockers (slow foetal HR), ketamine (uterine contraction +++, 2mg/kg uterine contraction
as much as ergot)
•
Non-fatal bradycardia reported with neostigmine – atropine > glycol – crosses placenta quicker
•
Analgesia: important, may risk of preterm labour - multimodal analgesia recommended
Specific surgeries:
Laparoscopy: smallest intraabdominal pressure should be used, no definitive evidence for open versus laparoscopic on
foetal outcomes
Pneumoperitoneum: pressure <15mmHg, tight PaCO2 target, avoid hypotension
Risk of pre-term labour after abdominal surgery ~5% (increased if uterus manipulated or infection present)
Trauma: 1st trimester foetus is protected by bony pelvis, later gestations risk of exposure + aortocaval compression
Neurosurgery: MAP <70mmHg may significantly reduce foetal blood flow – use foetal monitoring. Extreme hyperventilation
can cause constriction to blood flow + shifts oxyHb curve to left (less offloading to foetus). Osmotic diuresis can reduce
amniotic fluid.
No sufficient evidence to suggest any long term effects on foetal neurodevelopment from GA in utero.

title: TGA Medication Classification in Pregnancy
text:
TGA Medication Classification in Pregnancy
Category
Definition
Examples
A
Medications which have been taken by a large number of
pregnant women and women of childbearing age without any
proven increase in the frequency of malformations or other
direct harmful effects on the foetus
Paracetamol, codeine, LA (bup +
lignocaine), metocloperamide,
thiopentone, suxamethonium, terbutaline,
methyldopa, halothane, N2O, clindamycin
B1
Limited # of pregnant women
No increase observed
Animal studies show no increase in foetal damage
LA (prilocaine), gabapentin, ondansetron,
granisetron, cephazolin
B2
Animal studies are inadequate or lacking
Available data shows no increased risk
LA (ropivacaine), duloxetine, venlafaxine,
desvenlafaxine, hyoscine, domperidone,
sugammadex / rocuronium, sevoflurane
B3
Animal studies have shown foetal damage – significance of
which is uncertain in humans
Celecoxib, LA (procaine, levobupivacaine),
mirtazapine, moclobemide, pregabalin,
Keppra, desflurane, ketamine
C
Owing to pharmacological effect can be suspected of causing
harm, which may be reversible
Opioids, aspirin, NSAIDs, parecoxib, SSRI,
TCAs, clonazepam, prochlorperazine,
droperidol, hydralazine, methoxyflurane
D
Which have, or are expected to cause, damage that may be
irreversible
Adverse pharmacological effects
Paroxetine, carbamazepine, phenytoin,
sodium valproate, lamotrigine
X
High risk of permanent foetal damage
Should not be used if pregnant or possibly pregnant

title: Maternal Mortality in Australia
text:
Maternal Mortality in Australia
Definition: death whilst pregnant or within 6 weeks of delivery
Incidence: 5/100,000 (global 211/100,000)
Timing:
During pregnancy 30% (43% in first trimester)
During or within 24 hours of birth 20%
After birth within 6 weeks 50% (60% of those within 2 weeks)
Causes:
Direct: obstetric complication or related to management e.g. VTE, AFE, sepsis, HDP, ectopic, anaesthesia-related
Indirect: 2’ aggravated by physiology of pregnancy e.g. CVD, non-obstetric haemorrhage (ICH, splenic aneurysm), suicide,
substance abuse
Coincidental: entirely unrelated to pregnancy e.g. trauma, cancer
Cardiovascular causes are single, highest cause
Anaesthesia causes: airway-related, aspiration, neuraxial (subdural haematoma, cerebral vein thrombosis, total/high spinal),
anaphylaxis
RFs: age <20yo or >40yo, indigenous, higher parity, smoker, remote location

title: Lactation and Anaesthesia
text:
Lactation and Anaesthesia
WHO suggests:
Exclusive breastfeeding for 6mo
Breastfeeding + supplemental solids until 2yo (and ongoing)
In Australia:
96% initiate breastfeeding
69% at 3mo (39% exclusively)
60% at 6mo (15% exclusively)
28% at 12mo
9% at 18mo
5% at 24mo
No longer advised to “pump & dump” – only applies to a select list of medications (amiodarone, iodides, lithium, oral retinoids,
gold salts and chemo)
Risk of being given this incorrect advice:
Premature weaning
Feeding issues
Mastitis in mother
Pumping is difficult
Note: majority of breast milk is made at the time of the feed
Characteristics of drugs secreted in breast milk:
MW <800
Low maternal protein binding
Highly lipid soluble
Important factors at time of feed: [plasma], active metabolites
Features important to infant:
PO bioavailability + first pass metabolism
Half life
Therapeutic range in infants
Generally most drugs diffuse across lipid bilayer of the lactocyte
However colostrum and transitional milk immediately post-partum allows passage of large Ig, lymphocytes and proteins due to
gaps between alveolar cells → more maternal drugs pass than mature milk (however smaller volume i.e. 30-100mL/day = lower
total dose)
Pharmacology:
Drugs generally travel down [ ] gradient
Milk is acidic ∴ weakly basic drugs are sequestered (e.g. oxycodone)
Active transport systems for iodine/amiodarone (avoid iodine skin preps on broken/mucosal skin)
All anaesthetic drugs advice is “if mum is awake enough to hold baby it’s safe enough to breastfeed”
Some NSAIDs more data than others, but probably all okay
Aspirin: <300mg for antiplt effect probably okay, but analgesic doses avoid – possible risk of Reye’s syndrome
Risk of oxycodone trapping in breast milk – cyp2d6 metabolism → oxymorphone. Drug level in milk >3x maternal serum 2’
ion trapping. Advised to limit maternal dose to <30mg/day for 2-3 days and where possible choose another drug (i.e.
tramadol) though advised safe to use if mum is awake enough to breastfeed, monitor baby for sedation
Remi/fentanyl/alfentanil – limited t/f to breastmilk
Tramadol excretion to breastmilk is low, and even lower for M1 (O-desmethyltramadol) – cyp2D6 ∴ some population
variability → in poor metaboliser 1.5% usual dose, in extensive metaboliser 3% usual dose. Considered safe in UK/AUS.
If awake enough considered safe to breastfeed
Warnings related to codeine should not apply to tramadol
No data on tapentadol, probably safe but probably choose something else
Codeine CYP2D6, highly lipophilic, weakly protein bound → rapid metabolisers having high [ ] in breast milk → exposure
>10% recommended infant dose can occur
Pregabalin – caution advised
Clonidine can reduce breast milk
Local anaesthetics:

title: Lactation and Anaesthesia
text:
Amino amides: poor PO bioavailability, great option for parturients
Cocaine: limited data for non-medicinal uses, infants unable to metabolise, probably avoid feeding for 24 hours
Reversal:
Neo: limited data, short half life, unlikely to be harmful
Sugammadex: large and polar unlikely to enter breastmilk
Antimuscarinics: glyco better than atropine - large Vd, low oral BA, both can reduce prolactin
Anti-emetics:
Limited probably all safe inc ondans, cyclizine
Metoclopramide + domperidone milk production (D2 antagonist, check QTc)
Dexamethasone prolactin
Prochlorperazine – caution use with very young infants
Antibiotics:
probably all safe though risk of GI upset
tetracyclines can stain infants developing teeth
Medical imaging:
IV contrast – safe, consider if high dose / preterm infant
PET scan: limit contact for 12 hours due to radiation
Iodine skin prep:
Muscosa/broken skin → breast milk [ ] up to 20x plasma levels due to active transport
Transient neonatal hypothyroidism
Re: EtOH – greatest risk to infant is carer drunkiness, not EtOH via breastmilk. Some foods have surprisingly high EtOH %
including ripe fruits. Death BAC ~0.45% which is less than the EtOH in orange juice ~0.5%.
Fenugreek can cause serotonin syndrome
Peri-op care:
Always ask if breastfeeding, educate on safety of anaesthesia, address anxiety about separation, refer to lactation service
Minimise separation with child, consider first on list, provide space for breastfeeding, if significant delays consider IV fluids
or allow ongoing oral fluids
Facilitate expressing + storing milk if child is unable to stay with mother or in the event of prolonged surgery
Intra-op:
Undrained breasts are at risk of blocked ducts and mastitis – Rx frequent emptying +/- abx (fluclox)
Consider straps, arm position, prone/lateral positioning, using pt as table
Multimodal analgesia, regional where able, PONV prevention, neutral/positive fluid balance
Post-op:
Early reunion +/- discharge DOS if appropriate
Discharge advice for anyone with babies:
Shouldn’t co-sleep for 24 hours – longer if taking ongoing opiates, sleep related infant death 10x higher if bed sharing with
drug affected parent
Alternative adult for primary baby care/supervision during breast feeds (risk to baby is mum falling asleep, not drugs in
breast milk), sleep related infant death 67% higher if falling asleep on couch/chair
Provide analgesia weaning plan

title: Physiological Changes in Pregnancy (Primary Notes)
text:
Physiological Changes in Pregnancy (Primary Notes)
System
Δ
CVS
↑CO 40% (attained by 24/40) (both ↑HR 15 bts/min and ↑SV)
First stage labour: CO ↑25% (from prelabour values)
Second stage labour: CO ↑40% (from prelabour values)
Immediately after delivery up to 100% ↑CO from prelabour values 2’ autotransfusion, ↓LL venous pressure due to
aortocaval pressure release
↑femoral + IVC venous pressures → collateral maintenance of atrial filling however this leads to engorgement of epidural
(Baston’s) venous plexus (↑risk of venous epidural placement)
Filling pressures (CVP, cap wedge pressure, LV EDP) do not change due to cardiac remodelling
↓SVR 20%, ↓BP (↓sBP 8%, ↓dBP 20%)
ECG: possible benign dysrhythmias/tachy, ST dep or flattened T waves, R dev (1st TM) → L dev (3rd TM)
TTE: RH chambers ↑20%, LH chambers ↑10%, LV eccentric hypertrophy, every valve except aortic annuli increase, MR 25%,
small insignificant pericardial effusions
Auscultation: systolic murmur, MR/TR, 3rd or 4th heart sound
Resp
↑MV 50% (mainly 2’ ↑TV by 40%, lesser extent ↑RR 15% due to progesterone)
↑Alveolar ventilation due to ↑MV without ↑in dead space
↓pCO2 32-35mmHg (pH normal due to renal excretion of bicarb)
↑O2 consumption 35% at term; 1st stage labour O2 consumption ↑40% (prelabour), 2nd stage ↑75% (prelabour)
Production of CO2 can ↑by 60%, labour pain can cause hyperventilation of paCO2 down to 20mmHg
↓FRC, ERV, RV 2’ cephalad displacement of diaphragm
↓IC due to ↑baseline TV
↓TLC only slightly as ↑chest circumference / diaphragm excursion
CC (RV + CV) unchanged but ↓FRC → tendency for earlier desats
Mucous membranes become oedematous + friable 2’ RASS → ↑Mallampati w/ gestation (use smaller ETT)
→ ↑O2 consumption + ↓FRC → rapid desats
Also ↓FRC → ↓time for de-nitrogenation → ↑speed of uptake of volatiles i.e. ↑rate of rise FA/FI of inhalational agent
Metabolic alkalosis → foetal acidosis due to 1) ↓uteroplacental perfusion 2’ vasoconstriction and 2) L shift of maternal ODC
Upper airway oedema + vocal chord swelling
CNS
MAC ↓by 20-40% 2’ progesterone
↑sensitivity to general and Las (mechanism unknown) - ↓neuraxial anaesthetic req by 40% at term
Renal
↑GFR 2’ ↑renal flow → ↓urea and Cr 50%
Glucose + AAs not reabsorbed as efficiently → glycosuria and aminoaciduria
GIT
Uterus displaces lower oesophageal sphincter + progesterone relaxes → heartburn incidence 80% at term
Gastric emptying normal, but ↑intestinal transit time → constipation
Nil ↑risk of aspiration based on pH and volume of gastric contents prior to labour however during labour ↑risk aspiration
due to pain, augmented by opiates – should always assume full stomach – give non-particulate antacid
↑transaminases, bili, LDH, ↑↑ALP due to placental production
Serum cholinesterase production ↓by 25% (recommended to still use normal dose of sux)
Haem
↑Blood volume (plasma + red cells)
↑Plasma vol 50% (2’ RAAS)
↑Red cells 20%
→ physiological haemodilutional anaemia of pregnancy (w/ associated ↓blood viscosity by 30%)
Mech unknown – presumed 2’ initial ‘underfill’ state from vasodilation → RAAS stimulation
↑further during labour as blood squeezed from intervillious space, delivery → autotransfusion of 500mL
Clotting factors:
↑factors I, VII, VIII, IX, X, XII and fibrinogen → hypercoagulable state pre- & post-partum (↓factors 11 & 13)
Factors II and V unchanged
↓Antithrombin III and protein S (protein C unchanged)
↑TPO and platelets however platelet destruction also increased → fall in platelet count as pregnancy progresses
→ ↓PT and aPTT by 20%
Endocrine
↑TBG but free T3 and T4 normal
Adrenal cortical hyperplasia → ↑free and total cortisol
↓Fasting BSL but tolerance to glucose may be impaired due to placental lactogen → transient mild diabetic state
HPL → “insulin resistance”, mobilises FFAs for use
MSK
Hormone relaxin responsible for ligamentous relaxation + softening of collagenous tissues
Exaggerated lumbar lordosis (implications for regional anaesthesia)
Stretching of lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh → meralgia paresthetica
Derm
Melanocyte-stimulating hormone → hyperpigmentation
Mammary
Enlargement of breast tissue may complicate intubation – use short handled laryngoscope
Ocular
↓intraocular pressure 2’ 1) ↑progesterone 2) ↑relaxin 3) ↓production of aqueous humour due to ↑production of human
chorionic gonadotropin

section_path: Reference Ranges for Physiological and Biochemical Changes in Pregnancy
Pregnancy Effects of Wash-In of Volatiles
title: Pregnancy Effects of Wash-In of Volatiles
text:
Pregnancy Effects of Wash-In of Volatiles
Rate of volatile wash-in governed by balance of
uptake by alveolus from breathing system - governed by minute ventilation and FRC
uptake by blood from alveolus - governed by cardiac output and V/Q matching
Alveolar wash-in may be approximated by first order kinetics with time constant given by
 = FRC/MV (if blood uptake is disregarded)
∴ ↓FRC and ↑MV → smaller time constant () → faster alveolar uptake
Δ at
Term
Mechanism
Volatile Uptake
Overall Wash
In Effect
Resp
↑MV 50%
↑TV by 40%
↑RR 15%
Progesterone stimulates resp
centre
↑MV → ↑alveolar uptake of volatile from
breathing system → faster rise in FA/FI
↑wash-in
↓FRC
↓20% erect
↓30% supine
Cephalad displacement of
diaphragm (counteracted by
rib flaring)
↓FRC → ↓wash-in time constant → faster
rise in FA/FI
↑wash-in
CVS
↑CO 40%
↑SV
↑HR 15 bts/min
Upregulation of RAAS, low
resistance of placental bed,
↑SNS
↑CO → ↑uptake of volatile by pulm
circulation from alveolus → slows rise in FA/FI
↓wash-in
Haematocrit
↑Plasma vol 50%
↑Red cells 20%
Mechanism unknown but →
haemodilutional anaemia
Volatiles dissolve in RBC membrane
∴↓haematocrit → ↓blood:gas partion
coefficient of most volatiles → ↓blood uptake
↑wash-in
Other
2nd gas effect
Volatiles ↓uterine tone
∴N2O used to ↓volatile use
N2O ↑volatile uptake via 2nd gas effect
↑wash-in
OVERALL → volatile wash in is increased at term

section_path: Reference Ranges for Physiological and Biochemical Changes in Pregnancy
Reference Ranges for Physiological and Biochemical Changes in Pregnancy
title: Reference Ranges for Physiological and Biochemical Changes in Pregnancy
text:
Reference Ranges for Physiological and Biochemical Changes in Pregnancy
Biochemical changes:
FBC:
↑Plasma vol 50% but ↑red cells only 20% → dilutional anaemia
↑TPO and platelets production however ↑platelet destruction → ↓platelet count as pregnancy progresses
Renal:
↑GFR 2’ ↑renal flow → ↓urea and Cr 50%
↓Na 3-5 mmol/L 2’ ↑plasma vol
↓Ca2+, PO4, Mg2+ 2’ ↑plasma vol
Liver:
↑transaminases, bili, LDH
↑↑ALP due to placental production
Serum cholinesterase production ↓by 25% (recommended to still use normal dose of sux)
Endo:
↑TBG but free T3 and T4 normal
Adrenal cortical hyperplasia → ↑free and total cortisol
↓Fasting BSL but tolerance to glucose may be impaired due to placental lactogen → transient diabetic state
Clotting factors:
↑factors I, VII, VIII, IX, X, XII and fibrinogen → hypercoagulable state

section_path: Anatomy and Physiology of Pain in Labour + Childbirth
title: Pregnancy Effects on Neuraxial Anaesthesia
text:
Pregnancy Effects on Neuraxial Anaesthesia
Anatomical changes:
Uterine enlargement → ↑femoral + IVC venous pressures → collateral maintenance of atrial
filling however this leads to engorgement of epidural (Baston’s) venous plexus (↑risk of
venous epidural placement)
↑Epidural veins + ↑intraabdominal pressure → displacement of CSF from thoracolumbar
region of subarach space → ↓dose requirement for spinal anaesthesia
CSF has lower specific gravity in pregnancy → ↓dose requirement for spinal anaesthesia
Pregnancy ↑lumbar lordosis →
Smaller spaces for epidural / spinal insertion (i.e. “narrow interspace”
Cephalad movement of Tuffier’s line to ~L3/L4 cf L4/L5
Apex of lumbar lordosis is shifted caudad + thoracic kyphosis shifts cephalad → change in
subarach spread of spinal anaesthesia
Hormonal changes:
Hormones soften ligaments including ligamentum flavum
Pregnancy ↓amount of LA needed for both spinal and epidural anaesthesia (cf age-matched
non-pregnant women) likely 2’ to progesterone ↑sensitivity of nerve fibres

section_path: Anatomy and Physiology of Pain in Labour + Childbirth
Anatomy and Physiology of Pain in Labour + Childbirth
title: Anatomy and Physiology of Pain in Labour + Childbirth
text:
Anatomy and Physiology of Pain in Labour + Childbirth
Types of pain:
Somatic: Aδ fibres, fast / sharp / well-localised, trigger withdrawal
Visceral: C fibres, slow / dull / poorly-localised, elicits guarding
Referred: perceived at location distal to insult due to convergence of somatic and visceral
1° afferents on same WDR projection neurons
Stage of Labour
Mechanism
Pain Pathway
First
Onset of uterine
contraction → full
cervical dilatation
Somatic – minimal
Visceral - pain caused by visceral
stretch (uterus and cervix)
Nociceptors in LUS and cervix → visceral afferent (A and C fibres) travels
via sympathetic efferent fibres → uterine plexus → inferior
hypogastric plexus → sympathetic chain → T10 – L1 dorsal horn
Early moderate labour pain = T11 and T12
Late intense labour pain = T10 to L1
Second
→ delivery of foetus
Somatic – foetal descent →
stretching and tearing of perineum
(skin, subcutaneous tissue
and fascia)
Visceral – foetal descent → pressure
on other pelvic structures (bladder,
urethra, rectum,
lumbosacral plexus, etc)
Somatic: nociceptors in cervix and perineum → somatic afferent (A) via
pudendal nerve → S2, S3, S4 dorsal horn, also via ilioinguinal and
genitofemoral nerves → L1, L2
Visceral as above
Third
→ delivery of placenta
Somatic – passage of placenta
Visceral – contraction of uterus to
post-partum size (cramps can persist
for days)
Same as second stage but less intense
Final common pathway after synapsing in dorsal horn, pain signals ascend via:
Anterior spinothalamic tract → thalamus (esp. ventral posterolateral nucleus) → sensory cortex → mediates discriminative aspect of pain
(i.e. location, intensity, duration)
Lateral spinothalamic tract → thalamus (esp. posterior part of ventral medial nucleus Vmpo) → insular cortex → mediates autonomic and
emotional aspects of pain
Spinoparabrachial tract → parabrachial nucleus → emotional aspects of pain
*Both spinothalamic and spinoparabrachial tracts also have projections to periaqueductal gray matter → links to descending modulatory
pathway and mediates arousal

section_path: Effect of Pregnancy on Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics of Anaesthesia / Analgesia Rx
title: Analgesia Rx
text:
Analgesia Rx
Pharmacokinetic Δ:
Absorption and uptake:
Oral absorption and bioavailablity not effected, though may be affected by N+V
↓intestinal motility but gastric emptying only delayed during labour or after opioids
↑CO by 50% → ↑blood flow to skin and mucous membranes → enhanced absorption
↓FRC → ↑wash in of volatile anaesthetics
Distribution:
↑CO by 50% → ↑distribution to all tissues
↑TBW 8L, plasma vol ↑50% → ↑vol of distribution of hydrophilic drugs (eg neuromuscular Rx)
Body fat ↑~4kg but unimportant given large VOD of lipophilic drugs
↓plasma albumin by 70% which affects protein binding → ↑free drug
Metabolism:
↑CO ≠ ↑liver flow during pregnancy
↑activity of p450 + UGT enzymes → ↑metabolism of phenytoin, midazolam, morphine
Elimination:
↑GFR 2’ ↑renal flow → ↑renal excretion
↑MV → ↑elimination of volatiles
Placental transfer and metabolism:
Previously thought that transport across placenta was mainly via diffusion however placenta contains many
transporters
Foetal pH is lower than maternal pH – weak bases become ionised and prevents transfer back
E.g. opioids and LAs
Placenta contains many enzymes responsible for phase I and II biotransformation
Foetal and neonatal elimination:
Foetal elimination is mainly dependent on placental transfer
↓metabolism cf adults
Foetal drugs → first pass hepatic metabolism (but some drug will bypass liver)
Renal blood flow is minimal until term
Excreted products pass into amniotic fluid → swallowed
High MV promotes rapid neonatal elimination of volatiles
Phamacodynamic Δ:
GA:
MAC ↓by 20-40% 2’ progesterone
Regional anaesthesia:
↑spread of neuraxial block
↑sensitivity to general and local anaesthetics ?progesterone on nerves
Analgesia:
↑endorphins proposed to ↑nociceptive threshold
↑heat/pain threshold persists until 48hr post-delivery
Psychosomatic component can produce widespread variability

title: Utero-Placental Circulation
text:
Utero-Placental Circulation
700-900mL/min at term (i.e. 10-15% CO)
Blood supply to uterus: uterine artery +/- small variable contribution from ovarian arteries
Uterine artery arises from internal iliacs
Variability in origin of arterial vessels + presence of anastomoses can thwart attempts to cease haemorrhage.
Uterine artery → spiral arteries → intervillious space in fountain-like jets → chorionic plate
Maternal blood then returns to basal plate → collecting veins → uterine veins → iliac veins +/- ovarian veins
→ IVC on right and renal vein on the left
Uterine flow follows Ohm’s law: uterine artery pressure – uterine venous pressure / uterine vascular resistance
Uteroplacental circulation usually vasodilated, minimal autoregulation ∴:
Most important determinant is maternal MAP
Normal pregnancy entails ↓MAP ∴ also dependent on low uterine vascular resistance
Mechanisms of decreased uterine flow:
Aortocaval compression (main mechanism)
Sympathectomy from regional anaesthesia
Hypovolaemia from haemorrhage
Uterine contraction → ↓uterine diastolic flow
Labour pain → ↑MV → ↑resp alkalosis → ↓uterine artery flow
Endogenous vasoconstrictors: catecholamines, vasopressin (if hypovolaemic)
Exogenous vasoconstrictors: epinephrine, local anaesthetics (in high concentration) – relative refractoriness cf non-
pregnancy
Plasma protein binding important – it’s free drug that is in equilibrium across placenta therefore highly protein bound drugs are
in higher concentration in mother than the foetus. Drugs in non-ionised form cross placenta therefore pKa matters.

section_path: Bohr and Haldane Effects in Trans-Placental O2/CO2 Gas Exchange
Bohr and Haldane Effects in Trans-Placental O2/CO2 Gas Exchange
title: Bohr and Haldane Effects in Trans-Placental O2/CO2 Gas Exchange
text:
Bohr and Haldane Effects in Trans-Placental O2/CO2 Gas Exchange
Placenta: connects uterine wall to foetus
Function - facilitates nutrient and waste exchange between mother and foetus
At placenta, O2 and CO2 passively diffuse down their respective concentration gradients:
CO2 from foetus → mother
O2 from mother → foetus
Rate of diffusion is governed by Fick’s law of diffusion, which states that
Where –
D = rate of diffusion
A = diffusional surface area
t = membrane thickness
sol = solubility of diffusate
MW = molecular weight of diffusate
Δconc = concentration gradient
Placenta is much less efficient than the lung in terms of gas exchange because:
Smaller surface area for diffusion (15 m2 placenta vs 80 m2 lung)
Greater diffusion distance (3.5μm placenta vs 0.5μm lung)
Uterine Artery
Uterine Vein
Umbilical Artery
Umbilical Vein
Flow (mL/min)
pO2 (mmHg)
pCO2 (mmHg)
Placental O2 consumption = 6 mL/min
Foetal O2 consumption ≈ 17 mL/min
*Foetal O2 saturation does not exceed 60% even with maternal FiO2 100%
Foetal adaptations:
Left shift OHDC (p50 at 19mmHg cf 26mmHg) 2’ serine substitution → ↓affinity for 2,3-DPG
Hb 180g/L (cf 140g/L) 2’ hypoxia → erythropoeisis
Double Bohr and Haldane Effects
Bohr Effect
Haldane Effect
Principle
Changes to pCO2 or pH influences Hb affinity for O2
i.e. ↑pCO2 or ↓pH → ↓Hb affinity for O2 (right shift)
Changes to Hb-O2 binding influences Hb affinity for CO2
i.e. oxyHb →↓Hb affinity for CO2
Mechanism
O2 binding to Hb releases H+ (and vice versa) ∴ H+ binding
to Hb promotes O2 release
DeoxyHb is a better buffer for H+ than oxyHb ∴ deoxyHb
shifts the CO2 dissociation equation to the right (CO2 + H2O
→ HCO3– + H+) → carries more CO2
Placenta
Foetus unloads CO2 in placenta → ↑placental CO2 → ↓Hb
affinity for O2 → ↑O2 unloading →↑O2 available for
foetus
Placenta unloads O2 to fetus → ↓placental O2
→ ↑Hb affinity for CO2 → ↑placental CO2 uptake from
foetus
Foetus
Foetus unloads CO2 → ↓foetal CO2 → ↑Hb affinity for O2
→ ↑foetal O2 binding
Foetus takes up O2 from placenta →↑foetal O2 →↓Hb
affinity for CO2 → ↑foetal CO2 release to placenta
*gradient increased by maternal hyperventilation / resp alk

title: Brain Imaging
text:
Brain Imaging
Abnormalities:
Important to assess effects on surrounding structures:
Volume loss: structures move towards
Mass effect: push structures away
Common abnormalities:
Swelling/mass effect → loss of 3rd ventricle + sulci (note: raised ICP cannot be ruled out by imaging)
Scalp haematoma: alter contour of skin
Fractures: straight lucent lines through skull (cf sutures – wavy) +/- haemorrhage, fluid levels, pneumocephalus
Coup: injuries at site of impact
Contrecoup: injuries at opposite site of impact
Infarction: loss of grey/white differentiation + swelling
Malignant infarction: large infarct w/ mass effect + herniation – young
pts/pts without atrophy at greatest risk
Acute thrombosis: hyperdensity (white) on non-con, hypodense on contrast
Hydrocephalus: enlargement of ventricles
Tumours:
Primary: irregular mass with solid rim + low density centre
Mets: multiple, solid, cystic, less irregular
Risks:
Cataracts
Radiation

title: Vertebral Column
text:
Vertebral Column
2 columns:
Anterior:
Anterior longitudinal ligament
Vertebral bodies to discs
Posterior longitudinal ligament
Posterior (most strength):
Ligamentum flavum
Interspinous / supraspinous ligament
Spinous and transverse process

title: Spinal Cord
text:
Spinal Cord
Tracts:
Sensory
Posterior columns (ipsilateral – cross in medulla)
Ipsilateral vibration, light touch, proprioception
Spinothalamic (contralateral 1-2 segments)
Pain, temperature, course touch
Motor
Corticospinal (contralateral)
Blood supply:
Anterior spinal artery (anterior 2/3rd)
2x posterior spinal arteries (posterior 1/3rd)
Reinforced by: vertebral arteries, PICAs, radicular, artery of Adamkiewicz (T9-T12)
Spinal Cord Syndromes
SCI is the lowest level with normal sensory / motor function on both sides
Syndromes:
Tetraplegia / Quadriplegia: cervical level → arms / torso / pelvis / legs
Paraplegia: thoracic, lumbar or sacral w/ preserved arm function
Anterior Spinal Artery Syndrome:
Loss of motor (corticospinal)
Loss of pain, temp, course touch (spinothalamic)
Preserved vibration, light touch, proprioception (dorsal column)
Bladder dysfunction
Posterior cord syndrome
Loss of vibration, light touch, proprioception (dorsal column)
Preserved pain, temp, course touch (spinothalamic)
Preserved motor (corticospinal)
Variable bowel and bladder dysfunction
Brown-Sequard Syndrome: lateral cord damage
Loss of ipsilateral motor, vibration, light touch, proprioception
Loss of contralateral pain, temp
Cauda Equina Syndrome: lumbosacral nerve roots
Bowel / bladder dysfunction
UMN symptoms in legs
Central Cord Syndrome (2’ bleeding, infarction, oedema) – most commonly cervical
UMN legs
Mixed UMN/LMN arms
Loss of pain + temp in arms
Sacral sparing
Segmental Syndrome
All ascending and descending pathways in that segment + spinal shock
Ipsilateral dorsal columns
Contralateral motor + spinothalamic
Flaccid paralysis, urine retention, decreased reflexes

title: Autonomic Dysreflexia
text:
Consequences of Spinal Cord Injury
Neurogenic Shock
Disruption of sympathetic activity with preserved parasympathetic activity, particularly if high thoracic or cervical injury
SSx: SVR (→ venous pooling), inotropy, bradycardia (may also have haemorrhagic shock)
Diagnosis: sBP <100, HR <80 w/ autonomic dysregulation → can be life threatening
Differentiated from other forms of shock by lack of SNS compensation
Rx: pressors, inotropes
Spinal Shock
Generally not life-threatening cf neurogenic shock
Loss of spinal reflexes below SCI level
Day 0-1: flaccid, areflexia
Day 1-3: return of reflexes
Day 4-28: hyperreflexia
Month 2-12: hyperreflexia, spasticity
Respiratory Dysfunction
Level
Nerve
Vital Capacity
Cough
Management
C3
Phrenic
<10%
Absent
Immediate ventilation
C3-C5
Partial phrenic
10 – 30%
Weak
80% require ventilation
Above T8
Intercostals
Abdominal
30 – 80%
Weak / normal
Impaired sputum clearance
May require ventilation
Below T8
Low intercostals
Abdominal
80 – 100%
Weak / normal
Impaired sputum clearance
May require ventilation
Sympathectomy above T6 → bronchospasm, secretions → mucous plugging, atelectasis
Autonomic Dysreflexia
50-70% of patients with damage >T6.
Diagnosis: BP >20mmHg from baseline (but can be hypertensive crisis)
Pathophysiology:
Noxious stimuli below lesion
Sympathetic activation
Intact baroreceptors sense HTN → vagal response
Disruption to descending inhibitory pathways to SNS of splanchnic
vasculature (right →)
Causes: bladder distension, pressure sores, uterine contractions, UTI, surgical
stimulus
SSx: uncontrolled hypertension, cardiac arrhythmias, flushing, headache,
reflex bradycardia, sweating, blurred vision, nasal congestion, piloerection
Prevention during anaesthesia: spinal anaesthetic, always deep during
anaesthesia if GA (i.e. >1 MAC)
Management:
Sit upright, remove tight clothing / stockings
Check bladder
Empty catheter + check for blockages
If not catheterised – catheterise
Cease cystoscopy if currently in procedure
Exclude constipation: PR and remove any faecal mass
Vasodilators:
GTN 1-2 tab q20mins or nifedipine s/l 10mg
Hydralazine 20mg IV slowly or diazoxide 20mg bolus
Resistant: IV GTN, phentolamine or magnesium
Continue to search for cause throughout treatment

title: Chronic Spinal Cord Injury
text:
Chronic Spinal Cord Injury
Medical issues:
VTE: 50 – 100%
Analgesia
Pressure area care
Stress ulcer prophylaxis
Urinary catheterisation
Paralytic ileus
Hypothermia
Nutrition
Patients with SCI are at risk of abnormal emergency presentations → morbidity and mortality
Pre-op:
Assess:
Airway including C spine movement + fixation
CVS: bradyarrhythmia (high cervical lesions) +/- pacemaker, CAD
Resp: ventilatory function (see resp function), T-spine injuries may have inefficient cough
Flow vol loops (likely restrictive dz from intercostal muscle spasticity + FEV1)
Prior need for ventilation
risk OSA
?Recent infections
GI: delayed gastric emptying
Renal: SPC +/- infection
Haem: VTE (+/- prophylaxis)
Metabolic:
Impaired thermoregulation
MSK: osteoporosis
Neuro: spinal fusion may inhibit neuraxial, chronic pain
Psychological
Presence of ADR + triggers
?Previous post-op course
Anaesthetic plan →
Spinal anaesthesia very effective and ablates ADR
(height of block difficult to assess, loss of babinski
+ change from spasticity to flaccid paralysis
indicates block)
Intra-op:
Can be difficult IV access 2’ atrophy and contractures
Consider art line to monitor for ADR
Avoid depolarising NMBAs – ensure fully reversed at end
Reduced induction doses (smaller blood volume + muscle mass)
Very careful positioning and padding
Warm from anaesthetic bay to recovery
Obstetrics: higher rates of ADR, urological pathology, VTE, pressure
sores, resp compromise from gravid uterus, pre-term delivery, need for c-section
Note contractions may precipitate ADR (may be first sign of contractions) – consider early epidural

title: Intracranial Pressure
text:
Intracranial Pressure
Goals:
Closed cranium: to maintain adequate CPP (MAP – ICP) and prevent herniation of brain
Open cranium: may be to provide relaxation for surgical access, or reverse herniation
SSx of ICP: headache, N&V, blurred vision, somnolence, papilloedema
Normal values: 10-15mmHg adult, 3-4mmHg (<1yo) – treat ICP >22mmHg
For accurate CPP transducers for MAP and ICP should be at tragus (i.e. foramen of Munro)
Radiological features of ICP:
Midline shift
Obliteration of basal cisterns
Loss of sulci / oedema
Ventricular effacement / ventriculomegaly
Herniation
ICP monitoring: recommended in severe TBI *when ICP > venous pressure → bridging
veins collapse → obstruction of venous drainage → cerebral perfusion (global cerebral
circ arrest when ICP approaches MAP)
Two main modalities for monitoring:
Intraparenchymal bolts
EVD (allows monitoring + treatment i.e. drainage)

title: Non-Pharmacological Manipulation of ICP
text:
Non-Pharmacological Manipulation of ICP
Mechanisms:
CSF drainage
Blood:
CBF (i.e. arterial):
PaCO2 (but >25mmHg unless ++ emergency)
PaO2
pain/arousal/seizures
Normothermia
venous drainage:
Head elevation 30 degrees
intrathoracic pressure
Nil jugular compression / neck ties
Neutral neck position

title: Pharmacological Manipulation of ICP
text:
Pharmacological Manipulation of ICP
Mechanisms:
Steroids (nil effect acutely, usually given 48hr pre-op) – no role in trauma
Diuretics: frusemide
Osmotic agents: no evidence for superiority of either – pt individualised
Mannitol: 0.25 – 1g/kg over 15 minutes
Hypertonic saline 3% 2-5mL/kg (keep serum Na <160mM)
Blood:
CBF (i.e. arterial):
TIVA (except ketamine)
Avoid vasodilators / NO2
Rapid reduction in ICP:
Hyperventilate to ETCO2 ≥25mmHg
CSF drainage (ventriculostomy, brain needle) – never adjust bed height or head without clamping
Diuresis
CMR / burst suppression:
Thiopentone 3 – 5mg/kg then 3 – 5 mg/kg/hr or prop 50 – 100mg then >0.125mg/kg/hr
MAP reduction
Seizure control: saline irrigation, anticonvulsants
Clamped to
Free drainage

section_path: Basic Elements and Principles of Neuroanaesthesia
title: Basic Elements and Principles of Neuroanaesthesia
text:
Basic Elements and Principles of Neuroanaesthesia
Recurrent issues:
Control of ICP
Management of PaCO2
Management of arterial blood pressure
Use of steroids
Osmotherapy
Diuretics
Anticonvulsants
Patient positioning
Pneumocephalus
VAE
Monitoring
IV fluid management: balanced crystalloid or normal saline
Albumin avoided based on SAFE trial: however pt cohorts not equal, albumin solution was hypoosmolar
Hypothermia
Note bladder temp doesn’t correlate with deep brain structures
Glucose management
Emergence from anaesthesia: smooth to avoid straining → hypertension and oedema
Opioids - antitussive
Neuroprotective strategies:
CMRO2
PaCO2 35-40
Normoxia
Na 140
BSL 6-10mM
Normothermia

title: Intra-Operative Positioning
text:
Intra-Operative Positioning
Risks + risk minimisation
Implications for anaesthesia
Positions:
Supine: shoulder roll obstruction to venous drainage
Lateral (park bench)
Semi-lateral (Janetta)
Prone (see peri-op medicine)
Sitting: transducer at tragus, minimum CPP 60mmHg (higher for elderly)
Positioning Aids / Supports:
Pin (“Mayfield”) head holder
Radiolucent head holder
Horseshoe
Foam head support
Bean bag
Wilson-type frame
Andrews (“hinder binder”) type frame
Relton-Hall (four poster) frame
All pressure points - identify and pad.

title: Cerebral Blood Flow Monitoring
text:
Cerebral Blood Flow Monitoring
All types are indirect measures – use other measures to infer changes to CBF.
Indications:
Acute encephalopathy: severe TBI, space occupying lesions – gold standard is invasive ICP
Selective vascular clamping / high risk thromboembolic event: consider TCD, NIRS, EEG
Expected arterial hypotension / CO e.g. cardiac surgery: consider TCD, NIRS, EEG

title: Transcranial Doppler
text:
Transcranial Doppler
Infers cerebral blood flow from blood flow velocity. Assumes cortical flow ∝ basal flow.
Change in velocity ∝ flow assuming:
Constant angle of insonation i.e. probe must remain fixed
Constant vessel diameter
Method: 2MHz probe → pulses of sound waves through bone → reflected off RBCs back to probe, altered by velocity + direction
Changes from baseline + asymmetry more useful than absolute values
Examples of clinical applications:
Detection of emboli (highly echogenic)
Detection of vasospasm (e.g. after SAH) – velocity >120cm/s
Intracranial circulatory arrest
CAE: decision to shunt (>60% decrease in flow)
ICP via pulsatility index – change infers risk of flow

title: Jugular Bulb Venous Oxygen Saturation
text:
Jugular Bulb Venous Oxygen Saturation
SjvO2 measures oxygen delivery / extraction of the brain
SJVO2 = SaO2 – (CMRO2 / CBF) x (1 / (Hb x 1.34))
Method: fibreoptic catheter placed in retrograde fashion into jugular bulb through IJ vein under fluoroscopic guidance
Complications: incorrect placement – may give false reading, thrombosis, cannulation complications
Values: normal SJVO2 55 – 75%
<55%
O2 delivery versus demand
delivery: ICP, CBF, hypoxia, hypocapnia
demand: seizure, hyperthermia
>55%
cannot assume O2 adequate for demand
>75%
hyperaemia or metabolic demand
delivery: hypercapnia, vasodilation
demand: coma, hypothermia, infarcton
Limitations:
Possible differences between R & L sides – place on side of worst pathology
No indication of focal ischaemia
Prone to inaccuracy

title: NIRS / Cerebral Oximetry
text:
NIRS / Cerebral Oximetry
Uses reflectance oximetry to measure O2 sats (infrared @ 700 – 1000nm) via two sensors to both sides of forehead
~70% of cerebral blood volume is venous  predominantly reads local venous O2 sats (i.e. delivery versus demand)
Normal range: 65 – 70% w/ high variability - baseline value prior to induction is important
Sources of error: extracranial blood, ambient light, electrical interference e.g. diathermy
Limitations:
Global perfusion inferred from focal / frontal measurements
Data on normal values is absent – place prior to starting procedure and monitor trend; lowest acceptable value unknown –
generally desaturation >20% baseline
Causes of values: CBF, O2 content, O2 consumption
Uses: cardiac surgery, deep hypothermic circ arrest, CAE (>12% → shunt), IVH, beach chair
Other uses: splanchnic NIRS for NEC, calves during long trendelenberg / Lloyd-Davis position
Windows:
Transtemporal: MCA (flow 35-90cm/s, PCA,
ACA) – temporal bone too thick in 20% of
population
Transorbital: ophthalmic, carotid
Transforaminal: basilar, vertebral
Principle: pathway at risk must be
amenable to monitoring → must
produce reliable + reproducible
data able to be acted upon
% oxyHb / (% oxyHb + deoxyHb)

title: Evoked Potentials
text:
Evoked Potentials
All types described in terms of:
Latency: time between application of stimulus to response
Amplitude: voltage of response
Require reproducible, reliable tracings must be obtained at baseline prior to intervention – if not possible then should not be
used for clinical decision making. Should obtain baseline prior to surgery.
Clinically significant pathological change:
Prone to electrical interference – needs to be averaged
Type
Stimulus
Pathway
Uses
Considerations
Sig Change
SSEPS
Low amplitude
potentials
measured over
somatosensory
cortex
Transcutaneous
electrical stimulus
Peripheral nerve →
dorsal column → brain
stem → thalamus →
sensory cortex on
contralateral side
Spine surgery where
two posterior
spinal arteries are
at risk
Cerebral vascular
surgery
Aortic surgery
Carotid surgery
amplitude by 50%
(peak to trough)
latency by 10%
(stimulus to
peak)
MEPs
High
amplitude
potentials
measured in
skeletal
muscles in
response to
stimulation of
the motor
cortex
Transcranial train
of electric stimuli
(high voltage short
duration i.e. 500V,
1.2A, 5 serial
stimuli)
Motor cortex →
corticospinal tract
(anterior spinal a.
supply) → nerve root
→ peripheral nerve →
NMJ (muscle AP)
Spinal surgery where
anterior spinal artery
at risk
More sensitive than
SSEPs (changes
seen earlier)
Requires bite block
due to tongue
biting
NMBDs will weaken or
abolish MEPs so
should be avoided
amplitude by 50 –
80% (peak to
trough)
Brainstem
Auditory EPs
Clicking noise in
ear canal –
electrode placed
over mastoid
process – 5 short
latency (<10ms)
peaks
CN VIII → brainstem
(lower pons) → inferior
colliculus (most
important) → cortex
Posterior fossa surgery
Effect of anaesthesia
Drug
SSEP
MEP
Brainstem
Volatiles / NO2
 if >1 MAC
if >0.5 MAC
Minimal effect
Propofol
 but still useful
 but still useful
Barbiturates
Minimal effect

Benzodiazepines

Minimal 


