 / abolished
Causes of change in potential: surgical, pharmacological, physiological (hypoxia, hypotension, hypothermia, anaemia, hypoCO2),
positional, technical
Management:
Notify surgeon
Repeat check to validate + check all leads / connections / settings
Anaesthetist: check / adjust anaesthetic, assess depth + NMB, MAP to 90-100mmHg, optimise physiological causes then if
true and ongoing → neuroprotection including burst suppression
Surgeon: stop manipulation, assess for structural injury / compression, reverse, shunt, remove if temp clip, drain CSF

title: EMG Monitoring
text:
EMG Monitoring
Potentials measured in skeletal muscles in response to surgical stimulation of innervating peripheral or cranial nerve
Types:
Active: stimulation → action potential response from muscle is recorded
Passive
Nerve irritation → audible feedback to warn of impending nerve damage
Limitation: sharp section may produce no EMG discharge at all

title: EEG
text:
EEG
Pathophysiological effects on EEG:
Hypoxia: initially CBF then same appearance as ischaemia
Hypotension: EEG changes not very pronounced (mild hypotension may result in significant ischaemia)
Hypothermia: complete EEG suppression at 15°C to 18°C
Hypocapnia: may show ischaemia
Hypercapnia: only effects secondary to CBF
Anaesthetic drugs:
Can induce burst suppression: propofol, thiopentone
Can’t induce burst suppression: ketamine, benzos, precede, opioids

title: Spinal Surgery
text:
Spinal Surgery
Issues:
Prone positioning
Risk of airway loss + airway oedema
Major haemorrhage
Risk of post-op visual loss
Analgesia
Spinal cord damage
Pre-op:
Consent:
Transfusion: risk if age >50, obesity, tumour, intra-abdominal pressure, transpeduncular osteotomy
Post-op vision loss
Nerve injury
Scoliosis: restrictive lung pathology +/- pulmonary HTN → PFTs + ABG
Intra-op:
Airway: risk of difficulty with C-spine MILS – consider awake
Jackson table: normal ETT
Prone in Mayfield pins: nasal tube
NMBD: safe for condition
Neuromonitoring: routine + SSEPs, MEPs, BIS
Frequent check of eyes (Wilson frame associated with ischaemic optic neuropathy)
Pressure care
IDC
Glycopyrulate for secretions
Post-op:
Neuro ICU
Analgesia: multimodal
POVL:
Central retinal artery occlusion
Direct globe pressure → IOP → ischaemic
SSx: unilateral vision loss, ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, supra-orbital n. sensory loss
Ischaemic optic neuropathy – risk factors: male, obesity, length >6 hrs, blood loss
Special considerations:
Anterior thoracic spine surgery: thoracotomy – DLT + regional analgesia
Anterior cervical spine surgery:
Airway compromise 2% at 6 – 36 hours
Risk factors:
Multiple level surgery ≥3 levels including one above / including C4 (C1, C2 in particular)
Blood loss >300mL
Duration >5 hr
Combined anterior + posterior approach
Previous cervical surgery
Respiratory disease
Causes: prevertebral oedema (most common), haematoma, CSF leak, infection / abscess
Signs: neck swelling, stridor, respiratory effort, tracheal tug / deviation
Consider prior to extubating: intubation difficulty, facility i.e. 24 hr airway support, halo-thoracic brace,
OSA, resp dz, facial oedema end of case, type of surgery
Management:
Check cuff leak, if concerns or risks above consider intubation until D1 or 2
Airway emergency → remove clips / sutures, AFOI +/- surgical airway

title: Craniotomy
text:
Craniotomy
Craniotomy: removal of part of the skill to expose the brain
Pre-op: routine +
Neuro: deficits, ICP, seizures, GCS
Medications: AEDs, steroids, anticoagulation (?ceased / reversed)
Investigations: routine + TTE / TOE if high risk VAE
Electrolyte – specifically sodium - abnormalities
Considerations:
ICP / CPP
Positioning: pressure care, transducer height
BP targets
Risk of VAE → need for CVC
Expected blood loss
Neuro-monitoring: SSEPs, EEG, transcranial MEPs
Intra-op:
Pre-med generally avoided
Monitoring: routine + neuro + BIS + art line + VAE + ICP
CVS: 2x large bore +/- CVC for VAE and pressor support, fluid warmer
Induction goals: avoid ICP, maintain CPP (65-80mmHg), prevent hypertension if high risk of bleed
Neuroanaesthesia unless specific reason to vary
Rapid ICP management (per ICP notes)
TIVA versus volatile:
TIVA:
PONV (useful in neurosurgery as can be concern for new pathology)
Associated with ICP and better CPP
Prop/remi less hypotension than sevo/remi (but not significant)
No difference between TIVA & inhalation:
Eye opening / extubation time
Surgical time & reported operating conditions
Post-op agitation
Progression-free survival or overall survival
Inhalational:
MAC <1.0 does not ablate effects of CO2 on cerebral blood vessels / effect cerebral autoregulation
Limited studies on NO2 - appears safe for use except sitting position, pneumocephalus
Opioids:
Remifentanil:
Better haemodynamic response to intubation
Rebound hypertension on emergence
Earlier time to first analgesia compared to fentanyl
Ketamine: most data from TBI
In ventilated normocapnic patients shown to have no ICP
Maintains CPP without affecting systemic BP
Neuroprotective by inhibiting cortical spreading depolarisation
No difference in ICU stay / outcomes / mortality
Precedex:
Haemodynamic stability compared to placebo + prop/remi
MAC sparing
post-op opioid requirement
ICP
inflammation → neuroprotection
Compared with prop/remi – comparable haemodynamics + post-op events
Longer recovery time + PACU discharge + first analgesia cf remi
Analgesia:
Paracetamol alone is ineffective, NSAIDs useful if not CI, short acting opioids
Untreated pain → agitation; scalp blocks improve pain scores up to 12 hours + opioids for 24 hr

title: Craniotomy for Tumour Debulking
text:
Craniotomy for Tumour Debulking
Craniotomy +
Important features of tumour:
Type of tumour + location
Mass effects: ICP, N&V → give steroids 48 hours pre-op
+/- need for pre-op lumbar drain
Importance of pre-op imaging:
Size and location of lesion
Choice of anaesthesia: awake versus asleep, neuro-monitoring
Duration of surgery
Degree of oedema + midline shift
Likely patient positioning
Bleeding risk
Venous air embolism (if close to larger vessels)
Anaesthetic considerations:
No difference shown between TIVA & volatile for disease-free survival
Vomiting: an anti-emetic anaesthetic to reduce vomiting (as vomiting can be alarming for new neuro pathology)
Management of “tight” brain: do quick sweep i.e. ABCDEquipment
Airway: tube secured + not kinked, positioning
Breathing: CO2, oxygenation, airway pressures/PEEP
Circulation: blood pressure, venous drainage (ETT should be taped), consider further head up if not in pins
Drugs:
CMRO2: switch to prop if using volatile, pressors/downers, paralysis, anti-epileptics, steroids
Hypertonic / mannitol
Mannitol: satisfactory brain relaxation (at 1mg/kg), lower risk of moderate to severe post-op cerebral
oedema, greater urine output, higher lactate
*risk of cerebral oedema if BBB not in tact
Equipment: use lumbar drain if inserted pre-op
Post-op agitation:
Difficult to assess if new pathology versus emergence agitation

title: Craniotomy for Head Injury
text:
Craniotomy for Head Injury
Priority is to open cranium as quickly as possible
Conflicting issues for intubation:
Raised ICP
Not-fasted → cricoid pressure, sux is okay (only small ICP)
Uncertain C-spine status (10% unstable with GCS <8):
MILS, leave back half of collar as limits atlanto-occipital ext + x blade / stylet
If conscious, alert, not intoxicated + free of distracting injuries should have midline pain, limitation of movement +
neurology in presence of cervical spine #
Uncertain airway status (potential for blood, possible laryngotracheal injury, possible BOS #)
Uncertain volume status
Potentially uncooperative patient
Hypoxaemia
Avoid nasal intubation in setting of facial #s.
Aim Hb >90

title: Craniotomy for Extracranial-Intracranial Bypass
text:
Craniotomy for Extracranial-Intracranial Bypass
Indications: intracerebral atherosclerosis, moya-moya, aneurysm trapping
Intra-op:
Must balance O2 supply and demand – microcirculation often maximally dilated due to chronic ischaemia
Maintain normal / greater than normal CPP
Normocapnia to prevent ‘steal’
MAP 10-20% for temporary arterial occlusion

title: Craniotomy for AVM Malformation
text:
Craniotomy for AVM Malformation
Most commonly presents as ICH w/ 10-30% mortality (can present with an associated aneurysm)
Vascular mass: has a centre (nidus) with blood flow directly from dilated arteries to dilated draining veins creating high flow/low
resistance shunts, may present as ‘steal’ syndrome
Specific issue to AVM: normal perfusion pressure breakthrough
Occurrence of multifocal areas of haemorrhage after resection of high flow low resistance AVMs
Sudden engorgement and swelling of brain → cauliflower like protrusion from cranium – not entirely understood
Intra-op:
Similar principles to aneurysm surgery
Usually lower MAP
Post-op: high risk of seizures + risk that dysautoregulated brain adjacent to resected AVM will develop hyperaemia/oedema +/-
haemorrhage

title: Spontaneous Intracerebral Haemorrhage
text:
Spontaneous Intracerebral Haemorrhage
Based on AHA/ASA guidelines.
Early deterioration is common in first few hours – must be diagnosed quickly.
Paramedics: history, airway management, CVS support, transport to closest acute stroke facility
ED management:
Rapid CT – ?ischaemia v ICH
Severe coagulopathy – must reverse
Early lowering sBP to 140mmHg – associated with better functional outcome + no increase in death / adverse outcomes
Risk factors for underlying vascular abnormalities: age <65yo, F, non-smoker, lobar ICH, intraventricular extension, no hx of HTN
E.g moya-moya, AVM, tumour, cerebral vein thrombosis
IVH occurs in 45% of ICH and is an independent factor associated with poor outcome
Anticoagulation:
OACs constitute 20% of ICH – lower risk than warfarin
Haemodialysis is an option for dabigatran
Warfarin: must rapidly correct; FFP / vit K / prothrombin concentrate – (prothrombin may thrombotic complications)
Antiplatelets: multiplate can aid assessment, in high risk pts platelet transfusion within 12 hr → final haemorrhage size
and independence @ 3mo
ICP: principles same as TBI
ICP monitor if GCS 3 – 8
ICP <20mmHg
CPP 50 – 70mmHg
Immediate management:
No evidence for steroids
Surgery:
Supratentorial haemorrhage: early haematoma evacuation not shown to be beneficial / benefit unknown
Posterior fossa haemorrhage: cerebellar haemorrhage or brainstem compression – surgical decompression has
better outcomes
Should have early aggressive treatment and new DNR orders should be post-poned until D2
Ongoing management:
Neuroprotective measures
Intermittent pneumatic compression + elastic stockings for VTE prophylaxis
Initial monitoring should take place in a dedicated stroke unit / ICU
Treat seizures (no evidence for prophylaxis)
Formal screening for dysphagia prior to PO intake
Most common medical complications: pneumonia, aspiration, resp failure, PE, sepsis
MDT rehab
Prevention of recurrence: BP management, OSA, obesity, lifestyle modification
Optimal timing of resumption of anticoagulation is unknown

title: Subarachnoid Haemorrhage
text:
Subarachnoid Haemorrhage
5% of all strokes. Mortality 30 – 65%. Mostly ruptured saccular “berry” aneurysms at bifurcations (most haemodynamic stress)
RFs: HTN, smoking, AD PCKD, Ehlers Danlos, NF1, Marfan’s, coarctation of aorta
Aetiology:
Non-aneurysmal
Aneurysmal:
Location:
Anterior 85% (ACOM, MCA)
Posterior 15% (basilar, PICA,
cerebellar)
Risk of rupture:
Size >7mm
Growth
Posterior circ > anterior circ
Classification:
Small: <12mm
Large: 12 – 24mm
Giant: >24mm
Presentation:
18% die pre-hospital
Thunderclap headache: sentinel headache, meningism
Neuro: LOC, N&V, photophobia, neck stiffness, focal neurology
Neurogenic pulmonary oedema (22%, more common in posterior circ)
Stress CM
Evaluation:
Stroke series: CTB non-con, CT perfusion, CT arch to COW (+/- MRA)
LP: xanthochromia, RBC
DSA: gold standard for aneurysm diagnosis
ECG: short PR, prolonged QTc +/- canyon T waves, ST depression
No relationship between ECG and cardiac dysfunction on TTE
Risk of Takatsubo’s
Severity ∝ neurological injury
Risk of Torsades with prolonged QTc
Bloods: routine + G&H + trops + TFTs
SAH grading:
WFNS (clinical)
Grade I
GCS 15, no motor deficit
Grade II
GCS 13-14, no motor deficit
Grade III
GCS 13-14, motor deficit
Grade IV
GCS 7-12
Grade V
GCS 3-6
Fisher (radiological) – validated for predicting risk of vasospasm
Grade I
Blood <1mm, no IVH
24%
Grade II
Blood <1mm, bilateral IVH
33%
Grade III
Blood >1mm, no bilateral IVH
34%
Grade IV
Blood >1mm, bilateral IVH
40%
Hunt & Hess: surgical risk based on initial neuro examination
No IVH
IVH
Blood <1mm
Grade 1
Grade 2
Blood >1mm
Grade 3
Grade 4

title: Subarachnoid Haemorrhage
text:
Management
ABCs
Intubation if: GCS ≤8, ICP, hypoxia or hypercapnoea, haemodynamic instability, need for sedation / paralysis
Transfer to neurocritical centre
Prevent re-bleed:
Bed rest
Analgesia
Euvolaemia
Stop + reverse anticoagulation
BP control:
Target sBP <160mmHg, MAP <110mmHg
Rx: labetalol, clevidipine, hydralazine
Prevent secondary injury:
Neuroprotection: normothermia, normal O2, BSL 6-10mM
Treat seizures
Stool softeners
DVT prophylaxis: mechanical
Prevent / treat vasospasm:
Nimodipine: 60mg PO q4 hourly for 21 days
Commence with 96hr of SAH – note no evidence that it affects vasospasm or DCI – only proven for
aneurysmal SAH
MgSO4 no effect (MASH-II)
Normoglycaemia
Euvolaemia + hypertensive augmentation
DSA +/- angioplasty pr intra-arterial vasodilator
Early aneurysm securing: clipping or coiling
Complications:
Mortality 40% at 7 days
Rebleeding:
Highest in first 12 hours (5-10% in first 24 hours)
Mortality 70%
ULTRA trial:
TxA: no clear benefit in clinical outcome at 6mo
No difference: rebleed prior to treatment, good
clinical outcomes, all-cause mortality, delayed
cerebral ischaemia, thromboembolic events
May delayed cerebral ischaemia
Vasospasm / delayed cerebral ischaemia:
Incidence 30%
Risk days 4 – 14, peak at 7-8 days
Raised ICP:
Hydrocephalus: EVD, 22% develop shunt dependence
Hyponatraemia: 30%, SIADH versus cerebral salt wasting
Seizures: 6 – 18%
Anaemia: 18%, target Hb >80
Cardiac: 25 – 35%
Neurogenic pulmonary oedema (2’ catecholamine surge), stress CM
Trop elevation in 36%
Hyperglycaemia
Fever
HPA dysfunction
Terms:
Delayed neurological deterioration (DND):
clinically detected deterioration after
stabilisation that is not due to a re-bleed
Delayed cerebral ischaemia (DCI): any
neurological deterioration >1 hour
presumed due to ischaemia (and other
causes excluded) – occurs in 30-40% in
those who have Fisher grade 3/4

title: Coiling
text:
Perioperative Management of Subarachnoid Haemorrhage
Management: coiling v clipping
ISAT trial:
Primary outcome death or dependence @ 1yr
Significantly better outcome in coiling
Despite higher risk of rebleed amongst coiling group (survival benefits for 7y)
Indications for clipping:
Wide-necked aneurysms
Diseased or occluded proximal vessels
Otherwise complex anatomy
Pre-op for both:
ASSESS:
Cardiac fx: ?Takatsubo’s, long QTc
Assess for APO
Discuss BP targets with surgeons
MANAGE:
G&H + crossmatch
REFER: ICU
Coiling
Anaesthesia considerations:
•
Blood management
o
Knowledge of closest blood fridge
•
Warm: fluids, patient
•
Radiology precautions (distance, ALARA, PPE)
•
Lines on left
Prepare for acute bleed - recognition:
Bradycardia / hypertension
Contrast extravasation
GCS if awake
BIS / EEG / DSA
Management of bleed – initially they will aim to keep coiling:
sBP <140mmHg
Reverse heparin with protamine 1mg / 100iu of heparin
Consider antiplt reversal (pooled plt, desmopressin)
Manage ICP
Blood management
Consult neurosurgery early (may require EVD, crani)
Alert theatres

title: Clipping
text:
Clipping
Craniotomy considerations+
Pre-op:
Must discuss BP targets
Must have plan for rupture:
Cross-matched blood in fridge
Adenosine
Defib pads on
Uppers and downers – reasonable to site CVC if clipping following a bleed cf elective
Important considerations of aneurysm:
Neuromonitoring: SSEPs, BIS, NIRS
BP targets: discuss with surgeons but generally
If normal ICP: sBP <140mmHg, ≥60mmHg
IHAST: normothermia > hypothermia → hypothermia → bacteraemia
GA with controlled induction
Transmural pressure = MAP – ICP
Avoid rapid  or  of blood pressure → rapid change in transmural pressure gradient → risk rupture
Reasonable to reduce BP and hyperventilate just prior to dural opening
Management of rupture + acute bleed
BEFORE aneurysm exposure:
CPP ≥50-60mmHg
MAP >90mmHg
ICP (CO2, osmo Rx, venous drainage)
AFTER aneurysm exposure: must create bloodless field to facilitate clipping
Induce hypotension → MAP 50-60mmHg
CMRO2 w/ burst suppression
Flow arrest:
BP: labetalol, esmolol
Adenosine: 0.3mg/kg + ALS drugs + defib pads
CI: reactive airways dz, severe CAD, conduction abnormality, allergy
Method: place transcutaneous pacing pads → give dose
Repeat dose only if SR and normotensive
Temporary clipping:
BP facilitates clipping
BP then facilitates collateral circulation (MAP 10-20% titrated to monitoring)
Post-clipping aim sBP <140mmHg
IHAST post-hoc analysis:
Pharmacological burst suppression not fully substantiated
Pts with temp vessel occlusion >20mins have worse outcomes despite pharmacological intervention 2’
ischaemia distal to clip
Only barbiturates have been shown to protect against ischaemia though prolonged wake up, reserve for
when prolonged vessel occlusion is unavoidable
Indocyanide green: 25mg IV (prepare for NIRS, peripheral sats)
Remi good for rapid extubation + lack of straining
Adenosine adverse effects: flushing, dyspnoea, chest pain, GI, headache, AV block, AF, ST changes, arrhythmia, bronchospasm
Defib pads on
Specific considerations:
effect of adenosine: cardiac transplant, dipyridamole, carbamazepine
effect of adenosine: methylxanthines, WPW, SVT, AV block, afterload dependent
High degree of caution if severe CAD, AV node disease, PPM, WPW, afterload dependent, Rx (verapamil, digoxin,
carbamazepine)
Dose: 0.3mg/kg – higher doses may be needed if no central access
Repeat doses only if HR & BP at baseline

title: Posterior Fossa Surgery
text:
Posterior Fossa Surgery
Contains: cerebellum, ascending and descending sensorimotor pathways, cranial nerve nuclei, cardiorespiratory centres,
reticular activating system, neural pathways for crucial protective reflexes
Indications:
Tumour including cerebellarpontine
Vascular lesions e.g. aneuryms, AVM
Cranial nerve decompression
Congenital e.g. Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker
Haemorrhage decompression
Pre-op: routine +
Cerebellar dysfunction / CN dysfunction / ICP or hydrocephalus / VAE
Sitting craniotomy:
Benefits:
Gravity → CSF & venous drainage → ICP, “bloodless” field, less retraction
Direct surgical access
intrathoracic pressure
intraoccular pressure
Ergonomics
Risks:
cardiac preload
Post-op tension pneumocephalus
Extreme neck flexion → upper airway obstruction → impaired venous/lymphatic drainage, risk of kinked ETT,
pressure injuries
Macroglossia 2’ oedema – avoid unnecessary oral crowding
Must maintain >2 finger breads between chin & sternum
Potential for neuropraxia & pressure sores
Unfavourable position if need for CPR
Venous air embolism: incidence 75%
Venous pooling
Unexplained quadriplegia (presumed 2’ cervical spine stretching)
CI:
R→L cardiac shunt
Severe spinal stenosis (reported cause of quadriplegias)
Severe AS
Relative CI: PFO, uncontrolled HTN, extremes of age, autonomic neuropathy
Anaesthetic considerations:
Reinforced ETT, bite block
Circulation: transducer at level of tragus
RIJ CVC: for VAE aspiration
Neuromonitoring: BIS + EEG, SSEPs, MEPs, EMG
VAE monitoring: pre-cordial doppler, TOE
Risk of haemodynamic swings and arrhythmias associated with irritation of brainstem – warn surgeon
Posterior Fossa Syndrome: constellation of SSx
SSx:
Dysarthria
Irritability
Hypotonia
CN deficit
Ataxia
Dysphagia
Rare in adults cf 30% incidence in children

title: Microvascular Decompression
text:
Microvascular Decompression
Usually for CN V (trigeminal neuralgia), VII (hemifacial spasm), and IX
Dissect down → place insulating Teflon pad between vessel and nerve
Auditory SEPs can reduce risk of hearing loss from cerebellar retraction/stretch
Monitoring:
CN V decompression: brainstem auditory SEPs
CN VII decompression: brainstem auditory SEPs, facial nerve EMG

title: Vestibular Schwannoma
text:
Vestibular Schwannoma
Most common lesion at cerebellopontine angle. Benign. Usually younger pts, mostly has vestibular/hearing changes
Common origin of cochlear component of CN VIII and facial nerve → risk of hearing loss and facial n. palsy
Monitoring:
Facial nerve: EMG
Cochlear nerve: brainstem auditory SEPs (for tumours up to 1.5cm)
Long procedure: translabyrinthine vs retrosigmoid approach with ENT
No-paralysis – usually CN VII monitoring
Beware: close to brain stem + sinuses

title: Pituitary Surgery
text:
Pituitary Surgery
Pituitary (500-900mg) occupies sella turcica of the sphenoid bone at base of skull
Related to: 3rd ventricle, hypothalamus, visual pathways, CN III-VI, cavernous sinus, internal carotid arteries
Damage to surrounds can lead to CN palsy, visual field defects, major haemorrhage, CSF leak
Anterior lobe (adenohypophysis): ACTH, GH, LH / FSH, TSH, prolactin, MSH
Posterior lobe (neurohypophysis): ADH, oxytocin
Blood supply: ICA → superior hypophyseal a. (anterior pituitary) + inferior hypophyseal a. (posterior pituitary) → venous
drainage → cavernous sinus → IJV
Tumours:
Secretory versus non-secretory
Size: micro (<10mm) versus macro (>10mm)
Presentation:
Mass effects:
Visual status
Headache
Hypopituitism i.e. endocrine fx 2’ compression:
Gonadotrophins
GH
ACTH → hypoadrenal state / Addisonian crisis
Correct hypocortisolism + hypoNa+ pre-op
TSH
Secreting microadenomas: prolactin / GH / ACTH / thyroid
Prolactin secreting: most common
ACTH secreting: → Cushings dz → OSA (70%), HTN, central obesity, diabetes
GH secreting: → acromegaly → large tongue + narrow glottis
Incidental finding
Pre-op considerations:
Acromegaly:
Airway: macrognathia, macroglossia, large epiglottis, OSA (70%) → difficult intubation / BVM 40%
Respiratory: kyphoscoliosis, myopathy
CVS: difficult IV access (tough skin), HTN, LVH, IHD, arrhythmia / heart block, cardiomyopathy, valve dz
Neuro: entrapment syndromes (inc. RLN)
Endo: diabetes
Rx: somatostatin analogue, dopamine agonists
Cushings disease:
Airway: difficult positioning 2’ buffalo hump
Body: truncal obesity, moon facies, friable skin, thin veins, osteoporosis, exophthalmos
Resp: OSA, proximal myopathy
CVS: difficult IV CVC, HTN, LVH, diastolic impairment, high risk VTE, IHD
Endo: diabetes, peptic ulceration
Hyperprolactinaemia: dopamine agonists → postural hypotension
Central DI / SIADH
Hyperthyroidism
Emergency surgery: → consider hydrocortisone for acute insufficiency
Acute pituitary haemorrhage
Infarction (Sheehan syndrome)
Sickle cell crisis
Pre-op Ix:
Routine bloods + specific endocrine +/- treatment / correction
TTE in acromegaly, cushings
Visual field testing
Surgical technique mainly transsphenoidal, occasionally craniotomy

title: Transsphenoidal Pituitary Surgery
text:
Transsphenoidal Pituitary Surgery
Intra-op:
Neurosurg GA
ETT secured side opposite to surgeons dominant hand
Supine + head up with relative hypotension
Intranasal vasoconstrictor by surgeon (adrenaline, cophenylcaine or cocaine) – CVS management
Steroid supplementation is controversial – d/w surgeon prior to giving
Throat pack
Glycaemic control esp. Cushings / acromegaly
Smooth emergence: suction well (bloody +++) after removing throat pack + avoids CSF leak
Occasionally requires intra-op MRI
Post-op:
Nasal packing
Neuro-emergence
CPAP contra-indicated – care ++ with OSA
ICU
Complications:
CSF leak
Meningitis
Hypopituitism
DI
CN injury
Cavernous sinus / ICA injury

title: Shunt Insertion
text:
Shunt Insertion
Indicated for relief of hydrocephalus and idiopathic intracranial hypertension
Most common: ventriculoperitoneal shunt
Catheter inserted via burr hole into lateral ventricle on non-dominant side
Tubing travels subcutaneously to epigastrium → peritoneal space
Other shunts:
Distal end: may be intrapleural, right atrial
Proximal end: may arise from lumbar spine
Anaesthetic considerations:
Pre-op: cause of hydrocephalus
?Congenital cardiac defects
Management of Rx: acetazolamide, frusemide, anticonvulsants
Neuro exam + document ?SSx raised ICP
Peri-operative management of raised ICP
Maintain CPP
Neuro GA +
Gastric decompression (avoid gastric puncture)
Muscle relaxation to aid abdominal portion
Nursed flat post-op to avoid excessive rapid drainage of CSF
Monitor for subdural haematoma / bleed from bridging veins

title: Shunt Revision
text:
Shunt Revision
Considerations:
Neuro+
•
Reason for VP shunt revision
o
?Infection
o
?ICP
•
Review previous anaesthetic chart
•
RSI if raised ICP
•
Maintain adequate CPP (MAP – ICP)

section_path: Anaesthetic Considerations for Patients with Neurosurgical Implants
title: Anaesthetic Considerations for Patients with Neurosurgical Implants
text:
Anaesthetic Considerations for Patients with Neurosurgical Implants
Neurosurgical pts can be safely anaesthetised for non-neurosurg by adhering to general principles
Pre-op: routine +
GCS + neurological deficits - documented
Note location +/- path of shunt
Assess device working (?SSx of raised ICP)
Drug history:
Antiplatelets: intracranial stents
Anti-epileptics
Anti-parkinsonian drugs

title: Shunts
text:
Shunts
Considerations:
Peritoneal shunts:
Risk of intracranial CO2 transmission with laparoscopic surgery
Laparoscopic surgery not CI – one way valve can tolerate pressure <300mmHg no clamp required (plus
clamping will cease draining + potentially damage device)
Potential for retrograde infection → meningioencephalitis / ventriculitis
Presence of shunt may risk presence of abdominal adhesions (especially if multiple revisions)
Ventriculo-plural shunts:
CXR to assess for any pleural effusions (do not drain, seek neurosurg advice)
PPV can cause shunt obstruction
Ventriculo-atrial shunts:
Assess for pulmonary HTN
IJ + subclavian lines should be avoided
Lumbar-peritoneal: must avoid hypotension, careful patient positioning

title: Intracranial Stents
text:
Intracranial Stents
Must know: why, when, anatomical location, potential consequences of stent occlusion, antiplt Rx
Often placed to facilitate coiling of wide-necked aneurysms

title: Neurostimulation Devices
text:
Neurostimulation Devices
Types:
Vagal nerve stimulators: MOA poorly understood, modulates NT excitability
DBS: stimulate thalamus/globus pallidus/subthalamic nuclei
Spinal cord stimulators: stimulate spinal cord at selected levels
Neuraxial not CI as long as away from stimulator – must obtain op report +/- imaging for details
Intrathecal baclofen pumps: sited in abdomen s/c → connected to lumbar IT sac (malfunction can cause acute baclofen
withdrawal which is a medical emergency)
No current peri-op guidelines for neurosurgical stimulators. Check: type / location, date of implantation / last check, SSx control,
programmability, SSx when off, current Rx
Management:
Limit diathermy – place earth plate far from device
Discuss plan for defib if required
MRI safety must be d/w radiology + device technician
ECT safe, turn device off prior

title: Traumatic Brain Injury
text:
Traumatic Brain Injury
Based on brain trauma foundation guidelines. Three phases: treatment, monitoring, target thresholds
High risk C-spine injury
Treatment: AIM IS TO AVOID SECONDARY INJURY
Bilateral decompressive craniotomies to improve outcomes in pts with persistent ICP elevations (refractory to 1st line
treatment) is not recommended in pts without mass lesion(s) e.g. EDH, SDH
RESCUE ICP trial: decompressive crani → mortality, functional dependence
A large fronto-temporo-parietal decompression is recommended over a smaller one
Hypothermia: prophylactic not recommended
Hyperosmolar therapy:
Effective for raised ICP (though avoid subsequent sBP <90mmHg)
Should be restricted prior to ICP monitoring unless signs of herniation or progressive deterioration
CSF drainage via EVD zeroed at midbrain:
Continuous ICP monitoring > intermittent
CSF drainage in first 12hr if GCS <6 may be considered
Excessive drainage → herniation
Hyperventilation: only recommended as temporary temporising measure for reduction of ICP – should be avoided in first
24hr when CBF often critically reduced
Barbiturate therapy:
Prophylactic burst suppression not recommended without evidence of ICP
Recommended for refractory ICP resistant to maximal medical therapy
Haemodynamic stability prior to administration is essential
Steroids: contra-indicated
Nutrition:
Recommended by at least D5
Jejunal feeding recommended to reduce VAP
Infection prophylaxis
Early tracheostomy if benefit thought to outweigh complications
Use of povidone iodine oral care not recommended to reduce VAP and may cause an increase in ARDS
Antimicrobial impregnated catheters reduce infection related to EVD
DVT prophylaxis:
LMWH/UFH +/- mechanical DVT prophylaxis may be used – weigh against risk of ICH expansion (risk v benefit)
Seizure prophylaxis:
Prophylactic: no evidence
Phenytoin can reduce early seizures
Not enough evidence for keppra v phenytoin
Monitoring:
ICP: indicated in salvageable patient + GCS ≤8 after resuscitation with →
Imaging:
Abnormal CT scan: haematoma, contusion, swelling, herniation, compressed basal cisterns
OR normal CT with ≥2: age >40yo, motor posturing, sBP <90mmHg
Shown to in hospital and 2 week mortality
CPP: recommended, target 60 – 70mmHg
SjvO2: may be considered
Brain tissue O2 monitoring is not recommended
Target thresholds:
sBP:
Age: 15-49yo: ≥110mmHg, 50-69yo ≥100mmHg, >70yo ≥110mmHg
If other injury present – compromise sBP 90-100mmHg
ICP: treat if >22mmHg in combination with clinical and CT findings
CPP: target 60 – 70mmHg – consider autoregulatory range for patient (though avoid aggressive attempts to maintain ≥70 →
risk of ARDS)
Other:
Manage in specialist neurosurgical centre → aim to prevent secondary brain injury
Avoid hypotonic fluids and albumin
Classification of severity:
Mild
GCS 13 – 15
Moderate
GCS 9 – 12
Severe
GCS ≤8

title: Endovascular Clot Retrieval
text:
Endovascular Clot Retrieval
Guidelines for eligibility:
Ischaemic stroke with proven large vessel occlusion on CTA (ICA, MCA, basilar)
Independent pre-morbid function (MRS 0-2) – consider social and domestic interactions e.g. banking, shopping, driving
NIHSS ≥5
Time window: when procedure can be completed within 6 hours (up to 24 hours for basilar stroke)
Intravenous thrombolysis commenced (if not CI) – alteplase 0.9mg/kg
Accessible to clot retrieval + assessment by neuro-interventionalist
Considerations:
Remote anaesthesia
Time is brain – rapid pre-op assessment
GCS useful for assessing awake versus asleep
If asleep – consider D/X blade if predicting difficult airway due to flat
bed, limited ramping
NIBP v art line: q1 min BPs and then transduce femoral access / site art line
after if safe, otherwise quick art line
Consider room set up for monitoring – usually all lines on left
Neuroprotective measures intra-op
During retrieval: haemodynamics (BP target, pts can become vagal), emesis
Emergence: try to control BP, agitation, neuro assessment (hydrocephalus, worsening ischaemia, rethrombosis)
GA versus awake:
Previously data arguably skewed as more unwell patients more likely to have GA
SIESTA: in centres with high quality, specialised neuroanaesthesia, GA treated ECR →
Superior recanalization rates
Better functional outcome at 3 months than patients with conscious sedation
Blood pressure control:
Can be loss of autoregulation + possibility of loss of compensatory vasodilatory capability distal to the occluded vessel
Collateral flow can be compromised during hypotension
Protect ischaemic penumbra before recanalization
BP reduction prior to recanalization is associated with larger infarct volumes + worse functional outcomes
Rasmussen et al 2020: MAP <70 for >10mins & MAP >90 for >45mins associated with worse 90 day outcomes
MAP <70 for 5 min showed shift towards a worse 90 day outcome
For each 10 mins MAP <70, odds of shifting towards worse outcomes increased by 30%
For every continuous 10 mins with MAP <70 worse outcomes increased by 62%
MASTERSTROKE – induced targeted hypertension
SNACC 2014 recommendations:
Choice of anaesthetic technique should be individualised (propofol → improved functional independence)
SBP 140-180, DBP <105 (post reperfusion adjust per interventionalist)
SpO2 >92%, PaO2 >60mmHg
PaCO2 35-45 (one study shown that mean ETCO2 sig higher in pts with favourable 90 day MRS)
Normoglycaemia
Euvolaemia
Post-op:
Extubate to assess neurology if able
Stroke unit or ICU
Lie flat for 6hr post-groin puncture
Aspirin at 24-48 hours
Complete stroke work up
Complications:
Angiooedema 2’ thrombolysis
Contrast anaphylaxis
Vessel rupture / ICH +/- haemorrhagic transformation later
Groin haematoma / vascular injury / retroperitoneal bleed
ECR versus thrombolysis:
ECR 33% v 19% functional independence
(treatment within 6hr) (MR CLEAN
trial)
ECR disability at 90 days (NNT to reduce
disability by one level on modified
rankin scale is 2.6)
Door-to-groin puncture time – 1hr
increase in onset of reperfusion time
→ 38%  in good outcome

title: Awake Craniotomy
text:
Awake Craniotomy
Indication: epileptic foci, eloquent tumour resection (speech, motor, vision), DBS (PD, Tourette's, essential tremor, dystonia)
Scalp block: 7 nerves on each side
Supraorbital n. (V1): supraorbital notch
1mL
Supratrochlear n. (V1): 1cm medial to supraorbital above eyebrow line
0.5mL
Zygomaticotemporal n. (V2): groove lateral to eye, LOR
2mL below fascia
Auriculotemporal n. (V3): 1cm anterior to auricle/tragus, above TMJ
1mL below, 1mL above fascia
Greater occipital n. (C2-3): medial to occipital artery, above nuchal line
5mL
Lesser occipital n. (C2-3): 2.5cm lateral to greater occipital n.
5mL
Greater auricular n.: 2cm posterior to auricle at level of tragus
≤2.5mg/kg 0.2% ropivacaine with adrenaline 1:200,000
Total ~20mL
Pre-op:
Patient selection crucial (must be able to tolerate awake)
Airway assessment: limited airway access 2’ pins / frame
+/- functional MRI
Intra-op seizure foci: surgeons may discontinue or halve anti-epileptics for DBS – do not use benzo pre-med
Wada test: i.e. selective hemispheric testing
CIs:
Absolute: patient refusal, inability to lie still, confusion
Relative: cough, intellectual disability, inability to lie flat, ESL, OSA/obesity, difficult airway, large expected blood loss
Intra-op:
Scalp block + local infiltration by surgeons – usually requires imaging prior to commencing
Monitoring: routine + art line + BIS + capnography
Technique: MDT decision – asleep/awake or asleep/awake/asleep or awake throughout with sedation
Anaesthetic agents: titratable, fast on/off with no effects after cessation (prop/remi/precedex)
Deepen for: pins, incision, bone flap, dura – discontinue once bone flap removed
Lighten for: cortical mapping, resection
Deepen for: closure
Engage with patient, swab soaked with ice water, simple analgesia for back pain, keep warm + IDC (if long / mannitol)
Intra-op complications:
Seizures 3-16%: flood area with ice water, may need propofol (airway instrumentation not normally required)
Loss of airway whilst in head holder: adjuncts + LMA - must know how to rapidly remove frame if needed
Intracerebral haematoma: must manage hypertension (if substantial haematoma may need craniotomy for DBS)
VAE 2’ spont venting
Post-op:
PONV + systemic analgesia
ICU + neuromonitoring

title: Venous Air Embolism
text:
Venous Air Embolism
Pathophysiology: surgery where operating field is above level of the heart or surgical site under pressure
risk 2’ major cerebral venous sinuses that are non-collapsible due to dural attachments i.e. venous pressure < atm pressure
Most commonly: posterior fossa and cervical spine surgery (may also occur in supratentorial procedures)
RFs: sitting position, posterior fossa surgery, hypovolaemia, CVC insertion / removal
All pts should have central access in place to aspirate air (tip 2cm distal to SVC-RA junction)
Prevention: good surgical technique, volume, early detection + vigilance
Detection: look for drop in two domains of ETCO2, PAP, CVP, BP, ECG, sats
At risk situations consider:
TOE: gold standard (can detect as small as 0.02mL/kg air in RA)
Pre-cordial doppler (mill-wheel murmur)
Determined by volume of air + rate of accumulation (volume for fatal
embolism 200-300mL)
Management:
Declare emergency
Prevent further entrainment:
Inform surgeon
Flood field with warm saline
Lower the head (below RA) + elevate legs
Tourniquet neck i.e. jugular venous compression
size: 100% O2, aspirate CVC, stop NO2
Overcome mechanical obstruction: position, PEEP, vasopressors + inotropic support
Resuscitate: consider compressions to break up
M&M 2’ hypoxia, pHTN +/- RHF, paradoxical air embolus
Paradoxical Air Embolism
PFO ~25% all pts. Likely requires significant right heart pressure + air volume.
Risk:
by: PEEP (previously used to risk of VAE – now abandoned)
by: generous fluid administration
Treatment:
Hyperbaric O2 therapy: improves prognosis in cerebral gas embolism, start <8 hr

title: Vasospasm
text:
Vasospasm
Definition: observed narrowing of intracranial arteries (though most occur in small vessels)
Pathophysiology: Hb breakdown byproduct → vessel spasm (volume of bleed ∝ vasospasm)
Prevention: nimodipine 60mg q4 hourly for 21 days – commence within 48hr post-event (morbidity, but does not vasospasm
on DSA) – selective for cerebral circulation, improves outcomes 2’:
Dilation of small arteries not seen on angio
Ca2+ dependent excitotoxicity
plt aggregation (~40% in cerebral infarction and poor outcomes)
SSx: change in sensorium or new neurological deficit - commonly D4-14 (highest D7-10) but can persist up to D21
Diagnosis:
DSA (gold standard): up to 70% of patients with SAH detected on DSA – 30% have clinical symptoms
Diagnostic +/- therapeutic via balloon angioplasty and/or intra-arterial vasodilators (CCB, milrinone, papaverine)
Management: triple H i.e. hypervolaemia, hypertension, haemodilution (new management suggests normovolaemia)
For surgery: aim for waking BP
No evidence for statins or MgSO4

title: Tension Pneumocephalus
text:
Tension Pneumocephalus
Mostly occur in posterior fossa surgery and supratentorial surgery. Can use NO2 prior to closure (may have clinical advantage,
may resorb quicker), but do not use after. Mass effect likely worse post-op due to supine position + extubation. Rx: drill-hole +
dural needle puncture. May also develop de novo if there is a residual dural defect between nasal sinuses + intracranial space.

title: Seizures
text:
Seizures
Can occur awake or anaesthetised (less common).
Causes:
Neurosurgical: cortical stimulation, high risk tumour resection (frontal, temporal), acute haemorrhage, ischaemia
Non-neurosurgical: metabolic, hypocapnia, drug withdrawal, subtherapeutic anticonvulsants
SSx: difficult if paralysed – may need to rely on tachycardia, hypertension, hypercapnia, EEG
Management:
ABCDE
Cease surgical cause if able
Cold saline irrigation
Rx: propofol (0.5 – 1mg/kg), midazolam (2-5mg), thio (2-5mg/kg)
Bite block
MDT decision re: anticonvulsants

title: Neurosurgery Cardiac Arrest
text:
Neurosurgery Cardiac Arrest
Confirm arrest (clinical signs, monitoring, O2 to 100%)
Inform team + eliminate surgical cause
Asystole: consider retraction, instrumentation
VAE: flood field with saline, put patient head down if possible
Bleeding: control haemorrhage as best able (whilst minimising trauma / contamination)
If CPR not effective/possible in patient’s position → flip patient +/- release pins – ensure head is supported
START ALS with specific considerations
Give initial adrenaline boluses of 50-100mcg IV (up to 1mg – if no ROSC subsequent 1mg doses in cycles)
TTE ASAP to check for VAE

title: Hyponatraemia
text:
Hyponatraemia
Severity: mild 130 – 135, mod 126 – 129, severe <125
Hyponatraemia
Hypovolaemia
Normovolaemia
Hypervolaemia
Cerebral salt wasting
Adrenal insufficiency
Ketonuria
GI losses
Sweating
Blood loss
Diuretics
SIADH
Thiazides
Adrenal insufficiency
Hypothyroidsm
Iatrogenic
CCF
Renal failure
Liver failure
Iatrogenic
Incidence: SAH 50%, TBI 20%, brain tumours 15%
SIADH
Impaired water excretion due to inability to suppress ADH
Normovolaemia (or mild hypervolaemia)
Causes: TBI, SAH, CNS tumour / infection, drug induced (AEDs), pulmonary pathology (particularly pneumonia)
Cause: ADH release at a lower threshold →
Serum osmols <280mOsm/kg
Na <135
Urine osmolality > serum osmolality (i.e. inappropriately concentrated)
Urine Na >18mM
Normal renal, adrenal and thyroid function
Rx: treat cause, fluid restriction (self-limiting), hypertonic saline if severe
Cerebral Salt Wasting
Triad: low or normal Na, high or normal serum osmols, volume contraction, high urine sodium (>50mM)
Causes: SAH (correlated with symptomatic vasospasm), TBI, tumour, stroke, infection
Pathophysiology: BNP → aldosterone synthesis → renal sodium loss
Rx: IVF replacement with normal/hypertonic saline (endpoint – normovolaemia, normonatraemia), fludricortisone, sodium
tablets

title: Hypernatraemia
text:
Hypernatraemia
Diabetes Insipidus
Cause: failure of ADH release from HPA
Diabetes insipidus:
>3L/day, or >4mL/kg/hr of abnormally dilute urine
Serum sodium >145
Urine osmols <350mmol/kg
Serum osmols >310mmol/kg
SSx: polyuria, polydipsia, thirst
DI tri-phasic:
Polyuria: 4-8 days due to HPA dysfunction
Anti-diuretic phase: 2-14 days of uncontrolled ADH release
Recurrence of DI: once store is depleted (often permanent)
Rx:
IVF: hourly maintenance + 2/3 previous hour’s urine volume – type of fluid dictated by pt electrolytes
DDVAP 200-400mcg IV q6-12hr (usually when hourly requirement is >400mL)

title: Opthalmology
text:
Opthalmology
Anatomy:
•
Optic foramen:
o
Optic nerve
o
Ophthalmic artery (ICA)
•
Orbit:
o
Depth: 40-50mm
o
Volume: 30mL
▪
Globe 7mL
▪
Axial length (corneal surface → retina): 25mm (axial length >26mm i.e. myopia → subtenon or GA)
•
Innervation:
o
Motor: all oculomotor (CN III) apart from:
▪
SO 4
▪
LR 6
▪
Orbicularis oculi CN 7
o
Sensory:
▪
V1
▪
V2
o
Autonomic:
▪
SNS: ciliary nerves (superior cervical ganglion)
▪
PNS: oculomotor
Compartments:
•
Globe
•
Pre-septal space
•
Peribulbar (extraconal):
o
Posterior to septum outside cone
o
Contents: lacrimal and frontal nerves
o
CN IV
•
Retrobulbar (intraconal)
o
Posterior to septum within rectus muscles
o
CN II, III, VI, nasociliary n., ciliary ganglion
o
Ophthalmic vessels
Ocular reflexes:
•
Oculocardiac: trigeminal → vagus (release, LA, atropine) – avoid CO2
•
Oculorespiratory: trigeminal → pons (control ventilation)
•
Oculoemetic: trigeminal → vagus – best treated with regional block
Above common in strabismus Sx.

title: Intraocular Pressure
text:
Intraocular Pressure
IOP: tension exerted by contents of the globe on surrounding corneo-scleral envelope
Normal: 10-20mmHg; IOPP = MAP - IOP
Role:
•
Maintain corneal curvature
•
Maintain refracting index
Contents are a fixed volume except:
•
Aqueous humour: actively secreted by ciliary body (Na-K-ATPase, carbonic anhydrase)
o
Posterior to anterior chamber via pupil → canal of schlemm → episcleral veins; production relatively constant
o
Impaired drainage:
▪
Open angle glaucoma: sclerosis of trabecular network
▪
Closed angle glaucoma: obstructed drainage
▪
CVP
•
Choroidal blood volume
Factors affecting IOP:
•
Static:
o
with age
o
IOP  axial length
•
Dynamic:
o
Diurnal; highest in morning
o
Arterial blood: aurtoregulated, fall IOP
Affect of anaesthesia:
IOP
IOP
No Effect on IOP
Hyperthemia
Foreign body
Suxamethonium
Laryngoscopy
Ocular blocks
CO2, O2
Coughing, straining, vomiting
Valsalva
CVP
Supine, prone, trendelenberg
Mechanical obstruction i.e. tube tie
Metabolic alkalosis
Opioids + sedation (except ket)
Acetazolamide
Mannitol
B-blockers
Metabolic acidosis
Ketamine
Midaz
Non-depolarising NMBAs
LMA
Most important is episcleral venous pressure determined by CVP
Consequences of IOP:
•
Open eye injury → expulsion of contents
•
Retinal artery occlusion
•
Retinal ischaemia
•
Visual field loss
Anaesthetic goals:
•
Balance aspiration risk with IOP risk; smooth induction
•
Avoid coughing / straining
•
Blunt HTN to laryngoscopy
•
LPV with normoxia, ETCO2 35 – 40
•
Tape ETT
•
Avoid PONV
•
Smooth extubation

title: Pre-Op Assessment
text:
Pre-Op Assessment
Goals:
•
Optimise
•
Counsel, consent
•
Ascertain if suitable for day case
ASSESS:
•
History::
o
Ability to lie flat + still (movement disorder, backpain, vertigo, claustrophobia)
o
Urinary / faecal incontinence
o
Hearing impairment
o
Cognition / capacity
o
Coagulation
o
Opthal history: axial length, scleral buckle
▪
Risk of long axial length:
•
Known myopia + history of vision improving with age
•
Prescription stronger than -4
•
Exam:
o
Nystagmus
o
Flat
o
Single eye → GA (do not risk block)
•
Ix:
o
Coags if indicated
o
Opthal imaging (axial length)
MANAGE:
•
Continue all meds
•
Coagulation as required (usually continue)
Day of Surgery:
•
BP:
o
>180 – defer
o
<180 but high → give reg antihypertensives if missed, or treat aiming <160 + move later in list
•
Mark side
•
Ensure no active infection
•
Ensure pre-op drops
o
Inadequate dilatation after phenylephrine:
•
Block (may dilate)
•
If still inadequate give IV labetalol aiming sBP <160 then administer phenylephrine 2.5% to anterior
chamber
•
Don’t block until marked if toric lens
Intra-op:
•
O2 under drapes
•
Comfort padding / positioning
•
Head up slightly venous drainage
•
If GA use TIVA →
o
Neutral gaze (cf sevo)
o
Remi reduces cough

title: Day Surgery
text:
Day Surgery
RCOA.
Appropriate protocols, set up, pre-op assessment within 3mo.
Monitoring: clinical, pulse ox, ECG, BP
Suitably trained person for monitoring throughout anaesthesia + surgery
Everyone trained in BLS, one person at least with ALS.
DC: criteria, someone to accompany home, written instructions + emergency contact

title: Peribulbar Block
text:
Peribulbar Block
I: intraocular surgery requiring anaesthesia + akinesia for <2hr
CI: refusal, allergy, nystagmus, myopia (axial length >26mm), staphyloma, enophthalmos, extended surgery, coagulopathy
Performance: CIMPLE-D
•
Amethocaine 1% to globe
•
Ropivacaine 1%:lignocaine 2% 50/50 + hyalase 15units / mL
•
25G 25mm needle – Atkinson needle
•
Supine, retract lower lid, 2/3 lateral from middle canthus to lateral canthus
•
Orbital floor – observe for globe movement
•
Direct 20 degrees up when past equator, <25mm
•
-ve aspiration
•
Inject 5 – 8mL (reposition if resistance)
•
Stop if lid closes quickly or globe is tense / proptosed
+Top up: middle canthal ligament (up to 5mL)
Complications:
•
Globe perf
•
Central spread
•
Retrobular haemorrhage
•
Optic nerve atrophy
•
Muscular palsy / myopathy
•
IV injection
•
Chemosis (less than subtenon)

title: Retrobulbar Block
text:
Retrobulbar Block
I & CI as above
Disadvantages:
•
Higher risk major complications
•
No lid paralysis (may need to be supplemented)
•
Sharp needle technique
Performance: CIMPLE-D
•
As above +
•
Past equator direct towards apex
•
Depth 25 – 35mm
•
2-4mL LA
+ facial nerve block: 1cm lateral to orbital rim 2 – 4mL LA
Complications:
•
Globe perf 0.5%
•
Brainstem anaesthesia 1/1000
•
Retrobular haemorrhage 1%
•
Optic nerve atrophy
•
Muscular palsy / myopathy
•
IV injection
Complication
SSx
Management
Retrobulbar
haemorrhage
Proptosis, IOP, VA
Early:
•
External pressure (tamponade)
•
Mannitol / acetazolamide
Surgical:
•
Lateral canthotomy
•
Orbital decompression
+ continuous ECG – risk of oculocardiac reflex
Globe injury
Pain, VA
Immediate opthal input
Brainstem anaesthesia
Supportive

title: Subtenon
text:
Subtenon
I: intraocular surgery requiring anaesthesia + akinesia for <2hr, adult strabismus, optic sheath fenestration
CI: refusal, allergy, inability to lie still / flat, confusion, gross coagulopathy, perforated globe, trauma, scleral buckle, OI
Benefits:
•
Good anaesthesia / akinesia
•
Safe in anticoagulation
•
risk major complications
Performance:
•
Tetracaine 0.5% to globe + iodine half strength 5%
•
Drape
•
Barraquer speculum
•
Look “up and out” to expose inferonasal quadrant
•
Non-toothed forceps – lift conjunctiva + tenons fascia from limbus
•
Wescott scissors – small cut
•
Blunt dissect
•
Subtenon cannula 19G 25mm → posterior equator
•
LA solution 3 – 5mL
•
Gentle pressure
Complications:
•
Minor: chemosis, subconjunctival haemorrhage, disrupted conjunctiva
•
Major: retrobulbar haemorrhage, globe injury, muscular palsy, myotoxicity, brainstem anaesthesia
Benefits of hyalase:
•
tissue permeability
•
dispersion
•
orbital pressure after injection
•
block quality
•
speed of onset
MOA: hydrolysis of hyaluronic acid in ECM

title: Intra-Ocular Gas
text:
Intra-Ocular Gas
Used for retinal tamponade.
May have to be prone for one week.
Avoid N2O.
Use peribulbar block (subtenon may increase risk of oedema → issues with ports, discuss with opthal)
Gases:
•
Sulfur hexafluride (SF6) – 3 weeks
•
Octafluoropropane (C3P8) – 8 weeks
Avoid air travel until an ophthalmologist has documented that the bubbles have completed absorbed
LA
Onset
Duration
Lignocaine 2%
5 – 10 min
30 – 60 mins

title: Penetrating Eye Injury
text:
Penetrating Eye Injury
Establish mechanism of injury +/- other injuries
Goal:
•
Avoid IOP and extrusion of contents
Pre-op:
•
Visual assessment should be documented
•
Assess all trauma imaging
•
Open globe:
o
Examine carefully to avoid extrusion of contents
o
Shield at all times – do not pad
•
Additional management:
o
Antibiotics: ciprofloxacin
o
Ondansetron
o
Tetanus
o
Pain relief
Intra-op: regional usually CI
•
Avoid coughing / retching / straining / forceful blinking / crying
o
Extreme caution with BVM – avoid eye
•
RSI if unfasted – MILS + X-blade if C-spine not cleared
o
Profound analgesia / depth prior to laryngoscopy
o
Dexmedetomidine +/- IV lignocaine → significant IOP
o
NMBA:
▪
No published reports of extrusion 2’ sux if co-administered with adequate anaesthetic
▪
Non-depolarising: nerve stimulator to avoid laryngoscopy without paralysis
•
Maintenance: prop + remi TCI
•
PONV +++
•
Smooth extubation to avoid coughing, retching

title: Orthopaedics
text:
Orthopaedics
ICAROS 2019: lower odds or no difference for most complications of hip/knee arthroplasty between spinal v GA except urinary
retention in spinal group

title: Hip Arthroplasty
text:
Hip Arthroplasty
CI:
•
Infection – local or systemic
•
Medical CI
•
Quadriplegia
Pre-op:
•
Staph aureus decolonisation
•
Pre-op chlorhexidine skin wash
•
Avoid shaving / hair removal
•
/cease opioid use
•
Prehabilitation
Intra-op:
Regional > GA – but mostly similar outcomes
+PROSPECT 2021
Pre-op or intra-op:
•
Paracetamol
•
NSAID
•
Education
•
Exercise
Intra-op:
•
Spinal or GA
•
Dex 8mg
•
Single shot FIB or LA infiltration
•
Consider IT morphine 100mcg
Post-op:
•
Paracetamol
•
NSAID
•
Rescue opioid
Not recommended:
•
Gabapentin
•
Ketamine
•
Other nerve blocks
•
Surgical technique has minimal effect

title: Hip Fracture Surgery
text:
Hip Fracture Surgery
Association of Anaesthetists 2020 guidelines
Recommendations:
•
Experienced surgeon + anaesthetist
•
Anaesthetists should participate in formal pathways
•
Surgery <36hr post injury (delay >24hr risk of delirium by 2x)
o
HIP ATTACK: surgery <6hr did not significantly risk of mortality or composite of major complications
▪
Benefits: delirium, LOS, mobilisation
•
Aim for early remobilisation + rehab
•
Participation in peri-op data (focusing on first 5 post-op days)
•
All trainees should receive specific training in NOFs
Pre-op:
•
Patient information + education
•
Assess: comorbidities, frailty, risk of delirium – mostly non-
modifiable
•
?other injuries
•
Risk:
o
Mortality: Nottingham Hip Fracture Score
o
Frailty Score
•
MDT w/ orthogeris
•
Nerve block: FIB with US – rpt after 6hr
•
TTE only if sig CVS decline or concern - shouldn’t delay surgery – rather should inform anaesthetic
•
Resuscitation plan documented
Intra-op:
•
GA or spinal: ASAP2 – no difference in mortality based on technique (mortality associated with hypotension)
o
Regional: single shot FIB block should supplement either technique
o
Ensure LCNT blocked either with FIB or separately
•
Propofol TCI sedation
•
Avoid intra-op hypotension → associated with mortality @ 5 and 30 days
o
Associated with higher doses of spinal LA – suggested 1.5mL bupivacaine 0.5% plain (7.5mg) + no opioid
o
Aim MAP >70 or within 20% baseline
•
risk of bone cement implantation syndrome
•
Hb target variable:
o
Aim Hb >90 if frail
▪
>100 if frail + IHD
o
Hb >70-80 if younger / robust
•
TXA: transfusion
Post-op:
•
Aim:
o
Mobilise by D1 post-op
▪
Prevent pain, hypotension, delirium
•
If fatigue / dizziness delaying
mobilisation → Hb >100
o
Recommence ADLs by D2-D5
▪
Prevent constipation, urinary retention,
delirium
•
4As / CAM ICU
•
Rehab
•
Orthogeris care
Anticoagulation & spinal anaesthesia:
•
Single antiplatelet: not a CI – must weigh risk / benefit
•
DAPT: GA unless very good reason not to
•
Warfarin:
o
AF, DVT/PE: stop warfarin, check INR, give vit K 5mg
▪
Recheck INR 4-6hr: <1.5 → surgery, >1.5 further
vit K 5mg or PCC
▪
Surgery if INR <2, INR <1.5 can have spinal
▪
Restart 12 hours post-op – consider bridging
o
Mechanical valves: haematologist involvement +
bridging
•
DOACs: confirm last dose + document
o
Apixaban / rivaroxaban:
▪
Good renal function: wait 2x half lives (1x ½ life:
apixaban / rivaroxaban 12hr)
▪
eGFR <60: wait 4x half lives
▪
Or monitor anti-Xa
o
Dabigatran (half life 15 hours) – cease on arrival, plan
for surgery following afternoon
▪
DOS: take TT if normal proceed, if prolonged
contact haematology +/- idarucizumab
Monitor for vertebral canal haematoma: back pain, numbness,
motor weakness, bowel / bladder incontinence
7 acceptable reasons to delay surgery: try to correct ASAP
•
Hb <80
•
Na <120 or >150, K <3.8 or >6.0
•
Uncontrolled diabetes
•
Uncontrolled LV failure
•
Correctable cardiac arrhythmia at >120bpm
•
Chest infection with sepsis
•
Reversible coagulopathy

title: Knee Arthroplasty
text:
Knee Arthroplasty
CI:
•
Infection – local or systemic
•
Medical CI

Skin integrity breakdown at site

LL ischaemia

Blood loss:

o
TXA

Dexamethasone

•
Femoral: delayed mobilisation 2’
quadriceps weakness
•
Sciatic nerve: foot drop
•
Adductor canal block:
o
Benefits: analgesia v placebo, quads weakness
o
Disadvantages: 1/800 risk myotoxicity, medial knee only
•
iPACK block:
o
Interspace between popliteal artery and posterior capsule of knee
o
Motor sparing sciatic block – spares tibial and peroneal nerves
•
LA by surgeons
Post-op:
•
Analgesia:
o
Paracetamol
o
NSAIDs
o
Rescue opioids
o
Consider adductor canal catheter
•
ERAS
No evidence for gabapentinoids
Complications:
•
Neuropathic pain 12%
•
Haematoma
•
DVT/PE
•
MACE
•
PRAE
•
Peroneal nerve palsy
•
BCIS
Spinal
Benefits
Complications
•
DVT/PE
•
transfusion requirement
•
respiratory complications
•
LOS
•
IT opioid: urinary
retention, resp
depression, pruritis

title: Shoulder Arthroplasty
text:
Shoulder Arthroplasty
Innervation:
•
Cervical plexus C3-C4:
o
Supraclavicular nerve
•

Suprascapular nerve

o
Media cutaneous n. of arm

•
Benefits:

Improved surgical access posteriorly
o
Venous bleeding

Poor access to airway

Cerebral ischaemia
o
Pressure areas
o
Air embolism
o
Brachial plexus injury
Pre-op:
•
ASSESS:
o
Suitability for beach chair
o
Suitability for beach chair i.e. risk of phrenic nerve block
Intra-op:
•

Positioning + padding in beach chair (including head foam – check eyes)
•

Target high-normal CO2 to CBF
•
Dexamethasone IV

title: Bone Cement Implantation Syndrome
text:
Bone Cement Implantation Syndrome
Reversible reaction to cementing.
Risk factors:
•
Patient:
o
Age
o
ASA 3-4
o
Significant cardiac disease
o
Pulmonary hypertension
o
Osteoporosis
•
Surgical:
o
Pathological #
o
Intra-trochanteric #
o
Long stem arthroplasty
o
Not previously instrumented
GA v spinal – no effect on risk
Pathophysiology: likely combination embolic v anaphylactoid
Prevention / risk : GOOD COMMUNICATION
•
Anaesthetic:
o
Pre-assign crisis roles
o
≥1 risk factor: CO monitoring
o
Prior to cementing: FiO2, adequate preload, vasopressor
o
Vigilance
•
Surgical:
o
Avoid cement
o
Thorough intramedullary lavage (removes debris)
o
Venting hole in distal femoral shaft (relieves pressure)
o
Vacuum cementing
o
Retrograde insertion
Detection:
•
Clinical: hypotension, tachycardia, desaturation, ETCO2, cardiac arrest
•
Investigations:
o
TTE/TOE: right heart dysfunction
Severity:
•
Grade 1: mild (sats <94%, sBP >20%)
•
Grade 2: severe (sats <88%, sBP >40%)
•
Grade 3: cardiac arrest
Resuscitation / management:
•
A/B: 100% FiO2
•
C:
o
Right heart support + PVR
o
Consider TOE guided resus

title: Fat Embolisation Syndrome
text:
Fat Embolisation Syndrome
Presence of fat globules in circulation.
Causes:
•
Trauma: most
o
Long bone or pelvic fracture (risk multiple long bone #)
•
Non-trauma:
o
Acute illness e.g. pancreatitis, sickle cell, OM, DM, fatty liver disease
•
Iatrogenic:
o
Steroids
o
Liposuction
o
Cosmetic surgery
Epidemiology:
•
Femoral shaft # 98% of patients
•
Medullary reaming 88% of patients
Pathophysiology:
•
BM → venous circulation → 3 theories
o
Mechanical / embolic
o
Biochemical / inflammatory
o
Coagulation
→
•
Pulmonary: alveolar damage, hypoxia, ARDS, oedema, haemorrhage
•
Systemic organs
Presentation: rare during surgery – usually 24 – 72 hr post injury
•
Triad: not all pts – same as GURD’s major criteria
o
Hypoxia (96%) – resp SSx most common + earliest
o
CNS disturbance
o
Skin rash
+/- resp / cardiac / neurological / renal / jaundice / Purtsche’s retinopathy, anaemia / thrombocytopaenic, coagulopathy
Fulminant i.e. CVS collapse v rare
GURD’s criteria: 1 major + 4 minor
•
Major: (triad)
o
Hypoxia : hypoxaemia + bilateral imaging 
o
CNS signs
o
Skin / rash petechiae
•
Minor:
o
HR
o
Fever
o
Fundoscopic 
o
Hct or plt
o
ESR
o
Fat globules in sputum
Risk minimisation:
•
Early surgical fixation of long bone #
•
intramedullary pressure in OT
Management (suuportive):
•
NIV/intubation
•
Neuroprotection
•
CVS: IVF, pressors, inotropes, pulmonary vasodilators +/- ECMO
•
Drugs:
o
Aspirin if CNS SSx
No benefit shown: heparin, steroids

title: Fasting Guidelines
text:
Fasting Guidelines
Age <12mo:
•
Formula: 4 hr
•
Breast milk: 3hr
•
Clear fluids: 1 hr (<3mL/kg/hr)
Age >12mo:
•
Solids: 6 hr
•
Breast milk: 4 hr
•
Clear fluids: 1 hr (<3mL/kg/hr)
Aspiration: 0.1% paediatrics – less severe, <20% require post-op ventilation

title: Anaesthetic Assessment
text:
Anaesthetic Assessment
Assessment: must review medical record
•
History:
o
Birth complications
o
Syndromes / genetic abnormality
o
Sleep apnoea
o
Trauma / type of surgery
o
Age (<1 yr)
o
ASA 2-4
o
Aspiration risk: fasting, obstruction, pyloric stenosis
•
Examination:
o
Facial dysmorphia
o
Stridor
o
Dysphonia / hoarse voice
o
Swallowing / breathing difficulty
o
Obesity / under weight
o
Routine:
▪
Mandible protrusion
▪
Mallampati
▪
AO movement
▪
Tongue / tonsil size
▪
Mouth opening
▪
Dentition
▪
Thyromental distance
Airway Assessment
Airway differences:
•
Anatomical:
o
Obligate nose breathers
o
Large occiput, short neck
o
Large tongue, cephalad larynx (C2 – C3)
o
Long U shaped epiglottis, 45 degree angle
▪
Straight blade <1y
▪
Curved blade >1y
o
Cricoid is narrowest part
o
diameter airway, prone to obstruction / high resistance
•
Physiological:
o
Closing capacity > FRV
o
VO2 7mL/kg/min
o
Rapid desaturations → bradycardia
o
Pre-oxygenation is difficult
o
High vagal tone – risk of bradycardia on laryngoscopy

title: Paeds Ventilation
text:
Paeds Ventilation
6yo closing volume > FRC → airway closure (exacerbated by anaesthesia),
A-a gradient
LPV same as adults; accept sats >92%
T-Piece
Used in patients <20kg.
Advantages:
•
Light weight
•
Low resistance, valveless
•
Low dead space
•
Fast wash in → rapid induction
•
Portable
•
PEEP can be adjusted
•
Good feedback of compliance
Disadvantages:
•
Risk of rebreathing if FGF not sufficient
•
High FGF required (2-3x minute ventilation)
o
Infant + neonate: 3L/min
o
Child: 6L/min
o
Adolescent: 9L/min
•
Technique is important
•
No scavenging
THRIVE
Physiological effects:
•
Deadspace washout → alveolar ventilation, CO2 clearance
•
PEEP 4 – 6cmH2O → compliance, WOB
Uses:
•
Apnoeic oxygenation → safe apnoea time, desaturations
•
Tubeless anaesthesia for airway surgery

•

title: Extubation
text:
Extubation
Awake Extubation
Features: eye opening, facial grimace, movement other than coughing, conjugate gaze, purposeful movement, low volatile ET
(sevo <0.2%), SpO2 >97%, TV >5mL/kg, +ve laryngeal stimulation test (wiggle tube → cough + breath hold <5s)
When to awake extubate:
•
Difficult BVM / intubation
•
High risk reintubation
•
High risk aspiration
•
Risk of hypoventilation
•
Non-paediatric facility
•
Operator inexperience with deep extubation
Suction deep
USE BITE BLOCK
Pre-extubation recruitment
Deep Extubation
Indications:
•
Surgery: neurosurg, ENT/H&N, plastics
•
Prevention of coughing / bucking: ICP, IOP, bleeding risk
•
Patient: reactive airways dz
Method:
•
Suction airway
•
Reverse neuromuscular blockade
•
Depth of anaesthesia ≥1.0 MAC
•
If volatile anaesthetic give 1-2mg/kg of propofol
•
Start spont venting
•
100% FiO2
•
Extubate +/- airway adjunct
•
Breath hold for 15 – 30s is normal
•
Cease anaesthetic agent
•
HFNP or facemask
•
Position: supine or recovery position

title: Choice of Anaesthesia
text:
Choice of Anaesthesia
Inhalational
Benefits:
•
apnoea 2’ slower onset
•
Slower CVS changes
•
agitation avoiding IV access
•
Bronchodilation
TIVA
Benefits
Disadvantages
•
Rapid onset
•
Familiar
•
Depth of anaesthesia not dependent on airway
•
FiO2 100% (i.e. no volatile)
•
airway reactivity  less PRAE
•
Improved ciliary function
•
Bronchodilation
•
emergence delirium
•
Safe in: neuromuscular disorder, MH, core
myopathy
•
interference with evoked potentials
•
Titratable via pump
•
environmental impact
•
cost
•
PONV
•
Bacterial contamination risk
•
Pain on injection
•
PRIS / lactic acidosis
•
IV access + pumps required – harder to identify
tissued IVC
•
Risk of awareness – processed EEG is based on adult
algorithms, use with caution, keep IV visible
•
No concentration monitoring
•
Progressive CSHT
•
Disposables usage high
•
Variable PK in neonates
•
Vasodilation
•
Infusion line deadspace – flush end of case
•
Not suitable in metabolic disorders, ketogenic diets
for seizures, septic shock
Indications:
•
Patient:
o
MH
o
Muscular dystrophy, core myopathy, NM disease
o
PONV
o
Emergence delirium
o
Fear of facemask
•
Surgical:
o
Airway / neuro or raised ICP / middle ear surgery
o
Evoked potential monitoring required
o
High PONV risk – strabismus, T&A
o
Muscle biopsy

title: Anxiety Minimisation & Pre-Op Sedatives
text:
Anxiety Minimisation & Pre-Op Sedatives
Complications of peri-op anxiety:
•
Emergence delirium
•
analgesic requirements
•
Sleep disturbance
•
Bed-wetting
•
Poor experience for child + parent
•
Negative behavioural changes
RFs: age <4yo (separation anxiety), temperament, no pre-op preparation, anxious parents, previous negative experience
Assessment:
•
Previous pre-med + effect +/- adverse events
•
Confirm fasting status & monitoring available
•
CIs present
•
Allergies
Have pre-determined bail out stage (?elective versus time sensitive) – should not be held down once has clear memory
Non-pharmacological:
•
Age appropriate approach
•
Pre-hospital education
•
Play therapy / distraction
•

•
Environmental adjustment
•
Active involvement caregiver

•

title: IV Fluid Replacement
text:
IV Fluid Replacement
Total fluid requirement: replace deficit + maintenance + replace ongoing losses
(This is different from resuscitation 20mL/kg and assess up to 3x)
Resus
20mL/kg crystalloid
Deficit
Deficit = weight difference (kg) x % dehydration x 10 – give over 24 hours
Maintenance
Isotonic crystalloid (NS 0.9% / plasmalyte / Hartmanns) +/- glucose 5% (if no other source of glucose)
Neonate
24 hr maintenance
Hourly rate
D1
60 mL/kg/day
2 mL/kg/hour
D2
80 mL/kg/day
3 mL/kg/hour
D3
100 mL/kg/day
4 mL/kg/hour
D4 – 1yo
120 mL/kg/day
4 mL/kg/hour
Immature RAAS. Post-natal diuresis.
Weight (if >1y)
24 hr maintenance
Hourly rate
3 – 10 kg
100 x weight mL/day
4 x weight mL/hr
10 – 20 kg
1000 + (50 x weight) mL/day
40 + 2x (weight – 10) mL/hr
20 – 60 kg
1500 + (20 x weight) mL/day
60 + (weight – 20) mL/hr
>60 kg
Max 2400 mL/day
Max 100 mL/hr
Or just use 4 / 2 / 1 rule – max 100mL/hr
Risk of water retention 2’ to non-osmotic ADH secretion → reduce to 2/3 maintenance:
•
CNS conditions (meningitis, tumours, head injury)
•
Resp (pneumonia, bronchiolitis, ventilated)
•
Post-op
•
Trauma
^use if unwell

title: PONV
text:
PONV
Simplified risk - POVOC Score → 1 point each
•
Surgery ≥30 mins
•
Age ≥3yo
•
Strabismus
•
History or FHx PONV
Risk:
•
Low risk:
score 0 (9%)
1 agent
None or dex or 5HT3
•
Medium risk
score 1(10%) or 2 (30%)
2 agents
5HT3 + dex
•
High risk:
score 3 (55%) or 4(70%)
2 agents + TIVA 5HT3 + dex + TIVA
Prevention:
•
Propofol TIVA
•
Avoid prolonged fasting + liberal IVF (30mL/kg versus 10mL/kg)
•
Opioid sparing + regional anaesthesia
Prophylactic anti-emetics:
•
Dexamethasone
0.15mg / kg
max 5mg
•
Ondansetron
0.1mg/kg
max 4mg
•
Droperidol
15mcg/kg
max 1.25mg
•
Aprepitant
3mg/kg
max 125mg
•
Granisetron
40mcg/kg
max 0.6mg
Rescue treatment: anti-emetic from different class
Treatment:
•
Metoclopramide
0.25mg/kg
max 10mg
•
Dimenhydrinate
0.5mg/kg
max 25mg
Not recommended: prochlorperazine, cyclizine

title: Emergence Delirium
text:
Emergence Delirium
Up to 80%. Definition:
•
Transient state of marked irritation and disassociation after the discontinuation of anaesthesia
•
Disorientation + altered perception
o
Hypersensitivity to stimuli
o
Hyperactive motor behaviour
•
Diagnosis of exclusion (Ix & treat pain, hypoglycaemia, hypoxia)
Scales: PAED, Cravero, Watcha
RFs: preschool age, male, volatile anaesthetic, ENT / opthal surgery, pre-op anxiety, parental anxiety, poorly adaptable
temperament, inadequate analgesia on emergence
Complications: self-injury, post-op maladaptive behavioural changes, dissatisfaction (everyone)
Non Pharmacological
ADVANCE
Pharmacological
Effective
Ineffective
•
Anxiety reduction
•
Distraction
•
Video modelling +
education
•
Adding parents
•
No excessive reassurance
•
Coaching
•
Exposure shaping
•
TIVA > volatile
•
Propofol 1mg/kg end of case
•
Precedex
•
Clonidine (delayed discharge, BP)
•
Midaz end of case
•
Analgesia: fent / ketamine
•
Magnesium
•
Dexamethasone
•
Nitrous washout
•
Halothane @ 50% rate
•
Desflurane, isoflurane
•
Midaz pre-med
•
Parental presence at
emergence
•
Gradual sevo cessation
•
Lower maintenance sevo [ ]
Treatment:
•
Exclude other causes
•
Reassure parents
•
Ensure safety of child from injury
•
Observe
•
Rx:
o
Propofol
1mg/kg
o
Fent
1-2mcg/kg
o
Midaz
0.1mg/kg
o
Clonidine
1mcg/kg
Dexmedetomidine
Uses in paeds:
•
Pre-med: IN, buccal
•
Analgesia / opioid sparing
•
Surgical:
o
Rigid bronch
o
T&As
o
High risk anterior mediastinal mass (in combination with ketamine)
o
Cardiac surgery → early extubation
o
Awake craniotomy
o
MRI (spont vent)
•
Regional / caudal analgesia adjunct → prolongs block
•
OSA
•
Emergence delirium
Relative CI:
•
Conduction abnormalities / concurrent treatments with bradycardic Rx
•
Septic shock
•
Chronic hypertension
•
Hepatic disease

section_path: Effect of Anaesthesia on Developing Brain
Effect of Anaesthesia on Developing Brain
title: Effect of Anaesthesia on Developing Brain
text:
Effect of Anaesthesia on Developing Brain
Study
Details
Outcomes
GAS Study
RCT
Regional v sevoflurane for inguinal hernia
Exposure <1hr
No difference in IQ at age 5
MASK Study
Retrospective cohort study
Multiple exposures <3yo
No effect on IQ
Possibly mild deficits in processing speed and fine
motor skills
PANDA Study
Matched cohort study
Sibling pairs (not twins) exposed v not exposed <3yo
Inguinal hernia surgery up to 4 hr
No difference
Proposed mechanism of neuronal toxicity:
•
Accelerated neuronal apoptosis
•
Altered dendrite morphology
•
Dose, age and duration dependent
•
Shown with multiple drugs
Summary:
•
Single, short exposure <3 hr <3yo is not associated with any significant deficit in any measurable domain
•
Repeated (≥2) exposures <3yo may risk of learning disability or behavioural disorder
o
Multiple confounders not controlled for including comorbidity, illness, indication, surgery
•
Must weight risk of delaying surgery with small risk of neurocognitive effect
•
No data on premature patients, neurological disease, CHD
Consent:
•
Surgery is only when necessary
•
Anaesthetists prevent well-recognised complications
•
Knowledge is constantly growing
•
Association is not causation
•
Discuss if:
o
Parent asks
o
Repeated or prolonged exposure
o
Procedure cannot be post-poned

text:
Pain
Involve parent. Self reported ≥4.

title: URTI
text:
URTI
risk of PRAE e.g. laryngospasm, bronchospasm, breath holding, atelectasis, desaturation, pneumonia, unplanned admission
RFs for adverse event: age <1yo, purulent nasal discharge (cf clear), productive cough, wheeze / creps, systemic features (T >38,
malaise, headache, poor feeding), parental concern parental smoking, airway anomaly, asthma, OSA / snoring, ex-premi,
inexperienced anaesthetist, tracheal intubation
Pre-op:
•
History: SSx, frequency, RFs for adverse event, resp comorbid, previous cancellations
o
Beware of croup – if intubated unlikely to be extubated
•
Surgery: urgency of surgery, previous cancellations
o
?Implants required – may get infected
•
Exam: vitals, resp exam (WOB, accessory muscles), examine throat
•
Ix: leukocytosis, CXR changes
COLDS Score
Feature
Low risk (1)
Moderate risk (2)
High risk (3)
Current signs / symptoms
None
Clear sputum
Coloured sputum, fever
Onset
>4 weeks ago
2 – 4 weeks ago
<2 weeks ago
Lung Disease
None
Mild asthma
Asthma, pHTN, CLD
Airway Device
Mask
LMA
ETT
Surgery
T&As, flex bronch
Cleft palate, rigid bronch,
max fax
Increased risk of PRAE with higher scores
Intra-op:
•
Pre-treat with salbutamol
•
Anti-sialogogue: glycol 4mcg/kg IV
•
Induction: IV > inhalational
•
Airway: facemask > LMA > ETT
•
Consider deep extubation (but no proven difference)
If post-poning: wait 2 – 4 weeks + symptom resolution

title: Murmur
text:
Murmur
Feature
Innocent
Pathological
Symptoms
Asymptomatic
Symptomatic (SOB, URTI, fatigue, reduced ET,
syncope)
Timing
Early systolic
Continuous (venous hum)
Diastolic
Pansystolic
Late systolic
Or location other than L sternal edge
Quality
Blowing
Musical
Vibratory
Variable
Harsh
Loud
Precordial thrill
NO
Present
Variation in
posture
Often
Rare (except HOCM)
Causes
Venous hum
Flow
AS
HOCM
CHD (septal defect, CoA)
History:
•
Concerning: recurrent chest infection, cyanosis, RR, sweating, poor PO intake, FTT, age <1yo, syndromic, ET,
squatting posture during play (Tets spells), syncope, family history of sudden death
Examination:
•
Pulses all 4 limbs
•
Thrills
•
Murmur location + features above
•
Hepatosplenomegaly, ascites
•
Clubbing
Referral indications / red flags:
•
Any murmur if age <1yo
•
Symptoms / concerning features
•
Syndromic
•
Family history
•
Ix: ECG (LAD, LVH), TTE
Severe causes to exclude:
•
AS
•
HOCM
*Both have LAD / LVH on ECG
Note: if emergency surgery main consideration is is there an undiagnosed condition limiting CO – ask if child can play, running &
climbing is reassuring. Screaming without fainting indicative of good CO. TTE may not be available overnight.

title: Consent
text:
Consent
•
A minor is ‘Gillick competent’ once they have reached sufficient maturity to understand fully the treatment proposed
and its consequences. Once Gillick competent, they can consent to medical treatment
•
Parents cannot veto a competent minor’s consent to treatment
•
The laws governing a competent minor’s refusal of treatment that is considered to be in their best interests are
complex and uncertain. Doctors faced with this scenario would be wise to seek legal advice before proceeding
•
The rights of parents are qualified by the need to protect the health of the child
•
Physical or chemical restraint to facilitate treatment is legal provided that the restraint is necessary and proportional to
the harm being prevented
Components of capacity:
•
Understand proposition and
•
Retain long enough to
•
Weigh risks + benefits and
•
Communicate decision
Minor <18yo. Young person 16 – 18yo. Laws around minors and consent are state based.
Written consent + signature should be from person consenting
Any confusion – seek medicolegal advice

title: Prematurity
text:
Prematurity
<37 weeks:
•
Mod – late: 32 – 37 weeks
mortality 5.4 / 1000
•
Very preterm: 28 – 32 weeks
•
Extremely preterm: <28 weeks
Comorb:
•
Congenital defects
•
Resp: alveoli bud at 24 weeks, surfactant sufficient at >35 weeks
o
Less compliant lungs, VQ mismatch, PVR
o
Bronchopulm dysplasia (requires O2 >36/40 – prevented by steroids + surfactant)
o
Apnoeas: cessation of airflow ≥15s or ≥10s with bradycardia or desaturation
▪
Avoid triggers: GA / sedation, surgery, hypoxia, BSL, hypo/hyperthermia, anaemia, pain
▪
Rx: methylxanthines (caffeine, theophylline), HFNP, monitor until 12 hour post-apnoea free interval
▪
Apnoea treatment: stimulation, open airway, BLS if no recovery
•
CVS: assess for PDA, sensitive to iCa
•
Neuro: assess for IVH
•
GIT: NEC, jaundice, altered metabolism
•
Renal: risk of hypoNa, acidosis, poor renal clearance
•
Metabolic: hypothermia, hypoglycaemia
•
Haem: anaemia, possible coagulopathy 2’ vitamin K dependent factors
•
Other: retinopathy of prematurity
Anaesthetic considerations:
•
Pre-op:
o
Assess for above, consider TTE if concerns for CVS
o
Specialist centre
o
Equipment:
▪
Machine: neonatal circuit, suitable ventilator, T piece
▪
Suction: appropriate size for ETT, pressure <80mmHg
▪
Monitoring: routine + appropriate, pre- and post-ductal SpO2, temp, BSL, NIRS
▪
Airway: appropriate size
▪
IV: 22-24G, narrow bore vol extension, 4Fr CVC, art line 24G, glucose containing fluids, warmer
•
Intra-op:
o
Induction: inhalational or IV
o
Airway: tracheal intubation for all, SGA airway rescue an option for >1500g
▪
Smallest bronchoscope 2.2mm, 2.5ETT
o
Maintenance: sevo 3.3%, prop Steur model
o
Ventilation: VCV 5mL/kg, RR 30 – 60, PEEP 6-8, SpO2 90-95%
o
Temp control
o
Analgesia
o
IVF: balanced crystalloid + 2.5% glucose @ 10mL/kg/hour
▪
BSL: 2mL/kg of dextrose 10%
▪
Bolus IVF 10 – 20mL/kg
•
Post-op:
o
NICU + apnoea monitoring for 24 – 48 hours in PMA ≤60 weeks

title: Croup
text:
Croup
Viral laryngotracheitis → oedema of upper airway → narrowing
Causes / viruses:
•
Parainfluenza, RSV, adenovirus, coronavirus
Presentation:
•
Age 6mo – 3y w/ preceding URTI
•
Fever
•
Stridor
•
Barking cough
•
Hoarse voice
•
Respiratory distress
Treatment:
•
Dexamethasone:
o
0.15mg/kg PO or IM
o
Severe croup: 0.6mg/kg IV (max 12mg)
•
Nebulised budesonide 2mg
•
Nebulised adrenaline 0.5mg/kg (max 5mg)
•
Consider HFNP to help with O2 and WOB
Intubation:
•
Indications: respiratory failure, stridor at rest refractory to medical management, GCS
•
Technique:
o
Second anaesthetist/skilled assistant
o
Inhalational induction
▪
FiO2 100% + sevo only – aim to continue spont venting – can spray chords
▪
Can paralyse after ETT if needed
▪
Have IVC ready but important to not lose airway, only cannulate if very very deep
▪
Reduce sevo once deep enough to maintain spont venting
o
ETT size by one size
o
Prepare for slow + long induction
o
ENT present if able for rigid bronch – gold standard

title: Epiglottitis
text:
Epiglottitis
OFTEN REMOTE ANAESTHESIA.
Pre-OT:
•
CASH
•
Alert theatres + ENT
•
Difficult airway trolley, 2nd skilled assistant
•
Avoid stimulation/instrumentation: including examining + IV insertion
•
Keep patient sitting upright + 15L NRB
OT:
•
Sitting up until ready to induce
•
Emergency drugs including atropine
•
ETT 1-2 sizes smaller
•
Spont vent induction sevo + FiO2 100% + CPAP
o
If difficulty finding laryngeal inlet can press on chest → look for bubbles
•
Prepare for FONA
o
Have US available
o
ENT scrubbed + ready
•
IV ceftriaxone
Post-intubation:
•
ICU intubated
•
Nasendoscopy + cuff leak prior to extubation

title: Asthma
text:
Asthma
Pre-op:
•
Assess severity and control: triggers, frequency, parental smoking, medication use / frequency / compliance, recent
steroid use, recent exacerbations / worsening symptoms, hospitalisation / intubation, recent URTI, PEF / FEV1
•
Medications: continue all inhalers, cease theophylline night before
o
Consider adding steroids if severe / poorly controlled
•
Management:
o
Well controlled → proceed
o
Recent URTI → delay 2 – 4 weeks
o
Poorly controlled → refer and optimise
Risk of asthma → complications / events:
•
Lowest risk: all symptoms resolved for 2/52
•
Risk x2: symptoms resolved but for less than 2/52, or persisting symptoms are mild (clear runny nose, dry cough, T <38)
•
Risk x4: symptoms are more severe (green runny nose, moist cough, T >38)
•
Risk x8: symptomatic asthmatic (→ 4x risk of laryngospasm, 10x risk bronchospasm)
Intra-op:
•
Salbutamol prior to induction
•
Minimal airway manipulation: mask > LMA > ETT - regional anaesthesia if older
•
Induction: IV preferred, consider ketamine (avoid thiopentone)
•
Maintenance: sevoflurane
•
Avoid atracurium / mivacurium, neostigmine (use sugammadex), morphine & pethidine
•
Recognition of bronchospasm:
o
DDx: endobronchial/oesophageal intubation, PTx, APO, kinked ETT, obstructed ETT, anaphylaxis
o
Management: FiO2 100%, confirm diagnosis, deepen anaesthetic (prop, ket, sevo)
▪
Bronchodilators:
•
Salbutamol 12 puffs into circuit
•
Volatile
•
Magnesium IV: 0.2mM/kg → infusion 0.12mM/kg/hr
•
Anticholinergic IV: glycol 4mcg/kg, atropine 20mcg/kg
•
Adrenaline IV: 1-2mcg/kg
•
Salbutamol IV: load 10mcg/kg over 10 mins → 1-5mcg/kg/min
•
Steroid IV: hydrocort 4mg/kg
▪
NMBA to improve chest wall compliance
▪
Ventilation:
•
Permissive hypercapnia – target pH >7.2, low rate, PIP 35cmH2O
•
Long I:E ratio 1:4, titrated O2, no PEEP
•
Disconnect circuit to allow passive expiration
▪
ECMO if severe / refractory
Post-op:
•
Continue regular inhalers
•
PICU if severe
•
Analgesia, mobilisation, chest PT
Treatment outside of OT:
•
Mild:
o
PO pred 2mg/kg (max 60mg)
o
Salbutamol MDI q20min (<6yo 6 puffs, >6yo 12 puffs)
•
Moderate: as above +
o
Oxygen
o
Ipratropium MDI (<6yo 4 puffs, >6yo 8 puffs)
•
Severe: as above +
o
IV steroid: hydrocort 4mg/kg max 300mg or methylpred 1mg/kg IV max 60mg q6 hourly
o
IV magnesium: 0.2mM/kg → infusion 0.12mM/kg/hr
o
Aminophylline: 10mg/kg (max 500mg) over 60 min → infusion
o
Salbutamol IV: load 10mcg/kg over 10 mins → 1-5mcg/kg/min
o
Adrenaline

title: OSA
text:
OSA
Peak 2 – 8yo, respiratory complications up to 25%.
Pathogenesis: upper airway resistance
RFs: adenotonsillar hypertrophy, craniofacial abnormality, hypotonia, obesity, midface hypoplasia, macroglossia,
micro/retrognathia, glossoptosis, down syndrome, mucopolysaccharidosis, achondroplasia, passive smoking, ethnicity
Consequences: hypoxia, hypercapnia, acidosis, pulmonary hypertension +/- cor pulmonale +/- RVH, LVH, metabolic syndrome,
neurocognitive, pro-inflammatory, polycythaemia, opioid sensitivity
Presentation:
•
History: behavioural / neurocognitive, poor school performance, enuresis, snoring, daytime sleepiness
•
Examination: hypertension, cor pulmonale, obesity, syndromic, craniofacial abnormality
•
Investigations: polycythaemia +/- TTE
Terms:
•
Apnoea: flow >90% for ≥2 breaths
•
Hypopnoea: flow >50% + SpO2 by 3% or arousal
AHI (apnoea-hypopnoea index): combined average number of apnoeas and hypopnoeas per hour of sleep
Diagnosis:
•
Polysomnography:
Severity
AHI (children)
AHI (adults)
None
<5
Mild
1 – 5
5 – 14
Moderate
6 – 9
15 – 29
Severe
≥10
≥30
Nocturnal oximetry:
•
≥3 events SpO2 ≤90%
•
≥1 event SpO2 <80%
Treatment:
•
