Surgical: adenotonsillectomy
•
Medical: NIV, airway splints, weight loss
Pre-op:
•
Assess: severity/AHI, management, nadir / duration of desaturations, evidence of cor pulmonale / pulmonary HTN
•
Ix: if indicated – ECG, TTE, polysomnography if suspected and will change management
•
Caution with pre-meds
•
Risk factors for post-op complications i.e. not suitable for day stay: age <3yo, severe OSA, FTT, obesity, cardiac
involvement, down syndrome, prematurity, craniofacial abnormality, neuromuscular disease, chronic lung disease,
sickle cell disease
Intra-op:
•
Opioid sparing: multimodal, regional, opioids by 50% (sensitivity)
•
Airway: prone to obstruction, adjuncts, CPAP, difficult airway equipment available, use adjuncts early
•
Induction: try to secure IV access prior
•
Extubate: awake + fully reversed paralysis
Post-op:
•
Continuous sats monitoring
•
Short acting opioids if required
•
Consider CPAP

title: Cystic Fibrosis
text:
Cystic Fibrosis
1/2500. Mostly detected by newborn screening. Carrier 1/25.
Multisystem disease - CFTR gene mutation (autosomal recessive)
CFTR: chloride channel mutation in all exocrine tissues → deranged transport of Cl- +/- other affected ions →
•
Viscous secretions in lungs, pancreas, liver, intestines, and reproductive tract
•
Increased salt content in sweat gland secretions
Diagnosis: both of
1. SSx consistent with CF in one organ system or +ve newborn screen (trypsinogen) or sibling with CF
2. AND evidence of CTFR dysfunction (sweat chloride ≥60 mmol/L or 2x disease causing mutations or abnormal nasal
potential difference)
Methodology:
•
Newborn screening: Heel prick test for trysinogen levels
•
Sweat test (from age >2 weeks): transdermal pilocarpine → sweat → Cl-
•
Genetic testing: D508 most common
Clinical presentation:
•
Resp: chronic productive cough, sinus dz, nasal polyps (risk obstruction / epistaxis), bronchiolitis/asthma,
hyperinflation, chronic bronchitis, Pseudomonas colonisation, Staph colonisation, bronchiectasis, clubbing, obstructive
features, pulmonary HTN
•
Renal: renal stones 2’ enteric hyperoxaluria ( fat malabsorption), hypocitraturia (chronic metabolic acidosis)
•
GIT: pancreatic insufficiency (exo malabsorption, endo diabetes), meconium ileus, ADEK vit deficiency, neonatal
jaundice, biliary cirrhosis, portal hypertension +/- varices, recurrent pancreatitis
•
GU: absent vas deferens, male infertility, female fertility
•
Other: serum Cl- & Na+, pseudotumour cerebri, OP, #, kyphoscoliosis, DVTs (highly associated with CVCs)
Treatment options:
•
CFTR modulators (only certain genotypes) e.g. ivacaftor, lumacaftor, tezacaftor (new – no mortality data yet)
o
→ exacerbations, spiro, QOL
•
Airway clearance:
o
Dornase alpha (Pulmozyme)
o
Hypertonic saline 6%, mannitol
o
Chest physio i.e. postural drainage, huffing, percussion vests, exercise
•
B2 agonists (prior to hypertonic substances + antibiotics to prevent constriction)
•
Anti-inflammatories:
o
Azithromycin (effects attributed to anti-inflammatory effects must be colonised with P. aeruginosa)
o
Inhaled glucocorticoids (only if signs and symptoms of asthma - short term only)
o
High dose ibuprofen (slows progression of disease – must monitor for side effects)
•
Inhaled antibiotics if indicated: tobramycin
•
Prevention: exercise, vaccinations
•
GI: Creon (pancreatic enzymes), insulin (diabetes, OHGs ineffective), vitamins (ADEK + Ca2+), caloric supplementation
Pre-op:
•
History: medication, exacerbation, MRO, functional capacity
•
Ix: CXR, spiro, ABG, routine + BSL, TTE, ECG
o
FEV1 <1L → post-op ventilation
o
Functional capacity: 6MWT, CPET
•
Day case rarely appropriate unless mild / stable
•
Optimise: resp r/v, PT, treat infections, nutrition, neb drugs, glycaemic control
•
Pre-med: neb bronchodilator / mucolytic
Intra-op:
•
Monitoring: consider art line
•
Airway: LMA + spont vent, ETT requires suctioning
•
Ventilation: LPV, frequent suctioning, volatile, intra-op PT, humidified gas
Post-op: PT, early extubation, early mobilisation, ICU if FEV1 <1L or chronic hypoxaemia / hypercapnoea, poor functional status,
major abdo/thoracic surgery

title: Down Syndrome
text:
Down Syndrome
1/700
Clinical features:
•
General:
o
Appearance: brachycephaly, flat nasal bridge, epicanthic folds, upslanting palpebral fissure, small mouth &
ears, single transverse palmar crease
o
Low birth weight → obesity
o
Short stature
•
Airway: macroglossia, narrow midface, oropharyngeal hypotonia, micrognathia, small mouth, short neck, adenotonsillar
hypertrophy, subglottic / tracheal stenosis, atlantoaxial instability 15% →
OSA, difficult BMV/intubation, ETT one size smaller, take care with neck movement
•
Resp: OSA / CSA, frequent LRTI, GORD
•
CVS: up to 60% have CHD → AV canal defect (most common), ASD, VSD, PDA, TOF
o
→ pulmonary hypertension +/- Eisenmenger syndrome
o
Conduction defects post-repair
o
Adults → AR, MV prolapse
•
Neuro: neonatal hypotonia (careful positioning), intellectual impairment, sensory deficits (visual, hearing), generally
calm and good natured, peri-op anxiety / agitation, early onset alzheimers, epilepsy, low MAC requirement
•
GIT: GORD, atresia, Hirschsprungs disease, gallstones, coeliac disease, imperforate anus
•
Immune: recurrent chest infection
•
Haem: polycythaemia, leukaemia
•
Endo: congenital hypothyroidism, adolescent hyperthyroidism, diabetes
•
Spinal: atlanto-axial instability, spina bifida, cervical spondylosis
Pre-op:
•
Assess:
o
Airway: ?tracheal stenosis (stridor, wheeze, cyanosis), seek previous airway management
o
Atlanto-axial instability – screening XR
o
Cardiac: ?CHD, TTE
•
Pre-med: indicated, usually become agitated – must monitor due to OSA
Intra-op:
•
Difficult venous access – US nearby
•
C-spine: care with movement / positioning
•
Airway: difficult features but usually intubatable – have adjuncts, difficult airway trolley
•
Maintenance: lower MAC
•
Positioning: hypotonia (care)
Post-op: Caregiver in recovery

title: Cerebral Palsy
text:
Cerebral Palsy
1/500 live births. Risk much higher in premature babies.
Spectrum of movement and posture disorders which result from pathological injury to the developing foetal or infant brain
SSx: spasticity 80%, muscle contractures +/- neurological and other systems, epilepsy 50%
Treatment is supportive: improve posture, spasticity and epilepsy treatment +/- surgery
Pre-op: routine+
•
Assess: level of cognition (very important), involve caregiver
Intra-op:
•
Difficult IV access due to contractures
•
Propofol preferred agent (reactive airways)
•
High risk aspiration – consider RSI (sux not CI, non-depol have effect)
Post-op:
•
PICU – prone to hypoxia, hypovolaemia, hypothermia, poor cough and reduced resp drive, retained secretions
•
Analgesia: appropriate pain scales, involve caregiver
•
Treat pain + hypothermia – can trigger acute muscle spasms

title: Autism
text:
Autism
Definition: lifelong neurodevelopmental difference that influences the way a person interacts and communicates with others,
and experiences the world around them - common themes, but different profiles
Estimated significantly underdiagnosed in all age groups.
Triad:
•
Social communication
•
Interaction
•
Social imagination
Consequences:
•
Mortality gap up to 30y
•
Barriers to healthcare
•
2x risk of dying as inpatient after emergency admission
SPACE FRAMEWORK:
•
Sensory needs: noise / lights / smell / touch may make clinical encounter difficult
•
Predictability: intolerance of uncertainty
•
Acceptance: repetitive behaviour e.g. stimming is soothing, interest in single topic areas – use to build rapport
•
Communication: may be non-verbal, may prefer writing
•
Empathy: common misconception that lack empathy, may be hyperempathetic
+:
•
physical space
•
processing space
•
emotional space
Pre-op:
•
Assessment:
o
Communication needs e.g. picture chart
o
Syndromes
o
Psychological & physical needs
o
Developmental level
o
Co-existing conditions: obesity, diabetes, hypertension, Parkinsons, mental health, ADHD, hypermobility
syndromes, autonomic dysfunction, chronic pain
o
Must ascertain capacity
•
Quiet stream
•
Preparation
•
Pre-med: disguise in food / drink – administer pre-hospital if necessary
•
Minimise waiting times
•
Care with physical contact
•
Minimise distractions
Post-op:
•
Difficult to assess pain / nausea – use appropriate scales + engage caregiver

title: Obesity
text:
Obesity
Defined by age & sex specific BMI
Class
Percentile / BMI
5yo
5 – 14yo
Underweight
<5th
Normal weight
5th – 85th
Overweight
85th – 95th
>2sd
>1sd
Obese
≥95th
>3sd
>2sd
Severe class 2 obesity
≥120th OR BMI >35
Severe class 3 obesity
≥140th OR BMI >40
Comorbidities: same as adults – HTN, OSA (→ biventricular impairment, LVH, pulmonary HTN), T2DM, chol, GORD,
psychological, NAFLD
Pre-op:
•
Weight, height, BMI
•
Screen for comorbidities: BP, ECG, BSL, chol
•
Assess: GORD, diabetes, OSA, functional capacity
•
Avoid pre-med or use non-resp depressant
Intra-op:
•
Hover mat if >120kg, check max weight of operating table
•
Have US available for difficult IV access – IV > inhalational if able
•
Induction: ramp, good pre-oxygenation, RSI aspiration risk, adjuncts, ETT > LMA (lung compliance, PEEP)
•
Ventilation: lung protective, higher PEEP (beware risk PRAE)
•
CVS: appropriate BP size
•
Positioning: pressure areas, manual handling, restraint for trendelenberg & lateral
•
Drug dosing: TBW can lead to overdosing – use IBW/LBW (sux – TBW), TIVA use BIS and titrate
•
Extubate: awake and fully reversed
Post-op:
•
risk PRAE – monitor appropriately
•
Opioid-sparing analgesia, PONV
•
If OSA – overnight stay with continuous sats monitoring +/- HDU
•
VTE prophylaxis

title: Diabetes
text:
Diabetes
>97% of paediatric diabetes is type 1
Peri-op considerations:
•
Surgical stress → hyperglycaemia
•
Target BSL 5 – 10mM
•
Active treatment threshold: <5mM, >14mM
•
Monitor hourly
Pathogenesis + diagonisis – see diabetes
Pre-op:
•
Assess: HbA1c (>7 suggests suboptimal control), micro & macro complications, comorbidities
o
If poor control consider deferring: rationale for peri-op euglycaemia – wound infection, LOS, myocardial events
•
Hypos + awareness
•
Medication regime + insulin plan – if on insulin pump print settings
o
Premix insulin by 50%, long acting keep basal dose
o
Pump: same principles, keep basal + reg BSL checks, must check pump (may kink with positioning)
•
Aim morning surgery, minimise fasting times
•
Give parent / caretaker plan for peri-op hypos
•
Indication for insulin infusion: prolonged starvation, PONV, longer surgery, emergency surgery, DKA
Intra-op:
•
Induction: RSI, monitoring for autonomic instability, 5 lead ECG if IHD (beware silent MI)
•
Maintenance: TIVA due to PONV risk (due to no dex, ensure good visible drip), BSL +/- ketone checks
•
BSL: poor control – insulin / dex infusion w/ q1 hourly BSL checks – start with daily total insulin and divide by 24 for
hourly rate
Post-op:
•
Early PO intake w/ usual long acting + normal s/c with food – if on infusion cease 2hr post oral intake

title: Neuromuscular Disorders
text:
Neuromuscular Disorders
Pathophysiology:
•
Acetylcholine e.g. myasthenia gravis
•
Post-synaptic membrane e.g. channelopathies
•
Myofibrils: dystrophy, myotonia
•
Mitochondrial: mitochondrial myopathy
Pre-op:
•
History: diagnosis, progression, stability / flares, duration
•
Functional capacity including OSA, bulbar function
•
Family history
•
Previous GA: ?hyperthermia, requirement for post-op ventilation support
•
Exam: hypertrophied calves, syndromic appearance, cough effectiveness, cardiac / resp
•
Ix: routine+, ECG, EMG, CK, lactate +/- TTE / spiro / sleep study
o
Genetic testing may supplant muscle biopsy need
•
Minimise fasting, IVF + glucose if metabolic disorder
Considerations:
•
Appropriate facility (paeds ICU / HDU), paeds anaesthetist
•
Sensitivity to NMBA – use nerve stimulator
•
CI drugs:
o
Avoid sux in all except MG (resistance)
o
Avoid acetylcholinesterases in myotonia
o
MH risk: King-Denborough syndrome, central core disease, evans myopathy, hypokalaemic periodic paralysis
o
risk of propofol infusion syndrome in mitochondrial disorders
•
Aspiration risk: ?GORD, RSI
•
Anaesthesia induced rhabdomyolysis: DMD, Beckers
Reason for surgery:
•
Muscle biopsy
•
Complication of disorder e.g. contractures
•
Unrelated
Intra-op:
•
Avoid pre-meds
•
Prepare machine to eliminate volatile if MH / AIR
•
Consider regional technique
•
GA: RSI if aspiration risk, doses (sensitivity), IV induction to avoid MH/AIR (sedation to facilitate IV access) – PO, IM
or N2O
•
If NMDA required: roc + sugammadex, use lower doses, nerve stimulator
•
Analgesia: multimodal, opioid-sparing + regional where able
•
Positioning: care with contractures, pressure areas
•
Temp: monitor, avoid hyperthermia
AIR v MH
AIR
MH
Clinical
-
Rigidity
Masseter spasm
ECG
Peaked T waves
Bradycardic arrest
Tachycardia
SpO2
Normal
Reduced
CO2
Normal (increases late)
ETCO2
Bloods
K+
CK >1000
Acidosis
K+
Metabolic
Hyperthermia
Myoglobinaemia
Hyperthermia
Myoglobinaemia
DIC

title: Congenital Heart Disease
text:
Congenital Heart Disease
1/125 live births. Most common birth defect.
Low Risk – Safe to Proceed
Medium Risk – D/w Specialist +/- t/f
High Risk – t/f to tertiary centre
•
Well compensated
•
Minor surgery
•
Age >2yo
•
Elective surgery
•
ASA 1 - 3
•
Well compensated
•
Simple lesion
•
Major surgery
•
Age <2yo
•
Emergency surgery
•
Pre-op stay >10 days
•
ASA 4 - 5
•
Physiologically poorly compensated
•
Complications: cardiac failure,
pulm HTN, arrhythmias, VEBs,
cyanosis
•
Complex lesions: single ventricle,
balanced circulation,
cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis
Possible reason for t/f:
•
Major surgery: major
abdo/thoracic, vascular, predicted
major blood loss
•
Age <2yo
•
Emergency surgery
•
Pre-op patient >10 days
•
ASA 4 – 5
Classification of lesions:
1. Shunts:
a. L → R Shunts : VSD, ASD, PDA, AV canal →
i. VSD
ii. ASD
iii. PDA
iv. AV canal
→ pulmonary congestion, LV volume overload, pulmonary blood flow, pulmonary vascular resistance, pulmonary
hypertension, systemic perfusion
b. R → L shunts:
i. Tetralogy of Fallot
ii. Pulmonary Atresia / VSD
iii. Eisenmenger complex
→ cyanosis and RV failure
2. Mixing lesions
a. Transposition of the great arteries
b. Tricuspid atresia
c.
Anomalous venous return
d. Single ventricle
3. Obstructive Lesions
a. Interrupted aortic arch
b. Critical aortic stenosis
c.
Critical pulmonary stenosis
d. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome
e. Coarctation of the aorta
f.
Mitral stenosis
4. Regurgitant valves
a. Ebstein anomaly
Duct Dependence
•
Duct dependent pulmonary flow
o
Critical pulmonary stenosis / atresia
o
TV stenosis / atresia without VD
o
Severe ToF
o
Transposition
→ differential / reverse cyanosis
•
Duct dependent systemic flow
o
Hypoplastic left heart
o
Critical AS
→ differential cyanosis
o
Interrupted aortic arch
→ differential cyanosis
o
Coarctation of aorta
→ differential cyanosis
o
Transposition
→ differential / reverse cyanosis

title: Congenital Heart Disease
text:
Coarctation of Aorta
Descending aortic flow is duct
dependent → femoral pulses
Transposition of Great Arteries
Tetralogy of Fallot
Large VSD
Overriding aorta
RVOT obstruction
RVH
Blalock-Taussig shunt →
flow to lungs
Ebstein Anomaly
Failed tricuspid
delamination
Atrialised RV
RV impairment
Pre-op:
•
Cardiac history: lesion, physiology, complications, operations, functional status, medications +/- compliance
•
Other paed: recent illness, feeding, FTT
•
Venous access
•
Need for IE prophylaxis:
o
Any prosthetic valve / material
o
Previous IE
o
Type of CHD: cyanotic lesion unrepaired, repair <6mo (lifelong if residual shunt / regurgitation)
o
Cardiac transplant with valvuloplasty
•
Examination: cardiac failure, cyanosis
•
Ix: ECG, routine bloods + gas, TTE
Intra-op: 3x B’s (balance PVR / SVR, antiBiotics, Bubbles)
•
IV access prior to induction: if R → L shunt place air filter to prevent paradoxical air embolus
•
Induction: avoid propofol – ketamine, opioid, sevo OK
•
CVS: consider art line + careful management of PVR, SVR, inotropy, ventilation
•
IE prophylaxis if indicated:
o
Dental: i.e. gingival manipulation, periapical, perf of oral mucosa
amoxicillin 50mg/kg max 2g
o
Resp: i.e. incision or biopsy of mucosa, T&As, active resp infection
o
Skin / soft tissue: if infected
Antibiotics not required for GI or GU unless infection is present

title: Epilepsy
text:
Epilepsy
1% of children.
Causes:
•
Pre-natal: inborn error of metabolism, chromosomal abnormality, infection (TORCH), tuberous sclerosis, cortical
dysplasia, AVM, neurofibromatosis
•
Peri- and post-natal: hypoglycaemia, Ca2+, HIE, IVH, infection, venous sinus thrombosis, trauma, malignancy, fever
•
Unknown cause
Treatment with anti-epileptics – most are hepatic enzyme inducers
Can cause: hepatotoxicity, myelosuppression, thrombocytopaenia
Drug SEs:
•
Phenytoin 20mg/kg: enzyme induction, megaloblastic anaemia, haemolysis in G6PD
•
Sodium valproate: enzyme induction, plt, hepatotoxicity
•
Carbamazepine: enzyme induction, pancytopaenia, hepatotoxicity / cholestasis, Na+, sedation
•
Phenobarbital 20mg/kg: enzyme induction, sedation, megaloblastic anaemia
•
Clonazepam: sedation
•
Ethosuximide: hepatotoxicity, leukopaenia, thrombocytopaenia, sedation
•
Lamotrigine: GI, sedation / dizziness
•
Topiramate: NAGMA, enzyme inhibition
Pre-op:
•
Assess: cause, type, frequency, treatment + side effects, associations
•
Ix: routine+ AED levels, coags, TTE if associated disorder
•
Treat: continue AED (unless ceasing for seizure surgery), peri-op give NG/IV – d/w neurologist
•
Pre-med: indicated, avoid hyperventilation (but avoid if seizure surgery)
Intra-op:
•
Increased anaesthetic requirements
•
Prop, sevo, N2O okay
•
metabolism of NMBA: use nerve stimulator
o
Avoid sux (hyperkalaemia), atracurium (laudanosine)
•
Ventilation: normocapnia
•
Other drugs to avoid: ketamine, alfentanil, pethidine
•
Intra-op seizure:
o
SSx: ETCO2, HR, hypertension, muscle tone, pupil dilatation, VO2
o
Treatment:
▪
Deepen
▪
FiO2 100%
▪
Correct: hypoxia, CO2, BSL, Na+, temp
Post-op: continue or restart AED asap
Seizure
ABCD + check BSL, IV access
Seizure termination:
1. Midaz 0.1mg/kg IV OR 0.5mg/kg buccal OR diazepam 0.5mg/kg PR (can also use lorazepam)
2. Midaz 0.1mg/kg IV OR paraldehyde 0.8mg/kg in 50:50 mixture with oil PR
3. Anti-epileptic + senior help must be present at this stage
a. Phenytoin 20mg/kg IV over 20 mins
b. Phenobarbitone 20mg/kg over 20 mins
c.
Levetiracetam IV 40mg/kg
d. Sodium valproate IV
4. Raised ICP – ICP management
a. RSI with thiopentone 5mg/kg then 3 – 5mg/kg/hr
b. Midaz up 20mcg/kg/hr
Status epilepticus: 8% mortality
•
Continuous seizure ≥30 min OR
•
2 seizures without complete recovery between

title: Sickle Cell Anaemia
text:
Sickle Cell Anaemia
Most common inherited haemoglobinopathy. Abnormal B-chain → homozygous HbSS.
Pathophysiology: abnormal B-chain → HbS → B chains that polymerise at lower O2 tensions i.e. ‘sickling’ → vicious cycle of
venous stasis, hypoxia, further sickling + capillary congestion → microcirculatory infarction
Clinical presentation when HbF → HbS @ ~6mo.
Diagnosis:
•
Blood spot on neonatal screening
•
Haem: anaemia, macrocytic, high retic #, film, folate deficiency, iron overload from transfusion
Sickling triggers: hypoxia, acidosis, hypothermia, dehydration
Complications: vascular occlusion (stroke, organ infarct, pulmonary HTN, CKD), chronic haemolysis (transfusions, gallstones),
priapism, OM / avascular necrosis, splenic sequestration (→ functional asplenia)
Management:
•
Education
•
Vaccination: Strep pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae, meningitis, Hep B, flu
•
Prophylactic penicillin
•
Melaena prophylaxis
•
Folate supplementation
•
Hydroxyurea → HbF
Management of acute complications 2’ vaso-occlusive episodes:
•
Antibiotics for acute chest syndrome, incentive spiro
•
IVF, O2, analgesia
•
Transfusion target >100
Pre-op:
•
Specialist centre if possible, day case contra-indicated
•
Assess: disease, complications
•
First on list – avoid dehydration, prolonged fasting
•
Hb:
o
Transfuse if Hb <100
o
Exchange transfusion aiming HbSS <60%
o
TAPs study: pre-op transfusion associated with peri-op complications
•
Ix: FBC, EUC (?CKD), X-match (?Abs), TTE, CXR / spiro, transcranial doppler within 12mo, electrophoresis for HbSS %
Intra-op:
•
Avoid triggers
•
PONV prevention to allow post-op oral hydration
•
Tourniquet: benefit of blood loss, but risk of sickling (distal + after let down) – prevented by hydration, normal acid-
base + short duration
•
Cell salvage contra-indicated
Post-op:
•
Complications: infection / sepsis, ACS, vaso-occlusion, stroke
•
Q2 hourly incentive spiro
•
Keep hydrated; IVF if needed + PONV
•
Supplemental O2, ICU / HDU
•
Physiotherapy
•
Multimodal analgesia
o
Consider vasodilation with heat pads for pain

title: Neonatal Resuscitation at Birth
text:
Neonatal Resuscitation at Birth
Epidemiology:
•
85% initiate spont ventilation within 30s
•
10% require drying / stimulation
•
3% require PPV
•
2% intubation
•
0.1% CPR
RFs:
•
Maternal: prolonged ROM >18hr, bleeding, hypotension, substance abuse, drug therapy, diabetes, chronic illness,
fever, infection / chorioamnionitis, sedation, previous foetal demise, no antenatal care
•
Foetal: multiple birth, pre- or post-dates, small or large BW, poly- or oligohydramnios, haemolytic dz, DFM, congenital
abnormality, infection, hydrops
•
Intrapartum: non-reassuring CTG, abnormal presentation, cord prolapse, prolonged or rapid labour, haemorrhage,
meconium, narcotic, assisted delivery, GA
Neopuff settings:
•
FiO2 21%
•
PIP 30cmH2O (25cmH2O if preterm)
•
PEEP 5cmH2O
Intubation:
•
ETT size: gestational age (weeks) / 10
•
Laryngoscope:
o
00: ELBW
o
0: preterm <32 weeks
o
1: term
•
Depth: weight (kg) + 6 (8-9cm at term)
•
Suction: 2x ETT size in Fr
•
LMA: size 1 option for rescue airway if >2kg, >34 weeks
CPR:
•
Commence if HR <60
•
Two thumb techqniue
•
Ratio 3:1 compressions:breaths – 0.5s pause for breath
•
Rate 90bpm, 120bpm if intubated
Drugs:
•
Adrenaline:
o
IV: 10-30mcg/kg
o
ETT: 50 – 100mcg/kg
•
IVF: 10mL/kg crystalloid
•
Naloxone: 10mcg/kg or 200mcg IM
•
Glucose 10%: 2.5mL/kg
Drugs that can be given via ETT = ALIEN (atropine, lignocaine, isoprenaline, epinephrine, naloxone)
Vascular access:
•
Umbilical vein (2 arteries + 1 dilated vein in cord)
o
5Fr catheter flushed (3.5Fr if preterm)
o
Depth 5cm
o
Secure with tape around umbilicus

title: Circulatory Changes at Birth
text:
APGAR Scores
Score: 0 – 10 at 1 and 5 mins post-birth
•
7 – 10: reassuring
•
4 – 6: abnormal
•
0 – 3: concerning
Criteria
Colour
Pale / cyanotic
Peripheral cyanosis
Pink
Pulse
<100bpm
>100bpm
Grimace / reflex irritability
No response
Grimace / weak cry
Cry
Tone / activity
Floppy
Mild flexion
Flexion + resists extension
Respiration
Apnoea
Slow regular
Cry
A
appearance
P
pulse
G
grimace
A
activity
R
respiration
Circulatory Changes at Birth
At birth – gas exchange transferred from placenta to neonatal lungs
Foetal
Neonatal
Diagram
Circulation
Parallel
Series
Foetal
distinctions
•
UA x 2 – internal iliacs to placenta
•
UV x 1 – placenta to IVC / liver
•
Ductus venosus – UV → IVC
•
FO – RA → LA
•
DA – PA → aorta
O2
Placenta
Lungs
Route
•
50% IVC via ductus venosus
•
50% hepatoportal system
RA →
•
60% LA via foramen ovale (more oxygenated
blood sats 65-70%) → brain and upper
extremities
•
40% less oxygenated blood → RV →
o
10% pulmonary circulation (so little because
lungs are collapsed)
o
90% ductus arteriosus (PA → descending
aorta) → systemic circulation → umbilical
artery for reoxygenation
Same as adult circulation after PDA closes
Pressure
High
Low
Flow
Low
High
Transition steps: 2’ change in circulatory resistance
1. Low resistance placenta is excluded 2’ clamping → ↑SVR + ↑LV EDP
2. ↓RA pressure 2’ ↓IVC flow
3. → expansion of lungs and ↓PVR → ↓RV EDP
4. PVR decreases further with ↑PaO2 and pH and ↓PaCO2 (PA pressure falls to adult values within 2 weeks)
5. ↑LA pressure 2’ ↑flow through lungs + ↑LV EDP
6. Other changes weeks later include ↓RV wall thickness, ↑LV wall thickness

title: Circulatory Changes at Birth
text:
Functional and permanent closure:
Structure
Functional
Permanent
Umbilical arteries
Minutes
(Clamp, hypothermia contraction of Wharton’s
jelly, ↑PaO2)
Days
(Fibrosis)
Umbilical vein
Hours
(Clamp, hypothermia contraction of Wharton’s
jelly)
3-10 days
(Fibrosis)
Ductus venosus
Hours
(Stasis)
3-10 days
(Fibrosis → ligamentum teres)
Foramen ovale
Minutes; when LAP > RAP
(↓PVR, ↑SVR)
4-6 weeks
(Fibrosis)
Ductus arteriosus
12-24hrs
(↑PaO2, ↓PG)
2-3 weeks
(Fibrosis)
Variations to above:
•
Elevation of RAP → persistence of foramen ovale
•
Decrease PVR → persistence of ductus arteriosus
•
Prostaglandins and hypoxia → inhibit closure of ductus arteriosus

title: Collapsed Newborn
text:
Collapsed Newborn
Causes
Presentation
Management
Sepsis
Poor feeding, lethargy, fever, resp distress
•
Blood cultures
•
Immediate broad spectrum abx
•
Resuscitate
Congenital Heart
Disease
Cyanosis, murmur, shock
PGE1 to maintain ductal patency
Inotropic support
Consult cardio
Metabolic
Disorders
Lethargy, seizures, hypoglycaemia, acidosis
Correct, consult metabolic specialist
Respiratory
Tachypnoea, grunting, retractions, cyanosis
O2, CPAP +/- mechanical ventilation, cause (e.g.
surfactant for RDS)
NAI
Inconsistent history, injury pattern, bruising,
fractures
Stabilisation, reporting child to child protection, MDT

title: Cardiac/Respiratory Arrest
text:
Cardiac/Respiratory Arrest
Paediatric differences:
•
Resp causes > cardiac causes
•
Asystole and PEA most common initial rhythms (85%)
o
VF presents commonly in congenital heart disease, cardiac meds, channelopathies
•
Hypoxia and hypovolaemia most common causes (4Hs and 4Ts + HOCM / channelopathies)
•
2 rescue breaths prior to compressions, ratio 15:2
•
Compression depth: 1/3 AP distance
•
Compression technique: infant – 2 fingers / 2 thumbs, child – one or two hands
•
Paddle size: use largest pads that fit without touching each other
o
<10kg: 4.5 cm
o
>10kg: 8 – 12 cm
o
Age >8yo: adult pads
•
Intubation:
o
Cuffed & uncuffed both acceptable
o
Deflate stomach with OG / NG after intubation
o
Avoid hyperventilation post intubation
•
Circ: IO if pIVC/CVC not in place
•
Family presence should be facilitated with an allocated staff member
•
Use of real-time audiovisual feedback and prompt devices for quality assurance is
Arrest drug doses: (if weight unknown use tape – non-obese use actual body weight, obese use IBW)
•
Defib: 4J/kg
•
Adr: 10mcg/kg
•
Atropine: 20mcg/kg
•
Amio: 5 mg/kg
•
Fluid 20mL/kg
Specific drugs:
•
Calcium (Ca2+, Mg2+/K+, CCB overdose):
o
CaCl 10%: 0.2mL/kg
o
Ca Gluconate 10%: 0.7mL/kg
•
Glucose 10%: 2mL/kg
•
Lignocaine (VF, VT): 1mg/kg
•
Potassium (K+):
o
Mild: 0.2 – 0.5 mM/kg/hr (max 1mmol/kg)
o
Severe: 0.03 – 0.07 mmol/kg
•
Sodium bicarb (TCA overdose, K+): 0.5 – 1mmol/kg – ANZCOR recommends not giving for paeds cardiac arrest, only
TCA overdose and hyperkalaemia
Post-care:
•
No evidence for hypothermia, aim <37.5C
•
Normal oxygen, normocapnia (unless chronic lung dz, single ventricle, raised ICP)
•
sBP >5th percentile for age
•
BSL: 3 – 8 mM
•
Sedation + analgesia
Ix: full bloods, ECG, CXR, TTE

title: Tracheostomy Emergency
text:
Tracheostomy Emergency
Emergency management:
•
O2 to trache + face
•
Remove inner cannula if present and insert new one
•
Pass suction catheter
•
Tube change:
1. Same size
2. 0.5 size
3. Suction + down further 0.5 size
•
PRIMARY emergency O2: cover stoma → supraglottic technique with BMV / LMA
•
SECONDARY emergency O2:
1. Oral intubation (0.5 size, advance beyond stoma)
2. Stoma intubation with 3.0 tube
3. Advanced:
▪
Stoma bougie/AEC technique
▪
Fibreoptic scope

title: Anaphylaxis
text:
Anaphylaxis
2.7 / 100,000 – 4x rarer than adults (NMBA with highest anaphylaxis in NAP6 was atracurium)
Presenting symptom: bronchospasm, high airway pressures, hypotension, tachy/brady, rash, oedema, ETCO2
Most broncospasm in paeds is not due to anaphylaxis, but most common presenting feature is bronchospasm (64%).
Hypotension presents early in 75% of cases.
Grades:
1. Mild: general mucocutaneous signs
2. Mod: hypotension, tachycardia, bronchospasm, cough, mucocutaneous
3. Life-threatening: severe hypotension, tachy- or bradycardia, arrhythmias, bronchospasm +/- cutaneous
4. Arrest
Management:
•
Call for help – if refractory call paeds early
•
Remove trigger
•
Stop procedure, titrate anaesthetic
•
Establish airway, 100% O2
•
CVS:
o
Elevate legs
o
20 – 40mL/kg crystalloid
o
Adrenaline
▪
IM: <6y 150mcg, 6. – 12y 300mcg, >12y 500mcg
▪
IV:
•
Grade 2: 2mcg / kg
•
Grade 3: 4 – 10mcg/kg
•
Grade 4: 10mcg/kg
▪
Infusion:
•
Start at 0.1mcg/kg/min → max 2mcg/kg/min
o
Norad: 0.1 – 2mcg/kg/min
o
Vasopressin: bolus 0.04 units / kg → infusion 0.02 – 0.06 units/kg/hr
o
Glucagon: 40mcg/kg (max 1mg) IV
•
Bronchospasm: resistant more likely than with adults
o
Salbutamol: <6yo 6 puffs, >6yo 12 puffs
o
MgSO4: 50mg/kg (max 2g) over 20 mins
o
Aminophylline: 10mg/kg (max 500mg) over 1 hr
•
Other:
o
Hydrocort: 2.4mg/kg (max 200mg)
Tryptases at 0, 1, 4 and 24
Refractory paeds anaphylaxis – call paeds early

title: Meningococcal Sepsis
text:
Meningococcal Sepsis
Meningitis triad not always present
Septicaemia usually presents with fever + shock
Petechial rashes first present in areas of pressure i.e. elastic clothing
Management: (right)
•
ABC
•
Early antibiotics following cultures – do not delay for LP
•
Nasopharyngeal swab
CI to LP: SSx raised ICP, extensive purpura, convulsions, coagulopathy, local infection, resp insufficiency

title: Paediatric Trauma
text:
Paediatric Trauma
Leading cause of morbidity and mortality age <1yo. 80% blunt, 20% penetrating. Usually multiple injuries.
Head injury cause of 75% of deaths.
Trimodal mortality:
•
50% at scene (brain, bleed)
•
30% within hours (brain, bleed, airway)
•
20% late (organ failure, sepsis)
Mechanisms: non-accidental injury, falls, MVA, sports, drowning, fires
Differences to adult trauma injuries:
•
Energy dispersed over larger area → multiple injuries are common
•
Head & abdomen proportionally larger → more common injury
•
Bony structures → organ injuries without fracture
•
Prone to hypothermia
Pre-arrival preparation:
•
Staff: paeds ED, paeds speciality, PICU, anaesthetics, nursing, radiology, pathology / blood bank
•
Equipment: Broslow tape, warmers
•
Weight estimate:
o
Infant: (months + 9) / 2
o
1 – 10yo: (age + 4) x 2
o
>10yo: age x3
•
Calculate:
o
Doses for IVF, blood, drugs – NETS calculator for simplicity
o
ETT size, ETT depth
Primary survey:
•
C-spine (use soft collar, if unconscious use sandbags) + control haemorrhage
•
Airway:
o
Oral > nasal in trauma
o
Indications for intubation: resp failure, GCS <8, ICP, transport, OT required
o
RSI with MILS
o
Induction: ketamine 1-2mg/kg, fentanyl 1mcg/kg, sux 2mg/kg, atropine 10-20mcg/kg
o
Decompress stomach with OGT
•
Breathing:
o
Assess for: pneumothorax, haemothorax, flail chest
o
Lung protective ventilation with appropriate RR
•
Circulation:
o
Remember hypotension is a late sign
o
IV or IO access
o
Warmed isotonic crystalloid 20mL/kg
o
Haemorrhage control + blood 10mL/kg
o
Permissive hypotension sBP 80mmHg if no TBI
o
End point: HR, clear sensorium, pulses, colour/warmth/cap refill, sBP, UO (?response, transient, non-response)
•
Disability:
o
GCS / AVPU / pupils – d/w caregiver if there + ?moving all 4 limbs
o
BSL
o
Analgesia
o
WARM
Investigations:
•
Bloods + blood gas + G&H
•
Imaging: CXR, pelvis +/- C spine
o
Indications for CT brain: GCS <12, LOC, skull #, retrograde amnesia, neurology, severe injury
Secondary survey:
•
Head & neck
o
Soft tissue and bone
o
Neuro including cranial nerves

title: Traumatic Brain Injury
text:
SCIWORA – Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiological Evidence
50% of SCI. MRI + C-spine protection. Objective signs without XR or CT evidence.
Specific organ systems:
•
Chest trauma 3%: blunt trauma can cause organ injury without fracture
•
Abdominal 10%: indication for laparotomy → haemodynamically unstable with swollen abdomen, peritonitis,
pneumoperitoneum, renal vascular injury
•
Limbs involved 10-15%
Non-Accidental Trauma
Features: (have high index of suspicion in unusual injuries)
•
Retinal haemorrhage
•
Femoral shaft # <3yo
•
Bruising finger or hand shaped
•
Bites
•
Burns
•
Delayed presentation
•
Incompatible history
•
Child demeanour
•
Multiple injuries of different ages
→ d/w paediatrician + mandatory reporting
Other injury includes sexual, emotional, neglect + fabricated illness
RFs:
•
Child: disability, behavioural, prematurity, LBW, unplanned child
•
Parental: step-parent, teenage parent, substance abuse, mental health, generational abuse, parental disability
•
Family / social: single parent, DV, unemployment, poverty, social isolation
Traumatic Brain Injury
Raised ICP management: target <20mmHg
•
Signs of impending herniation (HTN + brady, severe headache, coma, abnormal breathing, decorticate posturing)
o
RSI with MILS
o
Osmotherapy + hyperventilate to PaCO2 30 – 35mmHg
•
No impending herniation → CT brain → surgery if lesion amenable to surgery
•
ICP monitoring indications: TBI with GCS <8, impending herniation, condition that will require ICP monitoring
o
ICP >20mmHg: osmotherapy + hyperventilate
o
Acute obstructive hydrocephalus on imaging → EVD + drain
•
Avoid boluses of midaz + fent as they may CBF
Decisions by neurosurg: thiopentone coma, decompressive craniotomy, hypothermia (32-33), hyperventilation <PaCO2 30mmHg
Management: neuroprotective measures, stabilise, control ICP +
•
Hb >70mmHg
•
Treat seizures
Osmotherapy:
•
Mannitol: 0.25 – 1g/kg
•
NaCl 3% 5mL/kg
o
Refractory raised ICP: saline 23.4% 0.5mL/kg max 30mL – avoid Na >170 for >72 hr (risk of thrombocytopaenia,
anaemia, DVT)
•
PaCO2 35 – 40mmHg, 30 – 35mmHg if very bad
•
CPP:
o
0 - 5yo: 40 – 50mmHg
o
6 – 17yo: 50 – 60mmHg
o
≥18yo: 60 – 70mmHg

title: Neonatal Surgeries
text:
Neonatal Surgeries
Considerations:
•
Airway:
o
Large occiput - careful positioning
o
Floppy U shaped epiglottis – straight blade
o
Short neck
o
Large tongue
o
Small airway
o
Cricoid narrowest part
o
Short trachea – secure at appropriate depth
o
Upper airway vagal reflex - atropine
o
Sub-glottic stenosis
o
Risk of gastric insufflation
o
High risk laryngospasm
•
Resp:
o
Apnoea risk – require apnoea monitoring post-op
o
High VO2 – shorter safe apnoea time + desaturations
o
Diaphragmatic breathing + risk of fatigue 2’ type 1 fibres
o
RR + WOB
o
Compliant chest wall, horizontal ribs, CC > FRC – high PEEP
o
Risk with circuit deadspace
o
Ventilator can have poor accuracy – transcutaneous CO2 monitoring
•
CVS:
o
Assess for congenital heart disease
o
Patent shunts: pre- and post-ductal SpO2
o
Stiff, non- compliant ventricle
o
Fixed SV; HR dependent CO – avoid bradycardia
o
High VO2
•
Renal:
o
concentrating capacity
o
Poor Na handling
o
drug clearance
o
Risk of hyponatraemia
•
Hepatic:
o
glycogen stores – monitor and manage BSL, early feeding, minimise fasting
o
Immature enzymes – reduced metabolism
•
Risk of hypothermia – warm
•
Haem:
•
Transfusion thresholds:
o
PRBCS:
▪
Acute blood loss >10% circ volume
▪
Hb <80g/L in stable newborn
▪
Hb <120g/l if resp distress, CHD, resp therapy
o
Platelets: >100 for surgery, ABO + Rh D compatible, CMV -ve, single donor apheresis
o
FFP: ABO compatible
Main anaesthetic issues: above +
•
Transitional circulation
•
Post-op apnoea risk
•
Hypothermia
•
Short apnoea time prior to desaturation

title: Neonatal Surgeries
text:
Pre-op:
•
Pregnancy + delivery, birth weight, APGARs, postmenstrual age, gestational age, syndromes
•
Resp distress: surfactant, airway, ventilation +/- level of support
•
CVS: ?support, coagulopathy
•
IV access
•
Ix: routine + gas +/- CXR +/- TTE – crossmatch if indicated
•
Transfer: consider if risk of deterioration, intubate prior to transfer, consider operation in NICU
Intra-op:
•
Experienced staff, paediatric anaesthetist
•
Paediatric equipment
•
Avoid hypothermia: warm IVF, forced air, room temp room (27C), minimise exposure, humidified gas
•
Monitoring: routine + as indicated, pre- and post-ductal SpO2, transcutaneous CO2
•
NGT prior to induction + 4 quadrant rotation
•
Pre-oxygenation
•
Induction: IV or inhalational
•
Airway: ETT
•
Ventilation: pay close attention, may need NICU ventilator, minimise dead space, PEEP, lung protective ventilation
•
IVF: equation. Laparotomy 10mL/kg/hr +/- resus boluses
•
Blood: weigh swabs, measure suction, aim Hb >120, transfusion trigger is 10% (i.e. 10mL/kg)
•
Analgesia: regional, paracetamol, opioids
Post-op:
•
NICU
•
Apnoea monitoring:
o
Definition: no respiratory effort for ≥20s, or ≥10s with SpO2 or bradycardia
o
RFs: postmenstrual age <56 weeks (preterm), <44 weeks (term), anaemia, history of apnoea, GA > spinal, BSL,
comorbid
o
Treatment: stimulation, O2, BMV, CPAP, caffeine
•
Analgesia:
o
Paracetamol: 28 – 32 weeks 7.5mg/kg q8 hourly, 33 – 36 weeks q6 hourly, >37 weeks 10 – 15mg/kg q6 hourly
•
BSL monitoring
Day Surgery
•
Ex-premature: PMA >54 – 60 weeks
•
Term baby: PMA >46 weeks

title: Inguinal Hernia Repair
text:
Inguinal Hernia Repair
Epidemiology: 6% males, <1% females
RF: male, preterm, LBW, congenital abnormalities, FHx
Presentation: painless groin swelling +/- incarceration +/- bowel obstruction +/- strangulation
Rx: surgery – balance risk of anaesthesia against risk of incarceration
Anaesthetic technique:
•
GA + caudal / ilioinguinal block
•
Neuraxial: spinal, caudal, epidural

title: Necrotising Enterocolitis
text:
Necrotising Enterocolitis
Incidence 2/1000 live births. Mostly preterm infants. Ischaemia 2’ mesenteric blood flow.
Causes:
•
O2 delivery / blood flow: CO (hypotension, cardiac failure, arrhythmia), hypoxia
Other contributing factors: enteral feeding, hyperosmolar formula, intestinal dysfx, bacterial infection, CHD
Ischaemia → necrosis +/- perf +/- septic shock
Diagnosis: via imaging – dilation of bowel with intramural gas
50% managed conservatively: decompression of stomach, broad spectrum abx, correction of fluid / electrolyte abnormalities
If requires emergency laparotomy:
•
Problems of prematurity
•
Large fluid losses
•
Usually thrombocytopaenic + coagulopathic
•
No N2O – intramural gas in bowel

title: Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia Repair
text:
Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia Repair
Incidence: 1/3600, mortality 30%, morbidity 87%
RFs: genetic 10% (trisomy, fryns, cornelia de lange, beckwith-wiedemann, CHARGE), M > F
Can have additional systems abnormalities (CVS, GU, limb, CNS)
Classification:
•
A: small defect entirely surrounded by muscle
•
B: <50% chest wall with absent diaphragm
•
C: >50% chest wall
•
D: absent hemidiaphragm
80% are left sided
Type:
•
Bochdalek (foramen): 95%, failed fusion of pleuroperitoneal folds
•
Morgagni (foramen): right sided, anterior, better outcomes
•
Bilateral 1% - usually fatal
Suspect if maternal polyhydramnios.
Prognostic factors:
•
Antenatal: liver herniation, early gestational age at diagnosis
•
Postnatal: defect size, cardiac involvement, pulmonary HTN, LBW, low APGAR, small contralateral lung, bilateral defect
Antenatal diagnosis: US screening, MRI
Foetal surgery: (TOTAL trial)
•
Foetoscopic endoluminal tracheal occlusion: treats most severe cases, reversible tracheal occlusion → development
of foetal lung + improved survival
•
Placed at 27 – 29 weeks, removed ~34/40
Post-natal diagnosis: resp distress +/- scaphoid abdomen, CXR
Treatment:
•
Intubation + lung protective ventilation (RR 50 – 100 / HFOV)
•
NG insertion to decompress bowel
•
TTE: ?cardiac abnormality, pulmonary HTN, shunt
•
Rx:
o
Pulmonary vasodilators (PVR and improve PPHN): sildenafil, prostacyclin (note: NO → mortality)
o
Inotropes
o
NMBA (O2 consumption, and airway pressures)
•
ECMO if required
Timing of surgery – once medically optimised. Can be open or thorascopic.
Aim: normal MAP, sats 85 – 90% on <50% FiO2, lactate <3, UO >1mL/kg/hr; may be on ECMO
Monitor for abrupt deterioration: ?contralateral tension PTx, pulmonary hypertension causing R → L shunt
Intra-op:
•
2 anaesthetists
•
Transcutaneous CO2 (ventilation and CO2 removal can be difficult)
•
Inhaled NO
•
Pulmonary hypertension may worsen
•
Risk of abdominal compartment syndrome on closure
Post-op:
•
ICU ventilated
•
Same as pre-op management (including pulmonary hypertension management)

title: Pyloric Stenosis
text:
Pyloric Stenosis
Pyloric stenosis: hypertrophy of smooth muscle of gastric outlet → outflow obstruction
Incidence: 1.5/1000
RFs: male (4:1), 1st born, genetic
Presentation: most often 2-3mo w/ projectile vomiting, non-bilious, weight loss, failure to thrive, dehydration, palpable “olive”
Diagnosis: ultrasound, barium study if needed (“string sign”)
Medical issues / sequelae: **medical emergency
•
Hypochloraemic, hypokalaemia metabolic alkalosis
•
Subsequent respiratory acidosis → hypoventilation, apnoeas
•
Dehydration: aldosterone → renal K+ wasting
•
Paradoxical acidic urine 2’ fluid conservation
Resuscitation:
•
IVF:
o
Bolus 20mL/kg bolus NaCl 0.9%
o
Deficit replaced over 1 – 2 days – NaCl 0.45% + glucose 5% + KCl 10mM/500mL @ 150mL/kg/day
•
End points: normal pH (HCO3 <30), normal chloride (>90), BE -4 – 2.5, K 3.5 – 5.0, UO 1mL/kg/hr (further replace K+
when UO is established)
Pre-op:
•
Resuscitation prior to OT – risk of CVS collapse on induction
•
High aspiration risk: NG with 4 quadrant drainage before induction (supine, R lateral, prone, L lateral)
o
Consider gastric US to confirm
Intra-op:
•
Modified RSI: IV preferred, adequate NMB to avoid aspiration, microcuff ETT
•
Analgesia: paracetamol, LA / regional
•
Laparoscopic or open: if laparoscopic aim <10cmH2O, adjust ventilation
•
Extubation: awake + NMBA fully reversed
Post-op:
•
Apnoea monitoring 12 hours (prone to hypoventilation 2’ alkaline CSF)
•
Early feeding

title: Cleft Lip/Palate
text:
Cleft Lip/Palate
Definition:
•
Fissure in upper lip / palate (complete fissure enters nasal cavity)
•
Unilateral or bilateral
•
Lip and / or palate
Incidence: 1/700 - cleft lip more common in males, cleft palate more common in females
Pathophysiology: fusion usually occurs 6/40, hard + soft palate 10/40
RFs: genetic, environmental (maternal age, smoking, EtOH, drugs, nutrition, infection, teratogen), syndrome
Timing of surgery:
•
Lip: primary repair 6 weeks – 6mo
•
Palate: 6 – 12 mo
Pre-op: routine +
•
Comprehensive airway assessment, URTI (chronic rhinorrhoea common), feeding issues
•
Elective – delay until optimised
•
Tertiary centre
Intra-op:
•
Induction: based on suspected airway difficulty
•
Airway: south oral RAE or reinforced ETT
•
Shared airway considerations: blood, access (draping), debris (throat pack + sticker), dislodgement (gag, positioning)
•
Maintenance: volatile or TIVA, consider remi infusion
•
Analgesia: paracetamol, NSAIDs, opioids, LA infiltration, dexmed, steroid
o
Nerve blocks: infraorbital, palatine, nasopalatine, maxillary
•
PONV: dex, ondans
•
Fluid: IVF + BSL monitoring
•
Temp control + monitoring
•
Emergence: inspect + suction, care not to disrupt suture line (avoid OPA), nasal airway may be placed by surgeons,
smooth extubation to avoid coughing / straining, can be deep or awake (consider bleeding)
Post-op:
•
Appropriate ward, likely 1-3 days
•
Monitoring for airway compromise for 24hr
•
DC when feeding well
•
Suture removal under GA 1/52 later

title: Removal of Foreign Body
text:
Removal of Foreign Body
Common <3y.
Culprit: food, hardware, toys, medications / pills, button batteries
Location:
•
Highest mortality: larynx 3%, trachea 13%
•
Mostly main bronchus: right lung 60%, left lung 23%, bilateral 2%
Presentation:
•
Witnessed choking episode
•
Cough / stridor / wheeze (may be unilateral +/- reduced AE)
•
Salivation
•
Haemoptysis
•
Cyanosis
Ix:
•
CXR: PA + lateral
•
CT
•
Bronchoscopy
Management: above +
•
Rigid bronchoscopy / suspension laryngoscope – allows surgery through lumen
•
Thoracotomy for those that can’t be removed
•
ECMO if complete loss of airway

title: Magnets
text:
Risk with surgery is complete obstruction of airway → asphyxiation – ensure surgeon is scrubbed and ready
Goals:
•
Maintain spontaneous ventilation (PPV can force FB deeper)
•
Topicalise airway (rigid bronch very stimulating, MAD device during laryngoscopy + spont vent)
o
Lignocaine max 4mg/kg
•
Aim for RR close to normal – careful titration of opioid / anaesthetic
•
Maintain adequate depth to prevent coughing
•
Oxygenation:
o
THRIVE
o
Ventilating bronchoscope
o
Tube through nose in posterior pharynx
•
Communication with ENT surgeon
•
Dexamethasone to oedema
Post-op:
•
Intubate + PEEP to reinflate lung
•
Follow up flexible bronchoscopy
•
Usually extubate
•
Nebulised adrenaline for post-op stridor
Battery Ingestion
Potentially life threatening. Button batteries generate OH- ions at the -ve pole → localised alkaline caustic injury → tissue
liquefaction and necrosis. Corosive injury can occur within 2hr of ingestion.
Location:
•
Oesophageal impaction ++ risk
•
Stomach causes less damage
Co-ingestion with a magnet risk of perforation.
Any suspicion of ingestion →
•
History
•
Examination
•
Xray of neck, chest and abdomen (button batteries have double halo sign)
Indication for urgent removal <2hr in button battery ingestion:
•
Battery in oesophagus
o
Sucralfate 10mL q10 min until removed
•
Battery in stomach + symptoms
•
Known GI tract abnormalities i.e. Meckel’s
•
Co-ingestion of button battery + magnet
Cylindrical batteries:
•
Oesophagus: remove <24 hours
•
Stomach:
o
Symptomatic: remove asap
o
Asymptomatic: no intervention but monitor for SSx
Anaesthetic management: if requires urgent removal proceed unfasted
Magnets
Single magnet should pass spontaneously if not impacted.
Possible harm if:
•
Multiple magnets
•
Magnet + another metallic object
•
≥2x neodymium magnets (strong forces)
Mechanism of injury: attractive forces can cause trapped bowel → pressure
necrosis, ischaemia
Management: symptomatic or ‘red flag’ features → urgent intervention

title: Grommets
text:
Grommets
Pre-op:
•
Patients often have recurrent URTIs and otitis media
o
2-7x risk of laryngospasm, coughing, breath-holding, obstructed airway. Further risk with intubation (11x)
o
risk of intra-op and post-op hypoxia
▪
When to cancel patient? (Remember most children have 4-6 URTIs / year)
•
COVID (look at new ANZCA guideline 2023)
•
T >38
•
Productive cough + coloured sputum / nasal discharge
•
Evidence of chest infection
•
Looks lethargic or unwell (if child happy and energetic they will usually be okay)
•
Requires intubation for surgery
•
<1yo
Consider location + availability of post-op support, should have discuss with surgical team + parent(s). If cancelled, re-schedule
4-6 weeks post-resolution of symptoms.
Intra-op:
•
Consider Mapleson circuit – very quick procedure
•
Pre-grommet insertion is very stimulating, have patient very deep but with short acting agents – no pain after grommet
is placed

title: Dental Surgery
text:
Dental Surgery
Pre-op:
•
Assess need for pre-med
•
Assess for swelling / associated infection / trismus – assess possibility of doing procedure under LA if concern for airway
(note: it is possible to drain submandibular swelling under LA)
•
Ascertain type of surgery:
o
Simple extractions: may be done under LA
o
Multiple extractions: LMA or nasal intubation
o
Restorations: nasal intubation
•
Choose appropriate centre for patient i.e. OSA, paeds
Intra-op:
•
Airway as above
•
Ensure not extubated when neck extended
•
Gag: check airway pressure
•
Throat pack if indicated – throat pack precautions
•
Simple extractions often don’t need abx
•
Dexamethasone
•
Extubation:
o
Suction coroners clot
o
Either awake or deep
o
Consider left lateral, head down

title: LBO (Laryngobronchoesophagoscopy)
text:
LBO (Laryngobronchoesophagoscopy)
Issues:
•
Shared airway
•
Loss of airway + oxygenation
•
Must be deep enough to maintain spont vent + deep enough for rigid bronch
•
No ETCO2
o
Transcutaneous CO2 monitoring available but not generally needed / won’t change management
o
Expect ETCO2 to be high at end (may be slow to wake)
Can be elective or emergency. Tertiary centre where able.
Technique:
•
Monitoring: routine +
o
RR from ECG impedance
•
Gas down with 100% O2 → IVC when deep + sevo 4%
•
Laryngoscopy – also used to assess how deep
o
Normal laryngoscopy
o
Parsons laryngoscope allows delivery of O2 via tubing from T piece from CGO + can be suspended
•
Spray cords
•
ENT →
o
Spray beyond cords
o
Rigid bronch – O2 on side port
•
Maintenance of anaesthesia:
o
Precedex
o
Propofol infusion (high rate 1mL/kg/hour or high TCI on paedsfuser) – titrate
•
Dexamethasone: high dose
•
End of case: depends on procedure + patient
o
Usually BVM wake up spont venting holding airway
o
Some will go to ICU intubated if indicated by procedure
Intra-op issue:
•
Complete loss of airway
o
If obstruction at carina communicate to surgeons → try to push into one main bronchus
o
Anaesthesia take over airway → OLV

title: Adenotonsillectomy
text:
Adenotonsillectomy
Indications: OSA, recurrent tonsillitis
Pre-op:
•
Assessment: indication, ?OSA, airway +/- syndrome, routine, ?recent URTI, airway reactivity, bleeding disorders
•
Avoid pre-med
•
Indications for planned admission: age ≤3yo, severe OSA, comorbid disease, social (e.g. proximity to hospital)
Intra-op:
•
Induction: inhalational or IV +/- adjuncts
•
Airway: south oral RAE or reinforced LMA, high risk difficult airway, caution with mouth gag may compress ETT, throat
pack sticker
•
PONV prophylaxis: 2 agents (high risk)
•
IVF: 20mL/kg crystalloid
•
Analgesia: paracetamol +/- NSAID (safe, usually based on surgeon preference), clonidine or dexmed, dexamethasone
0.3mg/kg, local anaesthetic, fent 1-2mcg/kg, tramadol 1mg/kg, ketamine 0.1 – 0.5 mg/kg
•
Extubation: awake to PRAE, suction + assess for coroner’s clot, remove throat pack, observe – high risk for
laryngospasm
LMA
ETT
Advantages
•
Smooth emergence
•
No paralysis
•
Minimal airway trauma
•
More secure
•
Good surgical access
Disadvantages
•
Less secure
•
May impair surgical access
•
Airway trauma
•
Risk of oesophageal / bronchial intubation
•
+/- paralysis
•
Airway soiling
•
Extubation
Post-op:
•
High risk PRAE
•
Avoid excessive opioids (reduce by 50%)
•
HDU admission for: syndrome, severe OSA, PRAE
Complications:
•
Immediate: trauma, burns, airway fire, displaced/kinked airway device, bleeding
•
Intermediate (<24hr): emergence delirium, pain, PRAE (5%), PONV, primary bleeding, death
•
Delayed (>24hr): pain, N&V, dehydration, poor PO intake, secondary bleeding (within 28 days, peak 5 – 7 days), speech
disorder, nerve injury, persistent OSA, stenosis, infection, IJ thrombus

title: Post-Tonsillectomy Bleed
text:
Post-Tonsillectomy Bleed
Define:
•
Primary: within 24 hr (more serious)
•
Secondary: within 28 days (usually day 7-10 days, can be infection related)
Issues:
•
Blood loss / hypovolaemia
•
Difficult airway
•
Full stomach (blood)
•
Uncooperative child
Pre-op:
•
Assess (including anaesthetic record) + resuscitate 20mL/kg bolus
•
2x IV → send bloods, coags, cross-match +/- administer blood products
•
No pre-med
Intra-op:
•
Routine monitoring
•
Airway – suction ready, ENT in room – scrubbed, difficult airway equipment, smaller ETT x2 (in case blocked)
o
First attempt: direct laryngoscopy – aim for bubbles
•
Induction:
o
IV RSI preferred, head down or left lateral
o
Inhalational: L lateral or head down, FiO2 100%, no N2O
•
CVS: IVF (resus as needed), fluid warmer +/- blood, vasopressor ready (metaraminol 10mcg/kg) + dilute adrenaline,
normothermia
•
Extubation: empty stomach prior with OGT, awake extubation in left lateral position, extended stay in recovery for
monitoring, check Hb / gas

title: Strabismus
text:
Strabismus
Issues:
•
May occur with other illness e.g. craniosyntosis, craniofacial abnormalities, chromosomal
•
Occulocardiac reflex (trigeminal V1 → vagus)
o
Rx: release traction, atropine 20mcg/kg, glycol 10mcg/kg, regional can block afferent limb
•
PONV +++
•
Cardiovascular effects of topical ocular medications e.g. phenylephrine
•
Painful: paracetamol, NSAID +/- longer acting opioid
•
Rare association with MH – avoid sux, monitor temp

title: Traumatic Eye Injury
text:
Traumatic Eye Injury
Issues:
•
Polytrauma likely
•
Avoid IOP (ketamine, suxamethonium)
•
Unfasted patient
Plan:
•
RSI with roc
•
Control IOP: normocapnia, smooth induction / emergence, no external pressure on eyes

title: Retinoblastoma
text:
Retinoblastoma
Intra-arterial chemotherapy (melphalan):
•
Remote anaesthesia / IR
•
Heparin to avoid ophthalmic artery thrombosis
•
GA with NMBA – frequent vent on / vent off
•
Melphalan → orbital swelling + vomiting → PONV +++
•
SEs: life threatening autonomic cardioresp reflexes (MOA not fully understood) – have adrenaline prepared, atypical
bronchospasm, atropine for bradycardia

title: Tracheostomy
text:
Tracheostomy
Indications: long term resp support, secretion clearance, fixed upper airway obstruction, airway protection, trauma, surgical
indication, EXIT procedure
Epidemiology: 30% <1y, 65% <4y, 25% have difficult / impossible intubation
Tracheostomy tubes:
•
Classified by internal diameter
•
Most have no inner cannula due to small internal diameter
•
Most are uncuffed
•
Shorter length for neonates
•
Most are NOT MRI safe
Intra-op procedure:
•
Supine, shoulder roll
•
LA + adrenaline
•
ETT withdrawn, trache tube inserted → ventilator
•
Fibreoptic scope evaluation
•
Maturation sutures – safety for paeds traches – sutures between anterior tracheal wall and skin to hasten maturation
•
Post-op CXR
•
Stay sutures removed at 1/52
Post-op:
•
ICU
•
Emergency trache box: TT same size + half size down, round ended scissors, tape, dressing, KY jelly, syringe + saline,
suction catheter
•
Bedhead signs: details, type, size, length, suction catheter size, info on upper airway patency
•
Mature at days 3 – 7, safe to change
Complications:
•
Immediate: loss of airway, bleeding, pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum, surgical emphysema, oesophageal injury,
RLN damage
•
Intermediate (<2/52): tube dislodgement before stoma maturation, obstructed tube, bleeding, infection
•
Late: granuloma, vascular erosion, suprastomal collapse, swallowing issues, skin integrity, tracheal stenosis, trachea-
oesophageal fistula
Anaesthetic management of trache:
•
Pre-op:
o
Assess medical conditions +/- critical illness weakness ?home ventilation
o
Trache: indication, brand, size, type, complications, maturation, suction catheter size, last change
o
Respiratory management: O2 requirement, bronchodilators, infections
•
Intra-op:
o
Emergency trache box
o
Leave in or change for cuffed
o
Inhalational induction via trache
o
Reinsert usual tube end of case
•
Post-op:
o
Location: appropriate ward or ICU
o
Signs + emergency box

title: Neurosurgery
text:
Neurosurgery
Paediatric neurophysiology:
•
CBF: higher than adults, lower in neonates
•
CMRO2: higher than adults, lower in neonates
•
PaCO2: less responsive in neonates i.e. hyperventilation less effective
•
PaO2: more responsive in neonates
•
Autoregulation unknown: MAP 20 – 40
•
ICP:
o
Before suture fusion skull can in size if gradual
o
Posterior fontanelle closure @ 6mo
o
Anterior fontanelle closure @ 12-18mo
o
Suture closure @ 10y
o
Normal ICP: neonate 0 – 6mmHg, child 5 – 15mmHg
SSx raised ICP: irritability, poor feeding, GCS, vomiting, full fontanelle, wide cranial sutures, headache, diplopia, papilloedema
CPP goals:
•
<1yo: 45 – 50mmHg
•
1 – 10yo: 50 – 60mmHg
•
>10yo: 60 – 70mmHg
Surgical issues: paeds/neonate, bleeding, VAE, ICP + CPP management
Pre-op:
•
Assess ICP
•
CVS: assess for murmur +/- TTE (risk in shunt + VAE)
•
Anticonvulsant therapy
•
Fluid / electrolyte
Intra-op:
•
Similar goals to adult neuroanaesthesia
•
Smooth gas induction if required – sevo only is okay (no N2O)
•
Maintenance: TIVA + remi or sevo <1 MAC
•
Drugs: mannitol 0.25 – 1g/kg, PONV, analgesia
•
Monitoring: invasive BP +/- CVC (esp if risk of VAE), VAE monitoring (precordial doppler, ETCO2), neurophys monitoring
if indicated, BSL control
•
IVF: avoid IV glucose + other hypotonic fluids
Post-op:
•
Likely ICU
Raised ICP management: must first confirm transducer height + zeroed
•
Physical: head up 30 degrees, avoid obstruction to venous drainage (neutral, no ETT tapes), drain CSF if EVD in situ,
ensure ETT not obstructed (clear secretions / suction, treat bronchospasm)
•
Physiological: temp, normoxia, PaCO2 35 – 40, high-normal sodium, normovolaemia
•
Pharmacological: adequate sedation, paralysis, treat seizures, osmotherapy (mannitol 20% 0.25 – 0.5g/kg, NaCl 3%
3mL/kg), steroids if tumour but avoid if TBI, barbiturate coma if refractory
•
Surgical: EVD, decompressive craniotomy

title: Craniotomy for Tumour
text:
Craniotomy for Tumour
CNS tumours are second most common paediatric malignancy. 60% posterior fossa.
Pre-op: routine +
•
Focused neuro history: evidence of raised ICP, focal neurology, bulbar signs, SSx DI
•
?Cardiac defect (due to risk of VAE)
Intra-op:
•
Consider inhalational induction if IV traumatic and concerns for raised ICP
•
Opioid to blunt SNS
•
Reinforced ETT secured with waterproof tape
•
TIVA maintenance
•
Neuroprotective measures
•
ICP management
•
Monitor for VAE
Post-op:
•
Most extubated
•
PICU
•
Maintenance fluids

title: Scoliosis Surgery
text:
Scoliosis Surgery
Diagnosis: Adam’s forward test 7 (exam)/Cobb angle 10 (radiograph)
Most common cause: adolescent idiopathic scoliosis
Surgery: posterior spinal fusion under intra-operative skull femoral traction
•
Metal rods adjacent to spine bilaterally
•
Rods rotated to realign spine → secured
•
Lower back pain comparable to general population
Pre-op:
•
Pain: education 2/52 prior with family
o
Start gabapentin pre-op
•
Pre-op aprepitant
•
Prone consent: PION, stroke (2’ arterial occlusion in neck), injury for inhibition of venous drainage, peripheral
neuropathy
Intra-op:
•
Blood management: active warming, TXA
•
Monitoring: art line, SSEPS + MEPS
o
TIVA to avoid interference
•
Prone: padding/pressure, check eyes
•
GDFT using SVV: LOS, APO, ileus, and avoids AKI
•
Analgesia: paracetamol, NSAID, IT morphine, ketamine, gabapentin
•
PONV +++
•
Antibiotic prophylaxis ++
Post-op:
•
PCA + APS
•
Early physiotherapy + IDC out
•
PONV
Scoliosis Surgery for Cerebral Palsy
Pre-op:
•
ASSESS:
o
CP: type, severity
o
Comorbidities: respiratory dysfunction, CVS status, nutritional status, previous surgeries
o
Neurological: spasticity, seizures, cognitive function
o
Ix: routine +
▪
PFTs + CXR
▪
TTE
o
Difficulty of airway
•
MANAGE:
o
Nutrition + hydration
o
Physical therapy
o
Optimise seizure management
o
Educate family + patient
•
REFER:
o
MDT: ortho, neurology, physio
Intra-op:
•
Intubation: difficult airway – may require FOB
•
Normothermia
•
Regional analgesia
Post-op:
•
APS
•
Incentive spirometry +/- CPAP
•
ERAS + physio

title: Paediatric Blood Management
text:
Paediatric Blood Management
Maximum allowable blood loss = ((Hb initial – Hb low) / Hb initial) x estimated blood volume
Estimated blood volume:
•
Preterm: 100 mL/kg
•
<3 mo: 80 mL/kg
•
>3 mo: 70 mL/kg
Hct targets:
•
Well child: 20 – 25%
•
Target Hb:
o
Well: 70 – 80
o
Cyanotic heart disease: 100 -120
Management:
•
Restrictive transfusion strategy recommended, usually indicated if Hb <70 but may be well tolerated
•
Volume to transfuse:
o
<20 kg: calculated based on weight and desired increment
Volume to transfuse (mL) = weight (kg) x desired increment (g/L) x 0.4
OR increment of 10 g/L = 4 mL/kg
o
>20 kg: transfuse single unit i.e. 10 mL/kg
•
Rate: 5 – 6 mL/kg/hr
Massive transfusion:
•
50% TBV in 3 hours
•
100% TBV in 24 hours
•
>10% TBV over 10 minutes
•
40mL/kg blood loss
MTP volumes:
•
pRBC: 20 – 25 mL/kg OR 1 unit / 10 kg weight
•
Platelets: 10 – 15 mL/kg OR 1 unit / 30 kg weight
•
FFP: 15 mL/kg OR 1 unit / 20 kg weight
•
Cryo: 5mL/kg OR 1 unit / 10 kg weight
•
TXA: 15 mg/kg loaded over 10 minutes → 2mg / kg / hr for 8 hours
(max 125 mg / hour same as adults)
•
Prothrombinex: 25 – 50 units/kg
•
Fibrinogen concentrate: 70 mg/kg
•
Factor VII: 90 mcg/kg
Ratio:
pRBC : FFP : platelets
2: 1: 1
Therapeutic targets:
•
Hb >80
•
Fibrinogen >2
•
PT: <1.5
•
Platelets >75 (>100 in TBI)
Equipment:
•
Fluid warmer
•
Rapid infuser

title: Paediatric Blood Management
text:
Calcium replacement
Ionised calcium
CaCl replacement
CaGluconate replacement
0.9 – 1.0
10 mg/kg
30 mg/kg
0.8 – 0.9
20 mg/kg
60 mg/kg
<0.8
30 mg/kg
90 mg/kg
Complications:
•
Transfusion reaction: allergic, haemolytic (acute, delayed), febrile
•
Immunological: TRALI, TRIM, GVHD, infection
•
Metabolic: Ca2+, Mg2+, K+, alkalosis / acidosis, hypothermia
•
Other: TACO, coagulopathy, air embolism

title: Paediatric Regional Anaesthesia
text:
Paediatric Regional Anaesthesia
Evidence for RA in infants → haemodynamic stability, post-op respiratory complications, stress response, faster return of gut
function and feeding
Differences of US imaging:
•
Anatomical:
o
Smaller, more superficial structures
o
Less endoneurium
o
Incomplete myelin sheath
o
Dural sac S3-4 (S2 in adults)
o
Spinal cord L3 (L1 in adults) – most cephalad spinal space without major risk for cord damage is L3/4
o
CSF volume 4mL/kg (2mL/kg in adults)
•
Physiological:
o
CO → LA absorption, cardiac sensitivity
o
hepatic metabolism <9mo
o
alpha1 acid glycoprotein → free fraction
o
spinal sympathetic nervous system maturity
Implications:
•
risk of nerve injury from needle
•
Faster onset block
•
Lower LA concentrations required
•
Prolonged motor block
•
Spinal: below L4, less hypotension
•
risk of cardiac toxicity
•
risk accumulation with infusion / repeat doses
•
Often performed sedated / under GA
Major plexus blocks:
Complications: 1/1000
Doses:
•
Upper / lower limbs:
ropivacaine 0.2%
0.5-1.5 mL/kg
•
Fascial plane:
ropivacaine 0.2%
0.2-0.75 mL/kg
Continuous Infusions
Age
Ropivacaine 0.1%
Bupivacaine
<3 mo
0.375 mg/kg/hr
0.25 mg/kg/hr
>3 mo
0.5 mg/kg/hr
0.5 mg/kg/hr
Peripheral adjuvants:
•
Clonidine / dexmed

section_path: Anatomy of Neonatal Spine and Spinal Cord
title: Anatomy of Neonatal Spine and Spinal Cord
text:
Anatomy of Neonatal Spine and Spinal Cord
Note: an imaginary line drawn between the two superior iliac crests (intercristal line) is below the lower level of the spinal cord
at any age.
Spinal Anaesthesia
Indications: inguinal, urological, lower limb
Spinal doses: bupivacaine 0.5%
•
<5kg:
1mL/kg
•
5–15kg:
0.4mL/kg
•
>15mg:
0.3mL/kg
Duration of effect: 45 – 60min, longer with adjuvants
Adjuvants:
•
Intrathecal morphine: 10-20mcg/kg
•
Fentanyl: 0.2mcg/kg
•
Clonidine: 1-2mcg/kg
•
?Adrenaline: 2-4mcg/kg
Procedure:
•
EMLA to site
•
Oral sucrose sedation
•
Fully flexed spine by assistant
•
Paeds spinal needle: 25G 25mm (or 27G)
•
L4/5 or L5/S1
Benefits:
•
GA / sedation  possibly neuro effects
•
pain
•
inflammatory response
•
Avoid airway manipulation +/- post op ventilation
•
Maintain spontaneous ventilation
•
ileus
No benefit: post-op apnoea incidence
Complications:
•
PDPH: blood patch 0.1-0.2mL/kg (headache rare in young children, more common in teens)
•
Failure: up to 20%

title: Caudal Block
text:
Epidural Anaesthesia
Depth from skin to epidural space: 1mm/kg (10mm in neonate) – measure prior with US
Ligamentum flavum is softer in children – use LOR with saline
Can do lumbar or thoracic
Incidence of serious and major complications are less than in adults:
•
Failure 5%
•
Technical 11%
•
Dural tap: 0.1-0.5% - higher in neonates
•
Epidural abscess is very rare
Confirmation of catheter tip position:
•
Epidurography: contrast dye
•
ECG guidance
•
Nerve stimulation: stimulation through epidural catheter → myotome specific activity
•
Ultrasound
Dose:
•
Load: 1.5 – 2mg/kg bupivacaine / ropivacaine
Avoid epidural additives <6mo 2’ risk of spinal cord toxicity and risk of apnoea
For all epidural + regional – total infusion bupivacaine 0.125% 0.3mL/kg/hr – split between all catheters
Caudal Block
Indications: analgesia for sub-umbilical surgery – analgesia or sole anaesthetic
Procedure: epidural space access via sacral hiatus – commonly landmark technique
Access epidural space caudally – single shot block into space
CI: normal epidural CI, spinal dysraphism, inspect for nappy rash
Anatomical considerations:
•
Sacrum does not fuse posteriorly until the late teens – can do until teens but uncommon
•
Sacral hiatus results from failure of fusion of the posterior arches of the fifth
(occasionally fourth and third) sacral vertebrae; it is covered by the sacrococcygeal
membrane
•
Sacral hiatus is relatively larger and higher in neonates (sacral anomalies are found in ∼5% of children)
•
Neonatal epidural space contains less fat and fibrous tissue → easier to insert catheters to higher levels from lower
approaches
Sacrococcygeal membrane:
•
Neonate: 5mm
•
<2yo: 10mm
Feel for pop or give.
Dose: ropivacaine 2mg/kg
Volume:
•
0.5mL/kg → L1 blockade
•
1mL/kg → T10 blockade (umbilicus)
Complications: injection in wrong location, infection (including sacral OM), hypotension, nerve roots injury, antesacral injection
with rectal perforation, haematoma, LAST, delayed resp depression, urinary retention (check urination before discharge in day
surgery)

title: Flaps
text:
Flaps
Transfer of tissue with intrinsic blood supply (excludes skin grafts)
Classification:
•
Blood supply:
o
Axial: regional blood vessel (named)
▪
Pedicled: remains connected to origin
▪
Free: disconnected and reconnected micro-surgically
Proximity: local, regional, distant
Dissected vascular tissue is denervated but still responds to physical, chemical and humoral stimuli
Pre-op:
•
Assess:
o
CI: hypercoaguable, sickle cell, polycythaemia
•
Manage:
o
Smoking cessation 4/52 weeks: nicotine flap perfusion
o
Weight loss
o
Nutritional (particularly head & neck)
o
EtOH cessation
•
Refer
Intra-op goals: flow = PR2 / 8ul
•
Maintain perfusion pressure (full, hyperdynamic circulation)
o
MAP
o
Low venous pressure
Management:
•
Radius:
o
Warm
o
Normovolaemia
o
Avoid indiscriminate pressor use (optimise causes of hypotension)
o
Normocapnoea
•
IVF:
o
Avoid hypervolaemia → interstitial oedema; goal directed fluid therapy
•
Maintain O2 delivery:
o
Hb, HcT 30 – 35%
o
SaO2
o
Normovolaemic haemodilution
•
Prevent thrombosis: s/c heparin
•
Long surgery: warm +
o
Monitoring: art line, temp, IDC + UO
o
Positioning: eyes, nerves, pressure areas
o
Consider wake up
o
Multi-modal analgesia
•
Extubation: avoid straining
Post-op:
•
Adequate analgesia: SNS, flap perfusion
•
Keep warm
•
Appropriately skilled location + monitor flap
o
Arterial failure: cool, pale, slow cap refill, no bleed on pin prick, loss of doppler
o
Venous failure: warm, congested, blue, brisk cap refill, rapid bleeding, loss of venous doppler
o
→ surgical management

title: Trauma and Resus
text:
Trauma and Resus
Criteria:
•
Mechanism of injury:
o
MVA >55km/hr
o
MBA >30km/hr
o
Cyclist >30km/hr
o
Pedestrian v vehicle >30km/hr
o
Child v vehicle at any speed
o
Fall >3m
o
Crush / entrapment
o
Ejection from vehicle
o
Penetrating injury
o
Burns ≥10% BSA
o
Inhalational or facial burns
o
Traumatic asphyxiation
o
Death in some vehicle / collision
•
Vital signs:
o
Airway compromise
o
RR <10 or >30
o
SpO2 <90%
o
sBP <90
o
HR <50 or >120
o
GCS <14
o
Seizure
o
Pupils dilated or non-reactive
o
Shock index i.e. HR / sBP = >0.9
•
Other:
o
Pregnant
o
Age >65
o
SCI
o
≥2 long bone fractures
Preparation:
•
Team: assemble team + brief if info known
•
Roles: assign - including team leader
•
Equipment
•
Drugs
•
Alert: OT, radiology, blood bank, surgeons, anaesthetics, ICU
•
Plan: airway, access, drug
•
PPE
•
Receive handover (prior unless impending airway issue or catastrophic haemorrhage)
Injury severity score - 6 regions – scored 0-6:
•
Head & neck
•
Face
•
Chest
•
Abdomen
•
Extremity + pelvis
•
External
Score 0 – 75 based on three most injured regions → A2 + B2 + C2
If any injury is unsurvivable score is 75/75 – futility in further medical care
PRIMARY SURVEY 6 killers – ATOM-FC
•
Airway obstruction or disruption
•
Tension pneumothorax
•
Open pneumothorax
•
Massive haemothorax
•
Flail chest
•
Cardiac tamponade

title: Damage Control Resuscitation
text:
Damage Control Resuscitation
Goals:
•
Rapid control of haemorrhage (pressure, tourniquet, haemostatic agents)
o
TXA 1g over 10 mins then 1g over 8 hours if within 3 hours of injury
o
Pelvic binder over greater trochanters
o
REBOA in extreme circumstances
o
Factor VIIa only if all other haemostatic interventions fail
•
Permissive hypotension (vital organ perfusion)
o
sBP 80-90, MAP 50-60+ restrictive volume until bleeding controlled
o
eFAST to exclude other fatal causes of hypotension: ATOM-FC
•
Prevention of coagulopathy
o
Acute traumatic coagulopathy:
▪
Early acute hyperfibrinolysis + hypocoaguable state
o
Resuscitation-associated / dilutional coagulopathy:
▪
Restrictive crystalloid
▪
Hb 70-90
▪
1:1:1 transfusion (PROPPR - mortality from bleeding at 24hr) or ROTEM guided
▪
Warm T >35
▪
Correct acidosis pH >7.2, lactate >4, BE <-6
▪
iCa >1.1, fibrinogen >2, INR <1.5
o
Trauma induced coagulopathy: activated protein C → DIC + hyperfibrinolysis
▪
Hyperfibrinolysis
▪
Consumption of clotting factors
▪
Platelet dysfunction
▪
Hypocalcaemia
+ other:
•
A/B:
o
MILS, assume C-spine injury
o
LPV
•
C: as above+
o
Wide bore access +/- sheath + art line + CVC
▪
Blood warmer + rapid infuser + cell saver
▪
Bair hugger + warm theatre
o
Pressor only if life-threatening hypotension
o
ROTEM

title: Damage Control Surgery
text:
Damage Control Surgery
Goals:
•
Haemostasis
•
Limit contamination
•
Operating time <90mins
•
Delay definitive repair until stabilised
Damage control surgery:
•
Surgeons scrubbed – prep and drape
•
Prepare - midline laparotomy may release tamponade
•
4 quadrant packing + exploration + bleeding control (resection, packing, ligation / shunting)
•
Control contamination
o
Seal / resect perforated hollow viscera
o
Avoid / delay re-anastomosis if risk of dehiscence whilst unstable
•
Temporary abdominal closure i.e. VAC
+/-
•
Thoracotomy
•
Decompressive craniectomy / evacuation of haematoma
•
Extremity: splinting, traction or ex-fix, fasciotomy of ischaemic limb
TBI:
•
BP targets:
o
sBP >100mmHg (50-69yo)
o
sBP >110mmHg (<50yo or ≥70yo)
•
Hb >90
•
Platelet >100
•
TBI-induced coagulopathy: thromboplastin
release → widespread clotting activation →
rapid depletion of fibrinogen
Harmful effects of crystalloid in bleeding trauma patient:
•
Haemodilution / dilutional coagulopathy
•
Blood loss under pressure through lacerated
vessel / dislodges formed clot
•
Tissue oedema →
o
Tissue hypoxia (+/- worsening acidosis)
o
Abdominal compartment syndrome
o
Cerebral oedema (disrupted BBB)

title: Trauma Induced Coagulopathy
text:
Trauma Induced Coagulopathy
Description: multifactorial biochemical response to tissue injury and shock mediated by →
•
Dysregulated coagulation
•
Altered fibrinolysis
•
Systemic endothelial activation
•
Inflammatory response to injury
•
Platelet dysfunction
Established within minutes of injury
RFs:
•
Hypotension
•
Hypoperfusion
•
High injury severity score
•
Metabolic acidosis
•
TBI
Worsened by resuscitation associated / dilutional coagulopathy
Mechanism:
•
activated protein C → FVa, FVIIIa, plasminogen inhibitors → hyperfibrinolysis
•
Endothelial dysfunction + glycocalyx disruption → endogenous heparinoids + activation of protein C
•
Platelet dysfunction
•
Consumption of clotting factors
•
Dilutional coagulopathy
•
Hypocalcaemia
Diagnosis:
•
Standard coags: PT >18s, INR >1.5, aPTT >60, fibrinogen <2.0, plt, D-dimer
•
POC:
o
Fibtem A5 <10mm
o
Extem:
▪
ML: ≥5%
▪
A5: <35mm
▪
CT: >90s

title: eFAST
text:
eFAST
Evidence: sensitivity 80%, specificity 99%
Benefits:
•
Fast (3 – 4 mins)
•
Bedside in ED
•
Non-ionising
•
time to operation (every 3 min delay to OT for damage control laparotomy → mortality by 1%)
Indications:
•
Haemodynamically unstable (stable patient should have CT)
•
Assess for pneumothorax
Limitations:
•
Does not identify or grade solid organ injury
•
Does not identify retroperitoneal bleed
•
Cannot detect <400mL fluid
Procedure:
•
US probes:
o
Curvilinear 3-5Hz for abdomen
o
Phased array 3-4.5Hz for chest
Location
Assessing
Probe Placement
Probe Image
US Image
RUQ
Morrison’s
pouch
Ant - mid axillary line longitudinal
7-8th IC space
LUQ
Perispleen
Left posterior axillary line
7-8th IC space
Pelvis
Pouch of
Douglas
Above pubic symphysis
Cardiac
Pericardium
Subcostal / parasternal long axis
4-5th IC space L sternum
Lung
PTx
Apices to assess for lung sliding

title: Haemorrhagic Shock
text:
Haemorrhagic Shock
Remember possible other kinds of shock
MTP definitions:
•
Adults:
o
Replacement of >50% blood volume (≥ 10 pRBCs) in 4 hours OR
o
Replacement of >1x blood volume in 24 hours (70mL/kg)
•
Children
o
Transfusion of >40mL/kg (*paediatric blood volume 80mL/kg, or 90mL/kg in neonates)
MTP trigger is institution dependent, may include:
•
Gestalt (senior clinician)
•
Pre-hospital vitals: HR >120, BP <90, GCS <8, penetrating injury
•
Unstable pelvic #
•
+ve FAST scan in ED
Must remember to terminate MTP, reasons may include:
•
Control
•
Targets met (clinical, biochemical)
•
Futility
•
Agreement

title: Pelvic Fracture
text:
Pelvic Fracture
Mortality 5 – 15%. Bleeding usually from pre-sacral venous plexus (pelvic cavity + retroperitoneal space)
Young and Burgess classification:
•
Anteroposterior compression
•
Lateral compression
•
Vertical sheer
Management:
•
Assume other injuries including C-spine
•
Pelvic binder over greater trochanters – remove <24hr when stable / corrected coagulopathy
•
Traction if vertical displacement
•
Avoid log rolls
•
Stability
o
Stable → CT
o
Unstable → eFAST to exclude other life-threatening causes (ATOM-FC)
Treatment:
•
IR embolisation
•
Laparotomy + pelvic binding (may require diverting colostomy)
•
Surgical stabilisation
•
Surgical fixation
Note: bleeding usually from presacral venous plexus – can be catastrophic as pelvic cavity + retroperitoneal space can
accommodate an entire blood volume before any tamponade effect
Anaesthesia for surgical fixation:
•
Pre-op:
o
Injuries ?C spine and need for MILS
o
Hb, coagulation + G&H
o
D/w urology if IDC CI
•
Intra-op:
o
Haemorrhage management +
▪
RIC / sheath + level 1 tubing + Belmont
▪
Cell saver
▪
TXA if not already given
o
Careful positioning
•
Post-op:
o
DVT prophylaxis
o
Multimodal analgesia

title: REBOA
text:
REBOA
subdiaphragmatic haemorrhage whilst proximal perfusion
No high grade evidence for REBOA over manual aortic occlusion via thoracotomy
Zones – descending aorta:
•
Zone 1: left subclavian artery to coeliac artery - subdiaphragmatic bleeding, coronary perfusion
•
Zone 2: coeliac artery to lowest renal artery – never inflated here
•
Zone 3: lowest renal artery to aortic bifurcation - pelvic bleeding
Decision tree →
Stages following insertion:
•
C-REBOA (complete): inflate until proximal
improvement in BP + distal flat line – restricted to
20mins (transducers either side of balloon)
o
>45 mins is fatal → spinal cord + abdominal
ischaemia
•
P-REBOA: balloon deflation until distal pulsatility +
distal MAP is 10mmHg greater than C-REBOA
Peri-op management:
•
Ideally induce after balloon inflated
•
Permissive hypotension before haemostasis
•
Ketamine 0.5-1mg/kg + roc 1mg/kg – if peri-arrest less
ketamine
•
MAC 0.3-0.5 when appropriate
•
Ensure transducers flushed regularly
•
Prepare for reperfusion (vasoplegia, arrhythmias)
•
Surgical closure of insertion site +/- thrombectomy (commonly needed)

title: Blunt Neck Trauma
text:
Blunt Neck Trauma
Risk of SCI. Immobilise.
Red flags:
•
SSx: stridor, dysphonia, dyspnoea, dysphagia, odynophagia
•
Exam: resp distress, ecchymosis on neck, surgical emphysema, tracheal deviation, haemoptysis, expanding haematoma
Blind ETT dangerous: risk of false passage, worsening bleeding
Airway:
•
Cooperative: AFOI or surgical trache under LA (avoid HFNP >30L flow)
•
Uncooperative: mRSI without cricoid + VL + oral FB
Inflate cuff beyond injury

title: Penetrating Neck Trauma
text:
Penetrating Neck Trauma
Deep to platysma. SCI uncommon cf blunt trauma. Routine immobilisation not recommended.
Anatomical zones:
•
Zone 1: clavicle to cricoid (highest mortality)
•
Zone 2: cricoid to angle of mandible
•
Zone 3: angle of mandible to skull base
Signs:
•
Vascular trauma: haemorrhage, expanding neck haematoma, hypovolaemic shock
•
Aerodigestive tract trauma: airway compromise, subcut emphysema, bubbling / sucking around wound, haemoptysis
Goals:
•
Determine urgency of secure airway – if intubated place cuffed tube in lumen distal to injury
•
Avoid exacerbating injury or tube migration
•
Avoid exacerbation of subcut emphysema
If possible only remove penetrating foreign body in theatre
Option
Considerations
Airway Options
Crack On
Indications:
•
In extremis
•
Severe hypoxaemia
•
Airway obstruction
•
Decreased LOC
•
Shock
•
Cardiac arrest
•
Expected rapid deterioration i.e. stridor, respiratory
distress, subcut emphysema, expanding neck
haematoma/swelling, inability to lie flat
•
RSI (VL + FB – 2 person technique w/ MILS, avoid
cricoid / HFNP, use nasal cannulae at 15L/min)
•
FONA double set up
•
Immediate FONA
•
Intubation through neck wound into trachea
AWAKE + SPONT VENT IS IMPRACTICAL
Stay and
Play
Risk of transfer > advantage of transfer
Time to:
•
Gather equipment + personnel
•
Ix: nasendoscopy, bedside XR, airway US
•
No evidence of rapid deterioration
•
Other injuries: haemorrhage, TBI, smoke/thermal
inhalation
Compliance:
•
Compliant: awake (VL or FONA with LA)
•
Non-compliant: spont vent (FB, VL, FONA) or RSI (VL +/-
FB assisted)
Head for
Home
Stable enough for transfer to OT
Time for comprehensive assessment including CT,
nasendoscopy, CXR, airway US
Compliance:
•
Compliant: as above – +/-remifentanil assisted
•
Non-compliant: as above
Failure plan for all is eFONA
Conservative management:
•
Observed critical care location
•
Humidified inspiratory gases
•
Q2 – 4 hourly neb saline, PPI
•
Daily nasendoscopy

title: Thoracic Trauma
text:
Thoracic Trauma
Assess for immediately life-threatening injuries of chest can also use ATOM-FC:
•
Aortic injury
•
Thorax (hemothorax, pneumothorax)
•
Oesphageal perforation
•
Muscle - diaphragmatic injury
•
Fistula (bronchopleural) and other tracheobronchial injury
•
Contusion / cardiac tamponade
Blunt Thoracic Trauma
Blunt Aortic Trauma
80% die at scene.
Mechanism: rapid deceleration / collision
Ix:
•
CXR: widened mediastinum, obscured aortic tubercle, left apical cap, L haemothorax, R deviation NGT, R tracheal
deviation, R mainstem bronchus deviated down, wide left paravertebral stripe
•
CT scan if stable
Management:
•
Minor aortic injury: <1cm intimal abnormality, localised intramural haematoma, no external contour deformity
→ conservative management
•
Significant aortic injury: active bleeding, full thickness rupture, pseudoaneurysm
→ urgent repair
Grading:
•
Type 1: intimal tear
conservative, anti-impulse therapy
•
Type 2: intramural haematoma
→ surgical repair (emergent or delayed)
•
Type 3: pseudoaneurysm
→ surgical repair (emergent or delayed)
•
Type 4: rupture
→ surgical repair (urgent)
Surgical repair can be endovascular or open
Management:
•
ABCs
•
2x large bore access + arterial line + CVC
•
Blood pressure: anti-impulse therapy – lower targets – see vascular notes
o
Target: sBP <100mmHg, HR <100bpm
•
NOTE: REBOA is CI
•
Immediate surgical repair if haemodynamically unstable
Blunt Cardiac Trauma
RFs: anterior chest pain, sternal fracture, cardiac symptoms / signs, major mechanism
Types of injury: myocardial rupture, septal / valvular injury, MI, myocardial contusion, arrhythmia
Ix:
•
Troponin
•
ECG: usually RBBB (RV closest to sternum – LBBB rare) +/- arrhythmia including ectopy, ST changes
•
TTE: RWMAs, valve function, tamponade
Management:
•
If ECG and troponin changes – admit and monitor with telemetry for 48 hours
•
Tamponade: pericardiocentesis, thoracotomy
•
Valve / septal injury: CTSx review
cMRI adds little if TTE already performed

title: Penetrating Thoracic Trauma
text:
Blunt Pulmonary Trauma
Assess for:
•
Pneumothorax
•
Haemothorax
