•
Pulmonary contusion: irregular, non-lobular opacification or radiology (analgesia, chest PTx, may need vent support)
o
Can be very serious
•
Tracheobronchial injury
•
Diaphragmatic rupture
•
Oesophageal rupture
•
Chest wall injury: sternal, thoracic spine, scapular, rib, flail chest, sternoclavicular dislocation, clavicle
Penetrating Thoracic Trauma
Location:
•
Chest wall:
o
Intercostal artery / vein injury
o
Rib fractures
•
Lung:
o
Pneumothorax / haemothorax
o
Pulmonary contusion / laceration
•
Heart:
o
Tamponade
o
Myocardial rupture
o
Great vessel injury
•
Tracheobronchial injury
•
Oesophageal injury
•
Diaphragmatic injury

title: Chest Drain Insertion
text:
Needle Thoracostomy
Indication: haemodynamically unstable tension pneumothorax
Location:
•
2nd intercostal space mid-clavicular line
•
5th intercostal space mid-axillary line
Procedure:
•
Skin prep
•
Standard or long 14-16G cannula
•
10mL syringe with several mL of normal saline
•
Insert over superior border of 3rd rib
•
Aspirate until air bubbles in syringe
•
Disconnect syringe → whoosh of air
•
Proceed to intercostal catheter insertion
Chest Drain Insertion
Indications:
•
Pneumothorax
•
Haemothorax
•
Pleural effusion / empyema
•
Pleurodesis
28 – 32Fr used in trauma
CI: coagulopathy, localised skin infection
Procedure:
•
IV antibiotics, LA, skin prep + drape
•
5th intercostal space mid-axillary line
•
Techniques:
o
Blunt dissection:
▪
2-3cm incision parallel to intercostal space
▪
Blunt dissect to rib with curved clamp
▪
Blunt dissect over rib through parietal pleura
▪
Open clamp to spread muscle / pleura
▪
Insert finger into pleural space
▪
Clamp tube at insertion end and insert into space (direct apically or basally)
▪
Unclamp
▪
Advance until >2cm in cavity
▪
Connect to collection system / underwater seal
▪
Suture + CXR to confirm position
o
Seldinger:
▪
Introducer needle – aspirating for air / blood
▪
Guidewire
▪
Sequential dilators
▪
Tube
▪
Remove guidewire
▪
Suture
▪
CXR

title: Resuscitative Thoracotomy
text:
Resuscitative Thoracotomy
Definition: anterolateral chest incision to control exsanguinating haemorrhage or other life-threatening chest injuries
Indications:
•
Penetrating thoracic trauma with haemodynamic instability
•
Blunt thoracic trauma with cardiac tamponade
•
Penetrating abdominal injury with exsanguinating haemorrhage
•
Appropriate resources for continued resuscitation and repair available (4Es)
•
After arrest:
o
Penetrating: <15 minutes
o
Blunt: <10 minutes
Contraindications:
•
No signs of life at scene
•
Asystole without pericardial tamponade
•
Prolonged arrest >15 minutes
•
Non-survivable injury
Goals:
•
Relief of cardiac tamponade → pericardotomy
•
Control of haemorrhage → aortic XC
•
Open cardiac massage
Usually thoracostomy performed first
Technique:
•
Lung isolation (endobronchial, DLT, bronchial blocker)
•
Skin prep/drape
•
Left anterolateral → ventilation of left lung
•
Extend thoracostomy incision transverse, enter pleural cavity
•
Insert rib spreader (handle in axilla – do not block access to clamshell)
•
Artery forceps to pick up pericardium → incise to make window to relieve tamponade and access heart (cephalad to
caudal incision to avoid transection/injury to left phrenic nerve traversing pericardium)
•
Delivery heart from pericardium to inspect for injuries
•
Insert hand along posterior aspect of left pleural cavity until you find the descending aorta → manual occlusion
(afterload → perfusion to coronaries and brain)
•
Open cardiac massage
•
Internal defib if indicated
•
Extend thoracotomy to
clamshell if potential pathology
is in contralateral cavity, may
need Gigli saw to bisect
sternum
•
→ OT for definitive repair
4Es:
•
Expertise
•
Equipment
•
Environment
•
Elapsed time
Survival:
•
Penetrating cardiac 35%
•
Penetrating chest 15%
•
Blunt chest 2%

title: Traumatic Cardiac Arrest
text:
Traumatic Cardiac Arrest
Likely one of:
•
Haemorrhage
•
Oxygenation
•
Tension
•
Tamponade
Management: defer CPR and defibrillation
•
First priority – stop bleeding
•
A: secure ETT
•
Bilateral thoracostomies on spec
•
US ?tamponade
•
Emergency thoracotomy → within 10 mins of arrest (more clearly defined role in penetrating trauma cf blunt trauma
where mortality 8x higher from thoracotomy)
After ROSC:
•
Clamp RIMA /
LIMA
•
Caution adr
administration
•
Treat K+ and
acidosis
•
Debrief

title: Rib Fractures
text:
Rib Fractures
Risk:
•
5 rib fractures: mortality 10%
•
8 rib fractures: mortality 34%
•
1st rib fracture: marker of severe chest trauma because protected by clavicle
o
10% aortic transection
o
2% bronchial tear
Complications: atelectasis, pneumonia / contusion, ARDS, PE, pneumothorax, haemothorax, altered lung mechanics, pain
Flail chest:
•
Radiological: 3 contiguous rib # in ≥2 places
•
Clinically: paradoxical chest wall movement during spontaneous ventilation
•
Mortality 35%
•
May need surgical fixation (only indicated in flail chest requiring mechanical ventilation – but not prolonged ventilation)
Risk factors:
•
Injury factors:
o
Rib # as above
o
Bilateral fractures
o
Flail segment, sternal #, scapula #,
o
Pulmonary contusion
•
Patient factors:
o
Age ≥65
o
Frail
o
CCF
o
Respiratory disease
o
Diabetes
•
Clinical factors:
o
PaCO2 >45
o
PaO2 <60
Analgesia in pain notes

title: Acute Spinal Cord Injury
text:
Acute Spinal Cord Injury
30% also have non-spinal injuries
Immobilisation: cervical collar, spinal board, log rolls
Avoid secondary injury: avoid hypoxia, hypotension, hypercapnia, hyperthermia - no evidence for steroids or hypothermia
Airway:
•
Always assume unstable C-spine
•
Intubation indications: hypoxia, reduced GCS, C3-C5 injury
•
Technique: MILS, RSI (sux contra-indicated 48hrs – 6mo), VL or fibreoptic
o
Jaw thrust okay, avoid chin lift and head tilt
•
Beware:
o
Associated maxfax trauma +/- blood / vomit in airway
o
Cricoid pressure
o
Bradycardia with laryngoscopy (give atropine on induction)
Breathing:
•
Avoid hypoxia → secondary injury
•
High injury – ventilation improved in supine position as diaphragm breathing improved
Cardiovascular: aim MAP >85mmHg for 7 days post-injury
•
Neurogenic shock:
o
Bradycardia: atropine, pacing
o
Hypotension: vasopressors
o
Avoid excessive IVF: minimise ARDS, spinal cord oedema – goal directed therapy
•
Haemorrhagic shock / tamponade / PTx may coexist
•
Invasive monitoring
•
Insert IDC to monitor UO and aid overdistension
Examination: look for diaphragmatic breathing, hypotension / bradycardia, priapism, flaccid areflexia, loss of pain below a level
Investigations: normal + trauma + early MRI

title: C-Spine Clearance
text:
C-Spine Clearance
Decision tools not applicable if: paediatric, direct blow to neck, penetrating neck trauma, reduced GCS, age >60
NEXUS low risk criteria: “NSAID” (NPV 99%) – applicable >1yo
•
N
Normal neurology
•
S
No spinal midline tenderness
•
A
Alert, age <60yo
•
I
Not intoxicated
•
D
No distracting injury
Canadian C-Spine Rules (99.4% sensitive)
1. Image if:
a. >65yo
b. Dangerous mechanism
i. Fall >1m
ii. Axial load to head
iii. MVA >100km/hour
iv. Motorised recreational vehicle accident
v. Ejection
vi. Bicycle crash
c.
Parasthesia in extremities
2. Assess for low risk features:
a. Simple rear end MVA
b. Sitting in ED
c.
Ambulatory at any time
d. Delayed onset neck pain
e. Absent midline cervical tenderness
3. Able to rotate neck 45 degrees to each side
Does not meet low risk criteria → IMAGE
Approach to C spine XRAY: lateral
•
Demographics
•
Obvious injuries
•
A: alignment of 3 vertebral columns
•
B: bones outlines
o
Should be able to count out all C vertebrae
•
C: cartilage – spacing between bones
•
Soft tissue

title: Envenomation
text:
Envenomation
Snakes
Lethal: taipan, brown, tiger, death adder, black, rough scaled, sea snakes
Issues:
•
Thrombotic microangiography
•
Myotoxicity
•
Systemic symptoms including neurotoxic paralysis: headache, diaphoresis, respiratory distress, LOC
•
Venom-induced consumptive coagulopathy
Management:
•
First aid:
o
Broad pressure bandage (prevent lymphatic spread not blood – start at bite)
o
Immobilise joints either side
o
Immobilise patient (lay)
o
Do not remove until at centre with full facilities and after anti-venom – do not wash or clean in case venom
detection kit required (can clear afterwards)
•
Resuscitation:
o
ABC
o
2x pIVCs + take bloods (FBC, EUC, coags, fibrinogen, CK – will need serial)
o
Systemic effects:
▪
Cardiovascular collapse
▪
DIC
▪
Nerve paralysis → respiratory failure
▪
Rhabdomyolysis
▪
Haemolysis / MAHA
•
Prepare for anaphylactic reaction, give antivenom (in consultation with clinical toxicologist)
o
Dilute in normal saline – give over 15 mins
o
If cardiac arrest give antivenom as push – it is not weight-based, same dose for all
o
If child critically unwell retrieval team should bring to regional location for treatment prior to transfer
•
Observe and further resuscitate
•
Venom-induced coagulopathy: not aided by more antivenom – takes 10-20 hours to improve, up to 30 hours for full
resolution, role of FFP and cryo is controversial – generally only indicated if bleeding
*If anaphylaxis occurs there is high risk of ICH with adrenaline + coagulopathy – consider titrated adrenaline infusion
Spiders
Lethal: funnel web, red back
First aid:
•
Funnel web: pressure and immobilise
•
Other spiders: ice/cold compress
Jellyfish
Lethal:
•
Box: respiratory and cardiac arrest
•
Irukandji syndrome
First aid:
•
Vinegar
•
Antivenom for box jellyfish
Blue-ring jellyfish and cone shell:
•
Pressure immobilisation (risk of respiratory failure)

title: Drowning
text:
Drowning
Respiratory impairment due to submission / immersion in liquid
RFs: age (toddler or adolescent), male, aquatic occupation, aquatic exposure, alcohol / drugs, medical comorbidity, trauma,
assault, hypothermia
Sequence of events: water enters mouth → next conscious response is to hold breath (~1min) until respiratory drive too high to
resist → water aspirated into airways → coughing reflex +/- laryngospasm → hypoxaemia → LOC and apnoea
Final mode of death: tachycardia → bradycardia → PEA → asystole
Pathophysiology
•
Respiratory:
o
Laryngospasm → hypercarbia, hypoxia, acidosis (breaks due to hypoxia)
o
Pulmonary aspiration – recovery position if spont venting
o
ALI: pulmonary oedema, bronchospasm, acute emphysema +/- inhaled toxins e.g. chlorine
o
V:Q mismatch
o
compliance
o
Respiratory infection (freshwater > sea water)
•
Metabolic:
o
Hypothermia
o
Lactic acidosis
•
CVS:
o
Diving reflex: triggered by cold water on face (via trigeminal n.) → apnoea, bradycardia, vasoconstriction
o
Catecholamine surge: → vasoconstriction, arrhythmia, cardiac failure
o
VF common <28 degrees
•
CNS:
o
Cerebral global hypoxia → oedema
•
Haem:
o
Haemolysis
o
DIC
Management:
•
First aid:
o
Remove from water
o
Check for response (pulse, ventilation)
o
5 rescue breaths
o
CPR / ALS
o
Rhythm: usually PEA
•
Hospital:
o
ABCs + C spine precautions
o
Rewarming to 32-34 degrees (therapeutic hypothermia) for 24 hours
▪
Passive:
•
Remove wet clothing
•
Insulating cover
▪
Active:
•
Forced air warmer
•
Radiant heater
•
Warmed IVF
•
Humidified inspiratory gases
•
Lavage
•
ECMO/bypass
o
Ventilation: lung protective, avoid permissive hypercapnoea due to CNS injury
•
Assess for:
o
Trauma
o
Underlying cause e.g. medical episode
Further management:
•
Neuro: neuroprotective measures, MAP 80
•
Renal: manage AKI +/- rhabdo
•
Infection: consider antibiotics if grossly submerged in contaminated water

title: Hypothermia
text:
Hypothermia
Definitions:
•
Mild
32 – 35
•
Mod
28 – 32
•
Severe <28
Mortality of mod-severe is 40%
Causes: exposure, drowning, therapeutic hypothermia, disease (infection, hypoglycaemia, adrenal
insufficiency, hypothyroidism, overdose)
Iatrogenic: deep hypothermic cardiac arrest
Ix:
•
Routine bloods + TFTs + toxicology + CK + lipase + cortisol
•
ECG: J wave
System
Mild
Mod
Severe
CNS
Confusion, slurred speech
Impaired judgement
Amnesia
Paradoxical undressing
Lethargy, hallucinations
Loss of pupils reflexes
EEG changes
reflexes
Loss of CVS regulation
Coma
Loss of ocular reflexes
CVS
Tachycardia + SVR → CO
Bradycardia
CO, SVR
Arrhhythmias, J waves
Prolonged intervals
CO, SVR
VF
Asystole
RESP
Tachypnoea, bronchorrhoea
MV, O2 consumption
CO2 production
Loss of cough reflex
Apnoea
Pulmonary oedema
Renal
Cold diuresis
Cold diuresis
Oliguria
renal blood flow
GIT
Ileus
Pancreatitis
Stress ulcers
Hepatic dysfunction
MSK
Shivering
shivering
Muscle rigidity
“Pseudo rigor mortis”
Metabolic
metabolic rate
Hyperglycaemia
metabolic rate
HAEM
Hct, plt, WCC
DIC
Bleeding despite normal coag studies
Management:
Avoid jostling / moving → may precipitate AF
•
A/B:
Intubation
•
C:
CPR (may be prolonged)
Warmed IV crystalloid + pressors + inotropes
Severe hypothermia – CPR may be delayed / intermittent to facilitate rescue
•
D:
Measure core temp (oesophageal, rectal, bladder)
Rewarming:
Passive external: remove wet clothes, insulated blanket
Active external: forced air warmer
Active internal: warm fluids, warm humidified O2, pleural / peritoneal lavage, endovascular warmer
ECMO / CPB
Complications:
•
Core temperature after drop: fall in core T when peripheries are warmed (beware hypotension, acidosis, VF)
•
Burns from rewarming
•
Takatsubos
•
Electrolyte abnormalities
•
Rhabdo
•
Cardiac arrhythmias: refractory until patient warmed
•
Frostbite

title: Crush Injury
text:
Crush Injury
Major issues:
•
Prolonged ischaemic + muscular damage → rhabdo + reperfusion injury on release
•
Limb damage (often numb + peripheral pulse) → rapid swelling with compartment syndrome
Field management:
•
Full monitoring
•
1L crystalloid prior to extrication
•
500mL crystalloid alternating with 500mL 5% dextrose per hour
Hospital management:
•
Myoglobinuric renal failure:
o
Bicarb as indicated to maintain urinary pH >6.5 if rhabdo + induce polyuria
o
If urinary pH >7.45 give acetazolamide
o
Continue until urine is myoglobin-free
•
Limb care:
o
Splinting:
▪
Splint in functional position
▪
Active & passive movement as pain allows
▪
Contractures and paralysis dealt with late reconstructive surgery
o
Compartment syndrome / fasciotomies (see below)
o
Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: no large scale studies of use in crush injury but listed for approved use
▪
Can be used during impending compartment syndrome (before established)
▪
3x treatments at 2.5atm for 90-120mins
▪
Should never delay fasciotomy in established CS
▪
Use post-fasciotomy: useful for ischaemic muscle, unclear demarcation of viable muscle, massive
swelling, ischaemia >6hr, vascular compromise of flap/graft, and residual neuropathy

title: Compartment Syndrome
text:
Compartment Syndrome
pressure within a closed compartment and compromises circulation
Compartments:
•
Osseofascial (foot, hand)
•
Cranium
•
Eye
•
Spine
•
Abdomen
•
Chest
•
Pericardium
Pathophysiology: in tissue volume with externally applied pressure
Causes:
•
Trauma: fracture, crush, burns
•
Vascular: ischaemia, reperfusion, haemorrhage
•
Iatrogenic: tourniquet, cast, extravasation, prolonged Lloyd-Davis / trendelenberg
Compartments:
•
Thigh:
o
Anterior: femoral + saphenous n.
o
Posterior: sciatic n.
o
Medial: obturator n.
•
Leg
o
Anterior: deep peroneal n.
o
Lateral: superficial peroneal n.
o
Deep posterior: tibial n.
o
Superficial posterior: no nerves
•
Arm:
o
Anterior: ulnar and median n.
o
Posterior: radial n.
•
Forearm:
o
Anterior (deep & superficial): ulnar and median n.
o
Posterior: radial n.
Presentation:
•
Pain out of proportion, worse with passive muscle stretch
•
Paraesthesia
•
Weakness / paralysis
•
Swelling
•
Pallor
•
Pulselessness
Diagnosis:
•
Clinical
•
Compartment pressure
o
Normal <12 – 15mmHg
o
Fasciotomy if dBP – CP = <30mmHg
Treatment:
•
Release external pressure
•
Keep at level of the heart
•
Maintain BP
•
Fasciotomy and debridement
•
Treat underlying cause
•
Treat complications e.g. rhabdomyolysis
5 Ps:
•
Pain
•
Paresis
•
Pulselessness
•
Pallor
•
Paraesthesia

title: Burns
text:
Burns
Burn
Description
Skin Layer
Description
Management
Superficial
Epidermis
only
Red, dry, no blisters
Not counted
in rule of 9s
Superficial
partial
thickness
Dermis
(Superficial)
Pink, blister
Painful
Heals
without
scarring
Deep
partial
thickness
Dermis (deep)
Lobster/cherry red
Cap refill +ve
Less painful
May need
grafting
Full
thickness
Entire
thickness of
dermis
Waxy, white, charred
Not painful
Needs
excision and
grafting
First aid:
•
Cool water 20 mins
•
Cling wrap
•
Warm
•
Remove contaminated clothing
•
Irrigate chemical burns: acid 45 minutes, alkali 60 minutes
Burns Management – Emergency Department / Pre-Transfer
•
MIST handover +
o
Time of burn (for IVF calculation)
o
Entrapment?
•
MDT management with critical care specialties: ED + second skilled anaesthetist +/- ICU
•
Remove burned clothing + jewellery
•
Monitoring: sats, ECG if possible, art line + CVC + temp probe + BIS (high risk awareness in ED)
•
2x long 16G IVC + ketamine 0.5mg/kg for severe pain
•
A/B:
o
>25% TBSA → SIRS response + high risk of airway oedema later → will require intubation
▪
Assess airway: usually minimal inflammation early
▪
20mL/kg crystalloid if hypotensive prior to induction
▪
Midazolam 0.1mg/kg, ketamine 1mg/kg + fentanyl 2mcg/kg + rocuronium 1.2mg/kg
▪
X-blade + stylet, ETT size 7/8 + difficult airway trolley
▪
Tape ETT + wire to teeth to avoid dislodgement
▪
Propofol + fentanyl infusion maintenance
▪
Treat bronchospasm: salbutamol, ketamine, magnesium
▪
LPV
•
C:
o
Avoid fluid creep: modified parkland: BSA% x 3mL x weight = crystalloid / 24hr
▪
50% 1st 8hr – this is from time of burn
▪
50% remaining 16hr
o
Additional titrated to UO 0.5mL/kg/hr
o
Low dose metaraminol infusion if required MAP >65
•
D/E:
o
ABG:
▪
CO poisoning: FiO2 100% until COHb <3%
▪
Cyanide toxicity: persistent lactataemia → hydroxycobalamin
o
Temperature: keep warm (fluid warmer, forced air, heating lights)
o
Circumferential assessment:
▪
Escharotomy of any full thickness circumferential burns (extend 1cm at sides)
▪
Elevate limbs
o
Tetanus injection
o
Gastric decompression
o
Send full bloods + monitor EUC for risk of rhabdo
o
Rule out other injuries: full examination + CXR
Indication for transfer to burns centre:
•
Dermal burns >10% BSA, full thickness
>5% BSA
o
All burns >5% in paeds
•
Face, arms, feet, perineum, over a joint
•
Circumferential
•
Inhalational or other
•
Electrical / chemical
•
Suspected NAI
BSA:
Palm + fingers 1% +
Rule of 9s:
•
Head 9%
•
Chest 18%
•
Back 18%
•
Arm 9%
•
Leg 18%
•
Perineum 1%

title: Burns Hospital
text:
Burns Hospital
Goal: remove full thickness burn and cover, save zone of sepsis
•
Partial burns: remove superficial portion, apply biobrane (silicone + porcine collagen) and monitor
•
Full thickness burns: early burn excision → necrotic load, infection risk, SIRS, blood loss, improved aesthetic and
functional outcomes
If very large full thickness burns delay grafting until off inotropes (grafts fail) – cover with BTM
Pre-op:
•
Volume status
•
Cardiac fx (early may have takastubos)
•
Do not fast if tubed, aspirate NGT
•
Exact plan from surgeons
Intra-op:
•
RSI if no NGT, avoid sux after 48 hours
•
Blood loss: previously 4% blood volume / 1% area excised – slightly reduced now with tumescent mixtures
o
Blood management bundle including rapid transfuser
o
+ limb tourniquets, compression bandages, topical adrenaline / thrombin
•
Temperature:
o
Warm +
o
Cool if >39.5: debulk dressings, ice to non-burned skin, bladder irrigation, cool IVF
•
Fluid management: balanced crystalloid +/- albumin
o
UO: 0.5 – 1mL/kg/hr
o
Lactate
o
Hct
o
CO monitoring
•
Multimodal analgesia
Post-op:
•
Nutrition: early enteral
o
Dietician for caloric requirements: 55% glucose, 30% lipids, protein 2g/kg/day + micronutrients
•
Itch: PO antihistamine, gabapentin, laser therapy, pressure garments
•
Extubation:
o
Cuff leak
o
Consider AEC
Complications:
•
Immune: infections, toxic shock
•
CVS: IHD, CCF, CVA, myocardial fibrosis, ET
•
GIT: diabetes, GI disease
•
MSK: fractures, mobility
•
CNS: seizures, migraines
Other: death, cancer risk, PTSD / anxiety / depression, chronic pain, pruritis

title: Burns Hospital
text:
System
Early <48hr
“Burn shock”
Late 48hr – 1 year
Hypermetabolic
CVS
•
HR, SVR (vasoconstriction), Hct
•
SV, CO, SvO2
•
HR, CO, SvO2
•
SVR
•
Subclinical myocardial dysfunction
•
Hyperdynamic circulation
Resp
•
PVR
•
Bronchospasm, APO / ARDS
•
mucociliary clearance →
•
Ventilation
•
Bronchospasm, APO / ARDS
•
Pneumonia
Endo
•
cortisol, RAAS, catecholamines
•
cortisol, RAAS, catecholamines
•
glucagon, insulin → hyperglycaemia
•
Muscle catabolism, lipolysis
GIT
•
Ileus
•
GI stress +/- ulceration
•
Hypoalbuminaemia
•
Gluconeogenesis
•
hepatic blood flow
•
Fatty liver
•
Altered drug metabolism
Renal
•
Oliguria +/- AKI
•
Myoglobinuria
•
urinary Na excretion
•
GFR
•
tubular function
Haem
•
Generalised oedema
•
Hct
•
Coagulation factors
•
Haematopoiesis, anaemia
•
Immunosuppression
Other
•
Hypothermia
•
VO2
•
Hyperthermia
•
Weight loss
•
Impaired wound healing
Pharm
•
albumin, AAG
•
Vd
•
CO
•
hepatic / renal clearance
•
Sux CI (although first case report of hyperK 9
days)
•
hepatic / renal clearance
•
Phase 1 reactions
•
dose non-depolarising muscle relaxants
•
propofol, opioid requirements
•
catecholamine sensitivity

title: Burns Analgesia
text:
Burns Analgesia
Type of pain/discomfort:
•
Background
•
Breakthrough
•
Procedural
•
Neuropathic
•
Hyperalgesia / allodynia
•
Itch
Treatment:
•
Non-pharmacological:
o
Dressings: draft + contact pain
▪
Biosynthetic dressings time to healing and pain during dressings changes (L1)
▪
VR distraction, augmented reality techniques and multimodal distraction methods pain and
unpleasantness during burns dressings (L1)
o
Positioning
o
Cutaneous stimulation
o
Acupuncture
o
CBT
o
Hypnosis / virtual reality (L1)
o
Distraction
•
Pharmacological:
o
Regular paracetamol
o
Opioids: infusion or PCA (avoid IM/subcut due to poor absorption)
o
Ketamine / precede / benzos
Opioid tolerance → rotate, or use opioid sparing techniques
Neuropathic pain:
•
Pregabalin (level 2 evidence), gabapentin (level 3 evidence)
•
Ketamine
Procedural pain:
•
Opioids
•
Ketamine
•
Precedex (poor evidence)
•
N2O / methoxyflurane
•
Biosynthetic dressings
•
Topical agents e.g. lignocaine spray
No evidence for IV lignocaine
Procedural anxiolysis:
•
Propofol
•
Benzos – lorazepam
Itch:
•
1st line: citrizine, cimetidine, gabapentin
•
2nd line: loratadine

title: Electrocution
text:
Electrocution
Entry + exit point
Electrical injury:
•
Tissue with greatest resistance will heat the most I.e. bone, and adjacent deep muscle will cook leading to rhabdo and
compartment syndromes will consequences of both (I.e. renal failure, hyperK, fasciotomies +/- limb loss)
•
If involves the heart - might have reduced function in setting of normal ECG and no trop rise
o
Consider doing a TTE and delay surgery if able until cardiac function improves (usually 48 hours)
Degree of electrocution:
•
0.1mA – to myocardium = VF
•
1000A – severe burn, loss of limb (high tension injury)
•
>12,000A – lightning (coma, severe burns, loss of limb)
Management:
•
ECG
•
TTE
•
CT of extremities
•
CK levels
•
Urinary myoglobin
•
Opthalmic examination (if indicated)
•
Monitor for compartment syndrome
Specific management:
•
Intubation if airway burns
•
Debridement and amputation of damaged muscle
•
Fasciotomy of limbs
•
Vigorous fluid resuscitation + management of rhabdo + acid-base balance
•
Malignant cardiac rhythm: defib indicated
•
Tetanus shot
Supportive management:
•
FAST HUGS

title: Altitude Sickness
text:
Altitude Sickness
Partial pressure of O2:
•
80mmHg @ 5500m
•
48mmHg @ 8900m (summit of Everest)
Hypobaric hypoxia causes:
•
Primary trigger for altitude acclimatisation
•
High altitude illness
Altitude Acclimatisation
Compensatory responses to acute hypobaric hypoxia (begins within minutes at a new altitude)
Acclimatisation:
•
Improves but does not normalise hypoxia
•
Complete compensation is not possible >5500m
•
Past acclimatisation has no effect on subsequent acclimatisation
•
Lost within weeks of descent
Processes:
•
ventilation to improve hypoxaemia
•
Respiratory alkalosis (requires compensation)
o
carbonic anhydrase in renal tubular cells → HCO3 excretion (days)
Other responses to hypobaric hypoxia:
•
SNS stimulation
•
Erythropoeisis
•
2,3-DPG
•
VO2 max (severely reduced at 4500m)
High Altitude Illness
•
HAPE
•
HACE
RFs: rapid ascent, lack of acclimatisation period, past history of HAI
Not associated with age, fitness or smoking history
Prophylaxis: when >3000m ascending <500m / 24hr
Acute Mountain Sickness and HACE (different severities of same spectrum of disease)
•
AMS: headache + PONV, insomnia, dizziness – common - 25% @ 3000m, >50% >4000m
•
HACE: CBF 2’ hypoxia → cerebral oedema +/- ICP +/- brain herniation and death (up to 4%)
o
SSx: encephalopathic symptoms i.e. ataxia, lassitude, cognition, LOC (may not have AMS pro-drome)
Prevention: Rx with acetazolamide (only if history of AMS)
Management:
•
Avoid further ascent
•
Simple analgesia + anti-emetics
If severe:
•
Rapid descent >1000m
•
Dexamethasone 8mg + 4mg q6 hour until descent complete
•
Supplemental O2 +/- hyperbaric O2 therapy
HAPE
Uncommon <4500m. Up to 15% at 5500m. Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema 2’ HPV at pulmonary arterioles
SSx: SOB out of proportion to exertion, non-productive cough, frank haemoptysis
Risk of AMS and HACE is markedly increased.
Prevention: salbutamol (in some people), pulmonary vasodilators, dexamethasone
Management:
•
Rapid descent
•
Supplemental oxygen – preferably hyperbaric O2
•
Rx: pulmonary vasodilators (nifedipine, PDE5)

title: Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy
text:
Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy
Exposure to O2 partial pressure >1 atm
Clinical effects:
•
dissolved O2 (>3tm dissolved O2 enough to supply body at rest i.e. can support body oxygenation without Hb)
o
E.g. severe anaemia in Jehovah’s witness patient
•
rate of O2 diffusion into tissues
o
wound healing and collagen formation
o
tissue oedema
o
post-reperfusion injury
•
Arteriolar vasoconstriction (overall SVR with inotropic support, improvement in acidaemia)
•
Killing of bacteria from super peroxidation
Note: pressure alone only effective in treating gas embolism
Clinical applications:
•
Acute decompression illness
•
Massive haemorrhage without transfusion (has been effective in Jehovah’s witnesses with massive haemorrhage)
•
Carbon monoxide poisoning: CO >25% or >20% if pregnant, GCS, pH <7.1
•
Gas gangrene
•
Necrotising fasciitis
•
Osteomyelitis
•
Compartment syndrome and reperfusion
•
Enhanced wound healing / flap compromise
CI:
•
Absolute: pneumothorax, premature infants, bleomycin, disulfuram, cisplatin
•
Relative: obstructive lung disease, sinus infection / URTI, recent ear or thoracic surgery, fever, claustrophobia, seizure
disorder, pregnancy, asthma, CO2 retention, spherocytosis, optic neuritis
Chamber types:
•
Monoplace: for one patient, portable for remote rescue, can be compressed with air or oxygen
•
Multiplace: >1 patient
Drug interactions:
•
Sympathomimetics: effects
•
 and  blockers: effects
•
Acetazolamide: cerebral oxygen delivery
•
Opioids, benzos, barbiturates and propofol: safe
•
Insulin: may need to due to BSL in O2 therapy
•
CI: doxorubicin, cisplatin, disulphuram
Adverse effects:
•
Pressure changes:
o
Risk of tympanic membrane perforation – common to perform prophylactic myringotomies +/- grommets
•
Decompression illness:
o
If supplied air instead of oxygen
o
If rapid decompression of chamber necessary in fire or cardiac arrest
•
Oxidative damage
o
CNS O2 toxicity (improved by short 5 min breaks breathing air q30 mins)
o
Pulmonary O2 toxicity (vital capacity - recovers between treatments)
•
Myopia
•
Cataract maturation
•
Hypoglycaemia
•
Systemic vasoconstriction, bradycardia (can worsen CCF)
Normobaric O2 therapy uses:
•
Subcut emphysema
•
Pneumothorax
•
CO poisoning
•
Cluster headaches
•
PONV
•
surgical site infection
•
anastomotic integrity

title: Corrosive Ingestion
text:
Corrosive Ingestion
Injury patten:
•
Alkalis: adhere to oral / oesophageal mucosa → severe local injuries (stomach sparing)
•
Acids:
o
Strong acids: irritant & cause coagulative necrosis + eschar +/- gastric perforation & stricture
o
Weak acids: localised laryngeal injury
•
Neutral pH: less extensive injury but can cause airway oedema
Acute management:
•
PPE to prevent damage to staff
•
Assess for airway compromise
•
Nasendoscopy if compliant patient
•
IV corticosteroids
•
Nebulised adrenaline
•
Do not delay endotracheal intubation if evolving injury or worsening oedema
o
Early call to ENT
•
Vomiting can cause further damage → ++ anti-emetics
•
Avoid activated charcoal
•
CXR: to rule out perf
o
Antibiotics only if evidence of GI perf
•
NGT under direct vision (blind may cause injury)
Further management:
•
Gastroscopy within 24hr (to assess extent of injuries)
•
Dexamethasone for 3 days if grade 2b oesophagitis
•
May require tracheostomy (1%)
•
Psychological support
1000x risk of oesophageal cancer

title: Organophosphate Poisoning
text:
Organophosphate Poisoning
Source:
Insecticides
Nerve agents
Mechanism:
Absorbed via skin, lungs, GIT
Inhibit acetylcholinesterase → cholinergic crisis
Initially reversible, becomes irreversible
Presentation: cholinergic excess systems effects
CVS: bradycardia, conduction block, QTc prolongation
Resp: secretions, bronchoconstriction
CNS: miosis, respiratory depression
Renal: diuresis
GIT: diarrhoea, vomiting, salivation
MSK: weakness, diaphoretic
Management:
A/B:
Intubation (avoid sux, dose on non-depolarising)
C:
Atropine: high dose i.e. 50mcg/kg IV
Double q5 min until effect
May require infusion
Pralidoxime: cholinesterase reactivator
30mg/kg AFTER atropine for MSK weakness
D:
Seizures: benzos
Decontaminate
Activated charcoal 1g/kg

title: Adult Resuscitation Guidelines
text:
Adult Resuscitation Guidelines
Chain of survival:
Early recognition + help
Early CPR
Early defib
Post resus care
Resuscitation:
Airway:
Capnography should be used to confirm ETT placement + quality of CPR + ROSC
Breathing:
Circulation:
Chest compressions:
High quality: 30:2, 1/3 depth with adequate recoil
Rate 100 – 120bpm
Interruptions <5s (only after defib charged)
Defib: avoid devices, consider 3 stacked shocks if witnessed VF/pVT arrest, biphasic 200J
Equipment (monitoring):
ETCO2 with waveform capnography
Blood sampling + analysis
Art line
Ultrasound
Post-resus care:
BSL 6 – 10mM
T <37.5
Unable to prognosticate <72hr

title: Interhospital Transfer
text:
Interhospital Transfer
Transfer exposes patient to additional risk
Must have accurate assessment / optimisation prior to transfer
Level of care must be at least equal to that of the point of referral
Centralised coordination of transport services
Choice of hospital based on:
Type of illness
Impact of transport environment (road, air)
Urgency
Distance + transport time
Weather conditions
Aviation restrictions / landing facilities
Resources at referring site
Fatigue limitations
Transport vehicle requirements:
Safety
Space
Power
Gas supply
Suction
Restraints
Acceptable noise / vibration levels
Speed / response time
Communication equipment
Monitoring
Supplies in excess of maximum travel time
Air transport considerations:
Reduced partial pressure of O2
Pressurisation / rapid desaturation
Expansion of air filled cavities and equipment
Limb swelling under casts
Worsening: air embolism, decompression sickness
Danger if agitated patient
Noise
Temperature
Acceleration, deceleration, turbulence, vibration
Motion illness

title: Mass Casualty
text:
Mass Casualty
Timeline:
Initial response
Consolidation phase
Recovery phase
Restoration of normality
Initial priorities:
Save life
Relieve suffering
Prevent escalation of incident
Protect environment
Preserve infrastructure / property
Restoration of normality
Enquiry into incident
Approach – CSCATTT
Command and control
Establish responsibility roles and command
Set up inner and outer cordons
Establish operational areas, casualty stations, entry and exit points
Safety: self, scene, survivors
PPE
Structural integrity
Communications
Coordination + dissemination of information
Assessment of the scene
Triage
Primary triage:
Distributive justice: maximum benefit for maximum amount of people
Establish priority levels and colour coded labels
Dead: black/white
Immediate: red
Urgent: yellow
Delayed: green
Non-injured → survivor reception area
Urgent care
Tourniquets
Airway adjuncts
Place in recovery position
Secondary triage: Triage Revised Trauma Scale 0-12
RR, GCS, sBP
Treatment and transport
Stabilise ABC
Transfer to appropriate location
Transportation of the dead

title: Mass Casualty
text:
Trial
Description
Outcome
CRASH2
TxA versus placebo
TxA 1g IV over 10 mins then
1g IV over 8 hours
sBP <90mmHg and/or HR
>110bpm
•
all cause mortality @ 28 days
•
death due to bleeding – best within 1hr, benefit <3hr
•
mortality if administered >3hr from injury
•
No difference: transfusion, surgical intervention, vascular occlusive episodes
TBI:
•
ICH expansion, neurosurg, mortality
•
No improvement in neurosurg outcomes
CRASH3

TBI within 3hr of injury
(exclusions: GCS 3, fixed
dilated pupils, patients with
major extra-cranial bleeding)
•
GCS 9-15:  head injury related death
•
Early treatment <1hr better than later treatment 1-3hr post-injury
•
Harm if TxA given >4 hours after injury
•
GCS 4-8: no difference with TxA
Other outcomes: no sig difference in all-cause mortality, disability, thrombosis,
seizures
PATCH

Within 3hr of injury (blunt /
penetrating trauma, burns)
•
No improved patient survival with favourable functional outcome
Note: many protocol violations – other studies have shown benefit within 1hr &
<3hr
Trial
Name
Description
Outcome
PAMPer
Prehospital Air Medical trial
Crystalloids versus
plasma
•
30-day mortality in plasma group (NNT
10)
CRISTAL

Critically Ill

crystalloid

No mortality benefit

PROPPR
Pragmatic Randomised Optimal
Platelet and Plasma Ratios Trial
pRBC : FFP : plt
1:1:1 versus 2:1:1

•

1:1:1
PROMMTT
Prospective Observational
Multicentre Major Trauma
Transfusion

No difference at 24 hours or 30 days

title: Pain
text:
Pain
Definition: an unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with, or resembling that associated with, actual or
potential tissue damage
Pain duration:
Acute pain: 0 – 6 weeks
Sub-acute: 6 – 12 weeks
Chronic pain: >12 weeks
Types of pain:
Nociceptive: caused by inflammation or damage to tissues
Somatic: localised, dull ache, sharp exacerbations (mechanical, MSK)
Visceral: poorly localised, cramping, dull (associated with nausea, sweating)
Neuropathic: caused by nerve damage, lesion in somatosensory system
Nociplastic: persistent pain from altered nociception without evidence of actual or threatened tissue damage
Sensitisation:
Lowered threshold
Amplified response
Widened receptive field
Altered sensation:
Allodynia: pain with non-noxious stimuli (e.g. paint brush stroke)
Hyperalgesia: pain with normally non-pain inducing noxious stimuli (e.g. BSL prick)
Hyperpathia: repetitive nociceptive stimuli → exaggerated level of pain

title: Neuropathic Pain
text:
Neuropathic Pain
Definition (IASP): pain caused by a lesion or disease of the somatosensory nervous system
Further divided into central and peripheral according to site of lesion
Hallmark characteristics:
Allodynia
Hyperalgesia
Dysaesthesia
+ pain descriptors (burning, shooting), regional autonomic features (colour & temp changes, sweating)
Neuropathic pain often poorly managed – only 35 – 50% of patients benefit from 1st line analgesics.
Combination therapy > monotherapy. Pain phenotyping may allow for more stratified and personalised therapies.
Management:
Medical
Psychological
NICE Guideline:
1st line: gabapentinoids (gabapentin, pregabalin), antidepressants (amitriptyline, duloxetine)
Special cases:
Carbamazepine 1st line for trigeminal neuralgia
Lignocaine patch 5% for post-herpetic neuralgia
2nd line: trial an alternative 1st line agent (trial all 4 if needed)
3rd line: opioids (buprenorphine > others)
Acute rescue therapy: tramadol is effective (L1)
Alternative therapy:
Capsaicin cream: for localised neuropathic pain wishing to avoid PO medications
High [ ] 8% capsaicin patches
Combination therapy:
WHO recommends ≥2 agents (limited efficacy with single agents, dose-related SEs)
Avoid drugs with similar adverse effects
Good approach is sequential combo therapy – if only partial response to single agent add a second
Novel agents:
Tapentadol: can be considered as single agent in difficult to treat patients
Cannabinoids: weak evidence, may play a role in weaning from high dose opioids or in combo therapy
Subcut lignocaine
Topical clonidine (thought to be peripherally mediated)
Multiagent creams: ket 10%, gabapentin 10%, imipramine 3%, bupivacaine 5%
Should not be started outside specialist setting:
Cannabis sativa extract
Capsaicin patch
Lacosamide
Lamotrigine
Keppra
Morphine
Oxcarbaepine
Topiramate
Venlafaxine
Long-term tramadol
Interventional therapy (adjuncts / refractory pain):
ESP for thoracic NP
Dorsal root entry zone ablation for complex, resistant segmental pain after SCI
DBS for refractory chronic pain

title: Chronic Pain
text:
Chronic Pain
Pain lasting >3 months. ~20% population.
Not every acute pain patient will develop chronic pain, but every chronic pain patient had an acute pain
Risk factors for developing chronic pain:
Severity of injury
Type of surgery
Pre-existing pain
Severe, uncontrolled acute pain → most consistent predictor of developing chronic pain i.e. intensity = risk
Anxiety and catastrophisation
Compensation status
Blame attribution and justice
Chronic neuropathic pain:
IV lignocaine is effective
Pain management programmes:
Patient behaviours and coping styles will determine functioning and QoL
Pain management programmes aid to focus on QoL through self-management and broaden the agenda away from pain
control alone
MDT input is essential
Clinical strategies in chronic pain:
Unhelpful:
Repeated investigations
Escalating analgesia focused on short-term pain relief
Reassuring results from investigations explained as “nothing wrong”
Persuading distressed patients that pain may be caused by emotions
Advising patients that they need to ‘learn to live with their problem’
Helpful:
Investigations + explanations that chronic pain may exist without overt pathology
Focus on long term functioning with medication deprescribing as important as prescribing
Clarify absence of malignant problems whilst addressing normal changes (i.e. degeneration)
Explain that thoughts and feelings do not cause pain but psychological management may be central to living with it
Introduce self-management carefully (e.g. exercise, goal-setting, understanding that hurt doesn’t equal harm, pain
does not necessarily need ‘rescuing’)

title: Chronic Post-Surgical Pain
text:
Chronic Post-Surgical Pain
Components:
Pain after surgical procedure
Area of surgery
Persisting beyond healing process (≥3mo)
Not better explained by another cause
May continue from acute PSP or may have pain-free interval. Often neuropathic component.
Characteristics:
•
Sensory abnormalities
•
Neuropathic
•
Somatic / nociceptive
Mechanism: central and peripheral sensitisation
Post-surgical persistent pain risk factors:
Pre-op:
Mod-severe pain >1mo
Repeat surgery
Psychological vulnerability (eg catastrophising)
Anxiety
Female sex
Younger age (adults)
Workers’ compensation
Genetic predisposition (e.g. COMT)
Opioid use (particularly if ineffective)
Intra-operative:
Nerve injury
Recovery:
Severity of acute pain (esp neuropathic like SSx)
Chemoradiotherapy
Catastrophisation
Patients with legal issues
Prevention:
•
Pre-op identification of at risk individuals
•
Routine post-op:
o
Effective management of acute pain
o
Limiting opioid exposure + multimodal analgesia
o
Regional analgesia
o
Psychological support + rehab
•
Specific (4)
o
Regional
o
Pharmacotherapy
o
Modification of surgical approach
o
Non-pharmacological
Type of Analgesia
Definition
Pre-emptive
Treatment/analgesia prior to incision / insult (e.g. paracetamol, NSAID, opioid, epidural)
Preventive
Analgesia intended to reduce short and long-term post surgical pain – timing is not important, but effect of intervention is observed
at a point in time that exceeds the duration of action of the target agent (defined as analgesia that lasts >5.5 half lives of the
medicine)

title: Chronic Post-Surgical Pain
text:
Specific interventions:
Regional
•
Benefit in 3 procedures:
o
Thoracotomy: epidural
o
Breast cancer: PVB
o
C-section
•
Possible benefit:
o
Open bowel resection: epidural
o
Amputation: epidural
•
LA infiltration:
o
Breast ca
o
Iliac crest bone graft
o
Craniotomy
Pharmacotherapy
•
Ketamine:
o
<24 hour infusion: CPSP at 6mo
o
>24hr infusion: CPSP at 3mo
o
No benefit at 12 months
o
Most efficacious and safe
•
Opioids:
o
High dose: pain (i.e. remifentanil)
•
Gabapentinoids: weak evidence, unlikely to benefit
•
IV lignocaine: CPSP at 3mo
•
Venlafaxine:
o
Masctectomy: 37.5mg/day for 10 days started pre-op → CPSP at 6mo
•
N2O: CPSP in Chinese patients

title: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome
text:
Complex Regional Pain Syndrome
Post-traumatic disorder:
Non-dermatomal
Severe + continuous in affected limb
Associated sensory, motor, vasomotor, sweat gland and trophic disturbances
May exhibit:
Hypersensitivity and / or allodynia
Temperature differences between affected and contralateral limb
Oedema
Changes in hair and nail growth
in symptoms after exercise
Two types:
CRPS 1: no demonstrable nerve lesion
CRPS 2: demonstrable nerve lesion
Pathophysiology: 4 component model
•
Local tissue damage
•
Pathological pain processing
•
Autonomic dysregulation
•
Immune dysfunction
Multifactorial, likely an exaggerated inflammatory response, certain HLA loci may be susceptible
Vitamin C >500mg / day initiated immediately after surgery and continued for 50 days may risk
Clinical diagnosis (IASP):
Continuing disproportionate pain to inciting event
Must have one symptom in 3 of the following 4 categories:
Sensory: hyperaesthesia, allodynia
Vasomotor: temperature asymmetry, skin colour changes
Sudomotor / oedema: sweating changes, oedema
Motor / trophic: ROM, motor dysfunction, trophic changes (hair, nail, skin)
Must have one sign in 2 or more of the categories above
No other diagnosis better explains SSx
Management categories:
Anti-inflammatories: steroids
Regional osteopaenia: bisphosphonates
Analgesics: gabapentinoids
Vasodilators: CCB, alpha blocker, PDE5 inhibitor
Muscle relaxants / spasmolytics: try PO prior to intrathecal baclofen, IM botox
Psychological → referral for CBT, education
Invasive treatment only if above fails e.g. spinal cord stimulator
Prognosis: varied

title: Stellate Ganglion Block
text:
Sympathetic Blocks
Rationale:
Vascular pain 2’ poor blood supply
Neuropathic pain
Indications: depends on level
PVD
Visceral pain
Hyperhydrosis
Neuropathic pain (including CRPS)
Method: sedation, aseptically, adequate resus available
Type of block:
Diagnostic: assess effect, aiming for no somatic block – often inaccurate
Prognostic: should do >1 and results should be consistent prior to neuroablation
Therapeutic: neurolysis
Stellate Ganglion Block
Fusion of 1st thoracic and inferior cervical sympathetic ganglia
Relations:
•
Posterior to subclavian artery + SCM
•
Anterior to 1st rib, vertebral artery, anterior scalene
•
Medial to superior intercostal vessels
•
Lateral to thoracic duct, vertebrae, oesophagus
•
Superior to dome of pleura
Indications above +
Raynauds
Angina / chest pain
Refractory arrythmias
CI:
•
Coagulopathy
•
Local infection / cancer
•
Anatomical / vascular abnormality
•
Recent MI
•
Glaucoma
•
Contralateral phrenic nerve palsy
Complications:
•
Horner’s
•
Nerve injury: brachial plexus, RLN, phrenic nerve
•
Organ injury: pleura, pneumothorax, trachea, oesophagus
•
Vascular
•
Intrathecal injection

title: Lower Back Pain
text:
Lower Back Pain
ASSESS:
•
History:
o
SOCRATES
o
Function / impact on daily life: BPI
o
Previous treatments: medications, physio, surgery
o
Associated symptoms: numbness / tingling, bowel / bladder dysfunction
•
Examination:
o
Inspect: posture, gait, deformities
o
Palpation: tenderness, muscle spasms, abnormalities
o
ROM
o
Neuro examination
•
Psychosocial:
o
Address hindering features: fear-avoidance behaviours, depression, social withdrawal
•
Investigations: only if red flags present (e.g. trauma, malignancy, infection, neurology)
o
Imaging: xray, CT, MRI, NCS
MANAGE:
•
Education + reassurance: information, importance of exercise, avoid bed rest
o
Targeted reassurance improves fear, worry, anxiety, catastrophisation and healthcare utilisation (L1)
o
Education using “biopsychosocial/neuroscience” anxiety, worry, fear, distress and healthcare utilisation (L1)
•
Pharmacological treatment:
o
Paracetamol + NSAIDs
o
Neuropathic: amitriptyline, pregabalin, gabapentin
o
Opioids only for severe pain unresponsive to other treatment, careful monitoring
•
Non-pharmacological treatment:
o
Physical therapy
o
Manual therapy e.g. massage
o
CBT
o
Mindfulness
•
Interventional:
o
Injections: epidural steroid, facet joints
o
Radiofrequency ablation: if refractory
•
MDT: physiotherapy, psychology, OT, pain specialists
o
Specialist if complex
•
Follow-up

title: Spinal Cord Stimulator
text:
Spinal Cord Stimulator
Superior to repeat surgery. Stimulation of dorsal column fibres (placement in dorsal epidural space) effectively reduces pain in
many neuropathic and ischaemic pain syndromes.
Indications:
Failed back surgery syndrome (disabling back or radicular pain despite adequate surgery)
Complex regional pain syndrome type 1
Chronic leg ischaemia
Chronic angina refractory to treatment
Case reports in: diabetic neuropathy, post-herpetic neuralgia, post-amputation pain (lack evidence)
Prior: should have trial, MRSA eradication
Special considerations:
MRI: controversial, may cause damage (newer may be MRI compatible)
Diathermy: avoid, bipolar, away from device
PPM / ICD: requires communication with cardiology team – relatively CI (demand mode may sense SCS)
SCS must not prevent use of external defib
Pregnancy: unknown data, no data to suggest adverse outcomes (but also none in support of safety)
Neuraxial anaesthesia: risk of damage to device – must be done completely sterile under radiological guidance
Anaesthetic considerations:
Pre-op:
Contact pain team, interrogate, turn off prior to anaesthesia (prevents inadvertent reprogramming, interference
with ECG leads)
Intra-op:
Antibiotics only if otherwise indicated
Careful positioning and padding
Diathermy: avoid if able, bipolar > monopolar, away from device
Lithotripsy: turn off
Neuraxial anaesthesia: risk of damage to device – best avoided, may also introduce infection
If done – d/w pain specialist, must be done completely sterile under radiological guidance, may cause
patchy anaesthesia due to fibrosis
Post-op:
Turn back on and pain team interrogate

title: Chronic Headache
text:
Chronic Headache
ASSESS:
•
History
o
Pain history: site, onset, character, radiation, associations, time course, exacerbating / relieving factors,
severity
o
Other features: photophobia, visual changes, aura, N&V
o
Effect on function
o
Impact on daily life
o
Red flags
o
Other related medical conditions
o
Efficacy of previous treatments
•
Examination:
o
Neurological
o
Head & neck
•
Investigations:
o
Red flags: worsening unrelenting symptoms, fever, recent procedure, immunosuppressed
▪
CT / MRI
MANAGE:
•
Education and reassurance
•
Pharmacological treatments:
o
Acute: paracetamol, NSAIDs
o
Medication overuse headache: educate, manage withdrawal
•
Non-pharmacological treatments
o
CBT
o
Physiotherapy (address MSK)
o
Relaxation: mindfulness
o
Lifestyle modification: sleep hygiene, regular exercise, reduce etoh / sugar / caffeine
•
MDT: consider specialised referral if refractory
•
Follow up to assess efficacy
Specific:
•
Migraine:
o
Acute: triptans, anti-emetics
o
Preventative: beta-blockers
o
Lifestyle / triggers
•
Tension-type: stress management, physical therapy
•
Cluster:
o
Acute: oxygen, sumatriptan
o
Preventative: verapamil
Individualised, evidence-based, patient-centred

title: Migraine
text:
Migraine
Treatment:
•
Acute headache:
o
Aspirin 1000mg (L1)
o
Ibuprofen 400 – 800mg (L1) – soluble faster onset
o
Paracetamol 1g (effective but less than other analgesic, efficacy with metoclopramide L1)
o
Addition of caffeine to simple analgesics efficacy and better tolerability (L1)
o
Triptan (5HT1) – highest withdrawal + MOH
▪
Subcut sumatriptan has fastest onset and highest efficacy (L1)
▪
Increased efficacy combined with naproxen than alone (L1)
▪
All triptans are superior to placebo however 40% of patients may not respond (L1)
o
+/- anti-emetic (improves absorption + efficacy)
▪
Metoclopramide and droperidol (L1)
▪
Phenothiazines and butyrophenones are effective but more side effects (L1)
o
Some opioids are more effective than placebo in treatment of acute migraine (L1) but associated with
significant side effects and poor outcomes
▪
Pethidine should not be used (L1)
Single adequate dose > multiple suboptimal doses
Above ineffective during aura phase, must wait for headache
Acute treatments associated with medication overuse headache – limit to 2x per week + start preventative
Hyperbaric O2 is effective in pain but no other outcomes (L1)
There is significant placebo effect in migraine treatment (L1)
•
Preventative (if >4 attacks/month):
o
B-blockers: metoprolol, propranolol
o
Anti-epileptics: valproate, topiramate
o
Amitriptyline
o
Bisoprolol
If >3 above failed can consider:
▪
Botox
▪
Greater occipital nerve block
▪
Occipital nerve stimulation
Acupuncture:
•
May frequency of tension headaches and migraine (L1)
•
May be tolerated better than pharmacological prophylaxis in migraines (L1)

title: Herpes Zoster
text:
Herpes Zoster
Shingles
Prevention: vaccination
Treatment:
•
Antiviral within 72 hours of rash onset → accelerates resolution
•
Simple analgesia + PRN opioid
•
Prednisone may pain
•
Gabapentin pain
•
Topical lignocaine
•
Topical aspirin
•
Nerve blocks
Post-Herpetic Neuralgia
Varicella zoster virus may cause post-herpetic neuralgia:
•
Persists for >3mo after onset of shingles
•
RFs: age >50yo, prodromal pain, severe acute pain, severe rash, ophthalmic involvement
Prevention:
•
Vaccination
•
Nerve block: epidural, PVB
•
Amitriptyline 25mg PO for 90 days
In-effective for prevention of pain:
•
Antiviral
•
Steroids
Treatment:
•
Topical capsaicin / lignocaine 5%
•
Anti-neuropathic:
o
Gabapentin 300 – 600mg TDS
o
Pregabalin
o
Amitriptyline
•
Anti-epileptic: valproate, carbamazepine, lamotrigine
•
SNRI
•
Intrathecal steroid
•
Botox
•
Neuromodulation, neurostimulation

title: Trigeminal Neuralgia
text:
Trigeminal Neuralgia
Unilateral pain characterised by brief electric shock like pain, abrupt in onset / offset, in the distribution of one or more
trigeminal nerve
Aetiology:
•
Unclear
•
Hyper-excitable neurons in trigeminal root ganglion
•
Central sensitisation
•
Demyelination
Risk factors:
•
Vascular compression of trigeminal nerve
•
Multiple sclerosis
•
Tumours
•
Trauma
•
Stroke
Diagnosis:
•
Paroxysmal attacks lasting up to 2 minutes in ≥1 trigeminal division plus:
o
Pain is:
▪
Intense, sharp, superficial, stabbing
▪
Precipitated by a trigger
o
Stereotyped
•
No neurological defect
•
No other apparent cause
Classification:
•
Classical: no apparent cause i.e. paroxysmal
•
Symptomatic: secondary to another cause i.e. MS
Treatment:
•
Pharmacological:
o
Carbamazepine MR 100mg BD up to 400mg BD (NNT 1.8) – many SEs
▪
Oxcarbazepine better tolerated
o
Other Rx: gabapentinoids, amitriptyline, baclofen, phenytoin, topiramate, duloxetine
o
Motor cortex stimulation
o
Botox
•
Surgical:
o
Peripheral: laser, EtOH, neurectomy
o
Gasserian ganglion: at foramen ovale under fluoroscopy
▪
Thermal, mechanical (balloon), chemical
o
Posterior fossa:
▪
Microvascular decompression (most successful)
▪
Stereotactic radiosurgery
Duration of relief:
•
Peripheral: 6 – 12 mo
•
Ganglion balloon compression: 4 – 5 years
•
Neurosurgical: up to 10 years

title: Methadone
text:
Methadone
50 – 120mg / day.
Pre-op:
•
SUD
•
ECG: QTc
•
Opioid induced hyperalgesia
•
Continue methadone
•
REFER: D&A, APS, pharmacy
In-hospital:
•
No exact conversion: IV ~0.7x oral dose s/c q6 hr divided doses
•
Avoid QTc prolonging drugs
Post-op:
•
Divide daily methadone into TDS dosing as analgesic effect is shorter than withdrawal prevention effect
•
Avoid QTc prolonging drugs + APS review

title: Buprenorphine
text:
Buprenorphine
Peri-op concerns:
•
Withdrawal
•
Inadequate analgesia
•
Overdose and respiratory depression
•
Relapse of substance use disorder
8 – 32mg s/l or s/c injection – ½ life 28 hours
Pre-op:
•
Screen for ORT
•
Dosing / frequency / duration / compliance / extra opioid use
•
Other substance
•
Withdrawal symptoms
•
Associated comorbidities
•
Anticipated degree of pain post-op
•
Refer for post op HDU bed
•
D/w surgeons minimally invasive technique
Optimise:
•
Continue buprenorphine at same dose
•
Involve D&A + pain specialist
•
Consider tapering to 16mg/day if high post-op pain anticipated
Intra-op / post-op:
•
Multimodal analgesia
o
Regional + consider catheter
o
Ketamine, lignocaine, dexmedetomidine, clonidine, magnesium
o
Non-pharmacological: ice, position changes, relaxation, peer recovery support, distraction
•
If using opioid use opioid with high affinity:
o
Fentanyl
o
Hydromorphone
o
Split / increase dose of bup
Post-op:
•
HDU: pain / resp / withdrawal monitoring
•
APS + D&A
•
Transitional analgesia + DC planning → taper to pre-op dose + d/w GP / specialist

title: Gabapentinoids
text:
Gabapentinoids
MOA: modulates GABA via alpha-2-delta ligand binding to calcium channels – mechanism poorly understood
Considerations:
•
High NNT
•
Extensive side effect profile
•
Many studies are poor quality
Benefits:
•
opioid consumption
•
PONV
Adverse effects:
•
Sedation
•
Visual disturbance
•
Resp depression, OIVI
•
Abuse potential
Evidence of benefit:
•
Breast ca surgery, hysterectomy, C-section, spinal, THR/TKR
•
Chronic: chronic neuropathic pain, fibrolyalgia

title: IV Lignocaine
text:
IV Lignocaine
MOA: binds to voltage gated sodium channels (+ anti-inflammatory, anti-hyperalgesic)
Adverse effects:
•
Sedation
•
CNS/CVS toxicity
Benefits:
•
Acute pain: small benefit, <1/10 pain score reduction
•
ileus
•
PONV
•
opioid requirements
•
CPSP
•
chronic neuropathic pain
Evidence of benefit in: bowel resection, mastectomy, prostatectomy, nephrectomy, cystectomy, bariatric

title: Opioids
text:
Opioids
2019 Australian National Survey on Drug Use & Health:
9.7M people >12yo misused pain relief in past year
>50% surveyed were given by, bought from or took from friend/relative
Only 35% surveyed received via prescription from one doctor
Other statistics:
US data on opioid-related deaths: 40% from non-prescribed opioids - 70% of those sourced from friend/family on a
legitimate Rx
>10% of patients still using opioids after surgery at 90 days in Australia
Definitions:
Misuse: opioid use contrary to the prescribed pattern of use, regardless of the presence or absence of harm or AEs
Abuse: intentional use of the opioid for non-medical purpose e.g. euphoria or altering state of consciousness
Addiction: pattern of continued use with experience of, or demonstrated potential for harm
Chemical coping: the use of opioids to cope with emotional distress → inappropriate and/or excessive opioid use
Issues with pre-op opioid use:
Opioid-induced hyperalgesia
Opioid-induced ventilatory impairment
Opioid misuse, diversion risk
Persistent opioid use
Opioid efficacy:
Acute pain: effective, up to 70% pain reduction, dose-responsive relationship
Persistent/chronic pain: less effective, 30% pain reduction
There is no quality evidence for opioid use beyond 1y.
Relevance for anaesthetists:
New persistent opioid use post-op ~5%
Iatrogenic opioid dependence or abuse ~5% patient prescribed opioids for pain i.e. surgery is a potential gateway
Predicted that excess unused opioid occurs in 70% of patients, with only 5% safely disposed
Factors influencing over- and under-prescription:
Under prescription: guidelines, institutional limits, state law, prescriber monitoring, reactionary fear → potential acute +
chronic pain
Over prescription: patient satisfaction, minimising prescriber inconvenience → misuse, overuse + unused residual opioid
Options for opioid disposal:
Pharmacy return
Flush down toilet
Landfill disposal
Burn
If you suspect opioid misuse in a patient assess:
Pain
Indication + consumption
Habituation
Expectation
Education

title: Opioid Stewardship
text:
Opioid Stewardship
Coordinated interventions designed to improve use of opioids in order to protect human health
Targets: persistent post-op use, OIVI, opioid misuse and diversion, drug driving
Discharge opioids:
Ensure continuation of multi-modals with communicated stop date
Ensure discharge amount reflects inpatient use in last 24 hours
Consider prescription of shorter duration i.e. 3 days + GP follow up
Note: there are prescribing recommendations on OPEN based on type of surgery
Opioid-free anaesthesia:
Noble but has limits
Does not allow analgesic titration based on patient needs
Is unclear about optimal components and role in different surgeries/settings
Do not serve to decrease the risk of persistent opioid use
Can distract from optimising pain relief and minimising realistic long term harms
Opioid-free dexmed v remifent trial stopped early due to 5 cases of severe bradycardia/hypoxaemia in dexmed group
JAMA June 2023: reduced opioid administration during surgery may have unintended outcome of post-op pain + opioid
consumption. Improvements in long term outcomes may be achieved by optimising opioid administration during surgery
OPIOID CRISIS MANAGEMENT
Upstream
Midstream
Downstream
•
Abuse deterrent formulations
•
Identifying high risk patients
•
Up-scheduling
•
Reducing pack sizes
•
Education
•
Pharmacist involvement
•
presciptions
•
Opioid-sparing analgesia
•
Opioid stewardship
•
Safe drug disposal
•
Follow up
•
Transitional clinics
•
“Opioid exit plan”

title: Opioid-Related Risks
text:
Opioid-Related Risks
Dose dependent.
Side effects:
Resp depression: 1-12%
Excessive sedation: 5%
Pruritis: 15% (higher with PCA) – opioid antagonists and ondansetron are effective treatments (L1)
Vomiting: 20%
Nausea: 30%
+/- urinary retention
+/- constipation (opioid antagonists > laxatives)
Opioid-sparing / side effects with NSAIDs, gabapentin, pregab, IV lignocaine, ketamine (paracetamol pain scores but not
opioid use)
Tapentadol similar efficacy to conventional opioids with GI side effects
Risks:
Overdose / abuse
Tolerance (highest with morphine)
Fractures
AMI
Sexual dysfunction
Peri-op risks: above +
•
OIH
•
OIVI
•
Persistent post-op opioid use
•
Misuse / diversion
•
Poorer pain control and reduced functional outcome
•
Infection / immunosuppression
•
Endocrine issues (HPA suppression including adrenal suppression, bone weakness)
Currently insufficient evidence to associate opioid use with cancer promotion / spread.
Opioid-Induced Hyperalgesia
OIH: state of sensitivity to noxious stimuli occurring after exposure to high dose opioids (usually remifentanil)
Nociceptive sensitisation 2’ opioids → paradoxical response to opioid agonist → increased pain perception
OIH → pain tolerance to noxious thermal stimuli but not electrical stimuli – pain detection thresholds unchanged
High risk remifentanil use:
Dose duration >1-2 hours
>20mcg/kg total
Infusion at >0.1mcg/kg/min
Plasma [ ] >2.7ng/mL
Development of remifentanil tolerance/OIH by:
(L1) Ketamine, magnesium, propofol
(L2) Pregab, NO2
Remi is associated with development of chronic pain
Important – but nearly impossible – to distinguish from pharmacological tolerance (may require quantitative sensory testing).
Tolerance: analgesia may improve with dose escalation
OIH: analgesia may improve with dose reduction
If patient on opioids sustains new injury:
Reasonable to trial dose increase
If worsens or fails to respond – consider OIH
Must also consider other reasons:
Neuropathic pain
Major psychological stress
Drug seeking behaviour

title: Persistent Post-Discharge Opioid Use
text:
Persistent Post-Discharge Opioid Use
Continuation of opioids >90 days after surgery
Minor surgery just as vulnerable as major surgery
Risk factors:
Patient-related:
Psychological comorbidity
Pre-op benzos, anti-depressants
Pre-op tobacco use, EtOH, substance use disorders
Pre-existing chronic pain
Pre-admission opioid use (aim to wean prior to surgery)
Lower age
Female
Low SES
Modifiable – relate to prescribing practices:
Long-term pre-admission opioid sue
Psychological comorbidities
Expectations
Chasing pain scores
Abnormal trajectories
Over-reliance on opioids
Use of MR preparations
Large quantity on discharge
Repeat prescriptions
Lack of deprescribing advice
Mitigating harm:
Avoidance of modifiable risk factors
Education
Communication with GP
Referral to specialist services if needed i.e. chronic pain specialist, psychologist, addiction medicine

title: Misuse and Diversion
text:
Opioid-Induced Ventilatory Impairment
OIVI 2’ three main interlinked mechanisms:
Central resp depression
Sedation
SGA muscle tone → upper airway obstruction
Highest incidence first 24h post-surgery
Risk factors:
Patient: elderly, female, obesity, neuro dz, cardiac dz, pulmonary dz, OSA, high dose opioids
Modifiable: coadministration of sedatives, multiple opioid agents, continuous infusions, long acting opioids (e.g.
methadone), multiple prescribers, reliance on unidimensional pain scores, using opioids for non-opioid responsive pain
Risk is less with atypicals i.e. tramadol, tapenatdol, bup (patches only)
Monitoring:
RR limited value; hypoxic episodes can occur with normal RR (no reliable correlation with PaCO2)
Continuous pulse ox detection of desaturation, continuous capnography is superior
Greatest correlation between sedation score and PaCO2
Regular appropriate sedation scores – AVPU and GCS not sensitive enough, do not describe ability to remain awake
In adults patient age rather than weight is a better predictor of opioid requirements (although large interpreter variation)
Most sensitive way to detect opioid-related sedation is sedation score
Misuse and Diversion
Quantity prescribed on discharge often far exceeds requirement → risk for patient and others
>50% of adults who misuse obtain from family & friends
Requires education about storage
Risk of misuse and diversion less with atypicals

title: Opioid Tolerant Patient
text:
Opioid Tolerant Patient
Goals:
•
MDT care
•
Effective analgesia
•
tolerance and OIH
•
Prevent withdrawal
•
DC planning
•
Outpatient follow up
Pain assessment:
•
Current treatment, allergies
•
Pain history
•
Expectations
•
Goals of care
•
Support systems following DC
•
Chronic non-cancer pain:
o
Diagnosis, pain scores, functional status, prognosis, psychospiritual, invasive treatments, medication misuse
Substance use disorder:
•
Substitution therapy + dose
•
Other drugs: prescribed, diverted, illicit + routes of administration, nicotine, EtOH
•
Prescriber + dispenser
•
Medical comorbidity: blood borne viruses, cirrhosis, chronic pain
•
Psychological comorbidities
Management:
•
Opioids:
o
dose requirement
o
IV PCA, otherwise PO / SL
o
Maintain >50% baseline dose to prevent withdrawal
▪
Avoid antagonists
o
Opioid rotation: incomplete cross-tolerance - dose by 30 – 50%
o
Consider HDU for monitoring
o
APS
o
DC planning: reverse analgesia ladder → pre-op regimen
Reduction of tolerance and OIH:
•
NMDA-R antagonist: magnesium, ketamine
•
Opioid rotation
•
Adjuvants

title: Non-Pharmacological Pain Interventions
text:
Non-Pharmacological Pain Interventions
Options:
•
Psychological
•
TENS
•
Acupuncture / acupressure
•
Photo-biomodulation
•
Physical therapy

title: Psychological
text:
Psychological
Types:
•
Information provision
•
Relaxation techniques
•
Attention strategies (i.e. mindfulness, VR, music)
•
CBT
Applied pre- or post-op
Often reduce pain score without reduction in opioid use

title: TENS
text:
TENS
Evidence:
•
Effective: most major specialties, phantom limb, shingles
•
Not effective: ACL repair, Colle’s #, labour

title: Acupuncture / Acupressure
text:
Acupuncture / Acupressure
Evidence:
•
Effective: most major specialties including spinal + crani
•
Not effective: laparoscopic surgery
•
Possible benefit in labour

title: Photobiomodulation
text:
Photobiomodulation
Evidence:
•
Effective: mucositis / stomatitis, maxfax / ENT, tonsillectomy, vascular access, sternotomy
•
Not effective: ankle sprain, episiotomy

title: Physical Therapy
text:
Physical Therapy
Includes:
•
Active:
o
Exercise: TKR, period pain, labour (birth ball)
o
Prehab: THR
o
Rehab: spinal surgery, trauma
•
Passive:
o
Massage
o
Manual therapy
o
Temperature therapy
▪
Warmth: labour
▪
Cold: cannulation, TKR, ACL

title: Acute Pain Services
text:
Acute Pain Services
Reasons to establish an acute pain service:
pain relief
incidence of adverse effects
post-op morbidity/mortality
Institution of analgesic techniques that may reduce persistent pain post-op
Cost-effective patient care
opioid use on discharge after surgery
Aims of an acute pain service:
Relieve suffering
psychological stress response to pain
Promote functional recovery
Prevent transition from acute → chronic pain
Prevent harm from acute opioid side effects
Avoid prolonged inappropriate use

title: Epidural Review
text:
Epidural Review
Bromage score:
•
0: free movement
•
1: feet + knee flex (just)
•
2: feet flex, not knee
•
3: unable to move legs
Investigating LL weakness in epidural:
1. Leg weakness → contact APS + switch off
2. APS aspirate catheter
a. CSF: remove + reassess q30 min + systemic opioids
b. No CSF: assess q30 mins
i. Leg strength improved → recommence at lower dose
ii. >2hr lapsed without improvement → investigate for epidural haematoma
Note: low [ ] TEA should not cause LL motor weakness – LL exam should be normal, low lumbar may occasionally cause LL
weakness but again low concentrations should not
NHMRC – How to develop a guideline
Determine need + scope: existing guidelines, reason, desired outcomes
Best evidence: lit review
MDT input: include allied health
Flexibility + adaptability
Economic impact
Dissemination: make accessible + inform target audience
Evaluation
Revision: schedule review

section_path: Assessment of Suicidality in Chronic Pain
title: Psychosocial Impact on Pain
text:
Psychosocial Impact on Pain
Important points (5):
Personal experience influenced by varying degrees of biological, physiological, and social factors
Individuals learn concept of ‘pain’ through life experience
A person’s report of pain should be respected
Pain is meant to be adaptive / protective, but may have adverse effects on function, social and psychological well-being
Verbal description is only one of several ways to express pain, inability to communicate must be considered and does not
negate experience of pain
Evidence:
Pre-op psychological interventions may be effective at pain, LOS and negative effect (L1)
May not be effective after cardiac surgery (L1)
Distraction and hypnosis needle related pain and distress in children (L1)
Hypnosis may also procedural pain and anxiety, postop pain, anxiety and analgesia consumption in labour (L1)
Music produces small pain, analgesic requirements and emotional distress (L1)
Patient education may pain and anxiety but does not affect analgesic use (L1)
Training in coping methods or behavioural instruction prior to surgery pain, negative affect and analgesic use (L1)
Relaxation techniques pain but does not affect analgesic use (L1)

section_path: Assessment of Suicidality in Chronic Pain
Assessment of Suicidality in Chronic Pain
title: Assessment of Suicidality in Chronic Pain
text:
Assessment of Suicidality in Chronic Pain
2x higher in chronic pain. Up to 14% of chronic pain patients attempt suicide in their lifetime.
Risk factors:
Pain related:
Intensity
Sleep disturbance / insomnia
Catastrophising
Opioid use
General suicide risk factors
Protective factors:
Problem solving
Coping skills
Positive future thinking and relationships
Access to support and care
No evidence for any questionnaires, must perform assessments
Look for warning signs – though may not be present (stating want to hurt or kill self, stockpiling, writing or talking about suicide)
Process:
Assess for intent:
Imminent risk: refer to local crisis team / ED (if patient leaves clinic contact police)
Not at imminent risk but limited barriers: probe, monitor, contact primary care clinician
Not at imminent risk and barriers: establish safety plan if risk increase
Safety plan:
Individualised barriers
Distractors
Restriction of access
Contacts for support

title: SOFA Score
text:
SOFA Score
Should not influence medical management or assess affect of intervention. Should just be used to determine level of acuity and
mortality risk. May be used to provide family with prognosis, or for clinical trials.
Variables (use worst values in last 24 hours):
•
P:F ratio
•
Mechanical ventilation (including CPAP)
•
Platelets
•
GCS
•
Bilirubin
•
MAP (including pressor doses)
•
Creatinine

title: Apache II
text:
Apache II
Severity of disease score applied within 24 hr of admission. >16yo. Score 0 – 71.
Uses:
•
May restrict certain procedures / medications
•
Predicted mortality based on morbidity
Three major categories:
•
Acute physiology score (blood biomarkers, vitals, GCS)
•
Age
•
Chronic health

title: Sedation in Intensive Care
text:
Sedation in Intensive Care
RAAS Score (Richmond Agitation Sedation Score)
Dexmed: conscious sedation which resembles natural sleep, no resp depression, anxiolysis, analgesia
Effects: decongestant, anti-sialogue, analgesia, hypotension/bradycardia, diuretic, bowel motility, shivering
No clinically significant adrenal suppression (despite being an imidazole)
ICU uses:
•
Analgesia
•
Anxiolysis
•
Bridge to extubation
•
Risk of delirium
•
Tolerance of NIV
Peri-op use:
•
Sedative pre-med
•
Analgesia
•
Sympatholysis
•
AFOI
•
RA adjuncts

title: Blood Management in Intensive Care
text:
Blood Management in Intensive Care
Patient blood management aims:
•
Optimise blood volume and red cell mass
•
blood loss
•
Optimise tolerance of anaemia
Recommendations:
•
Critical ill – restrictive transfusion strategy should be employed
•
Packed cells:
o
Hb alone should not be trigger, look at clinical status
o
Single unit → reassess
o
Hb
▪
<70: transfusion likely appropriate
▪
70-90: no mortality benefit – indication should be clinical
▪
>90: transfusion generally unnecessary
o
ACS Hb:
▪
<80: transfusion associated with mortality
▪
80-100: effect of transfusion on mortality is uncertain; may be associated with risk MI
▪
>100: transfusion associated with mortality
o
Risks: infection, VAP, ARDS/ALI
•
EPO:
o
Critically ill anaemia: does not transfusion cf restrictive, may VTE
o
Trauma: possible mortality, no effect on transfusion
o
Use of iron in both groups uncertain
•
FFP:
o
Identify cause of coagulopathy
o
Risk of ARDS, ALI – must consider
o
INR <2 can generally undergo procedures without serious bleeding risk
•
Cryo / fibrinogen:
o
Identify cause of coagulopathy
o
Risks uncertain
•
Platelets:
o
If not bleeding, transfusion may be appropriate in plt <20
o
Plt >50 can generally undergo procedures in ICU without significant bleeding
o
Risks / reactions uncertain
•
TXA:
o
Trauma: within 3hr mortality, acutely bleeding no effect on transfusion,
o
UGIB: critically ill can consider
•
Cell salvage:
o
Trauma: no effect on mortality, transfusion
o
Ruptured AAA: effect on mortality uncertain, may transfusion – reasonable to consider use

title: Nutrition
text:
Nutrition
In critically unwell catabolism > anabolism
Effect on outcomes:
•
Enteral feeding
o
infection (gut immune function, anti-inflammatory) esp cf parenteral
o
Borderline significant mortality
o
Early better than late initiation
o
Strengthens GI anastomosis
•
Parenteral feeding
o
Early: no mortality benefit, possible infection risk
Indications:
•
Enteral: unless CI
•
Parenteral: after 1 -2 weeks

title: Enteral Nutrition
text:
Enteral Nutrition
Complications:
•
Aspiration
•
Diarrhoea
•
Metabolic abnormalities
•
Mechanical complications: catheter related, constipation
CI:
•
Risk of bowel ischaemia: HD unstable, not adequately resuscitated
•
Non-functioning gut: bowel obstruction, ileus, upper GI bleed, vomiting / diarrhoea, GI ischaemia, high output fistula

title: Parenteral Nutrition
text:
Parenteral Nutrition
Complications:
•
Bloodstream infection
•
Metabolic abnormalities: hyperglycaemia, electrolyte abnormalities, nutrient excess / deficiency, refeeding syndrome,
wernicke’s encephalopathy, hepatic dysfunction
•
Venous central access complications
CI:
•
Hyperosmolality, severe hyperglycaemia
•
Severe electrolyte disturbance
•
Volume overload
•
Inadequate IV access
•
Inadequate attempt to feed enterally
•
Sepsis / SIRS
•
Short illness + recovery expected
Requirements:
•
Dietician involvement
•
Calories:
o
Low calorie > high calorie feeding – most are 1kCal/mL
▪
Start 8 – 10kCal/kg/day
▪
Goal: 25kCal/kg/day i.e. 1mL/kg/hour
•
Protein:
o
Mild illness: 1g/kg/day
o
Severe illness: 1.5g/kg/day
o
Burns: 2g/kg/day
•
Carbohydrates: min 2g/kg/day
•
Lipids: 1g/kg/day
o
Omega-6 i.e. linoleic acid ~10g/day
o
Omega-3 i.e. a-linoleic acid ~2g/day
•
Ratio: carbs:fat 70:30

title: Sepsis
text:
Sepsis
SIRS criteria - ≥2 of:
•
T <36 or >38
•
HR >90bpm
•
RR > 20 or PaCO2 <32mmHg
•
Leuks <4000 or >10,000 or >10% immature forms
Sepsis: life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection (i.e. SIRS + infection)
•
Organ dysfunction: SOFA score ≥2 (mortality risk 10%)
Septic shock: profound circulatory, cellular, and metabolic abnormalities
Pressors to maintain MAP >65 or
Lactate >2 (in absence of hypovolaemia)
Quick SOFA Score
For use outside of the ICU. Does not require lab results – clinical. Quickly identifies patients at risk of dying from sepsis at the
beside. Greater than or equal to 2 of:
•
sBP <100
•
GCS <15
•
RR >22
Should prompt immediate investigation
Surviving Sepsis Guidelines 2021:
•
Use sepsis screening tools
•
Recommends against using qSOFA cf SIRS, NEWS or MEWS as single screening tools
a. qSOFA predicts mortality and ICU stay (+ve if 2 out of 3 of RR >22, GCS <15, sBP <100)
b. qSOFA and SIRS yield different results – must know limitations
•
Measure lactate: lactate if elevated
•
Immediate resuscitation and management
•
Hypoperfusion or septic shock:
a. 30mL/kg of crystalloid in first 3hr (balanced crystalloid > normal saline)
i. Albumin if large volumes of crystalloid used (advise against starches, gelatin)
ii. Insufficient evidence for liberal or restrictive fluid strategy in first 24hr
b. MAP 65
c.
Haemodynamic measurement > physical examination or static parameters
d. Use cap refill to guide resuscitation as adjunct to other measures
e. Admit to ICU within 6hr
f.
High
•
If unconfirmed infection – continuously re-evaluate for other cause
•
Antibiotics
a. Septic shock + high likelihood of infection → immediate antibiotics (within 1hr of recognition)
b. Sepsis without shock: rapid evaluation – if concern for infection persists administer antibiotics within 3hr
c.
Low likelihood of infection – do not administer antibiotics
d. Advise against using procalcitonin to decide on commencing antimicrobials
i. If optimal duration of antibiotic therapy is unclear procalcitonin can be used in conjunction with
clinical evaluation to decide on appropriate discontinuation (over clinical evaluation alone)
e. Known or high risk MRSA use empiric + MRSA coverage (low risk don’t cover for MRSA)
f.
High risk of MDR suggest two antimicrobials with gram -ve coverage (low risk use one agent)
g.
High risk of fungal infection administer empiric fungal therapy (low risk don’t cover for fungal infection)
h. No recommendation on use of antivirals
i.
For sepsis or septic shock suggest prolonged infusion of beta-lactam after initial bolus > further boluses
j.
Daily assessment and de-escalation
•
Source control:
o
Recommend identifying any infection that requires source control
o
Prompt removal of IV access if possible source
▪
Midline < pIVC < PICC < tunnelled CVC < art line < CVC < PAC
•
Pressors: start peripherally if no CVC
o
1st line: norad
o
If norad inadequate add vasopressin (advise against terlipressin)
o
Cardiac dysfunction despite above consider: norad + dobutamine or adrenaline alone
▪
Advise against levosimenden

title: Sepsis
text:
o
If ongoing pressors required give IV corticosteroids
•
Arterial line insertion
•
Ventilation:
a. No recommendation on restrictive FiO2 if hypoxaemic
b. HFNP > NIV
c.
No recommendation for NIV v ETT (patient dependent)
•
ARDS: ARDSnet lung protective ventilation
•
Recommendations against:
a. Polymyxin B haemoperfusion
b. IVIg
c.
Vitamin C
d. Sodium bicarb
i. Only if shock + pH <7.2 + AKI
•
Recommendations for:
a. Stress ulcer prophylaxis
b. Pharmacological DVT prophylaxis unless CI (LMWH > unfractionated heparin)
i. Recommend against pharmacological + mechanical
c.
CRRT > IHD
d. Initiating insulin therapy at BSL >10mM
e. Enteral nutrition if not CI
f.
Early discussion re: goals of care with family <72hr
g.
Integration of palliative care principles where appropriate to address suffering + formal palliative care consult
h. Screen families for economic and social support
i.
Written education for families + integration into shared decision making
j.
Survivors →
i. Referral to peer support groups
ii. Comprehensive discharge information
iii. Support + follow up for impairments
iv. Follow up for physical, cognitive and emotional issues post discharge
v. Rehabilitation if ventilated for >48hr or in ICU for >72hr

title: Shock
text:
Shock
State of cellular / tissue hypoxia due to either:
•
O2 delivery
•
O2 consumption
•
Inadequate O2 utilisation
•
Or combination of above
Epidemiology:
•
Hypovolaemic
36%
•
Septic
33%
•
Cardiogenic
29%
•
Other
2%
Causes:
•
Distributive: septic versus non-septic
•
Cardiogenic: cardiomyopathic, arrhythmia, mechanical
•
Hypovolaemic: haemorrhagic versus non-haemorrhagic
•
Obstructive: pulmonary vascular, mechanical (eg tension, tamponade, abdominal compartment syndrome, aortocaval
compression)
•
Other:
o
Endocrine: adrenal insufficiency, thyrotoxicosis
o
Metabolic: severe acidosis, hypothermia
Variable +
Measurement
Preload
PCWP
Pump Function
CO / CI
Afterload
SVR
Tissue Perfusion
SVO2
Hypovolaemic



<65%
Cardiogenic



>65%
Distributive

 or 

>65%
Obstructive



>65%
Tamponade



<65%
Cellular
-
-
-
>65%
Stages:
•
Compensated (pre-shock)
•
Decompensated (shock) – evidence of organ dysfunction
•
Progressive / irreversible: organ damage, multiorgan failure, death

title: Cardiogenic Shock
text:
Cardiogenic Shock
Definition:
•
CI <2.2
•
PCWP >15mmHg (LV)
•
CVP > 10mmHg (RV)
•
CVO2 <65%
•
SVR
Mechanism:
•
LV failure: large infarct (≥40% of LV), small infarct + pre-existing dysfunction, infarct extension, re-infarction
•
Mechanical complication: acute MR (papillary rupture or dysfunction), VSD, LV free wall rupture, pericardial tamponade
•
RV infarction
Ix:
•
Full bloods + trops
•
12-lead ECG
•
TTE +/- TOE
•
CXR +/- angiogram
Management:
•
A/B: may require NIV for pulmonary oedema + LV afterload +/- intubation
•
C:
o
Resuscitation: treat hypo / hypervolaemia
o
Blood pressure support: norad, vasopressin
o
Afterload reduction if not hypotensive: GTN, SNiP
o
Inotrope: dobutamine, adrenaline, milrinone, levosimendan
o
Mechanical support: IABP, ECMO
o
Monitoring: PiCCO line, PAC, arterial line, CVP
o
MI: DAPT load
o
Revascularisation: PCI, CAGS, thrombolysis

title: Cardiac Output Monitoring
text:
Cardiac Output Monitoring
Cardiac output: volume of blood ejected from heart per unit time (flow cf pressure, usually L/min) – normal value ~5L/min
