Thermodilution is via right heart catheterisation is currently the gold standard method
PA catheter (PAC):
•
Inserted in IJ or subclavian veins → floated through RA → RV → PA
•
Proximal lumen ideally opens in RA– monitors CVP or used to administer injectate
•
Another lumen contains 2x insulated wires → thermistor ~3.7cm from catheter tip (proximally connected to CO
processor)
Mechanism:
•
Distal balloon filled with 1.5mL – catheter ‘sails’
•
Distal lumen attached to pressure transducer – monitors waveforms as PAC advanced
•
Mean pressure of 4-12mmHg indicates PCWP (surrogate for LA filling pressure) → balloon deflated and catheter floats
back into PA
•
10mL of cold normal saline (injectate) administered in proximal lumen → temperature-time curve as detected by
thermistor → calculation of CO (usually mean of three readings taken)
o
↑CO → quicker “washout” of cold fluid
Modification of indicator dilution technique, instead of dye, cold fluid with known temp and heat capacity known.
Mathematical derivation:
•
Single compartment model (the heart) ∴ clearance = dose / AUC
o
Dose = heat from indictor
o
AUC = area under temp-time curve
∴ CO = clearance = volume x (Tinjectate – Tblood) / area under temp-time curve (Stewart Hamilton equation for thermodilution)
Sources of Error
•
Measurement: thermistor, dead-space of line, calculation errors
•
Assumptions:
o
Injectate and blood have same density and heat capacity
o
Thermal equilibrium established by time mixture reaches thermistor
o
Injectate is warmed by blood (not true in low flow states, also warmed by wall of vessels / myocardium)
o
Unidirectional flow of blood (untrue in TR)
o
Cold injectate doesn’t depress CO (may transiently)
Advantages
•
Easy to repeat
•
No blood sampling
•
No toxic dye
•
No recirculation error (cf dye-dilution, lithium)
Disadvantages
•
Invasive – risks associated with PAC insertion
•
Cold fluid can cause cardiac depression, arrhythmias
•
Fluid load (though small)

title: HFNP
text:
HFNP
Triad:
•
Humidification
•
High FiO2
•
Improved compliance
Features & effects:
•
Warmed humidified gas:
o
Reduced airway surface dehydration
o
Improved secretion clearance
•
Gas flow up to 60L/min
o
CO2 washout, anatomical dead space
o
O2 reservoir
o
Allows FiO2 close to 1.0 to be delivered
•
Provides PEEP (variable, relies on closed mouth breathing)
o
end expiratory lung volume
o
Alveolar recruitment
Indications:
•
Acute hypoxic respiratory failure
o
FLORALI:
▪
HFNP can intubation rates in non-cardiogenic ARF with P:F ratio <200 (no difference >200)
▪
mortality (ICU and 90 days)
o
Particular benefits: pts with high secretions, cardiogenic pulmonary oedema
•
Apnoeic oxygenation
•
Post-op hypoxaemia (2’ derecruitment, atelectasis, altered mechanics from pain)
Other potential benefits: ICU bronch, palliative care
Tips:
•
Start lower flows (25L/min) and 31°C for the first 15 min → improves patient compliance
•
Titrate temp to 34-37°C in first half an hour to maximise therapeutic benefit
CI:
•
Severe type 1 or type 2 resp failure requiring mechanical ventilation
•
CI to PEEP
•
Epistaxis
•
Facial injury
•
Airway obstruction

title: ARDS
text:
ARDS
Acute, diffuse, inflammatory lung injury leading to increased pulmonary vascular permeability, lung weight and loss of aerated
tissue
Diagnostic criteria – Berlin criteria:
•
Acute (triggering insult within 7 days)
•
Bilateral process (opacity on CXR not due to lung collapse, effusion or nodules)
•
Hypoxaemia with PEEP ≥5cmH2O
o
Mild: PaO2:FiO2 ≤300 mmHg
o
Mod: PaO2:FiO2 ≤200 mmHg
o
Severe: PaO2:FiO2 <100 mmHg
•
Not caused by cardiac pathology (no obvious cause on echo)
Stages:
•
Exudative: 0-7 days
•
Proliferative: 7-14 days
•
Fibrotic: 14+ days
Risk & progression
Mild
Moderate
Severe
%
30%
45%
25%
Risk of progression
25%
12.5%
N/A
ICU mortality
30%
35%
45%
Hospital mortality
ICU mortality + 5%
Surviving Sepsis Ventilation Guidelines for ARDS + sepsis:
•
Vt 6mL/kg IBW
•
Plateau pressure <30cmH2O: barotrauma → pneumomediastinum, PTx, pneumopericardium, pulmonary interstitial
emphysema, systemic air embolism
•
Higher PEEP > lower PEEP: PEEP atelectotrauma → alveolar collapse, recruitment, shifts fluid into interstitium,
TLV/FRC, shunt, improved V:Q matching
o
Use ARDSNET tables
o
Effect of PEEP on ICP is minimal (difference in ICP with PEEP 0 → 25cmH2O is <5mmHg
o
Beware of paradoxical hypoxia due to creation of ‘West Zone 1’ with high PEEP
•
Traditional recruitment manoeuvres (recommend against incremental PEEP titration / strategy)
•
Mod – severe ARDS prone for 12 hours daily
•
Intermittent NMBA > continuous infusion
•
VV ECMO when conventional mechanical ventilation fails
Oxygenation:
•
Mean airway pressure can be  by i-time (same peak pressure)
•
May CO2 clearance +/- gas trap
Permissive hypercapnia:
•
Potential harms of ventilating to paCO2 may outweigh permissive hypercapnia
•
ARDSNET aim was pH >7.3 but even with significant hypercapnia (respiratory acidosis pH 7.2) patients still had better
mortality outcome than traditional ventilation group (unless hypercapnia harmful for other reasons i.e. raised ICP)
•
Max RR 35, if pH <7.1 Vt by 1mL/kg
Paralysis:
•
Pros: MRO2 → acidosis, spont breathing (desynchrony, volutrauma), chest wall compliance
•
Cons: critical illness myopathy, longer vent wean, pressure injuries, awareness/PTSD, DVT/PE
Positioning:
•
Supine: 45 degrees head up → lower leads to more VAP, higher leads to worse pressure injuries
•
Prone (relieves weight of mediastinum + improves V:Q mismatch): NNT 6, fewer cardiac arrests, though risk pressure
injury and airway pressures
o
Effect of PEEP in prone dependent on patient pathology – may recruit or may worsening V:Q mismatch
Severity: P:F ratio
•
Mild:
200 – 300
•
Mod:
100 – 200
•
Severe: <100

title: ARDS
text:
ARDS management:
•
Treat underlying cause
•
Empiric antibiotics covering bacterial pneumonia
•
Ventilation per above
•
Neuromuscular blockade:
o
ACURASYS: 24 – 48hr of continuous cisatracurium in mod-severe ARDS has significant 90-day mortality benefit
•
Enteral feeding if possible
•
DVT prophylaxis
•
Stress ulcer prophylaxis
•
Glucocorticoids
•
Restrictive fluid therapy
•
Rescue therapy:
o
Prone: PROSEVA 16hr / day → improved all-cause mortality at 28 days
o
Recruitment
o
Inhaled vasodilators
o
ECMO
EOLIA: severe ARDS early initiation of VV-ECMO (<D7) showed no statistical difference in mortality cf conventional ventilation at
day 60
•
ECMO group:
o
Less treatment failure
o
risk CRRT
o
More severe thrombocytopaenia
o
More bleeding events
o
Less ischaemic stroke
Vent strategy for VV ECMO to aid lung recovery: RR, Vt (<4mL/kg), low FiO2, Pplat, long I time, PEEP 5 - 15
APRV:
•
Pressure control mode of ventilation – almost continuous positive pressure, short releases at lower pressure
o
P high: plateau pressure <30cmH2O
o
P low: 0cmH2O
o
T high: 5s (recruits slow time constant areas)
o
T-low: 0.5s → check low enough to terminate at 75% of peak exp flow during pressure release breath – if too
low reduce the time
•
Longer I time → mean airway pressure → oxygenation
o
Maximises recruitment
•
Brief releases clear Co2: tolerate
hypercapnoea (pH >7.25)
•
Spontaneous breathing on top is encouraged
(stop paralysis, wean sedation)
•
Considerations:
o
CVS effects of intrathoracic pressure
o
Raised ICP relative CI
•
Not a substitute for prone positioning (for
which there is robust evidence in severe ARDS)
– can be instituted in addition
Advantages of APRV:
•
Improved O2 at lower airway pressures
•
Improved V:Q matching
•
Reduced sedation; enables spont venting
•
Reduced haemodynamic compromise

title: Severe Asthma
text:
Severe Asthma
Pathophysiology:
•
airflow resistance 2’ bronchial SM constriction, mucosal oedema / inflammation, mucous plugging
•
intrathoracic pressure → WOB, preload, afterload
•
Depletion of endogenous catecholamines
•
Dehydration
Management:
•
Supplemental O2 as required
•
Treat underlying cause / trigger
•
Bronchodilator therapy:
o
Salbutamol inhaled
o
Inhaled muscarinic antagonist
o
Magnesium sulfate 2g over 20 mins
•
Glucocorticoids:
o
Prednisone
o
Hydrocortisone
•
Rescue:
o
Volatile anaesthetics
o
Ketamine
o
IV beta agonists: salbutamol, adrenaline, terbutaline
o
Heliox
•
BiPAP for WOB as bridge to intubation
•
ECMO if unable to ventilate / oxygenate
Ventilation strategy:
•
Induction agent: ketamine + rocuronium
•
Most experienced airway operator
•
Pre-oxygenation
•
Induce upright, supine once unconscious
•
Largest possible diameter ETT
•
Indication: impending respiratory arrest, 3-5% of presentations require intubation
Ventilation:
•
RR 10-12
•
Vt 6-8mL/kg
•
I:E at least 1:3
•
PEEP <80% iPEEP, target iPEEP <10cmH2O
•
FiO2 titrated to PaO2 >60mmHg
•
Mode SIMV
•
Permissive hypercapnoea
•
Inspiratory flow 60L/min
•
Measure pPlat, target <30cmH2O
Trouble-shooting:
•
High peak airway pressures: important to do plateau pressure as most pressure is used to overcome upper airway
obstruction
•
Desynchrony: ineffective triggering, cough, low inspiratory flow rate, inadequate sedation – consider paralysis
•
Dynamic hyperinflation: CV collapse, barotrauma, WOB → temporarily disconnect ventilator
•
Pneumothorax
Try:
•
tidal volume → I time and E time
•
RR → E time
•
Optimise trigger sensitivity
•
inspiratory flow rate → I time and E time

title: Pulmonary Embolism
text:
Pulmonary Embolism
Classification:
•
High risk (massive): with haemodynamic instability
•
Intermediate risk (sub-massive): evidence of RV strain
o
Intermediate-high: trop rise
o
Intermediate-low: no trop rise
•
Low risk: no evidence of RV strain
Pathophysiology:
•
Infarction
•
VQ mismatch
•
PVR
Risk stratification: Well’s score
Ix:
•
Imaging: CT-PA, lower limb dopplers
•
ECG
•
TTE if concerns for RV strain
•
Bloods: FBC, ABG, trop
•
Stratify risk of bleeding
Treatment:
•
Respiratory support
•
CVS support including mechanical (i.e. ECMO)
•
Anticoagulation
o
Thrombolysis in high risk
o
UFH or clexane
o
Transition to PO anticoagulation
If anticoagulation CI:
•
Catheter directed thrombolysis
•
Embolectomy
•
IVC filter

title: VAP
text:
VAP
Definition:
•
Mechanical ventilation ≥48 hours
•
New or progressive infiltrate
•
SSx infection
•
+ve resp specimens (neutrophils or positive growth)
Features:
•
Clinical: fever, tachypnoea, sputum production, haemoptysis, rhonchi / crackles, reduced breath sounds,
bronchospasm
•
Ventilator: Vt, airway pressures (i.e. compliance)
•
Ix: PaO2, A-a gradient, WCC
•
Imaging: new/progressive infiltrate
•
Resp tract cultures: suction, mini-BAL, BAL
•
Blood culture
Common pathogens:
•
Staph aureus, Pseudomonas, Gram -ve bacilli, Enterobacter
Risk factors: mechanical ventilation, age, chronic lung disease, aspiration, surgery, gastric pH (PPI, H2Ra), antibiotic exposure,
ARDS, ventilator circuit changes, trauma, paralysis, glucocorticoids, ICP monitor, malnutrition, renal failure
Prevention:
•
NIV > intubation
•
Minimise transport of ventilated patient
•
Early weaning / extubation
•
Minimise sedation / paralysis
•
Elevate head of bed 30-45 degrees
•
Maintain circuit
•
Physiotherapy
•
Suction around cuff
•
Maintain cuff pressure 20-30cmH2O
Treatment:
•
Obtain cultures before antibiotics if possible
•
Tazocin / cefepime for 7 days – involve ID
•
MRSA – vancomycin
•
Gram -ve resistance: gentamicin

title: Bronchoscopy in ICU
text:
Bronchoscopy in ICU
Types:
•
Rigid: useful for massive haemoptysis, removal of large foreign body, dilatation, stents
•
Flexible
Indications for flexible bronch:
•
Aspiration: bronch with lavage rarely helpful, but may help if large particulate matter
•
Infection
o
BAL:
▪
No evidence over something less invasive i.e. blind catheter brushings
▪
PCP: gold standard
•
Lobar collapse: local directed suctioning + saline / mucolytics (e.g. NAC)
•
Assessment of airway e.g. injury
•
Aid in techniques for OLV
•
Haemorrhage (diagnosis, management)
CI:
•
Inexperienced personnel
•
Inadequate facilities, equipment
•
Inability to oxygenate and ventilate the patient
Optimise as much as able prior
Complications: safe, mortality 0.01%
•
ECG changes
•
5% mortality within 30 days of MI
•
Raised ICP
Procedure:
•
ETT: >2mm diameter than bronch
•
Aspirate NG / fasting
•
Sedation
•
FiO2 100%
•
Volume target, pressure-limiting mode
•
Adequate sterilisation / decontamination of bronch
•
BAL: 60 – 180mL normal saline + suctioned
•
Brushings: cytological diagnosis – malignancy, infection
•
Biopsy: rarely done in ICU

title: Tracheostomy
text:
Tracheostomy
Indications:
•
Acute respiratory failure with prolonged mechanical ventilation ≥7 days and expected to make a meaningful recovery
o
Facilitates weaning of ventilator and sedation
•
Upper airway obstruction
•
Airway protection i.e. post-op, neuromuscular disease
•
Need for more effective pulmonary hygiene
CI:
•
Unstable C-spine (need to extend neck)
•
Uncontrolled coagulopathy
•
Infection @ insertion site
•
Difficult anatomy
•
Unable to withstand period of apnoea
Technique:
•
Open
•
Percutaneous
Location: between 2nd and 3rd tracheal rings
Procedure:
•
Extend neck
•
Paralyse and sedate
•
Bronchoscopic vision of trachea
•
Deflate ETT cuff and withdraw under vision
•
Insert needle into trachea under bronch vision
•
Guidewire / Seldinger
•
Dilate
•
Insert trache tube
•
Remove sheath, wire and trocar
•
Inflate trache cuff
•
Connect to trache circuit
•
Confirm with capnography + bronchoscope
•
Secure trache
•
Remove ETT
Post-procedure care:
•
Do not change until ≥7 days after
•
Cuff pressure 20-30cmH2O
•
Inner cannula cleaned and replaced q4 hourly
•
Dressing change q24 hours
•
Change Velcro ties every 7 days
•
PRN suctioning: replace fenestrated with non-fenestrated inner cannula prior to suctioning (can cause severe tracheal
damage)
Complications:
•
Early: bleeding, obstruction, dislodgement, subcut emphysema / pneumothorax
•
Late: trachea-inominate fistula, trachea-oesophageal fistula, tracheal stenosis, phonation
De-cannulation:
•
Indications: weaned from MV, no upper airway obstruction, ability to clear secretions, effective cough
•
Technique: progressive decrease in size, cuff deflation trials until tolerating 24 – 48 hours

title: Tracheostomy Emergency
text:
Tracheostomy Emergency
Issues:
•
Patient not breathing:
o
Change fenestrated inner cannula for non-fenestrated
o
Check patency with suction catheter
o
Inflate cuff if deflated
o
Only ventilate if able to pass suction catheter
•
Obstructed trache:
o
Causes: occluded inner cannula, occluded trache, cuff herniation, dislodgement, kinked, anatomical
abnormality
o
Change cannula (non-fenestrated)
o
Attempt to suction
o
Apply O2: trache, mouth, laryngectomy stoma
•
Tracheostomy bleed:
o
Inflate cuff
o
Apply O2
o
Suction
o
Apply gauze
•
Accidental decannulation:
o
≤7 days: cover and apply O2 from above
o
>7 days: reconsider recannulation

title: Acute Renal Failure
text:
Acute Renal Failure
KDIGO classification: combination of RIFLE and AKIN
Stage
Serum Cr
UO Criteria
Cr 1.5 – 1.9x from baseline over 24 hr
OR
26μmol/L over 48 hr
<0.5mL/kg/hr for 6 – 12 hr
Cr 2.0 – 3.0x
<0.5mL/kg/hr for >12 hr
Cr 2.0 – 3.0x
OR
Cr up to 354μmol/L
OR
Initiation of CRRT
<0.3mL/kg/hr
OR
Anuria for 12 hr
Pre-Renal
Renal
Post-Renal
•
Hypovolaemia
•
Heart failure
•
Hepatorenal syndrome
•
Drugs: NSAIDs, IV contrast,
ACEi/ARB (all cause altered
regulation)
o
If high risk AKI use low-osmolar
contrast
•
Intrinsic vascular: vasculitis, MAHA,
TTP/HUS, scleroderma, athero-
embolic, malignant hypertension,
aortic dissection, acute renal vein
thrombosis
•
Intrinsic glomerular:
o
Primary idiopathic
glomerulonephritis
o
Secondary: anti-GBM,
granulomatosis with
polyangiitis, SLE, IgA/HSP,
infection / post-strep,
complement mediated, drugs
•
Intrinsic tubular / interstitial:
ischaemia, nephrotoxic drugs,
tumour lysis syndrome
•
Obstruction of any cause i.e.
prostate, cancer, retroperitoneal
Investigations:
•
History
•
Medications ?drug cause
•
UA: microscopy, protein:Cr ratio, sediment – red cells / casts
•
Renal tract US
•
Non-con CT
•
Bladder scan
•
Renal biopsy
•
Other: serum protein electrophoresis (myeloma), serology (autoimmune)

title: CRRT
text:
Indications for dialysis:
•
A: acidaemia pH <7.1
•
E: electrolytes i.e. K >6.5 or >5.5 and expected to rise
•
I: intoxication i.e. acute poisoning
•
O: overload / oedema
•
U: uraemic complications – pericarditis, encephalopathy
Management:
•
Stop nephrotoxic agents: avoid aminoglycosides if alternative available
•
Correct hypotension / hypovolaemia / hypervolaemia
o
Avoid IVF if overloaded or anuric
o
Overloaded and not anuric:
▪
Frusemide 80mg IV or double usual dose (dose 1/ GFR)
▪
Diuretics should not be used unless treating overload
o
CRRT
o
Daily weights + strict fluid balance
•
HyperPO4: binders
•
HypoCa2+: phosphate binders, measure iCa, IV calcium replacement
•
Acidaemia: NaHCO3, CRRT
•
Nutrition: restrict K, PO4, and Na, dietician review, 30kCal/kg/day

title: CRRT
text:
CRRT
Features:
•
Circuit runs continuously
•
Slow blood flow rate 100 – 200mL/min
•
Slow dialysate flow 1000 – 2000mL/hour (up to 3000)
•
Dialysate fluid bags
No proven advantage of CRRT > SLED, IHD
Theoretical advantage:
•
Continuous like kidneys
•
Haemodynamic stability
Minor disadvantages:
•
Inefficient dialysis: low counter-current
•
Anticoagulation required
•
Immobility – confined to bedspace
•
Hypothermia
•
nursing workload
•
cost
Anticoagulation:
•
No anticoagulation (if severe coagulopathy, liver failure, thrombocytopaenia)
•
Anticoagulation:
o
Systemic: heparin (CI in HITS)
o
Regional:
▪
Citrate/calcium: avoid if liver disease
•
Must monitor iCa
▪
Heparin/protamine: if citrate toxicity or CI
Starting:
•
Early not superior to delayed in AKI
•
CRRT dose = effluent rate
o
25mL/kg/hour
Citrate Toxicity
Features:
•
HAGMA or metabolic alkalosis
•
Low iCa with high/normal total calcium
Management:
•
Give calcium
•
Decrease citrate dose
•
Decrease blood flow rate
•
Change anticoagulant

title: CRRT
text:
Terminology:
•
CVVHD: diffusive dialysis (movement of solutes from high [] to low [] across semi-permeable membrane)
•
CVVHF: convective dialysis (movement of molecules through semipermeable membrane associated with fluid loss via
ultrafiltration)
•
CVVHDF: high ultrafiltration rate + diffusion. Replacement fluid added.

title: Rhabdomyolysis
text:
Rhabdomyolysis
Muscle necrosis with release of intracellular components.
Causes:
•
Traumatic: crush injury, prolonged immobilisation, compartment syndrome, ischaemia / reperfusion, electrocution
•
Non-traumatic
o
Exertional: extreme exertion, metabolic myopathy, heat stroke, seizures, psychosis / amphetamines, malignant
hyperthermia, NMS
o
Non-exertional:
▪
Drugs: statins, colchicine, dapto, MH, drug induced agitation / immobilisation
▪
Toxins: envenomation
▪
Infection / sepsis
▪
Endocrine: DKA, HHS, thyroid
▪
Inflammatory myopathy
Presentation: muscle pain, weakness, dark urine
Exam: muscle tenderness / swelling, induration / skin changes, hypovolaemia
Ix:
•
Serum:
o
CK: 5x ULN (>1500)
o
LFTs
o
AKI
o
PO4
o
Hypocalcaemia early, hypercalcaemia late
▪
Avoid replacing calcium, may exacerbate muscle injury
o
Hyperuricaemia
o
HAGMA
o
DIC if severe
•
Urine: myoglobinuria, proteinuria
•
ECG: hyperK+
Management:
•
Identify / treat cause
•
Identify / monitor / treat compartment syndrome
•
Correct electrolyte abnormalities
o
Allopurinol for hyperuricaemia
o
HyperK+
•
Prevent AKI: start fluids <6 hours if possible
o
Correct hypovolaemia:
▪
1-2L/hour if CK >5000
▪
Monitor volume status
▪
Loop diuretics for hypervolaemia
▪
IDC for UO monitoring
o
Prevent intratubular cast formation
▪
urine flow rate
▪
Target UO 200 – 300mL/hour (>3mL/kg/hour)
▪
Forced alkaline diuresis with sodium bicarb
•
No good evidence for this, but probably not harmful
•
Dialysis removes myoglobin – high-permeability membrane filter (even if not available standard CVVHDF AKI)

title: Renal Transplant
text:
Renal Transplant
Pre-op:
•
Indication + comorbidities + optimise
•
Haemodialysis: modality, frequency, access
•
Ix:
o
Bloods: FBC, EUC, LFTs, HbA1c, coags, G&H, iron studies
▪
EPO + iron if indicated
o
ECG: 12-lead
o
TTE only if indicated
•
Continue regular mediations unless CI
•
Manage anxiety
•
Consent
Immediately pre-op:
•
Organise pre-op haemodialysis check post-dialysis acid-base status + potassium + urea
•
Check volume of ultrafiltrate
Intra-op:
•
IV access: avoid forearm (in case future need for AV fistula)
•
Monitoring: ANZCA routine + 5 lead ECG + temp
o
Art line only if indicated
o
NIBP on non-fistula arm
•
ETT:
o
Modified RSI if gastric emptying (uraemia + diabetic neuropathy) – can use roc + sugammadex
o
No RSI: cisatracurium
•
CVC: CVP aim 8-12mmHg
•
Fluid: balanced crystalloid – aim ~1.5L prior to transplantation (avoid tubular necrosis)
•
Immunosuppression: prior to implant anastomosis
o
Methylpred: 500mg IV
o
Basiliximab 20mg IV
o
If high risk: thymoglobulin 1mg/kg
•
Frusemide (surgeon discretion)
•
Analgesia: paracetamol +
o
Pre-incision TAP blocks (risk of injury to anterior transplanted kidney)
o
Fentanyl (non-renal dependent)
•
Ensure full reversal with nerve stimulator
•
Check fistula thrill pre- & post-op - document
Post-op:
•
Monitor fluid balance + UO; IVF per renal team
•
Monitor renal function – may require dialysis
•
Fentanyl PCA + pain team review
•
Immunosuppression triple therapy: dosed by transplant team
o
Tacrolimus
o
MMF
o
Steroids
•
Other:
o
Nilstat for 1mo
o
PPI SUP for 6-12mo
o
Infection prophylaxis:
▪
PCP for 12 mo: Bactrim
▪
CMV: valganciclovir
•
VTE prophylaxis
•
Confirm CVC on CXR
Complications:
•
Acute rejection
•
Antibody mediated rejection
•
Leukopaenia
•
CMV

title: Hyponatraemia
text:
Hyponatraemia
Na <135:
•
Mild: 130 – 134
•
Mod: 120 – 129
•
Severe: <120
Chronicity:
•
Acute: <48hrs
•
Chronic: >48hrs
Evaluate:
•
Fluid status
•
Serum osmols: normal 270
•
Urine osmols
o
Low: <100mOsm/L
o
High: >100mOsm/L
•
Urine Na:
o
Low: <40mOsm/L
o
High: >40mOsm/L
Other: TFTs, LFTs, serum protein, serum TGs, VBG, random cortisol, short synacten test
SSx: ranges from nausea, confusion, thirst → vomiting, seizures, coma
Causes:
•
Hyper/iso-osmotic: sOsm >270
o
Added osmols: mannitol, BSL, lipids, TGs, post-TURP, radiocontrast, paraproteins
•
Hypoosmotic:
o
Low urine osmols:
▪
Diet: beer potomania, anorexia nervosa
▪
Psychogenic polydipsia
▪
Ecstacy
o
High urine osmols:
▪
Low urine sodium:
•
True hypovolaemia
•
CCF, cirrhosis
•
Psychogenic polydipsia
•
Ecstacy
▪
High urine sodium:
•
Cerebral salt wasting
•
SIADH
•
Diuretics
•
Adrenal insufficiency
•
Severe hypothyroidism
•
“reset osmostat”
•
Renal failure

title: Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome
text:
Fluid status
Hypovolaemic
Euvolaemic
Hypervolaemic
Causes
Renal Na+ loss:
•
Nephropathy
•
Cerebral salt wasting
•
Diuretics
•
Fluid restriction
Non-renal Na+ loss:
•
GIT
•
Sweat
SIADH
Renal, heart and liver failure
Management
Normal saline
Fluid restriction
Hypertonic saline
Fluid restriction
Diuretics
Management:
1. Determine duration (acute v chronic)
2. Determine severity
a. Signs of raised ICP (i.e. seizures, obtunded, coma, resp failure, headache, N&V, tremor, gait disturbance
confusion)
Correction:
•
Severe: rapidly raise Na+ by 4 – 6mM/L to prevent herniation
o
50-100mL bolus NaCl 3% over 10 mins
▪
Repeat up to 2 times
•
Correct Na (no signs of pre-herniation):
o
Rate:
▪
<10mM in first 24 hours
▪
Subsequently <8mM/24 hours
o
Either fluid restrict or hypertonic saline
•
Treat underlying cause
Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome
Rapid correction of sodium → rapid cellular shifts → cellular apoptosis
SSx: seizures, parkinsonism, dysarthria, quadriplegia, spastic hypertonia, coma, death, locked in
Risk factors:
•
Rapid rise in Na
•
Associated with: EtOH, liver disease, thiazides, anti-depressants
Rx:
•
Relower Na+
o
Stop sodium replacement
o
Dextrose 5%
o
Consider DDAVP

title: Hypernatraemia
text:
Hypernatraemia
Na >145
Mechanisms:
•
Whole body water loss: sweat, GIT, diabetes insipidus (central v nephrogenic), osmotic, impaired thirst mechanism
•
Water loss into cells: seizures, exercise
•
Sodium overload: iatrogenic
SSx: irritable, lethargy, seizures, coma, insulin resistance
Chronicity:
•
Acute: <48hrs
•
Chronic: >48hrs
Management:
•
Acute:
o
Replace water deficit with dextrose 5% + any ongoing losses (over 24 hours)
•
Chronic:
o
Lower by <10mM / 24 hours i.e. <0.05mM/hour
o
Dextrose 5% (~1mL/kg/hour)
Over-correction → cerebral oedema
If persistently high UO → DDAVP 0.4mcg IV q6-12hr (much less than vWD treatment)
See diabetes insipidus in neuro notes
(Causes of nephrogenic DI: lithium, congenital, hyperCa2+, hypoK+, pyelo, PCKD, post-obstructive uropathy, myeloma,
amyloid/sarcoid)

title: Metabolic Acidosis
text:
Metabolic Acidosis
pH <7.35
Mechanism:
•
acid production
•
Loss of bicarb
•
Decreased renal acid secretion
Anion gap = (Na+ + K+) – (Cl- + HCO3-)
Normal = 8 – 16 (4 – 12 if not including K+)
Correct for albumin: by 2.5 for every 10g/L below 45
Respiratory compensation: PaCO2 = 1.5 x HCO3 + 8
Delta ratio = change in anion gap / change in bicarb
i.e.
(AG – 12) / (24 – HCO3)
Because normal anion gap is 12, and normal bicarb is 24
Delta ratio:
•
0.4 = NAGMA
•
0.4-1.0: mixed HAGMA / NAGMA
•
>1.0 = HAGMA
•
>2.0 = HAGMA with pre-existing metabolic alkalosis
Causes:
•
HAGMA:
o
Lactic acidosis
o
Ketoacidosis
o
Ingestion: EtOH, methanol, ethylene glycol, aspirin / salicylates, toluene, paracetamol, metformin, propylene
glycol
o
Severe renal failure (urea)
•
NAGMA / hyperchloraemic MA
o
HCO3- loss: diarrhoea, type 2 RTA, carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, uretal diversion
o
renal acid excretion: mod renal failure, type 1 or type 4 RTA
o
Normal saline / Cl-

title: Metabolic Alkalosis
text:
Metabolic Alkalosis
Causes:
•
GIT H+ loss:
o
Vomiting or high NG aspirates (e.g. contraction alkalosis)
o
Congenital chloride diarrhoea
•
Renal H+ loss:
o
Primary mineralcorticoid excess
▪
Conn’s syndrome (i.e. primary hypoaldosteronism)
▪
Cushing syndrome
▪
Exogenous
o
Loop or thiazide diuretics
o
Bartter syndrome (NaCl resorption in LoH)
o
Gitelman syndrome (NaCl resorption in DCT)
o
Post-chronic hypercapnia
o
Licorice
o
Liddle syndrome
•
Severe hypoK+ with intracellular H+ shift
o
Villous adenoma
o
Laxative abuse
•
Alkali administration
o
Calcium alkali
o
HCO3
o
Citrated blood products
•
Contraction alkalosis
Respiratory compensation: PaCO2 = 0.7 x HCO3 + 20

title: Guillain Barre
text:
Guillain Barre
Acute demyelinating polyneuropathy
SSx:
•
Monophasic i.e. continues to worsen
•
Ascending symmetrical weakness (flaccid areflexic paralysis)
•
CN involvement
•
Autonomic instability
•
Sensory sparing
Likely autoimmune, usually follows prodrome (e.g. respiratory, gastrointestinal or viral infection)
Lack of fever at onset
Monitoring: ICU not always needed
•
Spirometry / PFTs: suggestive of resp function
o
FVC <20mL/kg
o
PEF <250L/min
o
Max insp pressure <30cmH2O
o
Max exp pressure <40cmH2O
Ix:
•
LP: protein
•
Imaging: mainly helpful to rule out other causes
•
NCS: velocity and prolonged distal latencies
Miller-Fisher Syndrome:
•
Ophthalmoplegia
•
Areflexia
•
Ataxia
Ix: possible antiganglioside GM1 antibodies
Rx: supportive +/-
•
Plasma exchange: usually 5 sessions
•
IVIg
No evidence for:
•
Steroids
•
Early tracheostomy
Neuromuscular +
o
Severe lower back pain – adequate analgesia
o
Mechanical ventilation: FVC <20mL/kg, bulbar involvement, resp failure on blood gases
o
Labile BP due to autonomic instability, sensitive to vasopressors

title: Encephalitis & Meningitis
text:
Encephalitis & Meningitis
30% mortality.
Determining organism - consider:
•
Geographical location
•
Immune status
Meningitis
Encephalitis
Definition
Inflammation of meninges
Inflammation of brain
SSx
Fever, headache, neck stiffness, altered mental
status (95% will have 2 / 4) +/- focal deficits
Rash associated with Neisseria meningitidis
Fever, headache, altered mental state, focal deficits,
seizures
Causes
•
Bacterial:
o
Streptococcus pneumoniae main cause in
adults (risk factors HIV, hyposplenism, EtOH,
chronic liver / kidney disease)
o
Neisseria meningitidis (main organism in
adolescents)
o
Others: Listeria, Staph aureus
•
Viral: less severe
o
Most common: enterovirus, HSV, VZV
Causes:
•
Infectious
•
Post-infectious
•
Auto-immune
Treatment
Bacterial meningitis:
•
Medical emergency
•
Initiate treatment within 1 hour – do not delay
therapy for diagnostic interventions
•
Abx choice based on likely organisms, local
resistance patterns, and age of patient
•
Steroids: hearing loss, neurological sequelae
•
Therapeutic hypothermia not recommended
•
Insufficient evidence: prophylactic anti-
epileptics, hyper-osmolar therapy
Start treatment within 6hr – ideally after CSF
sampling and neuroimaging.
Ix:
•
Blood cultures within 1hr presentation – very useful if LP is CI
•
Imaging: imaging prior to LP if concerns for ICP
o
Indications: focal deficits, papilloedema, seizures, GCS <12
•
LP:
o
CSF lactate useful for bacterial v viral – lactate <2mM essentially rules out bacterial disease
o
CI to LP: ICP, bradycardia/HTN, focal neuro signs, abnormal posturing, pupil pathology, papilloedema, shock,
doll’s eye movements, extensive purpura, abnormal coags, local infection at LP site, compromised resp fx
•
HIV test
•
EEG if concern for seizure activity

title: Tetanus
text:
Tetanus
Clostridium tetani:
•
Obligate anaerobic, spore-forming Gram-positive bacillus
•
Tetanus spores enter the body through contaminated trauma
•
Incubation period of 3 - 21 days, bacteria divide and release tetanus toxin
•
Travels from peripheries to spinal cord → inhibits neurotransmitter release
SSx:
•
First signs: stiff neck, sore throat, trismis
•
Other: muscle rigidity, spasms, autonomic dysfunction
•
Risk of apnoea from laryngospasm or chest wall rigidity
Resp failure leading cause of death
Diagnosis:
•
Largely clinical
•
Spatula test – induced masseter spasm
•
Wound culture may grow 30% of time
•
Serum antitoxin level: low levels demonstrate susceptibility
Treatment:
•
ABCs
•
Disable toxin: immunisation (toxin already within CNS will have no effect)
•
Kill bacteria: metronidazole + benpen
•
Surgical debridement
•
Control spasms: paralysis or benzo infusion
•
SNS: labetalol, MgSO4

title: Botulism
text:
Botulism
Clostridium botulinum:
•
Ubiquitous, obligate anaerobe, spore- forming Gram-positive bacillus
•
Anaerobic environment → spores germinate and grow into exotoxin-producing bacteria
•
Botulinum toxin enters presynaptic nerve cells of voluntary muscles and ANS
•
Prevent ACh release
SSx:
•
CN palsies
•
Descending symmetrical flaccid paralysis characteristic of botulism (prox before distal)
o
Consider if MG or Guillain barre a possibility
Diagnosis:
•
Afebrile
•
Acute onset of one of: vision changes, difficulty speaking, change of voice, secretion issues, thick tongue
•
Signs at least one of: ptosis, extraocular palsy, facial paresis, pixed pupils, descending paralysis
•
Lab test for toxin (gold standard is mouse bioassay)
Management:
•
ABCs
•
Antitoxin
•
Wound debridement
•
Vaccination (high risk only)
•
No evidence for any drugs other than antitoxin including abx, cholinergics

title: GI Haemorrhage
text:
GI Haemorrhage
Causes:
•
Variceal:
•
Non-variceal:
o
Ulcerative
o
Mass lesion
o
Vascular
o
Traumatic
Ix:
•
History: haematemesis (frank v coffee ground), melaena, haematochezia
•
Examination: volume status
•
Ix: full bloods + G&H
o
Urea:Cr ratio >30
•
Endoscopy
Management: No role for TXA
•
Resus + ABCs + correct coagulopathy
•
Specific:
o
Acid suppression: pantoprazole 80mg IV load then 8mg/hour (or BD dosing)
o
Source control:
▪
Endoscopy
▪
CT angiography / angioembolisation
▪
Double-balloon enterscopy
▪
SB tube
Variceal Bleeding
Management: (above +)
•
Pharmacological
o
Octreotide 50mcg loading then 50mcg / hour (same as carcinoid)
o
Terlipressin 2mg IV q4 hourly
o
Correct coagulopathy
o
Cirrhosis: prophylactic antibiotics – ceftriaxone (mortality, SBP, rebleeding)
•
Procedural:
o
Banding
o
Sclerotherapy
o
Cryoacrylate injection
o
TIPS
o
Emergency shunt surgery
Peptic Ulcer Disease
Management: (above +)
•
Octreotide if refractory, of endoscopy CI, or delayed (50mcg
then 25mcg/hour)
•
Intervention:
o
Endoscopic:
▪
Grade Ia to IIb have high re-bleeding risk →
treat
▪
Dilute adrenaline injection
▪
Thermal coagulation / argon plasma coagulation
▪
Haemoclip
▪
Fibrin sealant
o
Surgery
o
Interventional angiography / embolisation
Forrest Classification
Grade
Description
Rebleeding
Risk
Without
intervention
Ia
Active arterial
bleed
55%
Ib
Oozing without
visible vessel
55%
IIa
Non-bleeding
visible vessel
43%
IIb
Adherent clot
22%
IIc
Flat spot
10%
III
Clean ulcer base
5%

title: Acute Liver Failure
text:
Acute Liver Failure
Definition:
•
Acute liver injury
•
Hepatic encephalopathy
•
Impaired synthetic function (INR ≥1.5)
See liver failure notes
Management:
•
A/B:
o
Intubate early
o
PaCO2 35 – 40 for neuroprotection
o
Lung protective ventilation
•
C: hyperdynamic circulation with low SVR
o
Fluid resus with balanced crystalloid / albumin
o
Vasopressor for MAP >65 (>80 if raised ICP) – norad, vasopressin
▪
CPP >60 if cerebral oedema
o
Hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency
•
D:
o
Neuroprotective measures
o
Monitor for seizures
o
Normoglycaemia
o
High volume plasma exchange
•
E:
o
Control fever
o
Monitor for infection
o
Antibiotics for grade III and IV encephalopathy
•
F:
o
FB euvolaemia / slightly -ve
o
Sodium 145 – 150, serum osmols <320
o
Consider CRRT: high dose, avoid citrate
•
G:
o
Glucose IV – aim BSL >4 (high concentration to free water)
o
Early enteral feeding
o
PPI stress ulcer prophylaxis
o
Electrolyte correction
•
H:
o
Hb >70
o
Vitamin K 10mg daily for 3 days
o
Do not treat INR unless bleeding or invasive procedure
•
L:
o
CVC, art line, IDC, NGT, vascath +/- PiCCO
Specific management:
•
Antidotes:
o
Paracetamol +/- other: NAC
o
Wilson’s disease: D-penicillamine
o
Mushrooms: silibilin, penicillin G and NAC
o
Antivirals
o
Autoimmune hepatitis: steroids
•
Other:
o
Plasma exchange
Complications:
•
Sepsis (now leading cause of death)
•
Electrolyte abnormalities
•
Hepatic encephalopathy
•
Cerebral oedema (previously most common cause of death) → mannitol, hyperventilate, barbiturate coma
•
Seizures: phenytoin
•
Renal failure
•
Pulmonary oedema

title: Chronic Liver Failure
text:
Liver Transplant
Acute Liver Failure
King’s College Criteria:
•
Paracetamol induced:
o
Arterial pH <7.3, lactate >3 after 24 hours or
o
Grade III/IV encephalopathy, PT >100s and Cr >300nmol/L
•
Non-paracetamol induced:
o
PT >100s (INR >6.5) or
o
Any 3 of:
▪
Age <10yo or >40yo
▪
Unfavourable aetiology (wilson’s disease, drug reaction, non-hep A/B/viral
▪
Jaundice >7 days before encephalopathy i.e. not hyperacute
▪
PT >50s (INR >3.5)
▪
Bili >300
Chronic Liver Failure
MELD:
•
Chronic liver disease
•
Life threatening complications
•
MELD-Na score >15
o
Age
o
Bili
o
INR
o
Cr
o
Sodium
Contra-indications to liver transplant:
•
Irreversible brain injury
•
Malignancy
•
Uncontrolled sepsis
•
Lack of social support / non-adherence to therapy

title: Acute Pancreatitis
text:
Acute Pancreatitis
Diagnostic criteria:
•
2 out of 3:
o
Acute onset of severe epigastric pain
o
Elevated amylase / lipase >3x ULN
o
Imaging studies
Classification:
•
Mild: no local or systemic complications
•
Moderate:
o
Transient organ failure ≤24 hours
o
Local or systemic complications
•
Severe: persistent organ failure ≥48 hours
Causes:
•
Gallstones 40 – 70%
•
EtOH 25%
•
Hypertriglyceridaemia 10%
•
Post-ERCP
•
Drug-induced
•
Trauma – blunt / penetrating
•
Hypercalcaemia
•
Infection
•
Vasculitis
•
CF
Severity:
•
Ranson’s criteria - mortality
•
Apache II
Management: supportive care
•
Resuscitation: initial required for HD stability → 5-10mL/kg/hour
•
Analgesia
•
Monitoring:
o
Vitals
o
UO
o
Electrolytes (especially Ca2+, glucose, renal function)
•
Nutrition:
o
NBM
o
Early oral feeding as tolerated
o
Enteral / parenteral feeds
•
Antibiotics only if suspected infection
Treat underlying cause:
•
Gallstones: ERCP, cholecystectomy
•
Triglycerides: apheresis, insulin
Local Complications
Systemic Complications
•
Peripancreatic fluid collections
o
Conservative
•
Necrosis (sterile or infected)
o
Abx, debridement, perc drainage
•
Pseudocyst
o
Observe v drain
•
Walled off
•
Portosplenomesenteric venous thrombosis
•
Abdominal compartment syndrome
•
Shock / sBP <90
•
APO PaO2 <60mmHg
•
Renal failure
•
GI bleeding
•
DIC
•
Severe hypocalcaemia

title: Post-Intensive Care Syndrome
text:
Post-Intensive Care Syndrome
Epidemiology:
•
≥50% will have some component + QoL
o
Cognitive 25%
o
Psychiatric up to 60%
o
Physical up to 75%
RFs:
•
Pre-existing: cognitive dysfunction, mental health, functional disability, frailty
•
During illness: delirium, sedation, sepsis, shock, hypoxia, ARDS, mechanical ventilation, traumatic experience
•
After illness: early anxiety, depression, PTSD
Presentation:
•
Cognitive: cognition (concentration, memory, mental speed, executive function)
•
Psychiatric: anxiety, depression, PTSD
•
Physical:
o
ICU acquired weakness
o
Contractures
o
Malnutrition
o
Poor lung function
o
Insomnia / poor sleep

title: Withdrawal of Care
text:
Withdrawal of Care
Reasons:
•
Imminent death
•
Likely poor outcome
•
Lethal underlying condition
Capacity:
•
ACD
•
Guardian or legal authority
•
Consult stakeholders (e.g. family)
Communication:
•
MDT
•
Family + patient i.e. “shared decision making”
o
Consider culture, religion, language, life-stage
o
Affirm non-abandonment
o
Allow time for questions
Process:
•
Prepare:
o
Inform family and explain process
o
Spiritual + cultural care
o
Private room
o
Social work
o
Palliative care referral
•
Assess and manage symptoms
o
Pain, agitation, secretions, distress, dyspnoea, delirium
o
Titrate management to effect – avoid oversedation
•
Discontinue treatment
o
Non-comfort treatments
o
Continue O2 if relieves symptoms
o
Religious visit / priest
o
Order:
▪
Fluids + antibiotics
▪
CVS support
▪
Ventilatory support
o
Turn off monitors and alarms
o
Ongoing support
▪
Social work / grievance counsellor
▪
ALO if indigenous
▪
Formal debrief

title: Brainstem Death Testing
text:
Brainstem Death Testing
Brain death:
•
Unresponsive coma
•
Absence of brainstem reflexes
•
Absence of resp centre functions
*Clinical setting compatible with irreversibility
OR demonstrated absence of intracranial blood flow
Preconditions:
•
Minimum 4 hr of observed unresponsive coma, unreactive pupils, absent cough / tracheal reflexes, no spont resp effort
•
Core temp >36
•
sBP >100mmHg
•
No drug, toxin or sedative (>24 hours)
•
Absence of severe electrolyte, metabolic or endocrine disturbance
•
Intact neuromuscular function
•
Ability to examine brainstem reflexes
•
Ability to perform apnoea testing
o
Satisfactory gas exchange / normoxia
Examination findings: tests
•
Coma
•
Absent brain-originating motor response
o
Pain above the neck
o
Seizure
o
Decorticate or decerebrate posturing
Testing: tested in sequence
1. Unresponsive coma:
a. Painful stimulus: supraorbital pressure, nailbed in 4 limbs (may be spinal reflexes not elicited by SO pressure)
2. Brainstem reflexes:
a. Pupillary light: CN II, III
b. Corneal reflex: CN V, VII
c.
Vestibulo-ocular reflex: CN III, IV, VI, VIII
i. Head at 30 degrees, ice cold water into the ear, watch eyes for 60s, in brain death will remain midline
d. Gag reflex: CN IX, X
e. Cough reflex: CN X
3. Apnoea: pre-ox FiO2 100% 5 mins → switch off ventilator, supply O2 via manual BVM with PEEP valve – recommended
T-piece → observe for 10 minutes
a. After 10 mins: ABG (apnoea persisting with PaCO2 >60mmHg or 20mmHg above baseline, pH <7.3)
i. If patient becomes hypoxic a couple of mandatory breaths permitted to continue process
Observations:
•
Compatible with brain death: spinal reflexes, ext/flex UL/LL, undulating toes, Lazarus, deep tendon reflexes, head
turning, sweating, blushing
•
Incompatible with brain death: decorticate, decerebrate, true ext/flex response to painful stimuli, seizures, attempted
breathing
When clinical / apnoea testing cannot be performed (i.e. no access to one eye / ear, high SCI, severe hypoxia, HD unstable):
•
Radiological confirmation of no flow: DSA, MRA, CTA, transcranial doppler
•
EPS
Brain death mimics:
•
Locked in syndrome
•
Paralysis
•
Hypothermia
•
Drug intoxication / metabolic derangement
Tests all CN apart from I, XI, XII
Additional:
•
If cause is cardiorespiratory
arrest must wait 24 hours
post-ROSC
•
Age:
o
Above applies after 30
days of age
o
Prior to 30 days old
period of observation
is 48 hours, not 24
hours
o
Premature babies <36
weeks old, brainstem
death testing cannot
be performed with
certainty

title: Management Prior to Organ Retrieval
text:
Management Prior to Organ Retrieval
Monitoring:
•
Routine ANZCA + temp, UO, BSL
•
Bloods
Targets:
•
Bloods: Hb >70, normal sodium, BSL 6-10mM
•
CVS: MAP 60-110mmHg
•
Resp: LPV, prevent VAP (head up 30 degrees, pulmonary toilet)
•
Endo: manage central DI (vaso, desmopressin), steroids, thyroid replacement
•
Normothermia
Complications whilst awaiting organ donation:
•
Hypertensive autonomic storm
•
Vasodilatory shock
•
Cardiogenic shock
•
Diabetes insipidus
•
VAP
Must support family
Absolute CI donation:
•
Active cancer last 3y (exc non-melanoma skin cancer and primary brain tumours)
•
Haem cancer
•
Untreated systemic infection
•
CJD
•
HIV disease (not infection)
No longer age limits
DCD Donation:
•
Does not meet criteria for brain death
•
No hope of viable recovery
•
Expected to die <60 mins after withdrawal of supports

title: Peripheral Vascular Disease
text:
Peripheral Vascular Disease
•
Asymptomatic
•
Symptomatic:
o
Claudication
o
Critical limb ischaemia: (5Ps pain, pulselessness, pallor, parasthesia, paralysis) – 5y mortality 50%
▪
Pain at rest
▪
Ulceration / gangrene
Ix:
•
ABI ≤0.9 (normal 0.9 – 1.2, abnormally high if non-compressible - mortality)
•
Duplex US
•
CTA / MRI (best for run offs)
•
Invasive angiogram
Management:
•
CVS risk factor modification +
o
Rx: statin
o
BP (<140/90, <130/80 if diabetic)
•
Exercise (improves claudication, no mortality benefit)
•
Rx:
o
Antiplatelet: single unless stent (CAPRIE clopidogrel > aspirin CVS endpoints)
o
PCE3 inhibitors
o
5HT2 inhibitors
•
Revascularisation
Co-morbidities: CAD 60%, HTN, COPD 50%, CKD, obesity, diabetes, chronic pain, smokers
Complications of PVD: wound dehiscence, post-op MI / stroke, renal failure
CARP no evidence for PCI unless indicated
Pre-op:
•
Function + RCRI (non-exercise ST)
•
Modifiable RFs
Intra-op:
•
Monitoring: 5-lead + art line
•
Contrast → hydration
•
Manage reperfusion
Post-op:
•
Monitor for complications:
o
General: MINS / MACE, acute renal injury +/- contrast induced nephropathy, respiratory complications
o
Vascular: haematoma, graft failure, wound infection, re-stenosis, pseudoaneurysm

title: Carotid Endarterectomy
text:
Carotid Endarterectomy
Indications:
•
Symptomatic stenosis >50% (greatest ARR within 2/52 of last event)
•
Asymptomatic stenosis >60%
CI: asymptomatic 100% occlusion, high medical risk
Complications: CVA/embolisation, cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome,
ICH, MACE, CN / cervical nerve injury (RLN, SLN, hypoglossal,
mandibular), haematoma +/- airway compromise + general
GALA trial: no difference at 30 days for stroke, AMI, death (risk of
selection bias as LA patients often older + more comorbid). Higher
shunt rate for GA.
Pre-op:
•
Symptom timeline
•
Medical management:
o
Antiplatelets:
▪
Asymptomatic: aspirin
▪
Symptomatic: DAPT
o
Statin therapy
•
Contralateral carotid flow
•
Blood pressure control
•
Modifiable RFs
•
Neurological deficits
Intra-op:
•
Mode:
o
Awake: superficial cervical plexus + /- sedation (precedex)
o
GA: TIVA, south rae
•
Monitoring: 5-lead, art line
o
Neuro-monitoring: BIS+EEG+DSA, SSEPs
•
Important moments BP:
o
Induction (baseline +/- 20%)
o
Dissection (stop, LA, atropine)
o
Clamp (baseline + 20%) → do not touch anaesthetic
▪
Heparin prior
o
Unclamp: sBP <140
o
Emergence
o
PACU
•
Neuroprotection
•
Paralyse – no cough
•
Blood management
•
Rapid emergence
Post-op:
•
Q1 hourly neuro obs
•
Hypertension: headache, vision
o
Rx: labetalol, clonidine
•
Bleeding +/- airway:
o
Slow: oedema → AFOI nasal v oral?
o
Fast: tracheal deviation, release haematoma → normal oral
Stent v CEA:
•
risk periprocedural stroke and death
•
risk of MI, CN palsy, haematoma
•
No difference in ipsilateral stroke after procedure
•
Elderly: CEA > stent (consider ongoing DAPT) –
indications institution specific

title: Carotid Endarterectomy
text:
Modality
Method
Benefits
Limitations
Indication for Shunt
Awake
assessment
Assess clinical
signs
•
Direct
Evidence of cerebral
ischaemia i.e. agitation,
slurred speech,
disorientation, weakness
**contralateral hand grip
Carotid
artery
stump
pressure
Needle inserted
into distal
common carotid
and measures
pressure post XC
•
Easy
•
Cheap
•
Low sensitivity (high
false negative)
•
<40mmHg
EEG
Algorithmic
analysis of EEG
•
Easy
•
Cheap
•
Low sensitivity (high
false negative)
•
Cortical region only
•
GA alters results
MAC <0.5 required
•
Reduction of BIS >30%
indicates hypoperfusion
•
Delta / theta waves
•
Disorganised rhythm
SSEPs
Transcutaneous
electrical stimulus
to assess pathway
from peripheral
nerve to sensory
cortex
•
Detects subcortical
ischaemia
•
Low sensitivity (high
false negative)
•
GA alters results
•
amplitude by 50% (peak
to trough)
•
latency by 10%
(stimulus to peak)
Transcranial
doppler
Infers CBF from
blood flow velocity
•
Monitors flow and
presence of emboli
•
Very operator
dependent
•
Close to operating
field
•
Narrow acoustic
window
•
MCAvel reduction >60%
•
Flow <25cm/s
NIRS
Differential
absorption of
infrared light of
oxyHb and
deoxyHb
•
Higher sensitivity
•
Frontal lobe only
•
Predominantly local
venous O2 sats
•
Sources of error: eg
interference,
extracranial blood,
ambient light
•
High variability – no
‘normal values’ data
•
Fall ≥20%
•
Absolute ≤50%
(Generally not an indication
to shunt alone – use to O2
and blood pressure)
Local Anaesthetic
General Anaesthetic
Benefits
•
Awake + direct neuro examination
•
EEG unaffected
•
Preserved CNS autoregulation
•
incidence of MI in hospital
•
shunt rate
•
operative site bleeding
•
LOS
•
Motionless patient + optimised surgical field
•
Secure airway
•
Avoids emergency conversion to GA
•
Avoid regional / local anaesthetic risks
•
Decreased CMRO2
•
Patient comfort
Disadvantages
•
Not suitable if NESB / hearing impairment /
movement disorder / patient unwilling
•
Vertebral artery injection (seizure)
•
Subarachnoid injection (LOC)
•
Horner’s syndrome
•
Blockade of phrenic n. or RLN
•
Need for emergency conversion to GA (~4%)
•
Reliance on indirect neuromonitoring
•
shunt rate
•
intra-op hypotension
•
post-op hypertension

title: Limb Amputation
text:
Limb Amputation
Type: primary – no attempt at revascularisation, secondary – after failed revascularisation
Indications: ischaemia (unsalvageable), trauma, infection, malignancy, frostbite, compartment syndrome (failed management)
30 day mortality 17% (AKA > BKA) 2’ cardiac, sepsis pneumonia, DVT/PE
Types of post-amputation pain:
•
Surgical stump pain
•
Phantom sensation: still feels like part of the body ~100%
•
Phantom-limb pain: pain in missing part 30 – 85%
RFs for post-op pain: high pre-op pain, catastrophising, chemo/radiotherapy, age
Surgical post-amputation pain
Phantom limb pain 80%
Intra-operative
•
Pharmacological:
o
Paracetamol
o
Parecoxib
o
Dexmedetomidine
•
Regional:
o
AKA: sciatic + femoral
o
BKA: sciatic
•
Epidural (good for acute pain)
•
Gabapentin
•
Ketamine
Post-operative
•
Paracetamol
•
NSAID
•
PCA
•
Catheters
•
Daily APS review
Back pain common:
•
TENS
•
Heat therapy
•
Acupuncture
•
Gabapentin
•
Ketamine
•
Calcitonin (acute not chronic)
•
Tramadol
+/- spinal cord stimulator – case reports
•
Non-pharm - consider:
o
Mirror therapy
o
Sensory discrimination training
o
Motor imagery
No evidence for: amitriptyline, botox A, memantine, IV lignocaine
Pre-op:
•
Pain specialist
•
Modifiable RFs
Intra-op:
•
1st on list associated with mortality
Post-op:
•
Persistent stump pain 10%: infection, wound dehiscence, arterial insufficiency, OM, bone spur, haematoma, poor fitting
prosthesis, neuroma, heterotopic ossification (calcium in stump tissue)

title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm
text:
Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm
Definition
•
Widening >1.5x normal diameter (all wall layers, any vessel) OR
•
>30mm absolute diameter
RFs:
•
Development: >65yo, male, COPD, PVD, FHx, ↑lipids, HTN, smoking
•
Rupture: ↑size, ↑rate of expansion (diabetes protective), symptomatic, >60yo, female, HTN, smoking
Smoking most important in both
Cause: atherosclerosis (main), rarer - Marfan syndrome, Salmonella, Brucellosis, TB, Takayasus
Non surgical management:
•
Smoking cessation: slows growth by 20% + improves surgical outcomes
•
Statins (↓peri-op MI)
•
Aspirin
•
Consider BB and ACEi
Risk of rupture:
•
<5.5cm: <1%/yr
•
>5.5cm: 18% /yr for F, 12%/yr for M
Indication for surgery: >5.5cm M, >5.0 F, symptomatic, rapid expansion

title: EVAR
text:
EVAR
Requirements: neck >1.5cm, minimal plaque, disease-free iliacs, 1x fem a. >8mm (stent 7.5mm)
EVAR v open:
•
Benefits: ↓peri-op morbidity / LOS / blood loss (650mL v 1600mL), short term mortality
•
Disadvantages: graft related, need for reintervention
No difference in long-term mortality
Pre-op:
•
Breath hold
•
Check bilateral BP
Intra-op: stable haemodynamics until aneurysm secure
•
Lines on RIGHT (emergency balloon catheter from L axillary artery)
•
Monitoring: 5-lead, art line
•
Hyoscine: ↓intestinal motility
Post-op:
•
Complications: LL ischaemia / chol embolisation, stent displacement, endoleak, post-implantation syndrome
rEVAR (EVAR for Rupture)
rEVAR v open: ↓LOS, QoL, more cost effective
•
IMPROVE trial: no difference in 30 day or 3-year mortality
Intra-op:
•
LA v GA: 30-day mortality
•
If agitation or back pain: consider LA + sedation to facilitate REBOA prior to GA
•
If retroperitoneal haematoma may have respiratory insufficiency

title: Open Elective
text:
Open Elective
Pre-op:
•
Functional, RCRI
•
Must be on statin, aspirin + well controlled BP
•
Modifiable RFs
•
Consent: peri-op mortality 1-10%
•
X-clamp assessment / TTE: location of clamp, CI to clamp ?severe AR
Intra-op:
•
Neuraxial: post-op MI
•
Monitoring: 5-lead, art line, CVP, temp, UO
•
CLAMP ON: massive afterload – Anrep effect
o
Heparin 100iu/kg + circ
o
SNiP +/- GTN bolus pre-clamp
o
STOP lower body warmer
o
High risk MI: Hb 90-100, avoid excessive tachycardia
•
CLAMP OFF:
o
Fluid load prior (CVP >12-15)
o
Prepare for ischaemic reperfusion injury
▪
CO2 (hyperventilate)
▪
Insulin dextrose ready
▪
Defib pads on
▪
Dilute adrenaline
Post-op:
•
Monitor for ischaemic effects of X-clamp:
o
UO / AKI: intra-op UO not correlated, dialysis rates similar supra- & infra-renal X clamp – no evidence for
diuretics

title: Open Ruptured AAA
text:
Open Ruptured AAA
Above +
Pre-op:
•
Reverse anticoagulation
•
sBP 90
•
Early blood products
•
Avoid TXA
•
REFER: haematology, ICU
•
+/- REBOA (seldinger via fem a.)
Intra-op:
•
Surgeons scrubbed prior to GA (TMP)
•
sBP 90-120 (lowest recorded BP correlates 30-day mortality)
•
Major haemorrhage bundle:
o
MTP/ROTEM, sheath, level 1 tubing + rapid infuser, cell salvage
o
Coagulopathy: minimise crystalloid, warm, iCa
Post-op:
•
Monitor:
o
Abdominal compartment syndrome
o
Ischaemic colitis

title: Thoracic / Thoracoabdominal Aortic Disease
text:
Thoracic / Thoracoabdominal Aortic Disease
Indications for surgery:
•
Rupture or dissection
•
Symptomatic enlargement
•
Enlargement >1cm/yr or rapid increase
•
Absolute size >6.5cm (or >6.0cm in CT disease)

title: tEVAR
text:
tEVAR
As for EVAR +
•
Spinal cord protection: 2% SCI (risk  length of graft)
o
?lumbar drain

title: Open Aneurysm Repair
text:
Open Aneurysm Repair
Pre-op:
•
Functional, RCRI
•
Compression of adjacent structures:
o
Stridor or dyspnoea from tracheal or bronchial compression
o
Dysphagia from oesophageal compression
•
Baseline neuro exam
Intra-op:
•
Monitoring: 5-lead, 2x art lines – right radial + femoral, CVC, temp, UO
•
DLT
•
Neuromonitoring:
o
MEPs: anterior columns (anterior spinal a.) - avoid NMBA or volatile >0.5 MAC
o
SSEPs: posterior columns
•
?Partial left heart bypass
o
CBF via native vessels + distal aorta via CBP (ensures blood flow to distal organs + XC afterload)
▪
Cannulation LA/pulmonary vein → return distal aorta
▪
No oxygenator
▪
ACT 200 – 300
▪
T 34 (cerebral perfusion maintained)
•
Spinal cord perfusion:
o
Sequential clamping + re-implantation of intercostals/lumbar segmental vessels
o
Lumbar drain
•
X CLAMP as per AAA notes
•
Cell salvage
Post-op:
•
Monitor for ischaemia
•
CSIC

title: Dissection
text:
Dissection
Intimal tear → false lumen formation
Presentation:
•
SSx: acute onset chest / back pain 90%
•
End organ hypoperfusion:
o
CNS: stroke, syncope, Horner’s syndrome
o
CVS: AMI if obstructed coronary ostia, heart failure / aortic regurg,
tamponade, differential BP
o
Spinal cord: paraplegia
o
Gut: mesenteric ischaemia
o
AKI
o
Limb ischaemia
Ix:
•
ECG: may show ischaemia if coronary ostia involved
•
CXR: widened aortic silhouette, pleural effusion
•
TOE: dissection flap, lumens (F/F), thrombus, coronary arterial involvement, pericardial effusion, AR
•
CT-A/MR-A: show same as TOE + entry/re-entry points
Indications for emergency surgery:
•
Ascending aorta involvement
•
Descending aorta with compromised organ blood flow
•
Failed medical management
Management:
•
Anti-impulse therapy:
o
HR <60
▪
Esmolol 0.5mg/kg load → 25 – 50mcg/kg/min
▪
Labetalol: 20mg IV → 0.5 – 2mg / min
o
sBP 100-120mmHg
▪
SNiP: 0.25 – 0.5mcg/kg/min
•
Analgesia – IV opioids
Type A
Pre-op:
•
Assess organ hypoperfusion above
Intra-op: supine + midline sternotomy
•
Deep hypothermic circulatory arrest
•
Monitoring: 5-lead, RIGHT radial art line, CVC, temp, UO
o
Neuro: NIRS
Type B
Intra-op:
•
Lateral decubitus + left lateral thoracotomy + DLT

title: Fistula Formation
text:
Fistula Formation
Indication:
•
Stage 5 CKD
•
Stage ≤4 but rapidly progressive
Native vein arteriovenous fistula - commonest
Sub-types:
•
Radiocephalic: 1st line, lowest flows
•
Brachiocephalic: increased steal
•
Brachiobasilic transposition: highest risk of steal (usually due to failed distal fistulas)
1 – 4mo maturation. Within 1cm of skin for easy cannulation. Non-dominant arm.
Arterial-venous graft: used when unable to approximate artery and vein, or when previous fistulas have exhausted vessels
•
Pros: ease of cannulation, short maturation time
•
Cons: poor long-term patency, 4x salvage procedures, 6x thrombosis, 10x infection
Types of graft:
•
Forearm loop graft
•
Brachioaxillary graft
•
Femoro-femoral graft
Pre-op:
•
Dialysis + AEIOU status
Intra-op:
•
Padding to preserve current fistulas (document pre and post thrill)
•
IVC away from future sites
•
Regional: axillary brachial plexus + T2 +/- surgeon infiltration
o
Considerations:
▪
Uraemic platelet dysfunction
▪
Potential prolonged heparin after dialysis
▪
Vasodilation 2’ regional → higher vessel flow (predicts successful formation)
▪
Pitfalls: intercostobrachial n. / T2 needs to be blocked separately

title: Thorascopic Sympathectomy
text:
Thorascopic Sympathectomy
Disruption of sympathetic outflow at level of spinal cord:
•
T1 – T2: head & neck
•
T1 – T4: thoracic viscera
•
T2 – T5: upper limbs
Indications:
•
Hyperhidrosis
•
CRPS
•
Ischaemic symptoms (including angina)
•
Congenital long QTc
•
Intra-arterial injection
No longer for Raynaud’s as vasodilatory effects are transient
Pre-op:
•
Indication
Intra-op: usually GA
•
Monitoring: art line + 5 lead ECG if for long QTc (+ avoid QT prolonging medications)
•
Partial lung collapse:
o
DLT
•
Monitor for tension capnothorax
•
Cautious positioning to avoid brachial plexus injury
Post-op:
•
CXR to exclude residual PTx
